item.title: Rambling on Cartesian Certainty
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
1 The epistemic method founded in Meditation One of Descartes’s Meditations on First Philosophy has this as its object: to remove any possible doubt so that certainty, or indubitability, of certain truths, whatever they may be, might be obtained. The meditator has certainty as his goal, not knowledge. Certainty makes “sure knowledge” possible, and without it, there are no viable routes to attaining any knowledge. 1.1 For the meditator, knowledge and certainty are distinguished from each other in this way. 1.11 “But perhaps, even though the senses do sometimes deceive us when it is a question of very small and distant things, still there are many other matters concerning which one simply cannot doubt, even though they are derived from the very same senses: for example, that I am sitting here next to the fire, wearing my winter dressing gown, that I am holding this sheet of paper, and the like. But on what grounds could one deny that these hands and this entire body are mine?” (M 18; my emphasis) 1.2 Knowledge is that which can be doubted; certainty, or knowledge which is certain, is that which cannot. The concluding question attempts to doubt what the meditator asserts “one cannot doubt.” We seem to be forced to interpret the usage of “doubt” as a possible equivocation, or we can devise two forms of doubt: I will call them “restricted domain doubt” and “universal domain doubt”. 1.21 Restricted domain refers to propositions, as inferred from the quote at 1.11, which can be doubted only if the meditator can sufficiently doubt a “universal domain”; e.g. “The sky is above me”, “A kitten is on my keyboard right now”, “I have two feet”, etc would be doubted only if their corresponding universal domain is successfully doubted. 1.211 The proposition “I have two feet” and my knowledge of it carries no weight in showing the nature of my knowledge of a universal domain because the proposition could be uttered during my presence within any universal domain. The resemblance thesis later explained at 1.42 will justify this claim further. 1.22 Universal domain refers to propositions, as inferred from the concluding question at 1.11, which implicate the meditator’s entire experiential domain to doubt. e.g. “This is not my body”, “Suppose I am in a dream state”, “This is the waking world”, etc. 1.221 Doubts of the universal domain kind entail that one does not know for certain the truth or falsity of any restricted domain. 1.222 A universal domain may have a history (“Bill Clinton was the U.S. President in 1995”, etc), its own set of physical laws, experiential facts, etc; a universal domain is a possible world of experiences, i.e. your sensory perceptions, your memories, etc. 1.223 The nature of a universal domain and its relation to the meditator’s perception is this: Any universal domain can provide experiential data to the meditator. 1.3 To obtain the knowledge, or, in this case, certainty, of the meditator’s present universal domain entails at least possible knowledge of restricted domains (e.g. “This is a hand”) which constitute the makeup that universal domain. That is, knowledge of the meditator’s universal domain (e.g. “I know that I am not dreaming”) entails certainty, and certainty entails possible certain knowledge of restricted domain propositions, which are within that universal domain. 1.31 “…which are within that universal domain” would imply that “dreaming” universal domains, say, would have no relevancy (true or false) to one’s actual, or “waking”, universal domain. The propositions might be true for that “dreaming” universal domain, but you have determined, or come to know, that you are not dreaming. 1.4 It is possible, or thinkable, that universal domains can be exactly experientially alike; that is, universal domains may consist of a multiplicity of restricted domains (the knowledge of kittens, hands, facts, etc) which are persuasively indistinguishable when displaced, supposedly, to other universal domains. 1.41 “As if I did not recall having been deceived on other occasions even by similar thoughts in my dreams… I see so plainly that there are no definitive signs by which to distinguish being awake from being asleep” (M 19). 1.42 The strength of this resemblance thesis is twofold: (a) “no definitive signs” would imply that the “dreaming” universal domain might include the memory of the meditator’s history (past dreaming events, what was eaten for lunch, etc) which would not work as “definitive” indicators that one is not dreaming, and (b) there is no actual knowledge because, due to the lack of a “definitive sign”, it is indistinguishable that one is in the “waking” universal domain or the “dreaming” universal domain. 1.43 Knowledge within the supposed “dreaming” universal domain cannot be granted unless the meditator has ascertained which universal domain he resides in at the moment. The fact that the meditator does not know that he is not in the “dreaming” universal domain entails that the meditator does not know certain restricted domain propositions which are included in that domain or possibly another. For all the meditator knows, he could be a lobster which is dreaming that he is a human with hands. To know the antecedent of that entailment is the only condition by which the meditator can justify any knowledge-claim about restricted domain propositions. 1.431 From this, we understand clearly now that a restricted domain’s truth or falsity is contingent on our knowledge, which would be certainty, of our presence in the “waking” universal domain. 1.432 The evident claim is this: it is that only certainty (of our universal domain) gives us justification of restricted domain knowledge-claims. 1.5 The Dream argument is stated (using the previous terms): Suppose that you are dreaming (“dreaming” universal domain). Dreaming, as it has before, has impressed upon you all sorts of memories and past experiences (including that you woke up 4 hours ago after a pleasant dream, etc). If you do not know that you are not in the “dreaming” universal domain, then you do not know the restricted domains (“I have two feet”, etc) of the “waking” universal domain. 2 G.E. Moore, in his essay Certainty, advances two important counterarguments to the Dreaming hypothesis. Though they fail to achieve their object, they lay the groundwork for the arguments beginning at 3. 2.1 Moore finds that the proposition “If I do know that I am standing up, then I do know that I am not dreaming” is logically equivalent to the Dream argument’s proposition “If I do not know that I am not dreaming, it follows that I don’t know that I am standing up” (C 30). 2.11 Logical equivalence of the two propositions cannot stifle the skeptical argument because of what was said of the nature of restricted domain propositions combined with the resemblance thesis. “I do know that I am standing up” would be compatible with the “dreaming” and “waking” universal domains, and, given that these domains could be experientially (and perceptually) exactly alike, knowing that I am standing would not entail that the meditator knows his presence within a particular universal domain as opposed to another. By the Dream argument’s stipulation, Moore has proved that he knows “This is a hand” in one universal domain or “This is a hand” in another universal domain. It is logically possible that he knows either case, but it is not logically possible that he should so know at the same time. If he is dreaming, then he cannot know that he has hands. He is physically unable to even utter the proposition, which would convey that knowledge. His dream may be telling him any restricted domain proposition, which could be false, and he would not know, or be able to express his knowledge, if he were asleep. Nevertheless, even if it could be shown that the knowledge of restricted domain propositions paralleled, the mere conjunction of knowledge of restricted domains does not guarantee certainty because the proposition “You do not know that you are not dreaming” is not satisfied. 2.2 The propositions “I have these sense experiences and memories” and “I am now dreaming” (C 31), Moore claims, are logically “self-contradictory”. 2.21 “Sensory experience” and “memories” are restricted domains and would be assumed to be contained within a “dreaming” universal domain; the fact that the meditator is now dreaming combined with the resemblance thesis shows that all sensory experience and memory could be the product of that “dreaming” universal domain’s history which the meditator is a part of. 2.211 e.g. in the “waking” universal domain, the meditator could say “I had a dream last night”. By the resemblance thesis, this utterance could possibly occur also in a “dreaming” universal domain. 2.22 Therefore, Moore’s claim of “inconsistency” as to the premise “Some at least of the sensory experiences which you are having now are similar in important respects to dream-dreams which actually have occurred in dreams” is false. 3 Moore’s counterarguments, though strong, seem to fail to get around the Dream argument’s peculiar and seemingly exhaustive reasoning. Moore’s attempts were unsuccessful because he attempted to challenge the argument strictly based on its condition that: You know restricted domain propositions only if you know that you are not in the “dreaming” universal domain. Unlike Moore, who attempted to enter and combat the argument from within, we must attempt to find a fault in the argument at its exterior, so as to determine if its condition for knowledge and certainty is actually with fault. 3.1 How did the question arise at all that: You do not know that you are not dreaming; given the resemblance thesis, could there ever be a determinant which makes this proposition truly qualify as known? If you cannot at all come to know a proposition’s truth, then it is not a proposition that can entail knowledge. 3.2 Stroud makes examples using clearly restricted domain propositions so as to illustrate the nature of the Dream arguments relevance to commonplace, natural inquiry. However, being that these are restricted domain propositions (“That was a goldfinch”, etc), they are unsuccessful at actually showing the nature of a universal domain proposition. 3.21 If you determine that a goldfinch is incompatible with being a canary, you have a thinkable and imaginable possibility that you could possibly come to know to be the case. But is this the case with universal domain propositions? 3.22 Our object here is to show that the question of the meditator’s presence within a universal domain is illegitimately raised. Questions similar it, as Stroud elucidates with his Goldfinch propositions et al, are relevant to knowledge and certainty, but this is only by virtue of the possibilities, which could exist and could be incompatible with those knowledge-claims. This form of inquiry applies only to restricted domain propositions because it is assumed also that they could have incompatible propositions. Our rule is this: If there is no way to check or assess that a proposition p, which could be incompatible with other possibly true propositions, then it is not a proposition which can give knowledge. A proposition not in concord with this rule may be raised, but its potential usage, should it be true, as knowledge is closed off and inaccessible to other propositions. 3.23 A universal domain proposition cannot be compared with any other universal domain proposition (by the resemblance thesis), and these propositions cannot give meaningful assignments of value to restricted domain propositions, which are arranged within its “world” or “history”. Knowing the truth or falsity of the universal domain proposition assures nothing except itself; and, should we know its truth, it cannot explain how restricted domain propositions came to possess their values, why they maintain their values, etc. 3.231 e.g. knowing that I am not dreaming only give me certainty that I am not dreaming and that I am in a world that has restricted domain propositions, which I can affirm or deny and might be different from the “waking” universal domain. But if I wish to know why I have hands in this way as opposed to why I do not have hands in the way that holds in my dream, I cannot compare the propositions because they could possibly resemble each other exactly. But is not the true aim of this investigation knowledge and certainty? 3.232 If universal domains could possibly resemble each other exactly, then universal domain propositions, which only seek to determine their own truth or falsity, cannot be used during our investigation of restricted domain propositions. If our task is knowledge and certainty, we will reject the legitimacy of a proposition that seeks to cater to and entertain only itself.
M = Descartes, René. Meditations on First Philosophy, 4 edition. Trans.: Cress, Donald A. Hackett Publishing Company, Inc. (1998). C = Moore, G.E.. "Certainty." Epistemology: An Anthology. Ed. Ernest Sosa and Jaegwon Kim. Blackwell Publishing Ltd. (2000).

item.title: Statements & Laws
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Necessity, Possibility and Contingency A statement is necessary if it is not possibly false. A statement is possible if it is not necessarily false. A statement is contingent if it is possibly true and possibly false. Analytic and Synthetic An analytic statement is a statement whose predicate is contained in its subject. A synthetic statement is a proposition whose predicate is not contained in its subject. A priori and a posteriori An a priori statement is a statement whose justification does not reference to experience in every case of its utterance, but does rely upon experience for initial introduction to the terms found within it. An a posteriori statement is a statement whose justification does rely on experience. Metaphysical: Ethical: Epistemical: Incorrigibility A statement is incorrigible iff it is attentively, or occurently, believed at time t; e.g. "I am in pain!" Pragmatic Inconsistency Examples Cogito ergo sum; i.e. I think therefore I am. Logical: Examples Identity: P = P (necessary, analytic, a priori) Excluded middle: Pv-P Non-contradiction: -(P&-P) Bivalence: P is true or P is false

item.title: Spinozistic Problematics
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Parallelism "The order and connection of ideas is the same as the order and connection of things." Conatus Principle "Each thing, as far as it can by its own power, strives to persevere in its being." Value of Ontological Entities A thing is good because it is desired. Identity In essence, a thing's definition does not involve anything contrary to itself--that would destroy it. But further, the question is raised: It is not so evident that a thing's lack of involving something counter to it would also involve that thing's persevering. (But does this question presuppose that things "will" to persevere? Could it not be that "persevere" is used as a statement of affairs--"that thing merely continues to be in a way in which I perceive." As opposed to "I (a human) will to persevere in this way, and thus I do by my efforts." Are we ascribing "will" to things such as rocks? Can we say something perseveres without couching in the idea of "will?") Aside from those quibbles, by what means does a thing persevere? Internal positation of itself, or inclination to posit itself, against all other entities, presumably or by finititude, not therein its defintion or ontological identity. We ought to equate "persevere" with "posit." "No thing can be destroyed except through an external cause." "Through" might seem a bit ambiguous. What are the ways in which things might be destroyed, under the framing of things external to it? Can we posit externals without also presupposing that those things must, actually, be within the questioned persevering thing's ontological identity? Theory of Inherence Finite things inhere as approximations of the infinite thing. Rejection of Ends* App. I of Of God Error Theory of Ethics Speaker Relativity (linguistic relational) Correlativity (Parallel Presupposition Relational) Model Relativity (As far as conceived "God's image" relational, or Flirtation with Platonic Forms) Language as a Mode of Thinking (Remembering) Which words elicit the most accurate approximation of Deus sive Natura? Aesthetic Values as Modes of Thinking (Remembering) Principle of Sufficient Reason Assumption: Efficient causation is ontologically primary. All contingent (efficiently caused) facts must be explainable. Principle of Identity of Indiscernibles If two things are distinct, there must be an explanation for their nonidentity or we must be able to conceive of them as distinct. Different Modes Problem Put shared modes to the side because substances are prior to their modes. Substance A { modes: X, Y, Z } Substance B { modes: X, Y, Z } Different Attributes Problem Conceptual barrier Substance A { attributes: T, E } Substance B { attributes: T, Z }

item.title: Abortion Positioning as Performative Contradiction
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Last night my friend and I shared a discussion over abortion stances. The topic was introduced by me, as I find myself constantly debating the matter in my mind. Often I find my opinion sharing sentiments with that of pro-choice debaters. Why do I frame it that way, with "debaters?" Well, for this reason: I thought I had stumbled--despite my usual inclination--onto the ultimate pro-life argument. But then again, could it be the quintessential pro-choice argument? In any case, it seems like the basis of this argument, which I will draw out later, centers on the speech acts and knowledge, which both necessarily appear on the communicative stage of debate. So how did our discussion go? Well, I opened with an Aristotle Says* line of argument with Peter Singer as the source. His argument is essentially pragmatism backed by scientism. (I'm not tossing insults yet!) Look, let's at least be scientifically consistent, a 12 week old fetus has no cognitive self-awareness (no concept of self) nor does it have any sensory perception (cannot feel pain). By the way, it's debatable that non-human animals do not have emotions. Darwin believed they did, but in differences of degree with respect to humans, not in accessible "kinds" of emotions. The degrees, so to, vary between species, from bacteria all the way up to the "top" of the ladder (homo sapiens sapiens, presumably). I throw this in as an aside because although I am vegetarian already, a troublesome event occurred during out abortion debate. As we were arguing our cases, I noticed a cat peering in through the window, with its little paw on the ledge of it. The cat seemed to be investigating the Physically, the fetus may have potential to become a fully conscious human being, but, comparatively, to an already fully conscious human being (the mother), certain and definite judgment can be made in favor of abortion. If that's the case, personhood does not apply to the fetus. The case of potentiality is really irrelevant. Let's talk about what's actual. So, it's ethically permissible for a mother to choose to undergo an abortion. In fact, it's permissible for the State to allow doctor-patient confidentiality so that, in effect, abortion procedures can follow through carefully, safely, and privately. I was swayed to this view. However, my friend argued this:
(1) if you did not have a choice in your own birth, you should not have a choice in whether another birth is carried out.
There are some premisses here that need to be dug up. It seems the usage of "birth" implies "a human life." What does having a choice in one's own birth matter, anyway? I'm already born, and I'm looking at what's actual. By virtue of my being here, bringing this argument up is without merit. But is it really lacking merit? It seems to suggest something logical. And further, something lacking respect for temporality. This is the essence of the pro-life argument: The matter of life is atemporal; every human being has a spirit, or soul. But let's not get too hasty and bigoted; I know the scientifically minded would love to resort to name calling at this point. Roger Wolcott Sperry notes,
The events of inner experience, as emergent properties of brain processes, become themselves explanatory causal constructs in their own right, interacting at their own level with their own laws and dynamics. The whole world of inner experience (the world of the humanities) long rejected by 20th century scientific materialism, thus becomes recognized and included within the domain of science.
Emergent vitalism is a hotly debated issue. And I don't think this pro-/anti-abortion debate can go anywhere meaningful unless people begin to sufficiently grasp of the difficulties of the aforementioned issues of vitalism. The question now becomes, "When do emergent cognitive properties of the fetus arise?" This is contingent upon when the neural properties of the fetus are developed far along enough to our arbitrary standards. The debate becomes an issue of who determines what sets the standard for human life? Pro-lifers say we have "spirits," probably due to vitalistic leanings, and pro-choice proponents say we have "politics." Today, by United States federal law, cases with respect to protecting the pregnant woman's life, physical health, mental health, rape, fetal defects, socio-economic factors all permit abortion procedures.

item.title: Nuances and Noncounters of Gettier-types (draft)
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Edmund Gettier wrote and published "Is Justified True Belief Knowledge?" in 1963, a three-page paper that, by most modern epistemologists' judgment, demolished our most trusted normative definition of knowledge since the time of Plato, Justified True Belief. So, you've got an introduction and the source text. Let's discuss. I've come across various arguments against Gettier's cases; many of those argument misinterpret exactly what Gettier showed to be logically wrong with Justified True Belief as the necessary and sufficient condition for Knowledge. So, what exactly was attacked? S knows that P if and only if
(a) P is true; (b) S believes that P; and (c) S is justified in believing that P.
Now, we must clarify exactly what is meant by "justification" because many counterarguments to Gettier which I've seen fail to understand the nature of justification qua logical inference. Justification can come from "physical evidence" or "logical inference," "matters of fact" or "by relation of ideas" (for Humeans). Justification can be established or derived by synthetic or analytic propositional statements. In effect, logical inference as justification is just as important as physical evidence as justification. Furthermore, truth-functional assignment pertains to what can be believed and what can bear justification to be believed. For instance, I believe that "Jon is a bachelor" because "Jon is an unmarried male." My belief is true, I believe that it is true, and my justification for believing that "Jon is a bachelor" comes from my knowing that "Jon is an unmarried male." Look at it this way, "If I have justification to believe that 'Jon is an unmarried male,' then I have justification to believe that 'Jon is a bachelor.'" Thus, my evidence "Jon is an unmarried male" logically entails that "Jon is a bachelor." My initial belief entails my subsequent belief. So, by justified true belief, I bear knowledge about Jon's bachelorhood. I might wish to call this form of Justified True Belief (henceforth JTB) "Justified True Logical Inference (JTLI)," to hone in on the idea and make clear that truth-functional assignment to propositions through propositional logic, or first-order logic, is relevant and important to justified true belief. With that out of the way, we can move to my arguments against Case I. Smith believes "Jones has ten coins in his pocket" because he examined his pocket, and Smith believes "Jones will get the job" because the president told him that Jones would. Smith concatenates those two beliefs to form proposition (1) "Jones is the man who will get the job, and Jones has ten coins in his pocket." Now you might raise issue here: Jones doesn't actually get the job in the end, so it's just not true that Smith has a Justified True Belief. But we must keep in mind exactly which proposition fails to satisfy us in the end. The proposition is not (1) but (2), which reads: "The man who will get the job has ten coins in his pocket." Smith sees the entailment of (2) based on (1) before we find out that Jones actually does not get the job. Therefore, Smith has a justified true belief of (2) by JTLI. Now, you might raise argument: "(2) is ambiguous; it could mean many things." This is quite true, however, this does not prevent us from seeing that Smith nevertheless has the belief of (2). And (2) can be subject to truth-functional assignment. How did this belief come about? Where does this "ambiguity" come from that we intuitively feel? By existential introduction (2) is made possible. (2) means that Smith believes something like this "There is an x that is male such that x will get the job and x has ten coins in x's pocket." Essentially, (2) refers to maleness of the subject, that the subject will get the job, and that of possessing ten coins. Even if (2) is ambiguous, that does not prevent us, as said, from seeing that it is true, justified, and believed by Smith. He is believing in an analytic proposition. "Maleness" is the predicate of the subject in question, and this is all that is being referred to. The argument cannot be raised, "well, Smith was always thinking about Jones, so he could only be referring to Jones in (2)." This is very much true, and Smith might have been. But the argument is such that Smith believes in a proposition that refers to maleness, that is, proposition (2). My argument, however, depends on the one previously stated: when Smith sees the entailment of (2) he could not have anyone else in mind except Jones. It is not possible for him to even consider himself as a candidate because his justification rules himself out of (2). Yes, in the end, he has a JTB by JTLI, but we do not accept it as Knowledge because it just feels funny. It feels funny because we see that existential introduction seems to allow us to believe a grammatical generalization based on physical evidence not relevant to that grammatical generalization. The logical inference itself highlights the disjointed relationship analytic propositions have when considering their basis of synthetic propositions. The predicate of "maleness" holds, for all subjects in the given situational context, as true; this makes (2) true as an analytic a posteriori statement. "Maleness" is a predicate of the subject who gets the job. (1) necessarily depends on observation and retrospective analysis; thus, (1) is synthetic a posteriori. We must ask ourselves: What is the big deal? Smith being justified in the wrong way for believing (2) after the fact is no issue. And I agree: Smith, in order for us to consider his evidence false, must have in principle been able to consider himself as the candidate to get the job. If he could not consider himself a candidate for the job, his (2) could not implicate himself. If you were to ask Smith what he believed, the semantic delineation would always implicate Smith. He has a justified true belief of (2), but that introduces an argument of truth-functional semantics. I am here "digging out" the assumption Gettier seems to have made about truth-functional semantics. That the semantic identity of (2) is taken to be non-existent, and not ambiguous, is my argument. Gettier wants us to look at (2) as having utterly no semantic wealth, but view it purely in terms of truth-functionality. Are beliefs only truth-functional?

item.title: Prolegomena to Moral Grammar
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: I. Grounds to Avoid in Theoretical Ethical Philosophy Through my theoretical reflections of the nature of the State and its relation to Persons, I have found conflict of a semantic sort insofar as speech acts concerning those members of the sets involving such States and Persons. In mentioning "theoretical," I should not wish to be mistaken for endeavoring to contrive a metaphysical system of ontic relations. To involve myself with any ontology here is not my aim; but it is to conceive, as best as one might, the relation between our linguistic events with States and Persons as subjects. What sense can we make of our utterances involving States and Persons; this is the object of my undertaking. So, I shall strive to ensure that my words here do not take a metaphysical bent, for philosophy so frequently falls to error when one's mind is let loose on the mistaken grounds of grandiose themes. The fanciful nature of cognition can be an enemy when the imagination is not guided in a manner that kept bounded; it is the imagination that brings us here, giving us our impetus. It should not govern all that transpires in our thoughts. Metaphysics improper is that which the mind produces after reason is given furlough. II. Of the Distinction of the Necessary and the Sufficient When we conceive the State, we wish to establish those properties of it which necessarily are conducive to the well-being and happiness of humankind. Questions concerning the State involve the demarcation of intrinsic and extrinsic political rules which dictate the relation of political contexts. For any sovereign state S, what might be considered an intrinsic rule is that of its internal legal system which controls the consequences of actions for citizens therein. Though the rule itself is constituted by a multiplicity of interoperating rules (laws), we can conceive it as relating to other internal systems (say, the rules of commerce). Therefore, the legal system is one rule of many which compose the entirety of S. The success of interoperability between rules is determined by the governmental bodies therein; we can disregard the type of governmental system, be it "democratic" or "totalitarian." If we can conceive that there is a government at all, we must conclude that through a chain of communication and deliberation, rules are thus legislated and implemented by the government itself. Governmental systems only establish the process by which rules are translated from hierarchies of power and understanding. That is, for instance, a low-class citizen, within a democratic system, contributes her vote in various elections, participatory political events, etc. Rules themselves function as necessary conditions, but never as sufficient, for the moral worth of S. In saying this, we mean that S becomes a context composed of necessary conditions for moral import. However, the notion of moral worth cannot involve only necessary conditions. An action, say, cannot bear moral import because it must be evaluated in terms of strictly necessary conditions. You might wondered in what respect these conditions of S can only be considered necessary: it is because of the relation S has to internal citizens and external persons. With S in mind as a sovereign state must be considered the maximal political entity of any community of persons: for a collection of presumed citizens C, S will be the theoretical extent of C's power insofar as it is conceived by every member of C. There is no political entity beyond the mind of the members of C; therefore, the rules of S for members of C must be viewed as necessary once those rules are perceived by any member of C. Members of C must refer to the rules; the principle that members of C can change the rules does not obviate the point that as a member, or citizen, of C, there is a political obligation to the rules in some sense. If that member of C were not bound to the rules in some way, the prospect of changing those rules would be of no interest to that member; therefore, that member would not be a citizen of that political system.

item.title: Talking to religious people on street corners
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: While having a smoke outside one of the colleges before an exam, I noticed one of the campus proselytizers having a chat-baptism with a student. Decidedly I let my Socratic tick overcome me. I approach while grabbing for a cigarette. Just before I could light up, a friend popped up--Michael. I introduced them--Michael, Paul; Paul, Michael. The first question thrown out concerned whether Paul believes in our beloved evolution. I had my own question in mind, but I ran with it anyway. I warn, though, that must one be very cautious when engaging in this sort of comical pedantry not to let "evolution" be conversationally defined as something other than "the scientific theory of ..." Otherwise, you'll find yourself dealing with all sorts of generalities and shod-examples that are not even relevant to the theory as such. It will become even more comical if you see this direction of the conversation manifest and you can do nothing to steer it back to your proper, entertainment-seeking path. Paul professed his belief in microevolution but not macroevolution. A common stance among "scientifically-initiated" proselytizers. It's a peculiar one to me because of the following claim (or whatever its variant), typically given by Paul and his ilk: (a) The scientist believes that microevolution proves macroevolution. (a1) Microevolution proves macroevolution. This is the claim he professed is held by the "opposing view," usually the scientific materialist. Interesting that Paul's restatement of the scientific claim has this claim as its logical equivalent (after formatting it in such a way to linguistically account for truth-values): (b) The falsity of macroevotion proves the falsity of microevolution. (b1) If Macroevolution is false, then its falsity does not prove, or entail, the truth of Microevolution. That is, Microevolution is false. Does the scientist ever actually make either claim? At first blush, my intuition leads me to believe the scientist makes neither. Paul believes, however, that he logically concludes this claim, given falsity of (a1): (c) The truth of microevolution (Q) does not prove the truth of macroevolution (Not-P). It's logical equivalent is: (c1) The truth of macroevolution (P) does not proves truth of microevolution (Not-Q). Now what Paul believes seems to be right on. But he claims that he believes it because the scientist has a false belief (i.e., P if and only if Q). Paul believes (c) and (c1). He would not think the truth of microevolution entails or is entailed by macroevolution. But he believes the scientist holds the believe P< ->Q. Paul believes this because of his claims (c) and (c1). So he gets the following argument. 1 -(P< ->Q), Assumption. 2 Q, Provisional Assumption (Q->-P). 3 P, Provisional Assumption (-P). 4 P->Q, Logical Out. 5 Q->P, Logical Out. 6 Q, Modus Ponens. 7 P, Modus Ponens. 8 -P, Indirect Proof (*Not satisfied*). 9 Q->-P, Conditional Proof. As we can see, the claim purported by the scientific materials, say, as far as Paul is concerned, cannot have as a conclusion his claim (that Microevolution does not prove Macroevolution). So, it must be another assumption that he holds. This would be that Microevolution is true. This way, he gets his claim at least in principle, that Q->-P. Take the same argument, but add truth to his atomic assumption (for the sake of being economical). 1 -(P< ->Q), Assumption. 2 Q, Assumption. 3 -Q^-P, Provisional Assumption (7). 4 -Q, Conjunction Out (3). 5 Q, Reiterate (2). 6 Q^-Q, Conjunction In (4,5). 7-(-Q^-P), Indirect Proof. 8 Q->-P, some fancy derived rule that I do not feel like proving. As we can see, we did not need Assumption at 1. For Paul, Microevolution is true (based on whatever evidence) and that evidence which supports that theory is not evidence which can support Macroevolution. Again, does the scientist ever make this claim?

item.title: Belief in the after-death
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
If you were in the situation, would you appreciate being put out on the front page, without anyone notifying your families?
The situation: Your own death. No! Absolutely not! I will not be charged with being too literal, uncharitable. Ask yourself what this question could possibly mean! What could this person intend to mean? Easily we interpret as Would you have a journalist seek approval and consent from your family before having your photo published in a paper? We could radically interpret that question as such; we could ignore the obvious, overt religious overtone. And it ignores the situation. We're not talking about privacy. We're not talking about just another person. The person is dead. You would be dead. Perhaps there's the chance that it ignores important thoughts going through the mind of the victim before his death. Clearly this question ignores his own opinion on the matter. This is just loopy.

item.content:encoded:
WE, In constant confluence, In meritorious multiplicity, In omniscient ornamentation,--
Are crippled; where pleas, cries Instill no world from which pity May even emerge largo--
WE, In lament of a rhythmic world, In shame of a festooned construction In caution of inchoate locality
Begin a volatile winter, Deadform spills Into we who fervently collapse Before a clumsy origin

Yesterday a man crashed into me, I pardoned him before he could whimper; He applauded the audacity of my previous Line
I forgot my rights to etiquette, A swashbuckler before a floating world
I charm the horizon, With only the mess I made
"No one is careful anymore,"-- And what this could mean
Since the world is floating-point Number

item.title: [Review] Crimes and Misdemeanors
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: "We all have moral 'sins,'" or so one says to oneself in a feeble attempt at justification. Crimes and Misdemeanors takes the backdrop of such an utterance, that which compels it, and drives it to what may be called an extremity, a moral limit. This is the standard interpretation of the film: that its author was concerned with underscoring a central figure in his moral tumult, prying into the fabric of the "moral structure" so as to arrive at a generic procedure. We see numerous argumentative forms, framed in terms of the Multiple, "What am I supposed to do?" -- asked of one outside of the unique situation (Jack). Such an interpretation fails to acknowledge the obvious juxtaposition of Cliff's crime and Judah's misdemeanor. Why do I make such a twisted interpretive move? Invert the attribution of les conventionnelles morale de l'histoire? "I have a great murder story. Great plot... Let's say there's this man who's very successful" Landau's character frames. Judah and Cliff round off their discussion with the conclusion that the actual film we presently view is itself the bleak picture Judah set out to advance. Yet is it really? Notice the glimmer of radiance illustrated in Judah and his wife's final kiss. What is this? And apparently there's something happy -- and morally estimable -- in Cliff's defeat. Why should we view Cliff's "sin" as any less subject to the consequences that conventionally would -- or religiously should -- befall Judah? Were their intentions not the same? Their situations not staple and in common? The story's objective is to compare, I believe, something binding between the two characters.

item.title: Old categories and the third wheel
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Post found here: http://langer.tumblr.com/post/275604907 I am very glad that this post was written. It is certainly correct where the author makes this point:
First, Wittgenstein’s method in this case would have nothing to do with “analyzing the word ‘mind’”—this is precisely what he faulted other philosophers for doing!
The statement 'I don’t think the question “are there other minds?” can be settled simply by analyzing the word “mind”' is a complete misunderstanding of what Wittgensteinians engage themselves in. Witty asserts "An 'inner process' stands in need of public criteria." Clearly he is presupposing that the meanings of words, to say the least, but specifically meaning and whatever relation it has to use is most significant. Can this relation be defined in the same way mere words are defined? Can this relation be captured in the approaches of "the philosophers"? Analyzing "use" is a generic procedure, where under that we find derivative procedures akin to "linguistic analysis," linguistics, philology, etiology (in the scientific sense), sociology, etc. Morphemes, phonemes, "surface grammar," etc correspond to "use." And "meaning" is that which stands above, below, behind or whatever the "use"; perhaps it is identical to use! On popular interpretations, however (say, Millianism), "meaning" just is the object; other interpretations involve meanings being defined in terms locality with respect to the skull, neural distribution events within a brain map, "volitions" or "cognitions," embodied thoughts, senses, "Ideas," etc. However, Wittgenstein was chiefly concerned not with things that fall under "use" or "meaning," "syntax" or "semantics" but with the criteria by which relationships between the two are formed, governed; the criteria which established "laws" and "grammar." Wittgenstein was not concerned with the old dichotomies of "realism" and "idealism," but with a third category that, I believe, is not only irreducible to these concepts but, moreover, whose existence grounds the impossibility of reducing them to each other. Thus, the "civil status" of things turn on criteria. Primarily, why we assume identity, reducibility, causality, duty, morality, structure and so on as relations which hold, bear relevancy, or exist in the first place. These concepts are shaped by not only the things which fall under "old dichotomies": mind/brain, idealism/realism, soul/body, universal/particular, etc., but also by the metaphors, idioms, conceptual schemes, circumstances and so on which engender and produce criteria by which such concepts emerge and are applied. Say, criteria stand to identity just as the physical stands to the human brain. The laws of the brain supervene on the laws of the physical (natural laws); the "laws" of identity supervene on the laws which govern criteria (the logical structure of the criterion, rules for the applicability of concepts). "Use" may be seen as "externalized" (the physical, the linguistic, markings, utterances, effects, etc). We may quantify it, describe it, measure it. "Meaning" may be all together obscure, abstract, spiritual, intangible, etc.; it is "internal," say. To say "meaning is use in language" is to identify a third party: in language, wherein criteria are more or less manifest. Laws pervade language; but surface grammar and "logical" grammar identify interpretive approaches to disparate domains: the domain of meaning and the domain of use. However, the third domain is not on the same "level" or categorical position within this metaphysic: and nor are the other domains identical to or reducible to it. There is no "metaphor-in" or analogy into this domain, as it makes "identity," "complexity," "causality," "surface laws" (natural laws), their sensicality. This domain does not consist of objects for measurement, since "objects for measurement" is a concept that has sense in virtue of this domains existence. Might we say there is a recursivity that defines, in part, the nature of such a domain? It is not quite clear that "is recursive"

item.title: call & apply
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
A friend of mine applied to Google for a contracting gig. He faced a JavaScript question to the effect: "Provide a wrapper function which passes an arbitrary number of arguments to the openDiaglog window method. (You cannot use an array.)"

call

(function() { // passing n-number of arguments through a wrapper function // no explicit arrays declared var args = arguments; window.openDialog.call(null, args); }("openDialog-wrapper-function.html", "Google Search", "window.open features", "arg1", "arg2", 41263));

apply is very similar to call, except for the type of arguments it supports. You can use an arguments array instead of a named set of parameters. With apply, you can use an array literal, for example, fun.apply(this, [name, value]), or an Array object, for example, fun.apply(this, new Array(name, value)).
apply - MDC
