item.content:encoded: A philosophical metaphor which grounds cognitive, and even further, the mental, within the physiological system, insofar as it is embedded, or situated within its environment. Lakoff and Johnson have advanced theories of embodied mind/cognition which rides on the notion of the conduit/container metaphor. How? Assume that the mind is a container or a vessel; naturally, a vessel, as such, has content and environment, an environment which partially determines the nature of the content of the object

item.title: E-mail to Germain Preston
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Et al., http://designshack.co.uk/articles/css/15-tips-for-designing-terrific-tables This is mostly a follow-up to a series of talks Germain and I had today. The gist of it is captured in the first statement of the above article. In a way, s are for content authors, left to be given some (usually bland) "content area design default" that doesn't aim to raise eyebrows. But interactive/information-display UI pieces (product charts, interactive-tabular data tables, &c) where the content author isn't permitted and where UI/UX/Dev have to really think and plan, this is where the should be considered last. The problem is that s immediately restrict what one can do within a UI. Data in s usually originate from a database (table), but this doesn't mean it has to be presented, developed or marked up as a table on the front-end. I want to make clear, though, that I am not arguing the use of
s where it is obvious that a table is most apt; rather, I am speaking to the planning that goes on before even front-end development. For instance, for me, calls to action count as non-tabular data. There's never a reason to sort them because they usually say the same thing. What would you say are some similar examples of "non-tabular" data that have, in your experiences, made it into a table? With this said, I'm thinking in terms of the components of a table and how those components fit into the overall UI piece. Another consideration might be: What if the tabular data has a kind of presentational aspect to it? What I mean here is with examples like Mozilla Lab's projects page: http://mozillalabs.com/projects/ By "presentational aspect" I mean something that perhaps is best defined in the negative: Data that could be wrapped in a table but which is not meant to be consumed "quickly." When we look at one of our peer's, say, a project manager's, Outlook schedule for the day, we are usually overwhelmed. Should
s expected to have "overwhelming" quantities of data as opposed to small quantities be styled the same way? But to echo a few points made during our chat: tables are primarily used to satisfy the criteria of presenting information is a logically structured way. But the "primary" or essential feature of s can, in many cases, be accomplished by using, with some design and development ingenuity,
    • s,
      s, or strategically situated
      s. These approaches do not necessarily undermine semantic, accessibility and usability goals, and in many cases afford flexibility, ease-of-development, manageability, and cross-browser compatibility (since we don't have to conform to the rigid structure of a
    • s,
). True enough, tables should be used for tabular data; but the converse is also true: Non-tabular data should not be used in tables. This is just as important, I feel, as the first statement. Moreover, they amount to saying the same thing. What this means to me is that if I notice non-tabular data in a wireframe I begin to wonder whether a table is the best fit for the task. It isn't all-or-none, but a graded interpretive approach. One rule of thumb I use is that if there is at least one column that isn't sortable because it "just wouldn't make any sense to sort it," then I start to re-interpret the whole UI piece in a different light (in terms of
    s or
    s, etc). Plus, I personally find it very rewarding to wrap up a project where I started out with humble tables in my wireframes and rolled out with a fancy UI piece that immediately prompts developers to View Source.

item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: The original idea was the following. I've recently realized that when not influenced by marijuana I would describe my physical personal state as bad. What this means here specifically is that, say, for any given person, and, given an arbitrary roster of pre-existing physical ailments, marijuana may play a role in adjusting one's physical personal state, such that the adjustment renders a positive perception of one's assessment of physical well-being. This idea isn't new.

item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Silence. It was a queer sort of rule of his. Goes without saying, or so the joke goes. And naturally he could ramble a reputable length on it. Within it. Above it. Birth'd from it. Well, that is the trick, isn't it? The space between the lines. He, like few, was a Mechanist of Silence. Observant of what counts as space, one can analogize: clearing one's way through the conditions for silence. Rule. Space. Silence. Most of us get by thinking rules are in themselves queer things. And we best serve ourselves in not bothering with them. Though, for those syntactically inclined, silence flows as readily in the imagination as the air permeates the room. Deprive us of silence: can the mind breath at all? For the mind: silence is a basic need for self-preservation. But as yet, what must be the culprit? Space and silence, let us s'pose, are one. From the formal and physical sciences, we image silence and space to be fundamentally the same, so long as we presuppose a teleological mode of being. Rule and Language.

item.title: Evidence
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Often it is claimed that religious thinkers fail to provide evidential support to their claims. As often as it is claimed, it is just as often incorrect. No one, surely, would say that Catholic and Christian theologians, of antiquity, especially, or modern theodicies fail to provide evidence for their claims. With all the burden of proof business, it's clear that a commitment to a certain kind of evidence is key. The burden of proof functions as a line drawn in the sand, constituted by social agreement, which demarcates, implicitly or explicitly, when one has ventured into unreliable assertion. The burden of proof does not itself possess substantive content, but rather acts as a conceptual tool for categorizing certain types of claims insofar as their content implies certain propositions. The burden is both a logical rule and a implicit normative evaluation of a claim. That said, the burden itself does not establish, of course, the truth or falsity of a claim, but rather enables one to identify the weighty logical ramifications which may obtain from certain claims.
A miracle is a violation of the laws of nature; and as a firm and unalterable experience has established these laws, the proof against a miracle, from the very nature of the fact, is as entire as any argument from experience can possibly be imagined.
"...as a firm and unalterable experience has established" is operative here. Naturally, any invocation of Hume prompts one at least to reflect on his pernicious brand of skepticism. Statements of "The future will resemble the past" and its ilk aside, one may wonder what it means for experience to establish anything. Certainly it is not true that given a sufficient number of experiences a certain law follows from that total set of experiences. In the quotation above, Hume seems to imply a third-party insofar as something is established; that is to say, an institution of some kind. Of course, from a modern scientist's belief, I would think, what Hume seems to be implicating is the authority of peer review. Or let us say: the institution of peer review. It would be laughable to assume that human experience establishes anything, especially natural laws. But now, if this is the case, we need to fairly apply this interpretation to similar social groups, and perhaps reshape the behavior we understand concepts such as "evidence," "laws" and the burden of proof to have. If "establishment" is all that one can really achieve; that is, a concept fundamentally conceived as a weight, then such a weight should be no less present in exactly that tradition Hume seeks to undermine, or at any rate, what Humeans claim Hume to have undermined. Certainly religions can have their own notion of what is or is not established. There's little rigor behind such a notion to begin with other than intersubjective agreement defined in terms of repeatability, predictability, falsifiability and so forth. However, because these methods persist within the scientific mode of experience, it does not follow that these practices define exhaustively what counts as the right kind of evidence. Often the scientific-atheist's argument ultimately turns on such a position, "Well, this is what we mean by evidence. This evidence comports with this practice." The usual response to such a line of thought as I expose above is some accusation of relativism. All I mean to indicate is that some pre-theoretical evaluation of practice takes place, before one addresses the evidence in itself, whether it be a miracle or a comet dashing across the night sky. But perhaps we should take a step back: the aforementioned would be merely phenomena so indeed the observation of a miracle, should it happen, or a comet, is in itself pre-theoretical. Before any interpretation of the event takes place, there is simply the event as it occurs, or presumably occurs in the world. Then the effort of analyzing, interpreting and theorizing on the phenomenon takes place. I hazard this dissection for the point that religious thinkers, like scientific thinkers, must first observe and then interpret. The important point here ties us back to "evidence." Atheistic thinkers will often criticism religious thinkers, apologetics, etc as if they had no evidence since revelation, miracles, providence, and the like are, to say the least, highly unreliable phenomena. But being unreliable does not say one way or the other what influence such a kind of phenomena has on the language game of the person who professes to believe in such phenomena as evidence. Unpredictable, unreliable, untestable, unfalsifiable; there is no shortage of pejorative or objectively fair points we can raise to such a belief, but as evidence do these phenomena play a role in the lives of those with religious sensibilities. This, in part, points to what faith is about for the religious. Indeed, their form of evidence can be fairly criticized as being fundamentally based on unreliable, sporadic events (which they often construe by their narrative).

item.title: Privacy Statement
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Enfold Systems, Inc. operates the Ploud website and we respect your right, and your users rights, to personal privacy. We will collect and use information through our Web site only in the ways disclosed in this statement. This statement applies solely to information collected on this Web site.

How We Protect Your Information

We protect user information with secure servers, SSL encryption and other technology and procedures for protecting consumer privacy.

How We Collect Your Information

We collect data that is not personally identifiable information, including IP address, referring Web site and other metrics as tracked by Google® Analytics. We collect personally identifiable information through registration forms, server logging and upon purchase of our products. We do employ cookies. A cookie is a small text file our Web server places on your computer hard drive to be a unique identifier. Our cookies do not have an expiration date. They do collect personally identifiable information, including your user name for our Web site.

How We Use Your Information

We will use the information we collect for customer purchases, order processing, support, maintenance, Web site access and marketing effectiveness. Registered users may receive additional announcements from us about products, services, special offers or a newsletter. Out of respect for your privacy, we give you the option not to receive these types of communications. We will use the information we collect to create customer profiles based on browsing or purchasing history. We may supplement information we collect at our Web site with data from other sources, such as credit history, to authorize purchases. We may share data with third parties such as credit card processing and fulfillment companies. These third parties will use the information to process your order. We offer links to other Web sites. When you click on links to other Web sites, we encourage you to read their privacy policies. Their standards may differ from ours. Our Web site offers issue trackers (support collectors) to help customers, users and clients resolve problems with our products and services. Please note that information you post in these venues may become public knowledge.

How to Change Your Information

You may access and edit your own personal information, or contact us at customerservice@enfoldsystems.com to report any inaccuracies you find.

How to Resolve a Problem

If a problem arises, please e-mail us at customerservice@enfoldsystems.com. We are committed to resolving issues within five business days.

item.title: Mankiw's 10 Principles of Economics
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
1. People face tradeoffs
  2. The cost of something is what you give up to get it
  3. Rational people think at the margin
  4. People respond to incentives
  5. Trade can make everyone better off
  6. Markets are usually a good way to organize economic activity
  7. Gvmts can sometimes improve market outcomes
  8. A country's standard of living depends on its ability to produce goods and services
  9. Prices rise when the government prints too much money
  10. Society faces a short-run tradeoff between inflation and unemployment

item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Oft-repeat'd is the old joke,

"the two biggest problems in computer science naming things and " ...

Well, I s'pose for fail of memory, such a gesture should suffice. In itself such a gesture is at once a response to a wider philosophical problem and an assertion against its constraints. The saying finishes off, to wit, is "cache invalidation." As a response, one must first confer that only under a certain context can an action be described. Indeed, an action may occur across multitudes of situations, but nevertheless description of the situation, or say event, is logically prior to the description of the action. One may grimace at the conflation of situation and event, and such a reaction is certainly due, for a "situation" is clearly more all-encompassing in terms of its connotative qualities. And one certainly would not readily identify an action as a situation, or if at all, such analysis would be rare still than as event. A broader notion of "event" is one I treat here, and so I will label it as a situation, treating it accordingly. What is more, my topic chiefly centers on the notion, regardless of substantive -- historical, cultural, conceptual, material -- content, that events do not exist, on premiss that they are not proper wholes. Thus, it would make little sense to agree to terms such that actions purely, as events, logically antecede a larger event which is causally constituted by its actions. An event, whether it exists or not, would be itself describable in terms of any number of contexts. We might call such a description a model or interpretation of that context.

Existentialist-ic Mooreans

In exploration of a greater, say existential,

Old but endearing problematics

Primarily because it resonates with old philosophical problems. The second component, quite explicitly. The former less so. Though the notion of cache in itself presupposes certain relations between entities qua agents. Systems, nodes, servers, clients, and their pushes and pulls, bidirectionality, etc. To me it says: "There are two problems in CS: the present application of set theoretical thinking and whether or not we are engaged in something called 'set theoretical thinking'." Thus, realism and nihilism.

item.title: Escape From Leviathan: Liberty, Welfare, and Anarchy Reconciled
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: A reply to Peter Vinton Jr. Peter Vinton's title asks "And just where does `anarchy' fall on the spectrum again?" I was persuaded by an editor not to put my essay on this matter into an appendix of the book. I am not convinced that this omission was a good idea. Were it there, Vinton would have been answered and the ideological position of anarcho-liberalism might have been illuminated for other readers (maybe it can be in the next, a revised, edition). The short answer to his question is that anarchy is off the spectrum but on the compass. The long answer can be found here: http://www.la-articles.org.uk/pc.htm. My intention in writing Escape from Leviathan was, using the critical-rationalist epistemology, philosophically to defend (by responding to all the best or typical criticisms I could find) the social-scientific evidence (but certainly not summarizing it all) that private-property anarchy does not clash with either interpersonal liberty or human welfare (which italicised proposition I called the `extreme classical-liberal compatibility thesis'). I eschewed all moral advocacy as irrelevant and confusing, given the objective nature of my thesis. However, I did, where necessary, engage in meta-ethics to explain how morals and moralizing (but without any particular content) fitted with the rest of my arguments and theories. I emphatically did not avoid morals because I think morals are unimportant or irrelevant to all libertarian arguments, as some critics have supposed. Still less did I write the entire book out of a "desire to address the familiar argument that libertarian principles have no morality", as Vinton somewhat more strangely supposes. The introduction explains-as its subheadings indicate-the classical-liberal compatibility thesis, why moral advocacy is avoided, and the critical-rationalist method. So I don't agree that it begins "with a `recap' of exactly what constitutes classical liberalism". In the chapter on rationality I do not only, or mainly, look at altruism, as Vinton appears to suggest. I am attempting to give a comprehensive philosophical defence of aprioristic instrumental rationality. And I look only at the `logic' of altruism (and related aspects of morals), where I look at it at all, rather than "its underlying motivations". I nowhere suggest or imply the proposition that "an attitude of enlightened self-interest is actually a better framework for real altruism than the current atmosphere of welfare" (although I do argue that human welfare is best promoted by laissez-faire). Contra Vinton, I explicitly argue against the thesis that "[p]eople are naturally psychological egoists" and in favour of the thesis that altruism is genuine. Given the immediately previous quotation, he does not even appear to be consistent in what he asserts I say here. Nor do I suggest that "`self-perceived interest' is a better expression than `altruism'" but that it is clearer than `self interest'. And I explicitly defend, not reject, the view that "altruism implies having an interest in others as an end in itself." It is a howler, given what I write in the book about `coercion', to state "The second part of the book ... explores the end results of coercion versus liberty". And it cannot be accurate to state that the book has "some refreshing new theories on what constitutes equitable redress." For equity (fairness in justice) is not discussed; nor is any theory of justice propounded. However, Vinton is right to note the novelty and, I hope, interest of the theory of liberty as `the absence of [proactively] imposed cost' and the consequences of applying this as a thought experiment in various simple situations. In the chapter on welfare, I defend the view of (spontaneous-)want-satisfaction as a plausible theory of welfare for persons. That is not the same as advocating that people should be "embracing the motive of want-satisfaction". And to explain and defend the objective libertarian consequences of maximizing such welfare is not to argue that this "leads to a better system of social justice". That is just the kind of red herring about morals the book takes pains to avoid. The single short sentence on the anarchy chapter does not contain any obvious inaccuracies. Why do I reply to a review that does not appear to have any real criticisms and quite a few misunderstandings? I don't want to miss an opportunity to clarify what the book is about because I believe it to be both substantially true and morally urgent. However, I do not have high hopes of its being given wider consideration while the publishers continue to sell only the hardback at such a stiff price and while anti-libertarian professors prefer to repeat their old lectures on Robert Nozick's Anarchy, State, and Utopia. His book is often thought-provokingly clever but it is a justificationist, minarchist, ragbag bereft of a clear theory of liberty and its relation to property and human welfare. I have replied elsewhere on the net to most other amazon.com reviews, which have sometimes appeared in longer forms first. Seek and ye shall find. J C Lester, March 2005

item.title: Critique in Web Design as Two Parts
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Web design critiques should come two-fold: a negative critique whose primary purpose is to enable identification of core design elements, as many are tied to content which may demand categorically that a certain design element persist, which are to be kept and a positive critique whose purpose is to synthesize both new departure and the results of the exercise of critique.

item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
She'll die when the last memory I have of her fades; and I never forget anything, perhaps on account of such peculiarities as my conception of memory at all. For me, quite genuinely, there is Substance. Call it archaic, but new languages should frighten you too. Within it, nothing dissipates, expires, ceases or any of that; all that occurs may be described as 'the modification of Substance.' As such I cannot fathom, as such a philosophical intersection demands, true loss of memory. Natural laws 'Modification' - [coma memories]
Existentialists typically hold to a distinction between the will of circumstance and the will of establishment. In addressing the will at all the philosophical limits go no further; adopting certain notions as permitted in application to the will while rejecting others in and of itself is an effort to prescribe a method for addressing the problem of the freedom of the will. Authors of this sort make it a habit, say, to belabor the niceties and trivialities of existence, through their letter, so as to convince one that certain of this rank of environmental garnish are important as to the inner experience of the author or protagonist, etc. Life, say, consists primarily of influences from external objects not governed within one's perception, objects physical and abstract. But subsumed under this class of external object are objects fixed and objects contingent, abstract, concrete, or not. The will may not be free in terms of fixed events which may describe one's life, but may also be liberated in certain ways by the governance those events play over others who are similarly so categorically influenced. The will may be free in contingency, which readily comes to the imagination, but may be paralyzed when laws, say of fixed spaces, govern.

item.title: The Scaffolding of the Spectacle
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Monetization as a noble deployment toward terminable self-sustainability. Yet Text will ever be a possible value of currency. Capitalism enriches one's imaginary of failure in a set of unique and specific ways, along the lines commonly understood as narrative. In one way, as with any narrative, the possibility of failure must be contained within the conceptual refinements of the narrative itself. Capital must speak its own failure; by way of the constituency of its conceptual hygiene: what can be said to be valid or invalid behavior along the strictures of the narrative. -- As yet, historically, the Text has the capacity of recursive meaning, which Money cannot possess. Why relate these disparate concepts? In that technology has reduced their apparent distinction, apparent value, commonly held, to something vague and often misleading. Do these archaisms "the Self," "the Other," orientialisms, Architect egos and paladins of industry, and all of that, now, have they evolved distinguishably removed into concepts we as yet must fail in analysis in terms of Money -- the arch representation of political benevolence.

item.dc:creator: admin

item.title: _sexual
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Let's say that beauty is a talent. Why not? For in perception, beauty may be contrived or accidental, and in fabrication there should be no less mistake and miss of cue. We've touched on the word before, its role in language, namely to collect and swell with all the other properties, mundane to far-fetched and lovely. But is beauty a talent? Doubting such would seem to imply that beauty is only natural. And more dishearteningly, that beauty cannot be the subject of refinement. And certainly one's own beauty may be extended to the world, a push of one's aesthetic. The externalization of beauty, then, we might call aesthetic. The sexes: Women exact from me my talents in certain and undesirable ways. Men seem to lack refinement of beauty. A woman I might call beautiful and in a certain sense interesting but thus diminishing of sexual attractiveness. While the other lacks what I might call beautiful due to lack of refinement in talent.

item.title: The Utilitarian
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Our position concerns the Utilitarian. Often analysis orients itself and the concept in such a way as to imply truthfully that utilitarianism is a practical-ethical philosophical position one can possibly take under a given set of contingent moral circumstances. Where regardless of the way the world is, the agent may nevertheless digest an anxiety in perception of a moral principle subject to modification. Say, the categorical imperative, such that the principle acknowledges the properties of modes in existence; trees, cars, turtles, laws, beliefs, sea captains, etc. insofar as their effects, ignoring static qualities such as color, but rather in their reproduction of an attribute, but yet the principle heralds consistency across worlds. The undertaking, then, is that one develop a system of description which

And old omens realized would teach, Teach us how to hope and grip arms Of the Other
Children no longer sprawled and flayed The earth's skin until the small hours, And demons baked on the rooftops
Of snow-stained, quaint homes, Hungry for all that innocence Which once whisked whimsically

item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Let us imagine a gang of scientists -- on known assumption that in their culture they receive a dignified appellation "scientist," vaguely synonymous to our own -- who speak apparently eloquently and in long-winded fashion on unintelligible nonsense. Would we say, They speak a different language? In what sense would we mean "different language"? Breaking down and demonstrating the conceptual connections nonostensible and latent to such a phrasing is the job of the philosopher, for in common parlance and linguistic practice it is customarily assumed that concepts reveal themselves more readily in speech and writing in virtue of concrete connection with the tangible, historical markings and utterances who express and legitimate that "inner" conceptual space. The philosopher reminds us of our common assumption and the habitual mental and physical behaviors manifest in its implicit and explicit acceptance.

item.title: Some Meta-ethics
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Beginning with the question: What is a "fact"? As with most philosophical jargonology, there's no fact to the matter as to what a fact truly amounts to. We do have distinctions, however: facts, theories, values, laws. We have further distinctions, so it goes: Moral facts, ethical theories (not moral theories!), moral values (or just values), and moral laws (not legal laws; redundant?)

Moral Facts

Moral facts, as it follows from the widely adopted but nevertheless contentious, upon philosophical scrutinizing, take from the concept of fact the feature of being truth-makers. Moral facts make certain things true, whatever those things turn out to be. Often it is claimed that facts make propositions true; and propositions are expressed by statements, or sentences. More abstractly, and to the earlier point of contention, the world as a collection of facts makes propositions, expressed by sentences, or statements, or recordings, or pictures, etc., etc., true. So again it follows -- to keep to our P's and Q's, indeed -- the moral world makes our moral propositions true. Well beyond me is it that such a slip in language could send us spiraling into centuries of silence, even if we have been speaking and writing. John Mackie had the right intuition by laying down his Argument from Queerness, where the basic intuition is: Let us observe the World, which we will take for granted, and the Moral World; what might an intersection between these worlds look like to us given our epistemological structuring, practices, methods, limits, etc. I place an emphasis on "Worlds" to underscore a metaphysical consideration which Mackie himself introduces. I formulate it in this way: Is the posit of the atom (or any analogous theoretical entity) like the posit of a moral fact? The problem centers on the intuition I believe most share that in positing even one moral fact, a Moral World is instantiated. Perhaps the first problem, then, is the flawed analogy between "moral facts" and "scientific theoretical entities": We need a fleshing out of "the moral fact" in the way that the atom or the motley crew of known subatomic particles have been fleshed out (in terms of indirect observational evidence, best inference, etc.). Before we address the difference in would-be-Worlds, we have to first address the plain linguistic counter-intuition. Facts are not simples like atoms, bosons, quarks; moreover, facts would fall under the heading necessarily complex; whereas the categorical ancestor of the atom is potentially simple. Perhaps another way to put this is: Facts are necessarily irreducible; whereas atoms are domain-specific (say, to physics). (Naturally the implication here is that there is something to which the entities and laws of physics are reducible; and I'm fine with this.) In ordinary speaking the Fact is not explicitly or implicitly presupposed. ...

Ethical and Moral Theories

Let's keep this clean: a moral theory is such a theory that we may attribute to a moral agent in the event of practical moral theorizing. A moral agent produces a moral theory at certain points in his or her life so as to resolve a moral conflict. We might say that the moral theory is a conceptual child to the "critical moral attitude"; where such an attitude is marked by introspection, skepticism, grades of emotional detachment, etc. -- something akin to R. Hare's "critical level" of moral thinking (as opposed to the intuitive level). An ethical theory speaks on moral decision making, its processes, structures, results of moral agents who, here and there, undertake moral theorizing. An ethical theory takes on the various modes of moral thought (consequence-based, rule-based, character-based, etc.) and attempts to determine the right one over classes of moral situations or individual moral situations. So an author may advance an ethical theory which may be described as "utilitarian" or "Millian" if that author deems a fundamentally consequence-based mode of moral thought the best fit; or an author may be counted as a "Kantian" if one judges that the class of all moral situations are best dealt with, not only under a deontological, or rule-based mode of thought, but moreover under a distinct or derivative Kantian mode of moral thought. It is the ethical theories chief business to provide reasons as to why one mode of moral thinking is best for the relevance classes of moral situations; moreover, to defend its coherency against its detractors; to provide its basic structure and categorization; to expose the nature of its values; and to orient and inform its base language for communication of those basic values; and to reveal to unique logic it bears; and to establish its overlap with everyday moral intuitions, should it deviate, at the letter, very far from them.

item.title: Language
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Language as a collection of realized and unrealized images in the mind; Language as a collection of tools whose use may be warranted or unwarranted. Of the former sort of thinking, immediately and intuitively a complex hierarchical (or foundationalist) system of thinking emerges. Thought, like Language, is asserted to be composed of layers of logics, where the ground floor logic is isomorphic with the World. Readily available is the distinction between the surface forms of communication and the logical form of communication, where the logical form makes possible the coherency and

item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
"Language is the honeydew lemon drop which cradles within it the reflection of the tumultuous bowels of my mind, before the hollowed but virulent gymnosophist of which I am composed."
"Rush to foul by the borders of thought -- rush as you mightily doubt; but stay kept in mind the thought: the rhythm in one's postures speaks the folktale of you."
"A foot's shot is a shy's throw from a creaking cot."
"Splendid!"

item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
My sister and I rarely speak to one another. Asserting with less pride than regret, she and I grew up in no less than utterly different worlds, reasonably underestimating -- through the years, up 'til this point -- the narratives of the other. Through an unfortunate draw of the card, we knew less of what it meant to be siblings than what it meant to maintain a stable inner solace, but as we slowly drift into the way things typically even out to be, we're learning, surely, that the sage-like introspective internalizations of our hermetic childhoods, intentional and sometimes not, will only structure the inevitable later realized tie which binds us: our Mother. But she's no Saint.
I s'pose she's grown. I have the most inchoate snapshots of her personal progression, and even then which are few and far. But somehow, I'm s'posin' she's grown -- matured, as if it were even in my right to make such claim. I'm no genuine brother, but yet something in my blood dares me to hazard a boldness, a confidence, and compassion.
"We're happy when we're alone" she said. Yet what has plagued me? -- "You'll never be happy"; mutually agreed upon by closed friends who may as well have printed the script beforehand.
No wonder why I'm miserable, as I laugh for the first time at anything my father has ever said. And even still, likely an echo from before my last good night's rest.

item.title: A Farewell to Athena
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
(since I never got your number:) I cannot picture a world wherein last night, this morning, and all the rest, fails to happen. At the risk of sounding immature and all, I really do hope you enjoyed our reckless little sex-tantrum. And I hope you're physically all right.
That night, this morning, will, of course, be the subject of much personal, inner musings for quite some time, years perhaps; decades, with hope. This morning felt -- every word we shared, every grope, thought, thrust, scratch and claw and kiss -- it felt like the utmost necessity of Nature (I'm still a sap for Spinoza). For ill or good, I can only feel that it simply had to happen. Where I come in: I'm glad that it did.
Whatever the interpretation, I must know, if nothing else, that you made it safely and timely on your way to that new departure of yours. It's nothing less than impressive, from what little I know about the world of academia, and I hope your classes go well.
I'm not sure how you feel, and you may never ever wish to tell me, but I conjure that we have set aright the World in some twisted, manic and disagreeable way. Sure: drunk to begin with, but toward the morning hours? And all those peculiar qualities about myself; how surprising and moving that you should recall them so readily. Either you've had something up your sleeve since the day we met, or you're an elephant. I don't know; perhaps I shouldn't?
To say the least, I think we portayed a good drama. I recognize, of course, that at some layer of the confounding drawn-out dance between us, and perhaps in spite of the visceral night we leave behind, you aim to perserve a pitiable, naive, innoncent, enfeebled, incapable me, as an image to take with you well into the far future reaches of your life. True enough, I concede, one may find infinite romance in unrealized possibilities. I do apologize for infringing upon, and perhaps marring, such well kept or safe-guarded figurine, so installed in the every-now-and-then recollections of what you leave behind.
I don't feel it my right to put a seal on anything, but on the other hand, we are clearly set in divergent trajectories, for the time being, anyway. For the time being: How can I say that with real emphasis, beyond the typograhical? Who can really say? And what use is there in saying "if only had we done all this sooner"? And what's more, you are under a certain impression: where you are, as you say, "a bitch." Naturally, I can only disagree; how could I possibly do otherwise? All I can say is that I find you to be uniquely fascinating, for whatever words are worth. It is your vibrant mind, frenetic persona, devilish charm... these are how I see you in the abstract. I'll take these lonely words over "bitch," yes.
I s'pose I've rambled on more than enough. I'm starting to find myself intolerable. I'd like to say, though, that we should correspond (through postage perhaps?), but I really don't know where we stand, or if we stand, or what -- maybe I overestimate the gravity of all of this.
Terms aside, as I'm sure they will unfold in time, I will just get to my bittersweet farewell, should nothing more come to between us now, fifty years hence, or anywhere in between.
That is to say, with my own juvenile twist on Andrew Marvell's "To His Coy Mistress":
Yonder all before us lie. Desserts* of vast eternity.
Farewell, in a way, Athena

item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Ordinary language: that language whose meaning is partly constituted by its use in ordinary life.
We have "language," "meaning," "ordinary" and "life."
Language may be viewed as a combination of syntactic and semantic rules. With these in place, we may draw literal inferences, where "literal" is meant to constrain the language to no more than talking about itself. Thus, we may look at language, in this sense, as empty, or vacuous, symbolism. By "semantic" rules, we mean not to say that the language, or kind of language, in question talks about anything in the World, but rather states of affairs which do or do not obtain. So, the semantics of such a language amounts to the True or the False. Propositions of such a language point to the True or the False. Such a language bears semantics which extend nowhere beyond this. Semantics in a wider sense involves meaning in a wider sense: involving connotations, subjective meanings, the World, etc. Semantics of our "dried out" language stands outside the World.
Meaning, of this wider sense, is conjoined with language of our prior description

item.title: Connectionistism
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: The mereological fallacy is committed when one assumes of substantives, which are picked out by nouns and noun phrases, that they are semantically coextensive, despite being in possession of a dissimilar categorical, or logical, form. The presumption hinges on a superficial, or I should say "naive," (in the technical sense) apprehension of proximity between discrete entities. For instance, "Sam" and "Sam's stomach" may intelligibly, and validly (semantically), be substituted in the statement "X digested Y" in some cases. Our intuitions are not rubbed the wrong way. We get what is meant; but at the same time we understand that in a "broad" sense Sam digests his meal in a logically connected way to the "narrow" sense that his stomach digests (what the science reveals to us as the specifics and going-ons of the digestive system and its process). "To digest" carries with it a "semantic field" which accepts, by the conventions of our language, both entities without damage to sense. We see an obviously physical connection between both Sam and his own stomach, by way of the latter being a proper logical part to Sam. However, the meaningfulness of that connection is established by way of an empirical state of affairs. The meaty question amounts to in virtue of what is "form" established? The primary suspect for the mereological fallacy is the kind of thinking which ignores obvious semantic discontinuity between terms. The vulgar example, of course, is manifest in the claim that "Sam" and "Sam's brain" are semantically coextensive, or coreferential, in some cases. A central distinction that must be noted is that between universal and existential claims. In the case of digestion, it is plain that varying expressions that intimate or state exactly

item.title: Moore's Paradox
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Moore's paradox: In the first person, it cannot be asserted or believed, without contradiction, both that p and that one believes either that not-p or does not believe that p. The former is the commissive paradox while the latter invokes the omissive paradox. Asserted or believed independently, under questionable epistemic circumstances (experimental, "limit testing" scenarios), under coercion, in the past tense, or from the second- and third-person no paradox persists.

Types of paradox

  1. Commissive paradox: p and I believe that not-p.
  2. Omissive: p and I do not believe that p.
So,
  1. (p) & B~(p)
  2. (p) & ~B(p)
respectively. Prima facie, these do not formally look like paradoxes, but we must say that when conjoined a paradox emerges.

Problematic

Why is this a paradox? Explain it as a paradox, assuming that it is truly a paradox; or demonstrate why it is not in fact a paradox. What makes such a situation paradoxical?

Expansion approach

Generally speaking, assertions expand to beliefs, or rather assertions are maskings of beliefs. Strictly speaking, assertions imply belief. So, the semantic value of an assertion is the belief of the proposition. Assertions mean beliefs. Manifold questions, of course, naturally reveal themselves in consideration of such an assumption: What are the sociological, philosophical, linguistic, pragmatic consequences of such a view? Moreover, we must look at what determines the sense in which an assertion is a belief. By "sense" I mean whether a belief is held as true, false, probable, etc. We may require to look at the pragmatic or contextual constraints under which the assertion emerges. We may, perhaps, make a distinction between believing and believing to be true. Under this view, do we assume that all assertions are made under the constraint of tending to truth? Well, this is the common understanding of assertion. But an "assertion" is a phenomena that stands in need of explanation. We call a proposition on paper a "proposition," but what makes it an assertion? A mental state? A conversational inertia? Are we compelled to make assertions? Can we look as if to assert a proposition while not in fact doing so? (Speech act theory) More to the point: Assertions such that p are in fact abbreviations of believe statements. Thus, p expands to I believe that p. Therefore, we arrive at the paradoxical situation, under the omissive paradox:

I believe that p & I do not believe that p

That is,

B(p) & ~B(p)

However, under the commissive interpretation, we arrive at the following.

I believe that p & I believe that not-p

Under the commissive interpretation, we arrive at no paradox; notably,

B(p) & B(~p)

Minimizing approach

The converse of the above view gives us the minimizing approach. Belief statements reduce to assertions. Beliefs are in fact assertions. The semantic material of belief is exhausted by assertion; belief means assertion. So, the proposition that I believe that p becomes p. In similar fashion, we arrive at the following, under the commissive paradox.

p & not-p

That is,

(p) & ~(p)

Yet what of the omissive situation? That is, what would "I do not believe that p" mean under this minimizing approach? What would it "reduce" to? Let's ask: Would one assert what one does not believe? Well, purportedly, at the level of belief, the paradox persists. Would we arrive at the following?

p & not-p

It seems that this view may imply a convergence between the omissive and commissive paradoxes.

We have a matrix.

Omissive paradox at the level of belief Commissive at the level of belief

item.title: Lost from language
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: From very early on (pre-adolescence), one could find in me a general tendency and desire to deconstruct material objects, usually of mundane complexity (Legos, computing machines, circuit boards, etc). With Legos the realization of a deconstructive effort was ultimately the point (in case such an example is not obvious; and so that we need not entertain drab borderline cases where creation and destruction equally apply). The talent, if we can call it that, was by no means extraordinary -- hardly even worth mentioning at a family gathering before one's spouse's folks. But I'll mention it here, since it pertains. Such a penchant spilled over into my time spent in high school, wherein critique of the vernacular of my peers raised suspicion toward my commitment to social ties. The corrective mood was easily mobilized by every grammatical quirk; but I was often led to the belief that surely I could not be a divine philologist or a --- I am a human of mediocre intelligence, or so I'd be willing to bet. And in terms of quantification of my vocabulary, I doubt my chips would receive anything more than pity. Perhaps I am what's called an "avid reader," but I really have no means of comparison. All this is to say, I doubt that I am very "smart" by the usual standard. In taking refuge with the philosophers, I took myself to be landing upon estimable grounds -- well, not consciously anyway. I actually thought undertaking a regime in rigors of philosophy would aid me in fostering a level of precision of articulation that might undermine many of my almost denumerable issues with linguistic performance. But this sadly did little toward that end.

item.title: The most beautiful girl in town
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Always carry a lighter. And always fumble it in answer to her entreaty. She's an addict, and be addicted to that. Explain the causal mechanisms of the world, and imply the locality of our moral laws. Sip coffee as if your lips were taking in her words from the brim; bitter, hot and compelling. Blow smoke in her face by accident and apologize too earnestly and emphatically. Comment on the wear of her shoes only to invoke an imaginative fugue wherein her dice rolls save the party she's hosting, and make it conspicuous your personal imperative to stay behind to help clean and soak in her most shallow thoughts which echo the incoherence of the latest wave of hybrid dash feminism. Drill unrelentingly into the caverns of her family history; offer another smoke; and smoke the rare brand out of the perception of a tacit suggestion. Ruffle the feathers under her political wings. Own a cat named after a bumpkin. Translate into a mathematical language the justifications for her most irrational fears; and then convert all of this into another senseless rhyming poem. Puzzle over trips of grammars until 4:16 AM

item.title: They Were Regulars
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: They were regulars to a local open mic, recurring every Monday on a corner in some quaint, ugly neighborhood. He was oblivious to just about every going-on conventional to their cozy, little proto-culture; or at least this was his continual effort to be. Deftly so, he knew, or rather assumed, he could identify the vagaries manifest in conversation and exploit, surreptitiously of course, his audience into condescending their spirits, their wits, to draw joy from his whilings. He was crafty and nondescript, or so he aspired to be. He figure that he should excel at nothing thereby excel at not even the meager, trivial things; the audience can only makes note of consistent flagrancy. And exception in a vacuum only leads one to wonder at the concept of a vacuum. He had hoped to croak at thirty, but for him every day simply felt more difficult to complete, and as if an objective must obtain. Why -- or how -- was he connected to this necessity? Ask an amateur philosopher, fill in a Form, but don't ask me; I leave philosophy for those willing to see. But he dealt in such farcical entreaties, bringing Socrates to his knees and all that. I'm not much for rhyming either, so don't expect much more of that our of me in this tale, which I should probably get back to. He played the harmonica, blues in an unkept way, or perhaps the expected way. And she would learn guitar for an audience, always handsomely prepared, with sheet music and shine. This, primarily, was what tickled his mind. Just where did her confidence come from? More importantly, Could this be an irrelevant question? How could it? Perhaps such a tiff should trouble my mind too. And what was she after? Doubtful anything; maybe just a warm shoulder or his frizzy, vulgar hair. It was probably just the open mic that attracted her: good friends, foreign talents, deliciously awful comedians here and there. But that complements them too much. This would be the simplest theory, but simply theories make for boring stories. So, we'll go with that she was arrested by some complexity in him. And perhaps there was. He deplored the standard interpretations of Cantor's proof, and called just about everything philosophical "insens." She had a timorous, clumsy beauty about her, and as I pointed out earlier, she had attained a better-described-as-endearing mastery of guitar. He wasn't much a fan of guitar, except for those quiet, empty nights where he would seclude himself to a pitch black room with his audience, always clandestinely in chairs.

The city's pissed tonight. (soberly, abjected)

Few places are hospitable at such an hour. What did you expect?

So will you jump now? Are you sufficiently convinced?

Someone told me that you had training in these matters. I'm not convinced of that, on top of the rest of it.

We usually start from a uncertainty only to arrive at unheard of depths.

You know I was always quite daft on epistemology.

But do you believe such a thing?

It helps me

item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: The philosopher marks for us the answers to the obvious questions. In everyday conversation, the philosopher wrangles us into a childish way of moving, gesturing, and posturing ourselves. We say, "But your way of talking is cumbersome, slow, and resistant to advancement -- where is the utility in your way of talking?"; as if almost to assert that the philosopher is antagonistic to a certain theory or push. The philosopher seeks understanding. One way to go about securing understanding is to collapse complexity in language. Language, with its myriad forms of representation, -- and this is, of course, an inherited, tired mantra -- sets traps. Naturally one might accuse that a teleological assumption is being couched within this claim. The counter-assumption, which intuitively emerges, is that everyone understands the grammar instantiated within a conversation. So when A speaks with B, A and B share a grammar which, C, D, E, and so on, might readily and easily follow. Street grammar, say, is something we all share and can understand. Thus, we have the accept of an agreement. Certainly this is not doubted; that something binds and unifies us. But when we speak of representation in virtue of language a snag must be clear.

item.title: Knowledge as True Belief
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Yes, I'm going to take the position. Why? I think it will get me around the Gettier problem and Gettier-type cases. So instead of having to give a fourth condition to knowledge (when combined with the other three, they give the necessary and sufficient conditions for knowledge), I only have to give two (albeit a really damn convincing account of those two). This one philosopher similarly took this route in 1991 in an article titled "Knowledge is merely true belief." Here are some of the moves he makes. (1) Thinking this notion is silly or "pernicious" is not to bring an argument against it. (2) We can ask of the epistemological thought experiment: Is that really a case of belief? or are you deliberately (or perhaps tacitly) doing damage to our conventional notion of belief a disservice to make me think that you're licensed to bring justification in, that knowledge needs justification. Epistemologists tend to give impoverished accounts of "belief." Naturally, we need a rich enough notion of belief that does not in any way involve any feature of "justification." Beliefs presuppose (a) understanding the meaning of the terms of the belief, (b) commitment to the belief

item.title: Thought and language, a distinction
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: We do not think in any medium. We think into language, not in language. Thought is not a quasi-language or a quasi-method of expression. To use idiom such as "the language of thought" is to speak figuratively. A necessary condition for a word is that it consist of a finite concatenation of symbols or markings; a picture a finite set of strokes, markings, shapes, lines, etc. Thoughts, or thinking, do not satisfy, and thus do not depend upon or presuppose, such a necessary condition. Thus, to claim that we think in terms of words or pictures or symbols is to claim something that is literally false.

item.title: Non-cognitivism about morality
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: A cognitivist holds that moral propositions are truth-apt. A truth-apt proposition is one that has the capacity to record a fact of the world. A fact of the world is that which can be true or false of a state of affairs. Thus, a cognitivist holds that moral propositions express facts about the world, wherein the moral proposition is false just in case the fact which it purports to be the case is not the case. A moral proposition is false just in case the fact which it purports to be the case is not the case. A fact's being the case or not being the case is a matter of whether or not it obtains. That which is obtainable can be expressed; therefore, a proposition, generally speaking, could express it. What obtains when a fact is the case is the arrangement of properties of the state of affairs. The features, that is, of the state of affairs stand in a certain relation to one another. By the proposition that the house is the left of the tree, it is expressed that a house stands in a particular relation to the tree. The house, the tree and the relation are properties of the event that obtains. A fact is an event. No fact exists outside of the event of perceiving it. Thus, the proposition which records a fact of the world, a particular state of affairs, only does so in virtue of the fact's capacity to be perceived. An observer is essential to the status of the fact. Outside of the world of occurring events, facts do not exist. For to say that they do, we would be saying that facts persist outside of the world of occurring events. But do facts persist in the world of occurring events? This question seems equally difficult to answer. The space of events is the space of facts. A fact exists only insofar as it can be perceived through an event. The identification of the fact is itself an event. The fact is shaped by the identification. A fact is such under a particular context. What would we say of a context-free fact? A mathematical statement is true irrespective to any observer identifying or acknowledging it? When a thing is true, we can either praise or blame it. But what does it mean to say of a thing that it is true but we might never be in a position to praise it or acknowledge its pleasing feel? A statement true in virtue of its connection to us.

item.dc:creator: admin

The "problems" are contained commonly in each (Cantor's trick by interpretation). There is the syntactical maneuver (the diagonal) and the semantic sleight of hand (the "consequences" which must be drawn).

item.title: Notes on "David Papineau on Scientific Realism"
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: From: http://nigelwarburton.typepad.com/philosophy_bites/2009/01/david-papineau-on-scientific-realism.html Most scientists are committed to the claim that unobservable entities (theoretical posits of science: quarks, Higgs bosons, elementary particles, strings, viruses, radiowaves, molecules, etc), have reality ("really exist") to the same extent as everyday objects (chairs, books, cars, humans, etc). That is, the language of science achieves a correspondence, through its descriptions or descriptive powers, with "reality" to the same degree or with the same level of satisfaction as ordinary language. Moreover, (most) scientists believe that we know about these unseen objects. Our knowledge of them is guaranteed by our theories about them.

item.title: Philosophy as the logical clarification of language
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Philosophy is nothing more than the activity of philosophers. For a culture, it is a matter of course where some of its members fall under the criteria of meeting description of a philosopher. The meaning of philosophy, and all that one could hope to mean when one talks about philosophy, then, is exhausted by the activity of just those persons who meet the criteria under the everyday description. The distinction between academic philosophy and amateur philosophy indicate nothing more than an artificial demarcation made by the implicit, and often explicit, human tendency to recognize authority, "as such" as one might say within a language game. Can we say that academic philosophy really amounts to institutionalized philosophy? One has access to exactly those works of "academic" literature as would any institution(alized) philosopher. What is missing from the predicate is the aspect of unified social form. Philosophy of the university is its own language game, and this should be obvious. Wherein the notion of academic philosophy concepts of rigor, consistency, scope, purpose, agenda, micro-analytics, attention to language, structuring, philosophical patience, distinction, and so on are seriously brought to the fore, expected and sometimes realized. House philosophers certainly hold such virtues, or perhaps we should just call them habits; however, it is easy to see presumption infiltrate any School. Houses and Schools are quite different as concepts of institution. The latter's existence is manifest in the -ism and "one's philosophy" mentality. Forms of life center on or are outgrowths from a position on a singular claim. The presumption is that one, under a particular potential or putative School, has identified exactly those key concepts relevant to the perpetuation of a language game. One does not intend merely the continuation of a game, though it is a consequence, and this is what I focus on. I do not doubt that key concepts play a pivotal role in proper communication and cognition. What is my concern is that pieces of language capture just those key concepts in just the way that gets one to the kernel of a language game. There is no "center" to a language game; "key concept," or "capital concept," is similar to the king in chess.

The village, every evening slumbers uniformly, With simultaneity each woman, child, man -- Each flame, transaction, pathway, picture, spirit Dream of the ethereal and the Other, order And avalanche underflow the climate of night Only through the space of visceral unwaking-- A chaotic carrying on carries on beneath The covers of eyelids and an unsettling proximity To death --
Passions govern grievances and the transubstantiation Of wares into wars; traders tumble tragically together In this world of commerce and rationality; Children chant mechanically beautiful artifacts passing through Their hollowed cores, laying voice as labor, bit by bit On the essence of an edifice whose basic need is nothing More than their eternal unrequite: a sleeper's refusal Fall quietly unto the pillows of return

item.title: Remarks on HTML 5
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Source material: http://xhtml.com/en/future/x-html-5-versus-xhtml-2/#x5-uncool-sectioning http://www.w3schools.com/tags/html5.asp http://nettuts.s3.amazonaws.com/373_html5/final/index.html Over the next few posts, I will provide commentary, derived from my experience in learning and analyzing HTML 5, to its specification, the language itself, and recent developers' interpretations of HTML 5 along with their practices and executions on their own interpretations.

The politics

The W3C has pushed XHTML 2.0 to the side, where in its stead they have adopted WHATWG's HTML 5 as the markup language on which they will continue their work and development toward a future, deliverable HTML specification.

XHTML 2.0's development aimed at being a strictly normative specification as to how markup ought to be developed for Web applications and Web sites. The W3C's Recommendation of XHTML 2.0, were it to have been continued, would have been completely normative in that its development is not at all a reflection of current development practices which involve (X)HTML(what developers are currently doing out "in the field" under Web application projects, Web sites, etc). (X)HTML 5 more so mirror's current trends in development through HTML.

A new anatomy

First, an outline of the tags introduced with HTML 5. I will offer comment of, and raise question to, their purpose, meaning, function, etc.
<section>
Purpose: Demarcation at the layout level. Design-oriented. A section is an aspect of a Web page or Web site. The section, therefore, is more meaningful to the reader. So, the section has, or it must have, a greater semantic value than the division tag. Semantic: This tag is not equivalent to div tag. Function: Functionally, it is similar to the div both DOM-wise and attribute-wise. However, as seen in its Purpose, the section tag's function, though it can be accomplished by the div tag all the same, goes semantically beyond that for which the div tag is intended. The div tag is merely a structural division. A section tag is a division in the design concept. For instance, in XHTML 1.0 or HTML 4, we may use a div tag to separate the content and the form on a blog entry. However, these are properly sections of the entire blog entry page. To the page's design concept, these are divisions. div tags alone identify structural divisions in the document.
<header>
...
<aside>
...
<canvas>
...
<footer>
...
<nav>
...

item.title: Markup Naming Conventions
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I've committed much thinking over the past few days over what I call the dilemma of naming conventions.
It is a problematic in that the Web is generally a hostile environment to develop in. The issue is similar to development under JavaScript. Whereas the expected client-side domain is subject to the flux of the browser market, where at base the core set of popular Web browsers ground that domain, for Web developers, or "front-end engineers," the expected domain for naming conventions is grounded by the onslaught of recent (Web) resource description languages (eRDF, RDFa, Microformats, vCard, etc.) or ontological idioms (OWL, etc.).
What is demanded, then, of a Web developer is forward-thought as to how her own Web project will integrate with pre-existing and future ontological-linguistic paradigms. Depending on the incorporation of this linguistic models by search engines (Google, Bing, etc), a Web project may literally define itself outside of the parameters of search engine algorithms. Sure, at bottom, we've got primitive linguistic paradigms on which these algorithms work, but I can easily imagine meta-data as becoming that channel through which search engine algorithms derive their about-ness of a Website.
The crux of the problem that forced search engines to diminish authority of (meta-)keywords was abuse. The solution came from the assumption that the content itself implies a truer statement of the general nature of its whole (the Website). With these ontological-descriptive languages, we seem to revisit the spirit of the keywords approach; however, we approach things a bit differently. Semantic weight is distributed more evenly throughout the page or document (or Website). And this, I presume, factors into pre-existing natural language inference algorithms.
That's fine. But Web developers are left with the task of devising naming schemes on which to future-proof their projects. These new linguistic models impose requirements which one meets or fails to meet in virtue of their producing a naming convention more or less harmonious which those requirements. In one sense, we're being told how to think about our Web projects. In one way, it's beneficial for the sake of universal simplicity, but at the cost of potential creativity.
Sure, one may not think it very worthwhile to wax creative about what to call a street address or a telephone number. I doubt recommend that one go against well-established traditions, however accurate. These resource description approaches, in one way, merely mirror those traditions. And even then, this is quite a different battle.
What about structural semantics?
Are you very committed to what may be called a sidebar or a navigation block?

item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: 1 Any language L will, as a successful theory of truth must flesh out, consist of syntactic, semantic and pragmatic structures. 1.1 To take the usual route, I will begin will syntax. I would not like to think syntax is so straight-forward, for it is exactly the mapping of meaning to the sentences of L which should no easily bring difficulty to all co-related theories. 2 Of a syntactic structure extant are marks for arrangement which provide a sensible component to that language. Although, it is not necessary that the language in question must needs a written mode of expression. Propositions, that is, can be expressed phonetically only within L; this should be common knowledge. 2.1 L may contain symbols as its constituents when and only when marks are arranged in such a fashion as to demarcate one set of symbols (or an unitary set) from another set of symbols. Symbols for L are complexes of marks, but symbols themselves will be complex simples; thus, a symbol for L cannot be broken down into its constituent marks so as to presuppose a meaning for the marks which compose a meaning for the symbol so composed. Principle of Non-recursive Deconstruction [of Symbols]. 2.2 Symbols may become Words (as principle dependent upon the Pragmatic structure): Words will simply be symbols that are recognizable by language speakers of L. The vocabulary of L is an ontology of symbols which are "easily cognizable" to the set of all speakers of L. 2.21 The quantity of speakers is important: "Speakers of L" presupposes that no private language is possible, which is an axiom of this system. It seems that to use "speakers of" at all presupposes that the speakers speak to each other with some degree of intelligibility and success. Though, we can say that "intelligibility" and "success of communication" are properties that independently describe L from an observer's reference. Suppose 2 speakers of L: a word for the mutual speakers will be an arbitrary agreement to a set of marks (or a symbol) that poses no obvious loss or gain. 2.211 "Lose or gain" suggests that the agreement is founded on a principle, although rarely obvious to the speakers of L. We do not have to construe this "agreement" as positive or negative in consequences to the speakers of L. Thus, it is not necessary to suggest that the speakers of L consciously agree to symbols on a regular basis so as to bolster warm relations between them. Further, no degree of "trust" is required in "agreeing to a name" for words such as "tree," "mountain," "food," etc. Words do not carry with them a meaning, but the meaning is manifest in the agreement. This "meaning" of a word depends on its accidental explicit expression within a proposition. 2.3 An account for "proposition" is in due course, but for our focus on syntactic structure, a proposition can take on its usual role of at least being immaterial in the sense that tangible objects (sequences of marks and symbols, to be clear) express them. The proposition is the sense which can be expressed all the same through any arbitrary set of sequences of marks and symbols. 3 Semantic 3.1 Let us accept semantic holism but deal first with the traditional dilemmas which are manifest in postulating it. 3.2 We first ask such questions of L: Is L finite or infinite? what exactly does this mean? does L consist of an infinity of syntactic objects (this is self-evidently absurd)? but what of meanings--can meanings exist which are "in-themselves," as it were? that is, are there meanings expressed independently of sentential functions which express them? who would express them? But the assumption is that L is finite in syntactic objects at time t; further, multiple sentential functions can be mapped to a sense in order to express it. Two sentences can express the same sense: "a new sun", "the rising sun is here", etc. 4 Pragmatic

item.title: Spindle Scare
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Trey introduced me to the spindle cell and we elucidate for ourselves the notion of non-disadvantage features/mutations. Disadvantageous features will be weeded out by natural selection and advantageous features will increase the adaptability of the population which in turn increases that population's probability of passing on its genes for future generations. Speciation is a by-product of this process. A species is, more or less, a snapshot of the microstructural fixed state of the species (at the species level) at some arbitrary point in time. However, non-disadvantageous mutations will not necessarily "fall out" of the process. Imagine a neutral feature of a species that plays (approximately) no role in its species-survival, yet nevertheless this mutational feature gets passed on. This is where spindle cells, as is purported, come in. They are meant to account for our higher level emotions which are apparently not necessary for our species survival. In contrast to apes, etc., these spindle cells exist in a higher quantity within us than our nearest kin (at the species level). Do these apes not express higher level emotions? Are these emotions irrelevant to survival?

item.title: Belief Puzzle Redux
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Pierre is a monolingual French speaker. Some particular story accounts for how he got the belief that London is pretty. He would sincerely assent to the claim that "Londres est jolie." Thus, by Kripke's disquotation principle and translation principle, we conclude that Pierre believes that London is pretty. Not-so-however, Pierre lands smack in the middle of London. He picks up a phone and says to a friend back at home, "Londres est jolie."

item.title: Kripke a la Kripke a la
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Pierre croit que Londres est jolie.
(T)ranslation: If S expresses a truth in L, then an adequate translation of S as S' in L also expresses a truth.
Possible translations:
(1) Peter believes London is pretty. (2) Pierre believes London is pretty. (3) Peter believes Londres is pretty. (4) Pierre believes Londres is pretty.
(1) and (3) are "strict" or "strong" interpretations of (T). I make this point because it seems plausible to concern ourselves with the logical status of the two names used within the proposition. What would be our justification for translating "Londres" but not "Pierre"? Naturally, we say that though Pierre's name may change, he (in any of his features other than his name) does not. In translating "Londres," none of its features change either. (It's still the capital of England, it's still a city, and it's still pretty so far as Pierre/Peter is concerned.) So we can say (5) "Pierre believes L(english) is pretty" and (6) "Pierre croit que L(french) est jolie." Both (5) and (6) are true, regardless of their presentation in different language.
(D)isquotation: Ceteris paribus, if S sincerely assents to "p," then we may conclude that S believes that p.
Notice, however, that upon asking Pierre if he assents to p, we will drop the added "(language)" locution. It would not appear in our question, of course. Two facts are missing from Pierre's epistemic context: (i) he does not know "London" and "Londres" have the same referent and (ii) he does not know that "London" and "Londres" are translation equivalents; he has not stumbled onto a dictionary that would indirectly reveal fact (i). To suggest (ii) might be to suggest that we can ask something about the term which is a constituent of the statement p. Pierre is predicating of his referent, not predicating of the word itself.
Pierre lands in London, learns the language of the natives through immersion, and is found in the following situation. Pierre comes to learn that London is a pretty ugly place. He's disposed to utter, "London is not pretty." He could say it in the French and in the English.
(7) Pierre believes London is not pretty. (8) Pierre croit que Londres n'est pas jolie.
The "Jen Solution" requires that (7) and (8) would accurately describe Pierre. (9) and (10) would present a problem.
(9) Pierre does not believe London is pretty. (10) Pierre ne croit pas que Londres est jolie.
(9) and (10) have "wide scope" while (7) and (8) have "narrow scope." (9) and (10) bind the variable L within the scope of "believes".

item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Claim: An artificially intelligent agent could satisfy those same conditions under which we ascribe (R)ationality, (W)ill (as freedom of action), (R)responsibility, strong (A)ccountability, (M)oral intelligence and (G)eneral intelligence. Premise: Each of these properties, which function as description of a human being, or set of human beings, can only be, or necessarily are, applied within some public context. This premise rules out situations, or experiments, in which a one-to-one correspondence between AI-agent and human-agent give us any legitimate conclusion to make about the nature of the AI-agent. It seems unfair to base our final judgment on an experiment involving isolated use of language. For instance, the Chinese room argument proposed by Searle has us look at a "free environment," where no restriction on the goal of discourse is given. In effect, the AI-agent and the human-agent are given no topic, or guideline to follow. These agents are simply given language as such, and the end set before them is absent. What relevantly follows, I think, is that the AI-agent cannot engage in "small talk." With public context, I believe, comes a more immediate consequence of the talk exchange: public context presupposes a potential connection with other contexts.

item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Pierre believes London is pretty. Expanded Fregean Form: There is some, or at least one, mode of presentation under which Pierre believes London is pretty. Does this answer the question: Does Pierre believe London is pretty? Does "London" refer to the actual city of London, or does it refer to the object of the mode of presentation? Do modes of presentation have objects? Do names refer to objects in the world or objects contained within modes of presentation? Event1 and Event2 will contain different modes of presentation occurring at temporal points very close in proximity. When a Subject utters something about an object involved in Event1 at Event2 will that Subject be referring to the object itself or the object of the mode of presentation "kept" or "transferred" into the following event? More straightforwardly: There is "some mode of presentation" under which Pierre believes London is pretty. Well, given any and all modes of presentation, does Pierre believe London is pretty? Can we ask this latter question? Is the former statement even usual for ascribing beliefs. We want to know the content of Pierre's belief, but we are told that it's possible that he believes London is pretty. We are not told exactly which mode of presentation, but that there is a mode of presentation. We could seek out that mode of presentation; we could ask of Pierre under which circumstances he came to believe that London is pretty. He may forget. What will we say, then? That Pierre believes London is pretty but the mode of presentation which gave us our evidence to support an existential generalization is now missing.

item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Footballer: "I am good at this sport." Basketballer: "I am good at this sport." Golfer: "I am good at this sport." The antecedent conditions for these utterances are different. Each person must complete a material set of tasks before she might utter each proposition. , , , ; each presupposes a use, but at hierarchically different levels. , preceded by and followed by , is rule-logically governed. Its meaning follows from the context under which the utterance is given. It's not simply the grammaticalness that must be obtained, but it is the representation to which is constitutive. [Mapping of word to world] "I am good with this sport" may work pragmatically equally as well; "I am good in this sport."
