item.title: But not a budding Poststructuralist
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: I need to sack this trenchant tendency to claim language as bearing some deified status. The structures of marking, sign, symbol, sequence, variables bring me no avail unless I study them more rigorously, but already I feel the pre-theoretical conditions to which this Language "practices" its will are conditions which cannot possibly be so controlled and wrangled to the extent I misleadingly suggest to myself. Presuppositions abound as to the nature of symbol insofar as its capacity to enforce this or that ideological proposition. To which proposition are we indebted now? I can hardly shape a semantico-metaphysical monster to which I am in opposition anymore. It seems the hard-won dollar is our biggest enemy, and to no sentience am I aware to scrounge up the demon behind that desire for the profit motive. The profit motive appears, as far as I can see, appears to be just that simple: a motive for profit. There is no narrative (grand or otherwise). Where is the evidence for it? I see simple folks engage in simple activities and make simple mistakes. We jump quickly to the curious, "big" mistakes as if they hunt down big numbers ($700 billion). item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: The broadest split in ethical theories assumes that moral statements or propositions are to be viewed as either cognitive or noncognitive. A cognitive statement is that kind of statement which is said to be, in the least, meaningful or to be, in a stricter and empirical sense, subject to truth-functionality. In this way, moral propositions are thought to be synthetic propositions. Analytic truths are by no means about the world in the way a moral claim is purported to be about the world. Indeed, given the nature of analytic truths, it would be plain to all of their truth, if any one of them happens to be true, but it is quite difficult, I think, for anyone to produce a non-trivial moral claim that is accepted by every rational being. We shall touch on the trivial versus the non-trivial moral proposition, or claim, later, as it will be important to see that “trivial moral propositions” are indeed nothing more than analytic statements. Therefore, they should be treated as such, despite the belief of the speaker so uttering that (trivial) moral proposition. But back to our dichotomy between the cognitively meaningful and the noncognitive. A meaningful statement is that kind of statement which either (1) is thinkable within the cognitive framework of a rational agent or (2) expresses a proposition. Naturally, the noncognitivist must then hold negative views with respect to the cognitivist about moral propositions (or moral language). The noncognitivist will hold that a moral proposition either (1a) is not thinkable within the cognitive framework of a rational agent or (2a) does not express a proposition. Of course, we now have to ask the questions: What does it mean to be thinkable? What is, if anything, a proposition, let alone a moral one? “Thinking,” in this sense, refers to that capacity to entertain a thought, a faculty which a rational agent must possess. Examples are usually given to disclose what is and what is not thinkable. Surely, the proposition which states that (1) the shoe is inside the box is thinkable. To consider it, one merely needs to conceive (or imagine), roughly, a shoe and a box, to understand the preposition (which presupposes an understanding of spatial relation), the copula, the article used twice. The whole of the sentence is thinkable without much effort. But further, given that moral statements are thought to be subject to truth-functionality, we should use this example to highlight just what that means. Without question, it will be true of the situation so described if the shoe is in fact inside the box. If the shoe is not inside the box, then, accordingly, the claim that it is will be deemed false. (1) is a synthetic proposition, of course, because nowhere therein the definition of the terms so used will one find the presence of a contrasting term (found within the sentence). Like so, one will not discover that “shoe,” insofar as its definition goes, involves “boxes” or grammatical constructs. Now, the question is: Do moral propositions, if cognitive, resemble the outline of meaningfulness and truth-functionality that I have just given? Meaningfulness, so far as the charged is raised against the logical positivist, is a multifaceted term. It is as amorphous as, perhaps, poetry. As a concept, it is subject to the whims of the language-game. It is claimed that though I have rambled on about synthetic-this and truth-that, I, and any alike in my thinking, will be forever subject to the whirlpool of equivocality. When I lasso “meaning” down to a set of principles or statements, I have somehow pushed aside the tongues of common folk as illiterate and daft. Or, as a lesser criticism, I have simply ignored the “true essence” of the concept. Meaning is often, in this “true” sense, taken to mean something like “purpose” or has more to do with the agenda of the existentialists. Perhaps all that I have said in no way undermines their doctrine. But surely “meaning” must be grounded, whether it be “science” or the latest cultural trend is no concern of mine My project simply is to spell out the logical structure of the term so given and how it applies to ethical theories. If one thinks, then, that “meaning” is a forever unattainable linguistic object, lost to us except in our non-linguistic maneuvers, then my only possible counter, I think, could be to cry defeatism or to perhaps ask How is it that you now dictate the “true essence” of the term? Because surely if my opponent wishes to persuade me, this person will indeed need to put words to the definition of meaningful. But if “meaning” is something we do rather than say, then clearly my opponent has cast the term out of discourse. And I fail to imagine any argument that might be justified in leaning to this semantic vacuum. I render this caveat for a more personal purpose. I think an implicit psychological tendency we as human beings bears is to make this distinction between doing and saying. We may look back, as it were, at our behavior or response with respect to a proposition, then consider it natural to assume that the proposition itself is prima facie meaningful and thus not in need of a skeptical attitude. This occurs with respect to the majority of the propositions we encounter in daily living. It makes natural to consider God does so-and-so and the shoe is in the box as residing on the same logical foundations. However, the latter presupposes much less than the former. What follows is that we act on basis of both propositions, though they undoubtedly bear different logical infrastructures, in such a way that affirms their meaningfulness. We carry on in reacting to the proposition as if it were a meaningful one, satisfying the thinkability criterion and the truth-functional criterion. But surely, as many religious persons must admit, thought does not always follow claims about God’s going-ons. What usually transpires is an easy acceptance of that statement so uttered which involves the term “God” so to move along within the talk exchange or conversation. Indeed, in our daily linguistic moves, we “get” the “meaning” before or almost at the same time our pundit, preacher or patron does. In effect, behaving in a certain way gives one the illusion that what one has been dealt linguistically must have been meaningful in the sense I have outlined. But surely acting first and “remembering” the cognitive nature, if any, of a proposition does not entail that the proposition was in fact cognitive. Of course, many statements made in the context of errands and religious ceremony presuppose an array of implicit knowledge. Naturally, if one is religious and she stumbles into an atheist, a sort of grounding is demanded, namely a grounding, or equalization, of knowledge. To be more explicit: the atheist and the noncognitivist will be wary of special pleading. Most, if not all, propositions presuppose some background of knowledge, a set of thinkable and perhaps more basic truths about the world. That some of us have access to this knowledge is no guarantee for the truth-functional aspect of the moral proposition. At this point, we can see that I admit the sort of willy-nilly “meaning” the existentialist argues for. We can all carry on as if we have understood what we have just been told, and the teller, of course, will likely interpret our action, so long as it is more or less positive and congenial with respect to her general “meaning” (regardless of the literal function of the sentence or set of sentences and their entailments), in such a way that affirms to her that her propositions we “in fact” meaningful. But, as said, this aspect of meaning perhaps crudely satisfies the concept of meaningfulness to which I and the logical positivist spirit accept. I need not argue it too much because, nevertheless, truth is not at all brought into the picture of acting and speaking. Implicature is prevalent in this domain of “meaning” and approximate interpretations govern the discourse. And perhaps this is all the meaning there is to be had: meaning as use within a language game. But now we must ask, where does “truth” enter? Truth surely plays a significant role in (1), but what of the class of purported “moral propositions”? Unless this question is addressed, I can feel only a creeping nihilism, as I too often do, about the basis of all rationality. With this “meaning as use” notion, perhaps one can easily picture the world as a deterministic system of cause and effect, fully describable in mechanistic terms. Perhaps I step too boldly to equate nihilism and determinism… And this is easy to do, given that determinism itself is not a theory about the world. But enough of this digression. We have, with hope, touched more than enough on meaning. Now, we may touch on truth. It has been contended by the verificationists that propositions ought to be considered true, and thus meaningful, if and only if it is reducible to some experience which may verify it. The weaker verificationist line of thought took a proposition to be meaningful if and only if it was possible to translate that proposition into some experience or set of experiences, so as to verify it. The former demands that a proposition fit into the scheme of experiential understanding while the latter demands that a proposition fit into the scheme of potential, possible or future experiential understanding. To be able at all to verify a proposition, for the latter, implies its meaningfulness. Verification involves the concept of truth-functionality. What the verificationist uses as a standard for determining truth-value (the true or the false) is the definitional and the observational. A proposition may be true by definition or true if it corresponds to some observed event. (For me, events involve the objects. The objects themselves are irrelevant. They only make sense in terms of the event, which is the key object of science and observation.) With this said, we see that the shoe and the box are really meaningless terms on their own. The proposition is a claim about an event, namely the shoe and the box being related in such-and-such a way. I apply this line of thinking to subject-predicate or function-argument systems as well. “Susan is X” is a proposition that claims something about an event, namely an event which involves the subject, argument, object, whatever, “Susan” and the speaker’s understanding of the concept “X”. The proposition is true if the event is satisfied in the way intended by the speaker. Intentionality can be set aside for later. To say the least about intentionality, the way I use “intend” in this example involves something like “within an ascertainable context of time.” What might occupy “X” in this case will always shift the intentionality of the speaker, so as to make the concept “fit.” Surely, if “X” is satisfied with “happy,” it would be a stretch for us to believe that the speaker is claiming that Susan is happy all the time, indeterminately, etc. But we need not go too far into this. I surmise that this is already sufficiently understood that concepts presuppose more basic constraints or context in general. At this point, it seems fitting to introduce the noncognitivist.

item.title: A New Game
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: I've got a new pseudo-philosophical pastime. Let's call it Anthropocentric Metaphor! Yea! The rules follow as the name suggests, and you may already be playing it as you live at this very moment! But let's be more forthcoming in our play. Think of your own (1) reason for or (2) explanation of: (a) The beginning of the Universe or (b) The nature of God and other like deities without appealing to anthropcentrism or lost metaphor. Once you do, you've lost!

item.title: Ethics Notes, 01-28-2008
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Epictetus Law of Power Minor Premise - There exist free things in nature. Minor Premise - There exist bounded things in nature. Major Assumption - There are two aspects to nature: a free aspect and a bounded aspect. This would be a argument for duality in nature. It is an assignment of natures to potential ontological objects; either an objects status is free or it is unfree. There can be no middle ground. The assumption is that nature expresses itself in two distinguishable ways. 1 "The things that are up to us are by nature free, unhindered, and unimpeded; the things that are not up to us are weak, enslaved, hindered, not our own." Defined here is a Law of Power which distinguishes not what specifically is free and is not free in the world, but the duality between what could be free and those opposite entities in reality. Epictetus sets at odds all things at the outset by their ontological status in so far as freedom, but not the potential for freedom. Anything which is not free, for Epictetus, is enslaved in principle and forever subject to the whims and power of another, whatever that other power may be. The chains of impedance never unshackle from things which are "not ones own." The underlining assumption here is that theoretically there is at least one entity or thing in the world which is free to which this principle of freedom applies. 2 "And if it is about one of the things that is not up to us, be ready to say, "You are nothing in relation to me." It is believed that all things flowing within the domain of the enslaved and definitely determined exist outside of us in a sense unrelated to ourselves. But keep in mind that this is a method to achieve complacency and comfort when you find yourself at odds with the external world. Why should the same principle not apply to harmonious and agreeable things? We'll get to that. He applies this principle of aversion by proposing that we be averse only to those things that are abhorred by nature or the nature of things. However, we must presuppose first that the nature of a thing involves aversion of certain other things. How can we justify this? Furthermore, the principle of aversion describes relationships that are inherently negative between entities, but how do we explain this that are beneficial to the achievement of desired things? At what point does a desire for a thing become an innate property of any entity? Is the faculty of desire defined by the things which are desired or is it defined by the principle capability to desire? (a) If the former, then aversion and benefit are just as arbitrary as the things desired, for they are for which we desire--but aside from being unable to truly determine their benefit--they are outside of us, outside of being "up to us." Things desired at not significant because we desire them; they must be significant for some other reason, if we wish to follow this principle of determinism. We do not freely choose what we are averse to or what we enjoy or find benefit from. (b) If the latter, then we must explain how this faculty of desiring is justified: Are those things which we desire beneficial and Good merely because we desire them? It remains to be explained how this faculty of desire relates to external entities. Their ontological relation to our desire, is the meat of the problem.

"I adhere to the Socratic vision that philosophy should be premised on an encounter, preferably in public spaces, involving exchange and dialogue, and hopefully in such a way as to irritate the priests and the statesmen. Following Spinoza, Deleuze, and Badiou, I agree that the dream of philosophy since its inception with Thales is immanence, or the idea that we need not refer beyond the world or to special authorities to explain what is and value, and with Socrates that what matters is what is said, not who says it. Philosophical claims are claims that should be addressed to all, regardless of identity, nation, gender, religion, etc., or should be truly kosmopolitan claims premised on a subject that is void of its identifications. Following Lucretius, I hold that philosophy seeks to escape superstition and ideology. Philosophy seeks the conceptual technologies through discourse which might complete this dream. " - Sinthome http://larval-subjects.blogspot.com/

item.title: Intuition & Intention
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: 1 An ostensible action C will be made due to intuition, or by intention, A or B. 1.1 By any empirical verification, the contents of A or B—whether intuition or intention—are closed to that method of verification. That is, that "for which" the action C came about cannot be absolutely determined if the action came about from intuition or intention. 1.2 Intention cannot describe the state of feeling of a human being because the intention must be interpreted. 1.3 Intuition cannot describe the state of feeling of a human being because the intuition is not inferred by any object so observed. 1.31 The object would be historical; and thus, possibly observable. But by the nature of an "intutive knowledge" or intuitive action, the action would come about as disassociated from the given object. 1.32 Is intuition produced from the lack of consciousness or awareness of objects within one's own memory? Is intuition a mythical device?

item.title: Biography & Works by Benedict (Bento; Baruch) de Spinoza
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Biography Bento Spinoza was a child of the Dutch Enlightenment, also referred to as the Dutch Republic's "Golden Age." I refer to it as the Dutch Enlightenment because Amsterdam, rolling into the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries, as a European body, highlighted the origins & economic & intellectual flourishing of the larger European Enlightenment of the eighteenth-century. Thinkers such as Descartes and Spinoza, though members of what philosophers academically dub the "Age of Reason", champion the foundational ideology of the eighteenth-century Enlightenment. Indeed, they were the framers of said ideology, fostering for subsequent thinkers a systematized, rationalistic approach to the sciences and substantial argumentation for religious freedom, among other notable achievements. But I digress. "Bento", as his family called him, went by "Baruch" when speaking with elder Rabbis & fellow classmates at Hebrew school & synagogue, & sported "Benedict", following his cherem, or writ of excommunication, as he romped with the intellectual Christians of the day. He was around 24 at the day of castration of his Jewish credibility. To his community, he had become an invalid, if not despised & distrusted. But what exactly had he done to warrant such a punishment? The most likely explanation his immediate & later biographers can infer consists of his generally disturbing utterances of "abominable heresies" and "heretical deeds." More specifically, as it has been noted by [bluh], he pronounced doctrines which denied immortality of the soul, the existence of angels, and asserted the corporeality of the divine nature, i.e. God. Whatever it was exactly, Spinoza found what can be easily described as relief. As his blasphemous utterances actualized his separation from Jewish orthodoxy with official & public notoriety, his response to the hearing of his banishment was, humorously, his own absence. He had no qualms with the results of his actions, and he was out the door of his Jewish community without note. Short Treatise on God, Man and His Well-Being; 1660 ... On the Improvement of the Understanding; 1662 (unfinished) ... Principles of Cartesian Philosophy with Metaphysical Thoughts; 1663 Along with being an ecclesiastic authority on Hebrew & Christian history, theology, & culture, Spinoza was an acknowledged & well-respected expositor of Cartesian philosophy. Arguably so, his strength of adherence to Cartesian principles was greater and more consistent than Decartes' himself. A Theological-Political Treatise (Tractatus Theologico-Politicus); 1670 ... A Political Treatise (Tractatus Politicus); 1675-1676 (unfinished) ... The Ethics, Demonstrated in Geometrical Order (Ethica Ordine Geometrico Demonstrata); 1677 ... Hebrew Grammar; 1677 ... http://www.drury.edu/ess/history/modern/spinoza.html

item.title: I Got Aristotle'd & the Rules of Reasoning
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
You know how it goes; it went that way throughout the entire Scholastic heyday. Aristotle Says arguments were possibly the most ubiquitous quasi de jure arguments which surmounted any possibility of intellectual heterodoxy.
Peripatetic: "Aristotle Says: The Earth is the center of the Universe." Galileo: "That's an appeal to authority; furthermore, did he even perform the experiments which lead him to that conclusion? Did you? Your logical fallacies are maddening!" Peripatetic: "Well, Aristotle invented logic, so: Aristotle Says!"
This sums up about the climate of the Medieval Philosophic period in so far as "novel" thought is concerned; very slow to change. Principium Identitatis That is, the Law of Identity, commonly & mistakenly attributed to Aristotle, may have been explicitly invented during the Middle Ages or much, much later.1 Anyway, I've been carrying on (philosophizing) with the belief that Aristotle actually introduced the Law of Identity. The law states that a thing: (1) is the totality of itself; (2) is the same as itself; (3) involves itself; (4) is in itself or of itself; (5) entails itself (which I take to mean it logically is equivalent to itself); (6) is a proposition that is equivalent to that exact same proposition; There are many ways of interpreting the law, and its interpretations do convey a different meaning, depending on the context of the presented argument. Briefly and symbolically, it states: (7) A ≡ A (8) A ∴ A (that is, assume A; therefore, A, or A follows from A) Prove It! Well, here's one way: 1 A (premise) 2 -A (prov. assum.) 3 A&-A (1,2 conj. intro.) 4 A (2-3 raa) Another way: 1 A (premise) 2 A (prov. assum.) 3 A (1 reit) 4 A ⊃ A (2-3 cond. proof) 5 A (4,1 modus ponens) Thoughts What this means is that if you do in fact have a thing, i.e. that it is true; its truth-value assignment is "true"; it is empirically verified; it cannot be "false", the negation of that thing will lead to a contradiction or an absurdity. For instance, you do in fact have a cat that is orange. The negation of the proposition "I have an orange cat" will inevitably lead to a contradiction because, well, something had to leave orange fur on your sofa! Or, more strictly, as the previous case could be attributed to the likelihood that an orange dog broke into your home, you are now holding an orange cat in your arms. So the law of identity is strict, and as its scope for individuals, the law pertains only to the individual. It holds as a proposition which only has say about itself, and contrary evidence does not infiltrate the logical form of the concept or thing involved. The logical form of the individual does not involve evidence outside of it; if it did, then that evidence would in fact no be contrary to the logical form of the individual unless that contrary evidence shared the same nature to that which it is contrary to. An orange cat cannot have the color-property of green and orange; there could be a blend between the two, but then, you would have to admit that the cat was never orange. It was another color. Properties have contrary natures lead to gradations of their contrasts to produce a new property which, in fact, is an actual property of the thing in question. Law of Noncontradiction Introduced by Aristotle, the popular statement of the law reads,
It is impossible for the same thing to belong and not to belong at the same time to the same thing and in the same respect. —Metaphysics IV 3 1005b19–20; Aristotle
This statement applies to the "ontological" form. There are a total of three forms which were expressed by Aristotle. The three forms are listed as follows. (1) Ontological — Stated above. (2) Doxastic — "It is impossible to hold (suppose) the same thing to be and not to be" ( Metaphysics IV 3 1005b24 cf.1005b29–30). (3) Semantic — "opposite assertions cannot be true at the same time" ( Metaphysics IV 6 1011b13–20). D1: By contradictory propositions, I understand a pair of propositions which cannot both be true, and cannot both be false; e.g. "I am drinking water" & "I am not drinking water". That is, the truth of both propositions, for the subject ("I"), cannot co-exist. Further, the propositions "[It is false that] I am drinking water" & "[It is false that] I am not drinking water" cannot co-exist; the latter claims that I am drinking water while the former claims that I am not. D2: By contrary propositions, I understand a pair of propositions which cannot both be true, but can both be false; e.g. "That cat is orange" & "That (same) cat is blue" cannot both be true. But, as said, the latter stipulation of the definition maintains because the cat very well could be pink (to me). D3: By subcontrary propositions, I understand a pair of propositions which cannot both be false, but can both be true; e.g. "That person is male" & "That (same) person is female" cannot both be false together. The person must have a "gender"; so, we could say the person is transgender. Do subcontraries force linguistic invention? Law of the Excluded Middle Law of Bivalence List the laws of thought! Infinity!
1 Aristotle's Law of Identity

item.title: A Normative Theory of Power
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: 1 The object of any normative theory in ethics is the attainment of a universal code whereby all persons, whatever their intellectual constitution, can live by without committing harm—mental or physical, intentional or not—to constituents living within the same social context. An always looming question: What is the context? 2 An apparent problem with producing a normative theory is keeping sight of the future and that of calculating the scope of responsibility. The unapparent solution begins at basing our normative ethical claims upon what we understand of human psychology and neuroscience. 3 Beginning at the observation of "ends" of nature, where humanity is but an ontological constituent, is nothing but a pursuit for chimaeras, which I cannot consent to existing anywhere but in the consciousness lag of the human psyche. This lag exists with respect to our instructed edifying principles which we cannot help but feel that they stand firmly and resolutely in the safety of our memory. Whether they are there or not is not my concern with this point, but it is our natural consciousness of them. 4 Our actions move us to those "ends" we perceive, and we attempt to rationalize them, nevertheless, as absolutely following harmoniously from the statues of our well-constructed intellects. But truly, I declare, we could not be further than the truth of the matter of perceiving ourselves as acting in the ways in which we prescribe through written document and pen. 5 How far are we from acting in accordance with our "mental statues"; and how close to we come to engaging in whatever discourse as intellectuals coursing the world atop savage, inhumane beasts. 6 Human nature, as if it were two words not signifying one meaning, becomes internally detached and inconstant: the scapegoat for our flaws becomes nature, and the humanity we praise becomes king. We become the students of the academic tradition that studies humans in nature rather than humans as nature. 7 The primary truth is that what we know best of nature must necessarily be factored into how we claim be must necessarily be "human." Systems of morality which feign to establish truths notwithstanding close inspection of the constitution of humanity qua nature—without explaining humanity as such from that humble root—I say must be burned, books dashed and smashed to the ground. What use have we for the "virtues" of the Peripatetics or the alien duties of the deontologists? And the "goods" of the ulilitarians are, as said, nothing but fictions which cannot exist in nature. Pragmatists gather 'round and do not give us the illusion of right by statistics, as if statistical understanding were not the determinant of the cause of those very statistics you claim to have weight. And who but us will understand the cause of movement? Who but a human will interpret for this or that political party or end? You, pragmatists and utilitarians, have paraded in circles around your conclusions, never establishing anything but truisms which help no one. 8 The theory begins with nature; and humanity's presence and prescription cannot be explained by any means except through humanity's congruity and concordance with nature.

Encapsulation Certain information is precluded from usage under certain modules or "modes" of usage. Modularity Composed of parts which correspond each other's so intended description to serve a unified purpose. Polymorphism Allows you to treat derived members of a set the same as you treat that same set's own members. Inheritance Produce derived sets based on higher level sets, in which one is allowed to treat the attributes of those higher level sets within the derived set. item.title: Critiques of Utilitarianism
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Utilitarianism Actions should seek to obtain the greatest good for the greatest number. Immediately we can ask, "Well, who decides the 'goods'?" Of course, what is most pleasing to the greatest number is the answer. So the prediction of consequences must assume within its theoretical endeavor that peoples' opinions inasmuch as the 'good' is sufficiently understood. Premises: goods are calculable Critiques The criterion for applying a utilitarian outlook cannot itself be utilitarian unless all competing theories are shown not to achieve the greatest good for the greatest number. Further, utilitarian calculus cannot sufficiently judge the greatest good of non-calculable qualities of lesser or greater potential.

item.title: A Weird Gettier
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Human #1: "There's a little Jiff in the cabinet." Human #2: "Oh, yeah. I see it." [grabs the mini-Jiff peanut butter container] Human #2: [opens it and sees that it's almost empty] We say... Knowledge for #1 based on the "small container" interpretation. Not knowledge for #1 based on the "almost empty" interpretation. #1 says... Not considered for #1 based on the "small container" interpretation. Knowledge for #1 based on the "almost empty" interpretation. #2 says... Knowledge for #1 based on the "small container" interpretation. Not knowledge for #1 based on the "almost empty" interpretation if and only if #1 says "I did not know that"; vice versa if and only if #1 says "That's what I meant."

item.title: A Treatise on Opinion
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: 1 That the opinion is ubiquitous in communicative discourse is a question of little interest. Our object should not be to found a method by which the special locations in dialogue where the opinion might manifest can be more easily exposed. Thus, a practical assumption for our purposes will be that the opinion, whatever it may be, is present everywhere linguistically, first, and semantically second. However, the common preconceptions that haunt the opinion's ontological nature will be of interest to us, so as to strip it of unclarity and that we might view it essentially. That said, we might even question whether there is an ontological nature to such a concept as the opinion, and this will be one of our main objects: to find the "use" of the opinion in linguistic discourse and to determine sufficiently if the opinion extends beyond the struggle between meanings.

item.title: On Objective and Absolute Truth
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
1 Principles are a priori in so far as they do not bear temporal characteristics; i.e., principles are timeless. 1.1 Principles are modes of Nature by which in themselves they are never modified nor do they modify Nature. 1.2 In so far as timelessness is a virtue of Nature itself, a principle can be mistaken as Nature itself revealed. 1.3 Principles as timeless modes of Nature do not bear physical distinction but merely permeate the whole of Nature itself in so far as Nature can exist as any mode or all modes just the same. 2 In order to attain to objective truth, a methodology must be employed for a successful adventure! 2.1 The principle of induction and its phenomenological application procure a clear and processing base by which certain deductions of reality are made. 2.2 The principle of deduction can be attended to only by virtue of the principle of induction, and the principle of induction could not be attended to if not for the principle of deduction. 2.3 Inductions are made in so far as certain individual realities are viewed as distinct rather than illusory, and deductions are similarly made in so far as certain individual realities are viewed as distinct rather than illusory. 2.4 Inductions will
Principle of Deduction, Principle of Induction, Principle of Abduction, Principle of Reduction
Reality appears deductively or it is a truth which can only be deduced, but never induced in so far as its truth.

item.title: Is it "File Sharing" or is it "Thievery"?
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: -"sharing" with school yard analogy (material law versus copyright law versus internet law) -assumption that data does or does not inherently have a possessor -assumption that when data is given uniqueness, its arranger acquires possessive, material rights over that data (material law) -assumption that when data is given uniqueness, its arranger does not own the data itself but only the arrangement in which it is formed (copyright law) -thoughts on regulation of the internet if the assumption is that the data becomes possessed by the arranger;--to reconcile the fact that copyright laws are insufficient to enforce and ensure the end of illegally distributed data -thoughts on free internet if the assumption is that data is inherently free; thus, data is permitted to traverse even avenue of the Internet unimpeded -further, people only call it "stealing" [dysphemism] or "sharing" [euphemism] based on their predisposition or opinion

item.title: Philosophy and Suicide
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
The Universe exists; its antithesis is to not exist. Humans exist; their antithesis is death or to not exist. If free will were to be a reality, the only way it can be proven as such is for someone who debates the philosophical question of suicide to commit suicide purely from the argument. Because the only thing the Universe cannot do is cease to exist. Thus, for a person to have free will is to prove that non-existence is more valuable than existence. Which is to say, only a person can do what the Universe cannot. Thus, the only way to prove free will exists is to commit suicide. And the only "free" action that can be made is to end one's own existence.
"We will never find the truth."
And that is the whole point why the tradition of philosophy exists. To find the answer. When you say what you say; when anyone says, "there will never be an answer." It is a kind of awkward euphemism, that. Because it itself tries to pass off as a perverted answer which assumes exactly what is trying to be found [or is to never be found]. What is the concept of Truth being independent of the awareness of itself? Why would Truth be concealed from itself? Suicide necessarily and boldly brings truth to itself, "Be confronted by only that which can tame you." The answer is either within Truth or outside of it; but to claim that it is outside of it is to claim that Truth is dependent and not subsistent by its own means. There is an answer, but the quest is to found out whether it is existence or non-existence. We have to approach it as existing, because we do exist. In light of that,--and since non-existence isn't even a possible method or avenue to determine its truth--, we must necessarily find all the peculiarities of the path we seem necessitated to take.

item.title: Spinoza & the Abyss
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
To confront Spinozism, if one is consistently attentive to the plurality of opposing notions which afflict everyone's life in some form or another, is to, as Nietzsche put it with haunting succinctness, "gaze into the abyss."
Yet while those who shudder at the mere thought of an abyss, they find themselves easily falling prey to illusory happiness, never to truly face not their fear but their inadequacy. A far more disconcerting notion, for it humbles.
Following are those more reasoned—the championed atheistic—grounded by rationality but fickle by empiricism. To them, the abyss is there, but they bold it with nigh ignorance and courage—it is this courage that is produced by comparison of one's self to the strength of the gaze of the abyss. It must be assumed, quite foolishly, I feel, that there can even be what one may call a reaction from the abyss itself. In a certain and disturbing way, what must be realized is that the abyss is but a mirror, reflecting your empowered and burning gaze as a chilling and infinitely distant nothing.
How could Nietzsche come to such a conclusion if not for his understanding and confrontation of Spinoza's God--the God of the Abyss. Spinoza's God, in short, is the abyss itself.

item.title: "A Theologico-Political Treatise"
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Spinoza's Scriptural interpretation moves and inspires me! I will share some passages from his originally illicit yet seminal work of Biblical criticism, A Theologico-Political Treatise. On Obedience as Faith
[...] it follows that they are the true enemies of Christ who persecute honourable and justice-loving men because they differ from them, and do not uphold the same religious dogmas as themselves: for whosoever loves justice and charity we know, by that very fact, to be faithful: whosoever persecutes the faithful, is an enemy of Christ. [Definitions of Faith; Elwes, pp. 185]
Scriptural Basis: First John 2 3 And hereby we do know that we know him, if we keep his commandments. 4 He that saith, I know him, and keepeth not his commandments, is a liar, and the truth is not in him. What I Take Briefly, you know how liberal Christians today argue Christianity as "progressive" and generally good based on works of the religious constituency. Well, if this argument is to hold, the faith itself is obedience to producing good works. Spinoza argues "For obedience implies faith, and faith without works is dead" which is based on the Scripture. On Contradiction So you say the Bible has no contradiction. Well, under Spinoza's overarching thesis, that the Bible teaches (its sole purpose is to teach) obedience and faith and not reason and philosophy, it would be difficult not to find contradiction between the multitude of different authors (coming from different eras and cultures)! This contradiction is found in First Samuel against Jeremiah, both of which assume something of God which is, outside of the contradiction, nevertheless, unreasonable to suggest as pertaining to God or Nature. First Samuel 15: 29 The Glory of Israel neither retracts nor repents, for he is not man that he should repent. Jeremiah 18: 8 But if that nation which I have threatened turns from its evil, I also repent of the evil which I threatened to do. 9 Sometimes, again, I promise to build up and plant a nation or a kingdom. 10 But if that nation does what is evil in my eyes, refusing to obey my voice, I repent of the good with which I promised to bless it.

item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Stand down, sir! I do not feel our relationship as sufficiently matured to a point that would necessitate a discussion of my philosophical views proper. And of my faith, what has that to do with the aforementioned when it is by my works and deeds that I ought to be judged, and not by my ability to quibble over the nature of the absolutely infinite. It is the philosophers who contemplate divine things keenly and with much understanding while it is the theologian who speaks cleverly. But even those philosophers, the most learned of minds, can be found degrading the most esteemed faculty of humanity—the mind—with triviality and pettiness drenched in frustration and feuding. Of two non-philosophers such as ourselves sharing words of divine things,—not even in my nightmares could there be conjured a more harmful notion to the well-being of mankind.

item.title: Quality of a Good, Social Coercion, and Delusional Ethics
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: 1 Society A will say, "For this avenue or discourse, this is its good!"; Society Z will say, "For this avenue or discourse, this is its good!" 1.1 If the goods of either avenue or discourse of that society conflict, then they will enter into dialogue concerning those goods. 1.11 Dialogue can attempt to 2 People within A or B will tell themselves that good of an avenue or discourse is a legitimate good. For example, a coffee franchise, considered by those in A, produces a legitimate good. Why do they tell themselves this? Some will say it is not. Those who disagree with the legitimacy of that good will dissent. Should they do so, what is their alternative? Either repair the illegitimate good or replace the illegitimate good. If the people in support of that good see the good as a legitimate good, they will not observe re-structuring of that good. 3 If a dissenter says, "The quality of your good is poor because of its production or origin" but those in support of the perceived illegitimate good themselves perceive it as having great quality (the good as a result, not as a process), then the replacement of the good is not possible. How does the perceived illegitimate good reach a status of legitimacy and maintain it? Is it the good itself or the perception of it? 4 If the masses are persuaded that its resultant good is of great quality but its process is poor quality, what determines how they will make these observations with a certain prevalence. If the process does not satisfy them but the good itself does, why should they care for the process's quality? 5 If a poor process and an exceptional process can, in so far as the public perceives it, produce an acceptable good, then why should any person choose one process over the other? Can the claim "I only appreciate my products for how they satisfy me" justify any argument against the process of the good which satisfies. 6 Someone can both criticize the process and the good itself, but one cannot criticize a good in so far as someone appreciates it as a specific kind of pleasure through appeal to its process. If a good pleases someone, then how it came to be is of no importance. 7 A defense against the criticism of the process of product A cannot be, "but look how many people are pleased by it!" For instance, foot traffic does not legitimize the process, only the good itself as a result to a social context. 8 Ethos of a social context dictates what products are legitimate goods. There are agreed upon goods. 9 If someone in a social context is not aware of the process of products but appreciates their results, then that person must determine the good of her product's process in order to argue that it is better than the... 10 But social coercion occurs. Some common ideas are simply passed to one another, most only based on results and the presumed desire to those results, not interested in their processes.

item.title: Notes on The Ethics
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Chapter 1: Of God Meta-data:
  • Definitions: 8
  • Axioms: 7
  • Propositions: 36
  • Critical Propositions: 5, 7, 8, 10-13, 15-17, 18, 21, 25, 29, 33
Notes: [2:04PM, January 30, 2008] Proposition 8: Spinoza describes in detail the Principle of Sufficient Reason in so far as the cause of individual things. The definition of a thing does not assert or explain in any way the number of individual things that bear the definition. The definition only describes the nature of that thing. The number of individual things will have to be grasped through some other means than those things definition or essential nature. Furthermore, he establishes a Principle of Causality which demands that the cause of a thing in Nature must be outside of that thing. We can get to the controversial issue of why this Principle as such does not apply to Nature itself. In a word, Spinoza has formulated a dichotomy, as expressed through A1 and A2. It must be noted that any elucidation of the cause of Substances does not apply to the cause of Modes in so far as the Principle of Causality. Thus, the true issue is: Why two Principles of Causality; and furthermore, how does Spinoza make these two Principles (for Substances and subsequently for Modes) concordant.

item.title: Actarus - Self-titled
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Actarus's self-titled has a clean sound which fluctuates between post-rock and math rock - and no, not the kind math rock we know and love from old greats like Polvo. Their music is in the same vein as just about every other contemporary post-rock band; it's that kind of "math rock" that actually means "progressive." But nonetheless, their guitars are playful with all-around favorite start/stop dynamics, and their tempo is more allegro moderato with drifts into soft, melodic adventures while chanting along the way. It's unfortunate that they broke up only after releasing this EP and a split. Label: New Romance for Kids Download: RapidShare

item.title: Notes on Tractatus Theologico-Politicus
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Chapter 1 : Of Prophecy 1 "Prophecy, or revelation, is sure knowledge revealed by God to man. A prophet is one who interprets the revelations of God to those who are unable to attain to sure knowledge of the matters revealed, and therefore can only apprehend them by simple faith." [pg. 12 Unabridged Elwes Translation] 1.1 Spinoza argued that only Moses achieved physical (through the senses) communication with God; however, that communication was through the imagination. 1.2 He taught us that "nabi" means "speaker" or "interpreter", and argued that Aaron, Moses' older brother, was the "nabi"; thus, he received the title as "prophet", as an interpreter of God is a prophet when looking at Scripture. When Moses spoke to Pharoah, Aaron interpreted, acting as the "prophet."
"See [Moses], I have made thee a God to Pharaoh, and Aaron thy brother shall be thy prophet;"
1.3 Prophecy involves ordinary knowledge, like scientific or mundane sorts of knowledge. 1.4 Prophets had natural bodies and natural minds; they could not have had ontologically different minds or spirits. It would be ad hoc to claim they do in order to prove they spoke anything but ordinary knowledge. 1.5 Prophets are bound by Nature but can have Divine insight because the Nature of God emanates through all minds and bodies. 1.6 The Law of Moses nowhere describes God as "without body" or "without form"; for God must have had some sort of form in order for Moses to distinguish it. Either in Moses' dreams or in some physical sense. [pg. 17] 1.7 God speaks through "appearances and signs" 1.8 No other prophet except Jesus received revelation without use of imagination, which all other prophets used. 1.9 "ruagh" is commonly translated to "spirit" but it literally means "a wind", or a kind of wind. 1.91 It translates to many things under many contexts; courage, virtue, etc.
If the Jews were at a loss to understand any phenomenon, or were ignorant of its causes, they referred it to God. [TPT pg._ _]
1.92 Wind of God; storm = chiding of God; "Eolus" = Greek wind-god 2 Spinoza taught that phrases such as "Spirit of the Lord" and references to God in the most trivial sense were never meant to be supernatural. For instance,
16:14 But the Spirit of the LORD departed from Saul, and an evil spirit from the LORD troubled him. 16:15 And Saul's servants said unto him, Behold now, an evil spirit from God troubleth thee. 16:16 Let our lord now command thy servants, which are before thee, to seek out a man, who is a cunning player on an harp: and it shall come to pass, when the evil spirit from God is upon thee, that he shall play with his hand, and thou shalt be well. —1 Samuel 15-16
The passage suggest that a natural thing such as music can attenuate a supposedly supernatural ailment. (1) If God is supernatural, then God's affects require supernatural counterbalances. (2) Saul was not balanced (set well) by a supernatural counterbalance. (3) Therefore, God is not supernatural (God is natural).

item.title: The Memory! "Of God" through Spinozaphrase
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
By substance I understand what is in itself and is conceived through itself; that is, that which does not require the concept of another thing from which it must be formed.
That thing is said to be finite in its own kind which can be limited by another of the same nature.
By attribute I understand what the mind perceives of a substance as constituting its nature.
By mode I understand the affection, or modifications, of a substance; that is, that which is either in itself or in other, from which it constitutes the extended substances form in a various many ways.
By God I understand a being absolutely infinite; that is, a being consisting of an infinity of attributes, each of which expressing God's infinite and eternal essence.

item.title: Aristotle on Virtue
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Aristotle argues from observation of the functions of properties of the human being; properties such as “is a flutist” and “is a sports player” are presumed to have internal purposes within those properties so as to permit the observational “ends”, which allow for the observer to judge the quality of those properties. His argument hinges on the presumed ontological similarity of “human being” and, say, “flutist”; however, these are ontologically disparate entities. However, Aristotle further argues implicitly that, given the lack of “reason” in animals, humans are unique, rational animals. He further presumes that reason has a function, like that of musicians and sports players, and this leads him to conclude that the nature of “human being”, given its “rational” quality, sits in the same ontologically category as “musician.” This is an apparent category mistake; all Aristotle has done is explain what is good for a property of “human being”, and that property would be “is a rationalist”, say. The dilemma is still present: What is good for a human being? By Aristotle’s analogical argument, what have been compared are properties of “human being”. Simply because a human being exhibits that quality, it does not make it so that the quality is what all human beings must strive for. Furthermore, Aristotle stations himself within consequentialist framework in so far as he appeals to the “ends” of rationality—he sees a certain aesthetic to what rationality can produce as an end. If he is attempting to argue for supposed “virtues”, their conception cannot be based on the observation of utility of those presupposed virtues. If he does not appeal to ends, then he must be seeing rationality as a thing-in-itself which is a necessary property to be virtuous. However, virtue does not exist in a vacuum. In order to determine virtue, or good and happy living, the definition is contingent on the absolute reality of other human beings. Would be say that one can be virtuous who lives in solitude? If virtue hinges on observation, then rationality must be judged by its culminations amid observers. We now face again the flirtation with consequentialism. The task Aristotle set out before him was to present a viable option for virtue so as to explain how one could best live their life for a human being; but, as I’ve shown, he appealed to “ends” found in a property of “human being”. He showed that living as actualizing one’s potential as a rational animal is the best life, but, as argued, (a) this can only be judged rightly by appealing to consequences and (b) inevitably leads one to choose this sort of life given one’s fancy. Nevertheless, the nature of “human being” has never entered the picture.
Is Aristotle arguing from the tacit assumption that we have a priori understanding of certain concepts like justice and, for this discussion, virtue? Is he arguing that we intuitively know right and wrong; that we intuitively know contrasting definitions? How can we know that justice is right unless we have experienced or have at least witnessed injustice? If we must necessarily witness justice, then that ascribes virtue to “ends”; what is the constitution of an end? Is it utility? Consequence? How can anyone know they’re being virtuous unless someone tells them so? How can virtue exist discontinuously within the bounds of society or at least amongst observers? The proposition “she is virtuous” depends on a witness; if no witness can observe and make the claim, then she must look within herself to discover what makes her virtuous. Is it even meaningful to ask: Is she virtuous who exists as an utter savage?
Let’s say she lives in society but no one will tell her she’s virtuous. For whatever reason other constituents of society have for doing so, she receives a silent treatment upon any question of her own virtue. Whatever action she takes or discourse she engages in, no one will respond “you’re being a virtuous person.” She knows the concept of virtue exists—she read its definition in the Dictionary—, but how to obtain it is never directly or indirectly ostensively taught to her. Either she will have to determine what constitutes a virtuous action within her own understanding or by observation—that is, she’ll have to connect virtuous action to an innate understanding of virtue, or she will have to appeal to the consequences of her actions within the societal context. If she looks within herself solely, she will either reach perpetual questioning of virtuous action or assert that she is virtuous despite any response she receives. But the question has not been resolved, should the latter be taken as true in her mind. If she appeals to consequences of her actions amongst others, how will she determine, based on observation, that her attempted virtuous actions are in fact virtuous. She may observe that her actions elicit positive responses from others, and they may give her a general understanding of what draws out appealing ends—either by her perceptions or by theirs, more than likely both. Nevertheless, she has only determined what others are pleased by, and this is the definition of virtue which Aristotle wishes to avoid.

item.title: Ethical Values of Ontological Subjects
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
The value of a whole must not be assumed to be the same as the sum of the values of its parts. —§ 18; Principia Ethica; G.E. Moore
(1) [(x+y=z); value > z] XOR [(x+y=z); value < z] If you are conscious of a beautiful flower, the combinational, as it were, Value-Fact of your being conscious of that beautiful object will either be of greater value or lesser value than the independent and instrinsic values of your consciousness—no matter how fascinating you think your consciousness may be—and that of the beautiful flower, whatever those values may actually be; and certainly the Value-Fact will be greater than the totality of the parts which form that Value-Fact. Another example might suffice to make this clearer. Taking an object and that object which is taken have, concededly, intrinsically neutral values. The totality of this Value-Fact will either be greater in value or lesser in value than the separate values of those facts, or parts, involved. This Value-Fact, in this case, is neutral. But typically, the totality of this Value-Fact to one person is decidedly negative, or lesser, in value with respect to the independent parts and the sum of those parts when the object taken does not belong to the taker. This aspect of "ownership" must be combined with the Value-Fact previously described. Ownership would declare that the object taken belongs to someone or something by way of explicit claim or natural affinity. A business person owns (is related in this way to) her asserts through claim or, as it may be presumed, effort; a rock owns its--But the Value-Fact of a business person owning their property is positive to them, neutral to disinterested persons, and neutral or negative to persons who wish to take it, but never positive for the latter. Combine the positive intrinsic value of ownership of an object with the neutral intrinsic value of taking of an

item.title: Causality as Beauty
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: The question was not whether the concept of cause as right, useful, and even indispensable for our knowledge of nature, for this Hume had never doubted; but whether that concept could be thought by reason a priori, and consequently whether it possessed an inner truth, independent of all experience, implying a more widely extended usefulness, not limited merely to objects of experience. —Kant, Prolegomena; Preface: pg. 4

item.title: Use-Mention Distinction
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Remember: Failure to distinguish between the use ("A cat is a clawed animal.") and mention ("'Cat' is a three-letter word.") can result in inadvertent category errors in argument. Cats don't contain letters, and words do not have claws (in any literal sense).

item.title: From the perspective of UI/UX
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This document will serve as the basic recipe which will inform some fancy infographic I plan on cooking up that speaks to developing a process for User Experience, User Interface, Development, Quality Assurance, and Business Teams. As stated in the title, the following discussion, or rather conceptual model/scheme, flows from the perspective of User Interface developers and User Experience designers; as such, the given suggestive conceptual model/scheme may be unwittingly narrowed or limited by their biases and interests.

Phase 1: Planning

Business Team Deliverables

  1. Use cases
  2. Business Requirements
  3. Demo Expectations
  4. Milestone Planning

User Experience Team Deliverables

  1. Wireframes
  2. Creative (Layered PSD)
  3. Prototypes
  4. Specifications

User Interface Team Deliverables

  1. Prototypes Theoretical: Prototypes do not physically live in the Execution Phase but are used as the basis for Implementation; e.g., SSL/HTML ? JSP; contrast this example with other file types which live in a Web project: CSS, JavaScript, Sprites (Images). The original HTML documents become shared JSP, PHP or ASP documents.
  2. User Interface Architecture-Specification Possible topics: Tech stack, Frames (<iframe>?), Integration specification, process detail & limitation detail (between distinct sub-systems; e.g., CMS and custom app integration), File ownership boundaries document, Tech stack dependencies & limitations, AJAX, Implementation details & patterns (between distinct sub-teams; e.g., UI and Java), Cookies, HTML5, design patterns, security, validation patterns, QA guidelines, nomenclature definition & limitations
Sub-discussion: What is a wireframe?
  1. Conceptual
  2. General
  3. Low-fidelity (i.e., Black & White)
  4. Planning Document NOT an Execution Document
  5. Information Architecture/Structural
  6. Guide to Creative
Sub-discussion: Recommendations: Toward the Ideal
  1. Extend timelines for UX, relative to development teams, to flesh out deliverables. "More UX up front!"
  2. Less parallel development
  3. Never start development without Creative
  4. Expectations for Demos Sub-discussion: Demos are part of the Execution Phase, not the Planning Phase. If UI or UX should consider the concept of the "demo," expectations should be defined fundamentally differently from the way they are defined for the Execution Phase. Expectations should not be totally defined in terms of defect considerations. Consider that QA may not be well enough informed to validate Creative itself, since this team may not be versed in its documents. QA's primary purpose may be to test functionality alone, narrowly defined.
  5. Unified debugging pattern (to unify teams on debugging tools, concepts, tips, tricks)
  6. QA guidelines & nomenclature specification (e.g., defect severity definitions, defect assignment protocols; acts as a guideline from UI to QA which informs the process for assigning defects, with hope to promote more assignment accuracy and accelerated turn-around times)
Sub-discussion: UI/UX Science
The following list is composed of more readily identifiable concepts which constitute the conceptual foundation that sustains the discussion between User Interface and User Experience Teams. A User Interface developer may contrive such a list while reviewing the User Experience Team's deliverables. So, I tend to call this a "UI Ontology." Perhaps: the Candidate Ontology for that Developer.
  1. Special UI Elements (Common & Unique; e.g., carousels, tickers, widgets, calendars, etc.)
  2. Problematic areas (e.g., Integration points, CMS generated code, etc.)
  3. Structure (more so a statement that these elements exist, less so a statement of where these elements should be visually situated; e.g., footer, header, nav; property of Layout types)
  4. Heavy CSS Elements
  5. Headers (sidebar headers, footer headers, body copy headers, site headers, etc.)
  6. Modules/Web parts/Widgets, etc. (existing & novel)
  7. Content types
  8. Layout types
  9. Known pages (or "Content Inventory"; SEO specification & notes)
  10. JavaScript dependencies (inform'd by Tech Stack decisions)
  11. Notes on this list itself (how to interpret it, etc.)
  12. Meta-data (@alts, @titles, <meta />s, etc.)
  13. State Change/Events
  14. Use Case Flows
  15. Validation/Error Handling Behavior Specification/Error Messaging
  16. Accessibility Guidelines (informs Problematic areas)
  17. Identification of Data points (informs Integration map)
  18. Integration map
  19. Typography map (informs UI and CMS/MVC/Custom on the appropriate markup to generate; functions as a standard for correctness)
Sub-discussion: Action items
Between UX and UI, given the previous sub-discussion, who should develop what and why?

Phase 2: Execution

CMS/MVC/Custom Team Deliverables

  1. App
  2. Code Reviews (e.g., UI on Java, Java on Java, CMS on CMS, UI on CMS, etc.)
  3. Release Notes
[EDIT: 02-22-2011] Apparently there a tacit assumption of the waterfall model that founds this "perspective." The follow up question is: What should the UX model look like?

item.title: Reply to: Aaron Alan Alexander Arrested
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Article found on ultimatemontrose.com: Aaron Alan Alexander Arrested Yes, I was arrested for possession. I arrested for "0-2oz," sure, but do the details in such matters mean the world? Absolutely. Do journalistic entities bear such a burden to detail on pain of functioning as nothing more than a public nuisance? Again: absolutely. My main question, which I believe is a very complex one: Who is this article's target audience? Such an article, in terms of its style and substance, demands that you read it with a certain frame of mind unless you happen to fit within its target audience, otherwise it is tragically uninformative. The article, in a way, confesses this by noting that it was derived from exactly that entity which performed the arrest. Of course, offenders are offenders regardless of offense, and the tradition of "crime reporting" is a "tradition" that cannot change. More commentary available:
  • Thread started on g+: https://plus.google.com/100541351182813566938/posts/LoV3fr1dgkw
  • Thread started on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/permalink.php?story_fbid=258843187465008&id=100000179878753
E-mail sent (surely the beginning of a correspondence or at least a series of rants): Could you at least grab more facts about the arrest? Two people were arrested. It was at a park. It was by a patrol officer. We're people living in this community too, a community claim to give insight into. Well, respect its members, too. We're not just a bunch of houses and tax zones. Do we not deserve some kind of respect at least WITHIN that community? You would expect _this_ quality of journalism from a major news source, oblivious to detail because it has to be. But this entire site is presumably about Montrose, and its news is written in such an impersonal, lifeless way, it comes off as nothing less than malicious incompetence. To say the least, this article is juvenile. On its journalistic merits alone I find it appalling and embarrassing. Point is, this is supposed to be a news site that gives insight into a community and its members, but this article comes off like a unit of information for a realtor or a lawyer seeking to make generalizations. I cannot even make it to your "about" page to figure out what your mission statement is supposed to be, to judge whether this article is consistent with that general goal. Again, juvenile, amateurish ... and just sad.
On a personal note, don't you think I've been pushed around enough just trying to free myself from the financial and emotional chains of actually being arrested? Now you give me this? This is the worst. This utterly fails as any sort of respectable journalism, and now I feel disrespected. I mean, you know Harris County's corrupt and intolerable history, why on earth would you want to DERIVE your news directly from them? Why would you want to DERIVE your news from such an unreliable, painfully pithy news source? Without any quality control? I refuse to believe any writer in your midst would find such succinctness charitable, where exposure, detail, clarity and information is certainly due since, regardless of my personal concerns, I am nevertheless still a member of the community with whom you may wish to keep at least relatively decent affiliations.
Instead, this article makes the Chron out to be some kind of impersonal (not "objective"), narrow-minded, shoddy spy.
What does "Ultimate Montrose" even mean, anyway? Just the Internet trying to make sense of it all.

item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: "Hey, what are you up to?" It might seem one is overzealous in one's expectations on the human condition, yet it is quite unclear that expectation and assumption amount to what is the same thing. I assume that a human can, and this seems divinely prettily to me, for the purposes of a conversation, muster up, as it were, something relevant and significant in a conversation, regardless of

item.content:encoded:
Tarantula A.D.
Danny Bensi (Cello, Violin, Piano, Vocals), Saunder Jurriaans (Guitar, Bass, Vocals), and Gregory Rogove (Drums, Percussion, Piano, Melodica, Glockenspiel, Vocals) comprise the shuddering anthems of Tarantula A.D. Blending classical arrangements with elements of punk and metal, Tarantula A.D. delivers a hypnotic prog-rock sound with an ambient atmosphere. [...] –Last.fm profile, http://www.last.fm/music/Tarantula+A.D.
When John Zorn dines with an entire pantheon of ancient Roman Gods, this album happens. Download: http://www.mediafire.com/?azz4zmnyzim Favourite tracks: The Century Trilogy (3 tracks), Who Took Berlin (2 tracks), Palo Borracho School of Emotional Engineering - Self-titled
The name draws inspiration from a single line in Aldous Huxley's prophetic social critique Brave New World. School of Emotional Engineering is a loosely defined 'band', more of a 'project' created by composer Ben Frost. Primarily Frost, alongside multi-instrumentalist and engineer Daniel Rejmer, bassist and guitarist Andy Hazel, violin player Russell Fawkus and drummer Jova Albers, School of Emotional Engineering (S.E.E) began originally in Melbourne, Australia as a live extension of Frost's solo work. [...] –Last.fm profile, http://www.last.fm/music/School+Of+Emotional+Engineering
"...like watching a knife fight in a phone booth." The album is mostly bright ambient noise and soft keys with tracks blurring into each other, but occasionally heavy, moderate tempo drum beats will burst into the dense soundscapes. Lots of beautiful layering. It's not so much an album of tracks as it is a lengthy train of emotionally wavering thoughts and musical forces. Download: http://www.divshare.com/download/402848-66d Streamable album: School of Emotional Engineering Website: schoolofemotionalengineering.com (cryptic and creepy) Favourite tracks: Falling for Sylvia, She Dreams in Car Crashes Shellac - Excellent Italian Greyhound
Shellac did not release any records between 1000 Hurts in 2000 and "Excellent Italian Greyhound" in 2007, but songs which were to appear on the latter record formed the mainstay of their live-shows in the intervening period - in particular, "The End of Radio", "Paco", "Steady as She Goes", "Be Prepared", "Genuine Lulabelle", "Boycott", and "Elephant" (formerly known as "Repeat The Lie"). Excellent Italian Greyhound is named in tribute to Todd Trainer's Italian Greyhound, Uffizi; it was released on Touch and Go Records in June 2007. –Wikipedia, http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shellac_%28band%29
Why am I so late? This album released in June of this year. It's signature Shellac – frenetic Albini riffery, powerful Trainer drumming, routinely drilling Weston bass, screaming rambled vocals – and look out for Ken Nordine on "Genuine Lulabelle". Buy it. This album needs to be heard on vinyl, and like 1000 Hurts, it comes with an unmarked CD, for encouragement to buy it vinyl. Label profile: Shellac of North America Download: http://www.mediafire.com/?221c1eeqmtb Favourite tracks: Steady As She Goes, Elephant, Kittypants, Genuine Lulabelle

item.title: A Refutation of the Problem of Evil?, pt. 1
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
We must first make note that Epicurus (341-270 BCE) never actually wrote any literature stating the argument, but rather it was formulated as a riddle and passed along through oral tradition. The riddle first appears in De Rerum Natura, a powerful philosophical epic poem written by Roman poet Lucretius Carus (99-55 BCE), a strict disciple of Epicurean philosophy. What the problem of evil (POE) represents is an atheistic proposition for why an omnipotent, omniscience and omnibenevolent supreme being cannot logically exist. It is an argument stemming from the highlighted contradiction of such a being. Keep in mind that this argument was presented by an ancient Greek philosopher almost 300 years before the establishment of Christian Rome and 300 years, more or less, before Moses began writing the religious text which defined and saw to existence the Abrahamic God of Christianity, Judaism and Islam. Original proposition:
Either God wants to abolish evil, and cannot; or he can, but does not want to. If he wants to, but cannot, he is impotent. If he can, but does not want to, he is wicked. If God can abolish evil, and God really wants to do it, why is there evil in the world?–Epicurus, as quoted in 2000 Years of Disbelief
David Hume restates the original proposition given by Epicurus in his Dialogues concerning Natural Religion.
Is God willing to prevent evil, but not able? then is he impotent. Is he able, but not willing? then is he malevolent. Is he both able and willing? whence then is evil? Is he neither able nor willing? Then why call him God? –David Hume, quoting Epicurus
Now for the counterargument, with its theological muscle, strengthened under the disciple of theodicy, it supposedly refutes the paradox of problem of evil completely. Counterargument: http://www.christian-thinktank.com/gr5part1.html Briefly, the author-theologian restates the Problem of Evil for further analysis.
1. The world is characterized by vast amounts of intensive and extensive suffering and evil. 2. After enduring a life of hardship and pervasive suffering, many (if not most) humans will end up in hell, where they will be actively tortured forever and ever. 3. All of this was known ahead of time by God, before He had even created ANYTHING or ANYONE. 4. For some reason or motive, He "went ahead" with the plan anyway, but could have chosen to not implement it (or to start a different one altogether) or to interrupt it before it "went bad".
I am posting this now because I will eventually completely read the refutation and provide my own critique of it. I have a few initial ideas of why it is incorrect, but I will let them warm over in my thoughts for now.What is interesting, however, is that the author notes the Logical Problem of Evil (POE) is actually no longer a philosophically tenable argument nor is the Evidential Problem of Evil. Granted, he goes through almost excruciating lengths to disprove these two stances, but more importantly, he notes that contemporary philosophers no longer consider it a viable argument for their arsenal. This means that amongst philosophical circles and amongst debates, it should no longer be considered a sort of trump card against or threat to the theologian. This is important knowledge for any casual atheist or agnostic who enjoys keeping a few argumentative cards in his or her deck. The argument of the problem of evil may not so easily convince many people, and you may find yourself, at worst, succumbing to belief. That is, if the only reason for your atheism is the comfort in knowing that this riddle has gone unmatched and undefeated – it would most definitely be a surprise, if you are persuaded by the argument I've provided above.

item.title: "The Fourth of July" dans Août
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
A recent late night poem, written (you guessed it: on July Fourth, exactly one month ago) after I read some depressing news regarding...well, you know.
From a shift in earnest to democracy, Wars of affirmations of independence, Lived briefly... We have thrived pitifully In our dissent to perilous plutocracy, only To find ourselves enduring the media Corruption birthing an autocratic theocracy. And we are content with unrest and distant Unfathomable turmoils, cascaded by legislation, Writs to alienation and intellectual disease; It is the beauty of our nation. God Bless America.
Generalizations abound; redundant and nonsensical.
