p coheres with a field of relevant beliefs (coherence theory)

p is pragmatically-constrained (pragmatic theory)

Note: Consider the no-theory theory of truth in the definition of truth.

Other relevant definitions

"Objective" =def mind-independent "True for" =def believes for oneself (non-knowledge context; idiomatic use of "is true"); more akin to "is genuine" or "prefers" ("That's true for me"--Translation: "I prefer it thus and so"). "Subjective truth" =def As is clear by "true for," this term is idiomatic; in some cases it is fruitful to point out that it is a contradiction in terms, if the person means to argue about "truth" in the knowledge-that or knowledge context sense) "Subjective" =def mind-dependent (Whether or not the cat is on the mat is true does not depend purely on the status of my mind or your mind. Thus, there is a class of entities which can be true regardless of the status of one's or anyone's mind. (Refutation to "Global Relativized Truth"; not that anyone really assents to this bogus notion.) "Inter-subjective" =def consensus (not convention or norm or nonvolitional agreement) That we all wear jeans is not an inter-subjective truth (this is a convention or a social norm); that we all more or less accept that the sky is blue makes this proposition an inter-subjective truth (though some of us may not be able to supply a scientifically convincing explanation at any given time). "Statement" =def Stronger than grammatical declarative; or, as the joke goes, grammarians would be omniscient. ("The square root of my dog is pleased" or "The numbers are angry" or "God is a turnip every Wednesday at 8'o clock"--examples of nonsense, they are pseudo-statements, but nevertheless declarative-grammatical.) Record of a fact that stands the test of the logico-grammatical form. "Proposition" =def That which is expressed by the statement. "Il pleut aujourd'hui" and "It is raining today" are both statements which express the proposition that it is raining. "p" in the literature is usually substitutable with logico-grammatical statements, and "p" is called a propositional variable.

item.title: Contingency
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: I find the concept of contingency to be problematic. We generally hold that other humans, ourselves and the things and events we encounter in normal living to be contingent, or possibly other than they were. We say, "Yes, it was so, but it could have been thus," where in some cases we qualify how it could have been thus, more or less on some intuitive and quick metaphysical gloss. But my problem is similar to the problematic Hume encountered with the claim that the future must resemble the past, or that the future can be inferred from the past (implict or explicitly held). To justify such a principle or claim you'd have to venture (by some means) to the future to show that the future in fact resembles or logically follows from the past. But to do this, you may have to transgress a few spatiotemporal boundaries, laws, concepts, etc. So my analogy works this way: Things could have been different, but how might one justify this? Has one ventured to the future to determine that things could have been different? Or to the past to see that given a different situation, a new decision might've been had? But it seems past and situation and difference all make sense under the presumption of contingency as a genuine concept. So it would seem that the expression as manifestation of the concept is equally presupposed by the terms with which I use to lay out my complaint. But nevertheless, the intuition I have is that the concept so employed requires for its convincing any thinker some intuitve field. We might not say, "It could have been otherwise that X" where the situation recorded by X could be something diametrically opposed or perhaps causally alien to X. A car accident could not have been a baby shower, etc. And of course no one could know that things could have been otherwises, for one might believe it but justification and truth are lacking. For there's no method to verify (ontologically) what is not, for it is not, and we can only suppose that it is, which can only be a criterial or inductive verification--we end up back at our doorstep. Speaking of the truth of what is not with respect to that it might have been is to speak in terms of pure contradiction. And to justify a falsity, what is not, is to justify no thing but to indirectly, perhaps, confirm what is.

item.title: Belief-that (again)
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Logical grammar and linguistic grammar Declarative statements are subject-predicate statements (or noun-[grammatical-predicate]) which can record facts about the world on their own outside of the belief-context.
Caveat (non-essential to this post): Though it is not necessary that all declarative statements do this. They simply can. And they are the best candidates to do this. For instance, "Billy is the number 4" is a English grammatico-declarative, but this statement records no fact about the world, given our understanding of the concept of persons and the concept of number. Numbers and numerals are not the same thing. No person could possibly be a number. Though one could dress up like a number, but in that case the person would be dressed up like the symbolic representation of, say, the number 4, which is the numeral "4". This is a marking. Numbers themselves do not exist as such in the world; their corresponding numbers do. I can write twenty number 4s on a piece of papers, but what I would be writing is the numeral that represents the concept of the number. So one could, in a figurative way, be the numberal 4, but one could not, even in a figurative way, be the number 4. An expression or proposition which intimates this notion would be devoid of sense.
Thus, these statements are propositions which can express facts about reality. So, the belief-context is represented by "X believes that ..." or "X believes that p" where "..." and "p" call for propositions (which, again, can express facts about reality). Naturally, we find ourselves asking, "What is a 'fact'? What is 'reality'?" And, "What does it mean for a proposition to stand on its own? Best to go by examples. Lookit: "This pumpkin pie is good" cannot be a fact because though it is a grammatical statement, its proposition is ambiguous. This should be self-evident. This proposition cannot record a fact. Looking at the predicate ("is good") clearly shows that this statement, though grammatical, does not sufficiently have a sense. And if it were to have a sense, we could still say, "Look: It's too ambiguous. For example, 'This dog is well-trained.' Which dog? What is our standard? etc" Next: "with all my heart" is obviously not a grammatical statement; so it makes no sense to ask questions about whether it expresses a proposition. We're looking at propositional-belief and propositional-knowledge. We don't need to look at the conditions under which one might "believe in" the Communist party. We can easily manufacture convincing examples (involving psychology, etc) for why people might be prone to believe in certain objects. This would be unilluminating. The only category of belief we are concerned with is propositional-belief; belief insofar as it can possibly tend to truth. There's no truth to be had from preferences or conviction. Preferences cannot be true nor can conviction. In philosophy, we call the possibility of expressing a fact bit the constraints of logical grammar. So, the rule may be expressed thus: After passing linguistic grammar, an expression or (linguistic-grammatical) statement must also meet the requirements of logical grammar which states that the given statement must be capable of expressing a proposition (a thing which expresses a fact about the world, reality, etc). Non-logico-grammatical propositions might be
(i) "Bob is hello", (ii) "Colorless green ideas sleep furiously", (iii) "jalskjd askldjls skskj" (which just so happens to fail the linguistic grammar test), and (to be cheeky) as far as the logical positivists were concerned: (iv) "God is omnipotent and all-good" or (v) "The Absolute is sleeping" or (vi) "Substance consists of an infinity of attributes" and for physicalists (to make this interesting) (vii) "X believes that Y" (it has a sense, so it passes both tests) is systematically false or merely coincidentally true if the ascriber does not treat "believes" as a neuronal state of the brain.
One take on belief-that One idea I have for a necessary condition for belief is that the content of that belief ("the proposition") be thinkable (as opposed to, say, "X thinks that P"--thinkable seems to presuppose vaguely a normative constraint). Thus, we cannot believe contradictions. So, S believes that P only if "P" is thinkable; by contraposition: If P is not thinkable, then S does not believe that P. This obviously rules out belief in squared-circles (under a literal meanings and normal grammar). More generally, we cannot believe that where the clause following that is an outright (and confirmed) piece of nonsense. (1) Sam believes that he saw a squared circle yesterday only if "Sam saw a squared circle yesterday" is thinkable. By our contraposition, the "thinkable"-part is false (and perhaps necessarily false). Therefore, it follows that the "belief"-part is false. If the conditional statement itself somehow got 'round the material implication of the "belief"-part being false, we'd either need to (a) readdress our rule about thinkability or (b) the conditional statement itself would be vacuously true (ignoring the thinkability constraint), in which case, we'd still need to determine why thinkability is not a reasonable or relevant constraint. Another example by analogy Look at my "knowledge definition" example. S knows P iff

S believes P

S justifies P

P is true

What I've said here about belief is exampled by the knowledge definition. Suppose S does not believe that P. Can we speak of someone knowing something without believing it? Can someone know a falsity (not in the sense that you know that it is false--this would rather be S knows that ~P). Can someone be said to know something if that person has no justification whatsoever or insufficient justifications? Thus, one part of knowledge involves, as is evidenced by my questions: S knows P only if S believes P. By contraposition (and regardless as to the truth-values of the justification-condition and the truth-condition): If S does not believe P, then S does not know P. Thus, S does not know P, regardless of the truth-value of the other two conditions, if S does not believe P. A tricky case So, a lawyer might justify that the defendant committed the murder, and it might be truth that the defendant committed the murder. But if the lawyer does not believe it, then the lawyer does not know it. But one would think: If the lawyer can stand up in front of a jury, judge, etc, she certainly must know it. This example is supposed to test our definition of knowledge given (by me). Try to think of ways in which the definition of knowledge survives this test.

item.title: Against subjectivism
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: So subjectivism, even with its unsettling contrast between morality and science, is still not logically committed to producing practical consequences. It cannot even yield the conclusion that we are more solidly justified in having factual beliefs than moral ones; or on more objective ground in pursuing a factual question than pursuing a moral one; or objectively justified in seeking the truth about anything; or in trying to find scientific explanations of phenomena rather than resting content with superstition. For all it gave us was that factual and scientific beliefs were objective; that we should seek factual or scientific beliefs is not itself a factual or scientific belief. --Bernard Williams; Morality: An Introduction to Ethics

item.title: Constraints on Synecdoche and (Linguistic) Mereology
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: 1 The "ontological commitment" of reductive neuroscience, physicalist neuroscience and eliminative neuroscience viewed as a preoccupation, or semantic inertia, toward a certain conception of linguistic mereology. But the "preoccupation" or the "inertia" is a stumbling. The transgressed part-whole relation between brain and human organism might not be a valid, but is it an intentional error? Is there a "conception" or "conceptual scheme" at all? (Short-handism in neuroscience?) Should we call an abbreviation a "metaphor"? Brain* is an abbreviation for a set of descriptive/physical sentences. But this is not a metaphor: So why is "metaphor" or "analogical extension" or façon de parler ever brought up? 2 Is there an ontological commitment--really? 3 Internal synecdochic field: A part in some cases could never refer to the whole. The morphemic-semantic field may not include its own part, as linguistic entity, as a valid synecdochic input. For instance, "Punctuation stirs the reader" (dependence on what the part is actually capable of doing) but "Clauses stir the reader" (independence of the part); generally: What constitutes a proper part of the whole organism? A proper part for linguistic use? (Are some (synecdochic) uses essentially precluded from, improper to, practice?--Of what essence do we speak here? Social? Normative?) 4 Valid synecdoche versus invalid synecdoche. Again: Automobile / "Smooth wheels!" : "Smooth brakes!" (A forcing upon us to mind our context.) 5 The latter is not invalid as both are proper parts (but an organization of part relations to the whole formulate a hierarchy), though confusing or misleading or linguistic taboo. Of the brain: We consider the brain closer (semantically?) to the volitional, the cognitive, the emotional, the cogitative, the psychical, etc properties. But the kidney? the feet? the toe? the nail? the blood cell? the molecule? etc.

item.title: Counter to the Evidentialist Atheist
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
The evidentialist claims that it is irrational or unreasonable to hold a belief that has insufficient evidence. Belief in God is purported to be one such belief that has insufficient or inadequate or poor evidence. (Either there's so much obvious counterevidence or the evidence one has is lacking or one simply dogmatically holds the belief without ever searching for evidence in the first place.) Rationality and reasonableness are often construed as either intellectual obligations or duties or cognitive faculty. To be irrational or unreasonable is to ignore or reject your intellectual duty or obligation; or, alternatively, to be irrational or unreasonable is to be in a shoddy or unfortunate cognitive mode or to have a cognitive defect. Intellectual Duty as Rationality Claim: If you have insufficient evidence for your belief, then you ignore your intellectual duty. Cognitive Health as Rationality Claim: If you have insufficient evidence for your belief, then you have some cognitive deficiency. (You might be caught under some illusion or "drugged" or whatever.) Counter 1: Intellectual duties are imposed on us by others, standards that we have to meet. I highly doubt there's any reason to suppose that we have intellectual duties insofar as our beliefs in God, etc. What's more, surely one cannot suppose reasonably that we have an intellectual obligation to have evidence for all of our beliefs, particularly those beliefs which the belief in God reasons upon. Counter 2: Do you really want to claim religious people (those disposed to believe in God) all have a cognitive defect? (What about theologians and esteemed theistic philosophers and scientists? Wouldn't you at the same time worry that their "defect" bleeds into their other intellectual efforts?) But what exactly does it mean to be cognitively non-defective? That is, cognitively in working order? This isn't so clear. Ultimately, it seems, you'll have to give some underpinning metaphysical and epistemological account of what cognitively healthy or intellectually up-to-snuff means. But if you're atheistic, you likely already have preoccupations with, and commitments to, metaphysical and epistemological stances about human (working and non-working) cognition. But that's just circular!
These are all very loose characterizations of Alvin Plantinga's arguments found in "Theism, Atheism, and Rationality".

item.title: Time
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Tense operators: P =def Past operator ("It was the case that..."; F =def Futuer operator ("It will be the case that...") Predicate symbols: A-Z Variables: x, y, z Basic and quantificational cases: "It was the case that all cats are green." | P?x(Cx ? Gx) "It will be the case that some trees are purple." | F?x(Tx & Px) "It was the case that the cat is on the doormat." | PDc "It will be the case that some dog ate my homework." | F?zAz "The car had been operational for some time." | PPOc "It was the case that it will be the case..." | PFy "It will have been..." |  FPx (Future Perfect) "It will be the case that it will be the case..." | FFx PBb & PBa ("It was the case that Bob is in Barcelona" & "It was the case that Bob is in Barcelona") F?x(Bx ? Sx) ("It will be the case that, for all x, if x is in Barcelona, x is in Spain.") ~F?x(Bx ? Sx) ("It will not be the case, for all x, if x...") F~?x(Bx ? Sx) ("It will be the case that not for all x, if x is in Barcelona, then x is in Spain.") (Politics...) P?x(Bx ? ~Sx) ("It was the case that, for all x, if x is in Barcelona, x is not in Spain" or "It was the case that no x is in Barcelona is in Spain.") Syllogistic cases: Case 1: P?x(Tx ? Gx) P?x(Gx ? Cx) ?P?x(Tx ? Cx)

item.title: Language and the Existence of God
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: By teleological combined with analogical reasoning the conclusion of such is professed to show that the existence of God is at least plausible. That there is "design" is self-evident, but design as our author wishes to convey is putatively simple matter of generating a set of captivating and eloquent sentences--plausibility as rhetoric. The teleological argument is tantamount to a jester's performance before a unruly king. The human mind, in every intellectual endeavor of this sort, efforts to extend language beyond its bounds; jester jigs to save his life. A linguistic device is tried so as to do that which any grammarian of a natural language must forbid, or at least necessarily will forbid. A reminder will be given by the conservative of language, in each of us, that analogy itself is the culprit, and the use of it in such a way is abuse. All that which produces one component of the analogy reduces to one simplified predicate which simply does not fit. And by mereological understanding and stricture, only a grave fallacy can be produced. No design argument shall ever accomplish its task, which is nothing beyond that task of its author to imbue a syllogism with the feeling of some fine day. The design argument is impolite to human experience, and monstrous to our form of linguistic expression. So worthy of esteem is our human power to put thought to pen; we ought not sacrifice the dignity of literature with so idiotic an argument. Language cannot do what is wished, when all that is premise is experience or some awesome feeling. We say, "Language is a devil which suffocates creativity, feeling, the powers within us." But this is nothing but a confusion. Nevertheless, who has stumbled onto a grotesque metaphysic at this point? The scientific mode, basis for the cosmological argument, can do no better; at least, not without some presupposed metaphysical axiom. It's magical trick which efforts an "ending" where no end is justified by the axiom of inquiry which science cannot shirk. The only thing required to be discovered by the skeptic is the hidden premise, supposing she wishes to play the hunting game at all (and obtain some chair at some school). And that treasure will always conflict with the communalism and ironic conservativism of science. As if the scientists were in the business of preserving their investigative spirit. The ontological argument is a social error. At which point in the day is it appropriate to give it? If the argument has no place in the social stream, its potency is the effect of pebbles dropping into a tumultuous river. In some regions the argument has weight, but to the extent that it tests human ingenuity of formal language. The ontological mode must need a presupposition of correspondence; its coherence only artificial, which is obvious, in every sense of what it means to be "artificial." Nominalists charge that "God" is a word which touches nothing. Perhaps it is an empty "vessel"; more grievously, perhaps, a putative vessel. It is a word, which is itself questionable, and nothing more. To which we, in some off-brand realist mode, counter: "A fancy word at that!" I don't know--all the arguments weigh heavily in, and I can only feel mislead or distraught in the face of them. God, to me, is no object. And if "feelings," "conclusions," "emotions," "wills," "freedoms," "states," "governments," "ends," "purposes," "kingdoms," interesting Greek and Latin words, "fathers," fathers, "persons," "spirits," "deities," "traditions," "collections," "experiences," "abductio explanans," "noumena," "phenomena," "monads," "universes," "wholes," "substances," "absolutes," "ideas," "universals," "notions," "concepts," "forces," superhero pornstars, imaginations, conceptions, dreams, demons, desires, religions, Presidents, "obviously so's" and "self-evidence," warm feelings and kinship, those which must follow from basic beliefs, epistemic foundations, multiplicities, simples or complexes, "waves," "authors," poems, "posits," "algorithmic rhythms grooving across the contours of our universe," and so on, are in some sense objects (at the end of hearing tired qualifications), then God certainly is not referred to, nor even maximally or marginally suggested, by any of them. God isn't "is" nor "was" nor "will be." Vague spiritual hunches and stillborn anecdotes won't do. God does not fail to have properties, nor does God succeed in doing so; and we do not overcome language (a negativos might like to think), nor do we undermine ourselves with language. All this intellectual posturing is grandly irrelevant, despite the theologian's, the postmodernist's and your grandmother's wailing. From modernism to its downfall, God fits into no conceptual scheme; and nor does God fail to fit. Perhaps God is manifest from the platitudes of social mediocrity, everyone trying to keep a smile on their hapless faces as they stand before the monster of the other and those myths. "God is the extramundane supervening on the mundane," and even this is an absurd from a gimped sociologist's contortionist act. Yet we will talk about it, on and on and on. It will make sense as if the whole event of communication on this planet were just some cosmic implicature. And God certainly is not that either. What position do I call this? Not atheism, for that has become far too theistic, which is just to call it "political." Perhaps I shall call this a quietest mood. I am in the mood of a dogma, and in a dogmatic mood.

item.title: Some words on "the" pragmatic theory of truth
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Are beliefs true because useful, in that they serve some utility; or useful because they are true? And thus false, on the supposition of utility as implication of truth, because our needs or requirements have not been met. But naturally, if something is true (we can surely suppose this in a "neutral-to-our-pragmatic-definition" sense), we will likely wish to condemn it if (going along with our neutral sense), additionally, we discover that it serves not our needs or requirements. And if false, but it serves our needs? Are we permitted to speak of falsity outside our definition. From which point of view do we suppose falsity? From the eye of a competing theory? Or in the "objective" sense? It seems that to unlatch theory from our throats so to speak honestly, with clarity from bias, is quite a struggle. We are theory-mongers, whipped but insolent unto ourselves. What does it mean to call a thing a "utility"? Might something be useful in the objective sense? This seems to be nothing other than the question: Might something be pleasing (say, aesthetically) in the objective sense? A barrier between ourselves and truth will be artificially erected if we accept this pragmatic constraint--constraint as barrier. (How fair should this analogy go for any theory of truth?) So is this theory in fact no argument for truth as such, but a remark on the perilous state of humanity? Perhaps I speak too extremely and with hyperbole: Is this "theory" something more to the effect of a conclusion parasitic on some or any old sociological survey? Who surveys? How might we validate the truth of this survey independently of its own definition--could we? This seems unlikely. How might we determine the validity of its generalized theory of truth? It's social theory of truth? Seems rather Millian insofar as his inductive account for the concept of number. The concept of truth as a generalization from "the" human condition.

item.title: The moral & the logical
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: No logician will accept that a logical proposition, such that "A or B and not both" has justification from the moral sphere. Logical propositions--tautologous, as they are called--could never be justified by some moral viewpoint, nor a religious one. "Conditional proof" preserves validity not on account of some religious text or God's divine command. But would the tautologies of the moral be properly proven by the justifications of logic? What does it mean to say a moral claim follows? We seem to presume that all language is parasitic on the medium of logic. But is logic a "medium"? The "language of logic" is unfortunate, for logic certainly is no language on its own. It is a set of rules for inference. But what does it mean to be "rule"? Does all language depend on some foundational rule? Here we enter the question of the validity of language-games. Is the Frege-Geach problem even a problem? It seems to be a problem only if we subordinate the "logic" of moral language to the logic of first-order logic. But what is logic? A logical system is a set of rules which govern the validity of inference. But logic is the study of those putative rules for that system. But is there a Logic wherein all other putative systems reside: moral logic, propositional logic, predicate calculus, modal logic, deontic logic, the logic of economics, policy-making, of romance, essay-writing, English grammar, friendship and dog-training? We say these things can be logical but unto themselves or do they pay respects to first-order logic? Or some Platonic Logic hidden beneath the dashboard of our minds, linked mysterously and philosophically to the Heavens above our scientific heavens? What have we determined when our procedure shows us that something is logical? Normative versus descriptive logic. The distinction between, perhaps, soundness and validity. Soundness suggests something praiseworthy: We cheer and hurrah for soundness. Yet to claim "validity" seems stand-offish. To claim "invalidty" or "fallacy" seems to either to miss the point or takes us no step further than the invalid argument itself. Our descriptive logical view point suggests habit or behavior. Perhaps behavior as such is necessary before we can say it is logical. To call it behavior at all seems to imply that there is a logic to it; but do we merely be a "pattern"? Surely our normative view of what it means to reason well is more than merely to commend, "Yes, you have carried out the proper pattern or habit." Well, surely it might be this way, since logic, or those logicians, to declare more accurately, does not give us the values under which we convince, suppose, persuade, etc. So logic has no "internal truth." It has nothing to say about truth; a theory of truth enters into logic; the logician informs us of its following or obeying rules. Respected rules. But what pushes or compels up to respect them? Has "rationality" to do anything with "truth" or does it have, exhaustively speaking, everything to do with consistency, completeness and coherence? One might be coherent and irrational? Or complete and irrational? Consistently irrationality? I gloss heavily, I'm sure. So truth is sister to logic; we search for a theory of truth to compliment our logics or our Logic. The binaries of truth give way when we consider statistical study, and so too we introduce a fuzzy logic. But this seems ad hoc with respect to our Logic; I doubt the rag-tag gang of logics truly care. Paraconsistent to Aristotlean/Classical logics have nothing to say about the grades of the world; they're too pure, by fiat of symbology, to worry about correspondance.

item.title: Man--O man
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: A standard but resolute man strolls -- uneasily across hundreds, if not millions, of sidewalk denizens. Each one, carefully chiseled according to his skewed vision; make up a kind of bastard carnival of utterances and sentences. [While] A string of sense-laden coughs and gags confound our man's focus. He delves into the deeps of his mind distracted before an automobile breaks everything on him.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
This is Zetherin on Philosophy Forum. I'd like to discuss some things, if you're willing.
If so: aim - Zetherin

item.title: The Ship of Theseus
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: The years have worn your favorite bicycle, endearingly but recursively going by the appellation "The Bicycle," into a shoddy ride. Decidedly, since you haven't the excess funds and are keen on budgeting, over the next 100 days (or however many days per part) you replace one part every day on The Bicycle. Along side being economically prudent, you enjoy preserving everything you own, regardless of its quality or worth (which likely explains why you let the bike fall into the state it was in before repair). Sheer existence and at least minor relation to yourself, I suppose, determines essential worth. Hence, you store all the parts, now substituted, in a container. At the 100 or so day mark, you realize that all the old parts now have new stand ins. The Bike is now numerically another beast--in tip top shape and gleaming. After you take it for a quick spin 'round the block, you feel somewhat guilty and nostalgic. Something is missing; but though content, perhaps even overjoyed with this new ride, you feel that the old must be preserved in some noble and constructed state, rather than tossed and turned, mixed and mashed haphazardly in a crate. Thus, you rebuild the "old" with the old. (How odd it feels to formulate that sentence; how difficult it is to be clear.) But to which does the name properly apply? The condition for the exact use of a proper name is in question here. Do not say: "Ah yes, clearly qualities ride on the coattail of proper names." That is not so clear! Which qualities do you have in mind? "Gleaming," "defect"; relation at all? Does our exact use of a proper name hinge on our being intimately related to the object in question? Might I become closely familiar with an item on a conveyor belt and name it affectionately? In jest? But stipulation aside, what are the conditions for exact proper name use? Aristotle, etc (and I mean this) seem to offer no solution other than the posit of a new category or a distinction of categories. The "solution" becomes definitional. These solutions are answers to the question: Which qualities? (Which is nothing more than the question: Which categories condition our judgment?) These responses all seem so over-formal, over-pedantic and overcompensating. Frustratingly analytic and bloated. Quine's employment of, and implicit solution to, the puzzle is highly Wittgensteinian, I think, and much more pleasing, thought-provoking. Tacking on distinctions as solutions and "orders" or "dimensions" builds a "house of cards." Change the setting of the thought experiment, but preserve the logical feature of the puzzle. And why should we accept the story the way I have presented it or the way Plutarch had presented it as the paradox? Now we see that if riding The Bike no paradox arises. If at sea there is no paradox to speak of. Enjoy your thought experiment, but do not perpetuate myth; and reject the "necessary feeling" to craft a speculative metaphysic.

item.title: Objectivity and Truth - A characterization of William's critique
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Even supposing that there are any, and this we certainly must suppose, for it is possible if not likely that they be hidden from us, an objective truth does not entail that one's procedure in obtaining it is objective. Nothing prevents or precludes the possibility that one may stumble into an objective truth, either at the street corner or in the laboratory or during a passionate and sensual experience. A scientist or a lawyer, in the deep and sweat of their messy profession, may happily admit to you that they aim at an ideal procedure -- if they have the time and energy and capacity to speak sincerely yet intelligibly to you about it at all. This embodies the background of discovery -- what makes discovery in science so awesome, "meaningful." (The suggestion that the world as it actually is is more beautiful and inspiring than we can imagine it.) It is a discovery precisely because it took us this long. And this is what philosophy must lack: We mustn't treat the philosopher as if she we a scientist, toiling away for millennia -- just imagine how shocking her discovery will be! (We must put an end to the conflation of science and philosophy; it is an unfortunate and dangerous picture. Notice: The philosopher will happily describe to you her procedure.) And the scientist?: Ever does the feeling loom that this or that article is the mysterious, not the aim of it, its claim, its hypothesis, its evidence, its conclusion. The procedure, the scientific method behind what is expressed, concerns me. How faulty is the presumpion: If you stand where I stand, and nothing more is required, you will reach my conclusion. (The principle of objectivity: What does it mean to "stand in the same place"?) That we should seek objective truths cannot be of itself an objective truth. (Williams)

item.title: The burdening of proof
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: The burden of proof is not a rule of logic. I'm not sure where you could have pulled this idea, or from where it might have originated. One cannot use it to draw inferences. It is a demand that one should not leave the logical rules idle, on the sidelines. It is an imperative that one ought to allow the rules of logic play. As an "ought," it is essentially normative. As normative, it is social. Hence, the burden of proof is a social rule. It is an Academic Platitude the ordinary person takes as a sign of prestige, worth and understanding. Moreover, since you won't accept any argument from your three headings, you have a constraint on what "evidence" is supposed to mean. This is a (positive) linguistic claim (or rather, a presupposition: it needs to be put on the table). Perhaps you set the burden of proof too high? Or you are too conservative in your level of expected evidence. Clearly you have an implicit expectation of what counts as proof. Is this expectation propositional? If you could expound upon it, how would you justify it? It is positive, and thus it stands in need of justification. "The burden of proof is thus-and-so." -- What is your evidence for this? "Substantive reason" reason boils down to what? -- "A reason that pleases me." Of course, outside of your game, the religious person might ask: "Prove it with religious evidence" or "Convince us with spiritual proof" -- Will you call this nonsense? What makes "religious evidence" senseless? If you hold not to that claim, then perhaps you hold an error theory. Does "religious evidence" systematically make the proposition which it supports false? But is thisunfortunate? Perhaps, but you go further: You deem it "irrational." But what does it mean to be "rational"? Is this a cognitive defect? Or is it an obligation? The former would be an absurd assessment. The latter seems unconvincing, for what is it exactly that is my burden? So I give you a proposition with some support. But why must I do this? Well, the game of rationality can be enjoyable some days, other days not. But what makes me obliged? A need for superiority? Am I obliged to support the proposition or something more? My form of life? etc etc.

item.title: Preliminary thoughts: modal properties, identity and time
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: 1 Leibniz's Identity Law: If A and B are identical, then every quality of A will be a quality of B. 1.1 ToastOne is a piece of toast at time T1. ToastTwo is ToastOne at time T1+n, where n is any arbitrary length of time. 1.2 Suppose that A and B are identical, then it would follow, by (1), that ToastOne and ToastTwo are qualitatively indiscernible. 1.3 Moreover, if ToastOne and ToastTwo are not qualitatively indiscernible, then, by (1), ToastOne and ToastTwo are not identical. 2 Leibniz's Identity Thesis: If A and B are qualitatively indiscernible, then A and B are identical. 2.1 ToastOne and ToastTwo are qualitatively indiscernible only if ToastOne and ToastTwo are identical. 2.2 It follows, by (2), that if ToastOne and ToastTwo are not identical, then ToastOne and ToastTwo are not qualitatively indiscernible. 2.3 Concern: Modal properties. ToastOne might have been ToastTwo. It seems counterintuitive to say that ToastOne might have been ToastOne. But what of the former statement? ToastTwo might have been ToastOne: What constraints (likely empirical from a naive perspective) make us resistant to accepting this? Further, it seems to make little sense to say that ToastTwo might have been ToastTwo; clearly, it makes no sense to say that ToastTwo might not have been itself (ToastTwo). 2.4 Retrospective: ToastOne will be ToastTwo. What are the truth-conditions for this proposition? Likely they will be empirical-qualitative. (Non-retrospective: We will be making a prediction, of course.) 3 Does "is identical with" presuppose modal properties? ToastOne is necessarily temporally prior to ToastTwo. This seems fair. 3.1 ToastOne might not be ToastTwo; but: ToastTwo might not be ToastOne. Does this amount to: ToastOne might not be itself? ToastTwo necessarily is not ToastOne. ToastOne necessarily is  not ToastOne.

item.title: Proposition, the Non-linguistic, Rule
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: 1 A proposition is an expression of a relation. The relation is itself the content of the proposition. Moreover, it is a record of a fact: a relational fact. A relation stands under a context. Where there is no context, there is no relation. A proposition is committed. However, the speaker is not, at least not in the same sense of commitment. The speak does nothing beyond the obeying of a rule. The commitment of the proposition follows from the standard of its correct or incorrect application. Propositions are either correct or incorrectly applied, expressed with sense or without sense. A speaker cannot be senseless. 1.1 A sound is not necessarily linguistic. (Indeed, this is an important reminder that we ought to keep with us at all times.) A word insofar, and exhaustively speaking, as it contains a finite concatenation of letters is not linguistic. A letter is a marking. A proposition would be the expression of, or generally speaking, the function of the non-linguistic entity that is the marking. But a proposition requires a propositional space which is just to say, it requires a space for possible standings. Nothing stands related to another thing in this space, but things do fall under some while not others. I do not stand in relation to my self, nor do I stand in relation to my height or "a height." I meet a criteria for being said to "fall under" this or that. But we need not speak of extensions. I need not speak of the set of all those entities of so-and-so height. I am not on a list of sorts or of any sort. There is no list to speak of. I meet the criteria for saying of me that I am so-and-so height. But the criteria are conditioned. Between a man 5 feet in North America and a man 5 feet in South Africa, do each of them fall under the extension of "is five feet tall"? But where would we go to determine this?: The criteria for ascription under the N.A. and S.A. contexts. So is to say "each man here is 5 feet in height", under our extension-speak, the same as saying "each man here is the same height"? 2 From (logically) a genuine proposition, which is a proposition that agrees with the non-linguistic arrangement, to a pseudo-proposition. From a genuine to a genuine. From a pseudo-proposition to a pseudo-proposition. And from a pseudo-proposition to a genuine one. A proposition, generally, agrees with something. What does it mean to agree? And how is "agreement" possible? On what grounds might a thing (a proposition) be said to agree or fail to agree? 3 Every proposition agrees with something agreeable. But to be agreed with and to be agreeable need clarification. Might I make the basis of agreement (our question of possibility supposed affirmatively -- denying dogmatic skepticism) the subject of my proposition? To say that a proposition does agree is to cite some basis. But to ask: Is it nevertheless agreeable? This hints at the skeptical orientation. But what does it presuppose? Does it presuppose the "principle of skepticism": dogmatic skepticism? Is there a principle to speak of? 4 I ask: Is it agreeable? This is to ask: Have you checked the basis for agreement? We must be wary of accidental bases; but to the extent of dogmatic skepticism? Should we never speak for fear of the "global accident" or the Cartesian Demon? How might I discover that I am being universally tricked? What does it mean -- what would it look like -- this "discovery"? (( The construction of a theory versus the creation of a theory. ))

item.title: Intentionality
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Intentionality is a term that captures the property of "aboutness" or "directedness" of mental episodes or states. To give some substance to the notion of "state," rather than reducing it to some physical state, the theory of intentionality involves the supposition that a mental state requires an intentional state. Moreover, an intentional state consists of underpinning features which would be, at the same time, underpinning features of a mental state. Therefore, even if a mental state were "reducible" or "identifiable" with a physical brain state, or a neuronal state, then the properties which ground the intentional state would require explanation. If a reductionist methodology or identity theory does not account for these properties, then we can deem them philosophically irrelevant until or unless the general scientific principle is shown to adequately account for these properties. An intentional state, and thus a mental state, maintains at least three properties (beyond the general property of aboutness). I suggest that these properties answer the questions What does "aboutness" mean? That is, when asked: We should be able to identify, analyze and demonstrate the properties in question. I will here identify them only. An intentional state, or aboutness, requires an intentional object; this is the target of the direction of the mental episode. The conscious being attends to the intentional object. The object is bare. It is not colored. It is a point. The object is the form. It is objective. An intentional state, or aboutness, requires an intentional mode; this is the frame of the mental episode. The conscious being attends in virtue of the frame. The frame itself is the way in which the conscious being attends to the target. Psychologists call the frame the "propositional attitude." An intentional state, or aboutness, requires an intentional content; this is the coloring of the target. The content consists of the angle from which the conscious being attends to the target. Whereas the target is bare, the content is multiplicity. The content is the presentation of the object to the conscious being.

item.title: Whose language
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Language;— language is the shoes on my feet, the sheet under which I sleep; it is every echo of every stuttering child; the day's sweet wine tweak on lips of a savory wit
Language is my practical reason pitted Against the myopic nature of my theoretical It is my imperative, the after before my is -- Seven days a week I speak it; I step into it And fall out of it, and stumble back before Hopeless cautious steps feign to me a way out
Language, a beacon, caresses my tangents And corrals my sense, grounds my problematics -- I and it didactically careen necessarily into the novel Nitty gritty world of truth and composure, 'til reposure Settles and blankets every disquietude
Language bolsters but warns me, and sloppily adorns me It never suffocates me unless I allow it, but speaks for me Even when I raise raptures of rationality -- Yet it is I whose it is who holds claim to its force and will

item.title: from realms to fields (disjointed thoughts)
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
battalion of numbers twisting the mind arms a diarrheic experience worthy of nostalgia and vision flummoxes aright a distorted world
the landscape of sense, its own eminent domain (the philosopher as an ever-trespasser)
the feeling of an accidental experiment; a surprise in language, oh how quiet is this music searching through the rubble of rhythm
and we realize the defense of liberty is a deadbeat fuck who gropes every woman at every gaze; yet a clutter of smiles wrap themselves around his throat; he breathes through blithely lit passages of pupils and damaged egos, the scent of gesture drowns their every attempt at freedom
the dark corner of a bar is the safety of silence before expression

item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: I find myself in an uncouth maneuver; that we should revive our spirits in captured years

item.title: a minor comedy
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
every of my sorrows are stolen except this one
"Do you still remember when we were in love?" —i mumbled a foolish nothing: and she asked me to repeat myself
i hated that i always had to repeat myself she hated that i always mumbled
(thinkers speak epiphanies at those roadside diners we never enter, write threnodies in unknown pens;
lambent souls echoing cool against the militant brilliance of everyday bodies)
her beauty is a chameleon, a manifold which bleeds into surroundings; attitude a phoenix found anew each moment; spirit a bewildering bastion that speaks to the sky
each morning she welcomed me to this world by her celestial, horrifying glow — it seared the sin on my skin; and i agreed with the comedian, a matriarch on my misery
"would you deny me?" -- herein language is at a loss whereof i whistle of will at the walls; my heart an atlas cracked and i, with miles of road to travel, can only belie moral maturity
i woke one morning with a litany of hopes, chimeras on which i crafted a promise — a real trite affair with toy birds and song
songs sung without singers, love had without lovers

item.title: Cheap Little Blues Riff #0
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: So I have, for the past year or so, only put trivial and pitiable effort into learning the diatonic harmonica. But now I think I have got it (at least blues, anyway). Here's a little riff. I'd really like to continue study in blues but also learn jazz, bluegrass and folk (of eastern European styles). Let's see where we get in a half year's time. And this blues scale, come hell or high water, simply must be on the Internet at multiple localities (for those in search): (originally found at tenhole.com).

item.title: Notes on "Walter Sinnott-Armstrong on Moral Psychology"
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: From: http://nigelwarburton.typepad.com/philosophy_bites/2009/05/walter-sinnottarmstrong-on-moral-psychology.html Moral Psychology intuitively defined: study of moral judgment, using the experimental methods of psychology and neuroscience. Moral psychologists study and investigate moral judgment making, not so much moral behavior. Units of evidence include report, survey, questionnaire, etc; these units are correlated with neuronal activity. Separating philosophy and psychology is virtually impossible, but trends in modern science and philosophy have shown commonality and overlap between methodological tenets and research programs. Study by Josh Green: Kantian ethical judgments are popularly associated with rationality and reason (taken to involve deontological or rule-based reasoning, Categorical Imperative, consistency, "logicality," from duty, etc). Utilitarian ethics are associated with sensibility and sentimentalism. Brain scans show that emotive centers of the brain are more active in making deontological judgments. Areas associated with working memory/application of rules are active when we are involved in utilitarian reasoning, judgment making. Correlation does not imply causation, of course. Moral judgments making is influenced by on the environment (smells around, etc), circumstances (sometimes emotional dispositions, etc). Some moral judgment are shown to be problematic when dealing with first-, second- and third-person grammatical substitution. Individual scientists are irrational; though, science as a whole is rational. Recent developments in moral psychology: 1. Methodological push: Moral neuroscience 2. Diversity of moral judgments (Jonathan Height (emotional process) contra Marc Hauser (computational process)): dealing with different regions of moral judgment; Possible solution: break moral judgments down into "types" or "classes" to parallel the theoretical field or region of moral judgment making. Look for family resemblances, etc. Explaining away responsibility? "We have some control over our judgments. Not responsible for my judgments, responsible for my actions." Sinnott-Armstrong brings in a dispositional theory to answer the question of "Determinism over Judgment Making." We can go against our judgments; we do not necessarily always act in accordance with our judgments. "Thought Experiment" analogy drawn out to justify Game Show Ethics. Sinnott-Armstrong makes a distinction between "the Thought Experiment Lab" and "Real Life"; moreover, that findings in the former do not entail findings of the same kind in the latter. Legal systems may be made more effective if we investigate moral judgment making behind legal processes.

item.title: Spinoza and ontological commitment
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Spinoza was a substance monist. To the question: What is there? Spinoza would undoubtedly reply, "That which cannot be conceived except as existing, namely God; moreover, there's only one." All else, for Spinoza, is property of that one underpinning substantive being. In metaphysics we deal with this question at every possible level or category or context. To hazard a crude example, say we set our vision over a verdant green cast out before us for miles and miles. Within our field of vision, we will identify enumerable happenings, going-ons, to speak loosely and colloquially, events, objects, processes, entities, substantives, properties, to speak technically (under the language of metaphysics). Spinoza, as a monist, must also be a reductionist. Everything must be reducible, or defined in terms of, the one underlying substance, God. There is, for Spinoza, beneath the family resemblances, essentially disguised, one thing which answers the skeptic of every degree, a philosophical showstopper. Again, that thing is God, a concomitant of an infinity of attributes each of which express an infinite and eternal essence. All that esoteric talk really runs a mouth-full. What does it amount to in more practical terms? Well, I am really trying to figure that one out. Spinoza would likely, rather than the Realist, turn away from reducing everything to substantives (things, objects) and processes (events, activities). Spinoza held the mode to be the essential manifestation of contingency in reality (or Reality, perhaps). If you want to speak of the contingent matters, the matters of fact, the cats on the mats and the Kings of France, you are getting into talk about the modes of substance. For us, that just means: the properties of Reality. But we take "property" from the ordinary language all the way down to the speculative-metaphysical tongue. To introduce a model: subjects and objects are properties of substance (say, God or Reality or whatever). So the cat and the mat are properties of something, namely the underpinning reality. Properties, say, like a smile is to a face. We may say mats and cats, in any particular setting, inhere in the world (reality) in the way a smile inheres within a face. The smiling face is not a thing but nor is it an activity or process. The concept of smiling face captures more than its mere physical (substantive and chemical-muscular sequentive) aspect. But is it merely an event?  Well, it certainly is an event to smile. We certainly smile at this or that time. But is that all we get from the smile? "Event" is a gestalt term. It means very little without qualification. But does "mode" service us any better? Whatever these terms amount to, their acceptance certainly is step away from the ghost chase for real entities whom may correspond to the theoretical posits of our modeling.

item.title: Death of mind, revisited
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
A partition unto the hollowed sky, So etched in the final florilegium Of our towns teeming terribly with temerity
The shroud of our lawyerly, catholic edifice Bates not conviction but bolsters brimming, A reckless, bewildering benevolence toward Us, our own pitiable tirade in ornate tongue — Rather we burn cacophonous within our minds!
We, woeful we, rapture in quotations common To our descent, in condescension to our former Fellows — We, wretched we, rend origins In betterment, besetting the bowels of our bosom

item.title: The Undiscussability of Torture
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
The standard approach or question on torture is, to put it in Kantian terms: Do you find torture permissible, obligatory, or impermissible? What are the circumstances under which you may adjust your assessments originally made in these Kantian categories? The presumption is that in doing philosophy we toss about argument which gets us closer just this latter question. If we invite talk of permissibility hinged on circumstance, we also invite, I think tacitly, a never-arising conclusion, at least one we may arrive at propositionally, explicitly, to the question: Is torture just plain impermissible? What I get at is "torture in the abstract." One might ask you: Do you find torture deplorable? And you may very well respond: Well, what do you mean by torture? This is an invocation of the circumstantial, where "torture" just amounts to some culturally-laden concept -- perhaps a family resemblance concept. However, what warrants, or perhaps what causes, and moreover, what may justify, the initial reflex reaction to the word itself in our culture? The reflex may be best characterized by the quasi-absolutist moral proposition: We all stop at some point. Say, Nobody ever thinks that state mandate slaughter of children once they reach the age of 5 is permissible; or perhaps, Nobody ever finds it obligatory that we murder our wives if they fail to acknowledge a traffic signal as it properly should be acknowledged. And what is the nature of this "stopping"? Is it moral agreement? What are the differences that we may draw from between refusing to take a position in the realm of these questions and never having been introduced to them. What does it mean to say: These questions are simply off the table. We certainly view some questions as simply irrelevant: Some view philosophical questions as loony and wholly detached from anything important or significant, others have the same outlook on rigorous scientific questions, and so on. It's plain that some questions the answers for which are simply not options for us. Let's say, "I'm not qualified to really give you an answer at all." And what of moral qualification and just what these analogy may mean. The typical thought experiment, which is a reflection of some actual cases, is where a commanding officer is given some (possibly false) dilemma wherein that officer must either save numerous lives at the cost of degrading the humanity of a known terrorist. My position is a newly discovered one extracted from a Podcast by Philosophy Bites with Raimond Gaita. It isn't so much a position which takes a region in the torture debate as it is a meta-ethical position on the activity of debating, thinking about and discussing torture. The position is a broad one in that it forces one to weigh between the public debate of torture in relation to society overall.

Central claim: A society is defined in terms of those topics it refuses to see as thinkable or discussable.

And we should be concerned with the shaping we each play a part in of our society. Gaita makes the argument by analogy: Look, we don't see propositions such as "we should consider whether it is a good idea to enslave our entire Hispanic population" or "let's murder every third son" as discussable. For the most part, we passively agree that these propositions are, perhaps, other-worldly. Moreover, they simply don't crop up. However, our comedians and so forth certainly play on these concepts. They're imaginable, sure, but we don't view them as topics on which we even take ourselves to have a position. Asking what our position would be in a, say, mass genocide case would seem like sheer irony or satire. So there is a set of propositions of which we simply find undiscussable. Now, is "undiscussable" on the same logical footing as "impermissible," "permissible," and "obligatory"? It seems that the latter implicitly grant or presume the validity of talk of the "circumstantial." Even if we rule torture, generally, to be "impermissible" we may not necessarily be resistant to particular cases. But to say that it is undiscussable seems to block entrance to the notion of circumstantial talk. (Do you agree?) For the most part, positions which affirm these extreme examples sound either morally comical, in that we can only at most laugh at them for their sheer absurdity; or we question the authenticity of the speaker's utterance (we question whether or not he or she is being comical). Centrally, the position here held in this original post is that torture falls into the same set as those "extreme examples." (I remember in Orwell's essay "Politics and the English Language" that his antidote for eradicating certain forms of taboo or antequated pieces of writing was the recommendation of ridicule. Simply laugh the bad writers out of the position of popularity.) What Gaita has said resonates with my general meta-ethical outlook. Though, he blends an argument backed by humanistic thinking into it.

Normative claim: Never let your society reach the point where only "saints" are able to see the humanity in others. Torture should fall under the undiscussable.

Torture, so far as Gaita is concerned, is just one of those questions -- finding it discussable at all -- that tips society into the favor of depriving its denizens of that capacity to, on the whole, see the humanity in others. It reaches a point where, say, we become more dependent on the church as a moral guide, that entity to which we should look to for the right moral perception. But "saint" doesn't necessarily mean a religious concept; rather it presumes a core humanity we all share to pity or perhaps give benevolence without thought of being justified or feeling the need for "philosophical argument." Sure, we're caught in the trend now of seeing torture as discussable, as we do discuss it, but it need not necessarily be this way.

item.title: Variable fugue on Pi
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Pi has an infinite decimal expansion which may be generated by a rule. What does this mean? "Pi", the word, is the symbolic representation of both its rule and approximations to the potentially infinite decimal expansion. That is, the word "Pi", in ordinary mathematical parlance, is used to represent two fundamentally kind of things. Moreover, in a strict logical sense, as it happens, it is a synecdochic term because the "logical entity" which is the concept of Pi (the whole) itself is referred to by the same linguistic item as that which refers to the parts of the concept. Namely, we refer to "3.14" by the term "Pi" and we refer to "3.14159265 and so on" by the term "Pi." The mathematical description, which is the latter use, should never be mistaken for the former. Moreover, one must bear in mind that it makes no sense to describe that which is in principle imperceptible. Thus, we may as well give up the idea that we are "describing a mathematical entity." Pi is both a substantive: the former use (when it is a finite decimal expansion) and a rule: the latter use (one cannot give the full necessary and sufficient conditions for a rule, as it holds for every possible case; therefore, one cannot give a complete description of it, or rather, one cannot one infer from the substantive case that one as sufficiently described the rule).

item.title: "Free will" debates, rituals in misuse of language
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Nonphilosophers, and even some philosophers, often conflate the idea of "Libertarian Freedom" with "Transcendental Free Will." This is done in such a way that the negative features of political, social, and economic freedoms, involved in the concept of Libertarian Freedom, become mirrored with pseudo-concepts in the transcendental, where political tyrants and market pressures are treated as if they were metaphysical facts-of-the-matter. One draws the wrong consequence that because we're always under some societal norm or other, this is just like being pinned down by some metaphysical ball and chain. But it must be reminded that a bunch of politicians, for instance, does not equate to some metaphysical fact of reality. Moreover, there's no reason to treat transcendental freedom as if it were something which could be won by popular vote; indeed, it cannot be "won" at all. That is, conversely, there's no reason to "attack it" or "dissent" to it. It isn't a feature of reality in the way a political tyrant or fascist dictator are features of reality. Largely, this "free will" debate has come about due to an inattentiveness to the demarcations which undergird our everyday language. It is a case where technical terms, or façon de parler, have unfortunately overlapped, and we are left misguided, led astray by, and dueling over terms peculiarly crossed by wire, inherited from antiquated idioms (mental pictures) of the Enlightenment.

item.title: Pragmatics and the Gatekeepers between language games
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Let's first get a clear statement of the position I am taking. It is more so a skeptical question, a position-in-limbo, as it were. I warn you, it may appear to you that I am in search of necessary and sufficient conditions, but I am indeed not. It would be a fool's errand to look for such things between and in language games. Largely, my philosophical method isn't straightforward or "to the point"; I see no reason that it should be. So, this may just come off as a barrage of questioning (many-questions fallacy), but, at the same time, I have no argument to win or prove, but rather a line of inquiry I should wish to explore. But first, one simple question: Wittgenstein exchanged the picture metaphor for the tool metaphor. As a caricature, and perhaps as sometimes useful, many identify these metaphors as capturing in large part the philosophical orientation of Wittgenstein's Early and Late periods, respectively. Wittgenstein recanted his earlier views, almost immediately, but indeed, it seems as if he stepped from one overarching language game into another: The game wherein one is keen on representation of something and the other wherein one isn't keen on much of anything, but is nevertheless doing something meaningful. Of course, Wittgenstein was always concerned with what he himself was up to and what a representation has to do with what is represented. But he soon realized that he was doing things to his own agenda in virtue of taking up some agenda or other; thus, he realized that he had to investigate exactly what he was doing, or what he could intelligibly say he was doing, as he was doing it (Philosophical Investigations as an introspective fugue on the linguistic pretensions of a foundationalist philosopher interlocked with, perhaps, an anti-foundationalist). More concretely, Wittgenstein anticipated SJ Gould's "non-overlapping magisteria" and enshrined for a philosophical age the idea of language games or "realms," historically originating in Descartes and his Method (the Realm of Science as opposed to the Realm of the Divine). It's unfortunate that the appellation involves the word "game"; but at the same time that it is so is of utmost significance: People live and die, all the same, for football, and whether one thinks it is silly or not is a misguided question. Calling such behavior "silly," of course, is no attempt to understand it or participate in the game itself. Specifically, some of us say: No look, I'm a scientist, I follow The Method [of my tradition, however far back it goes], I cannot be bothered with religious posits and theory. It obviously doesn't respect my fundamental principle(s). But this in itself seems artificial to me, and that's about the only argument I can give. Explicitly claiming: "No! They're two separate realms!" sounds similar to rival gangs in a high school shouting that their colors are more fundamental and consistent with their school's pride, supposing they have any, just to wind up the other gang. In one sense, one doesn't really need to stand up on a stage before self-described "atheists" and preach to the choir as if that is some how maintaining the political inertia of their group, as if Richard Dawkins is somehow ensuring that religion doesn't enter the laboratory. Speaking as a philosopher, as he attempts to do, all he could possibly achieve is to leave everything as it proverbially is. My question/position is related to the shift Wittgenstein underwent, the adjustment or moving away from the picture metaphor. As you may guess, the picture metaphor is perhaps the fundamental principle of science. If you demand of, say, religious language in such a way that is parasitic on the picture metaphor, and you do not realize this, you will simply be begging the question in a very fundamental way. (Where one imperializes on the sense of the word "evidence.") Now, it seems, Wittgenstein made the jump from one metaphor to another, albeit with much strife and personal grief in his life, but nevertheless he did it in one life. In a sense, he was "secularly born again." So it seems, such a language game shift is one that occurs within a person. But yet, we have this concept of "language game" where we attempt to establish it between persons. And this is my fundamental question. Can one say of herself: I am of this language game, and so are they: We choose the picture metaphor, whereas the tool metaphor simply is not the basis of our work. (As opposed to sociologists who claim that scientists cannot speak intelligibly of objectivity because they are social entities.) Wittgenstein warns us to not be fooled by systematicity in language and that we not be presumptive by way of apprehending all grammar as uniform in virtue of surface structure ("distrust of grammar"). Like so, philosopher's like John Austin subsequently lamented the fact that many philosophers presume that all language is in the business of fact-stating. (As if we were all quasi-scientists, as if religious folk were nothing more than low grade lab assistants in need of better training.) Aside: Is religious language only in the business of fact-stating? And what are we doing, as atheists, when we criticize them from the picture metaphor, if we do, as I and I think Wittgensteinian's and ordinary language philosophers claim? Eh. I suppose there will be a part 2.

item.title: The world and its chores
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
A world we rebuild under the temerity of our fingertips,
Grasping at all odds and evenly equidistant obstructions
To a lyric of our gasping and heaving, chanting and moving

This world all here heavenly and good above our skinny
Arms, not outright wrong but almost ghastly, illuminates
Every where and when before our field of spirituality

A lulling world this is, palatable to we who transpose spheres —
Planet shifters, cosmic drifters, mountainous engineers
Clear the virtuous radiance black wherebefore vacuity limitless

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Ridiculously major EDIT.

item.title: The Anthropological and the Political
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: “A society, in part, is defined by those questions of which it refuses to take a position” (Gaita). We may observe a society from two stations: the Anthropological (external) and the Political (internal). These perspectives are such that  we orient ourselves and our investigation of cultural concepts. At bottom we are concerned with the thriving and existence of certain concepts within a culture, whether a concept can be said to be active or passive, explicit or tacit, normative or ignored, etc. (whether a concept can be said to exist within a culture and what exactly this amounts to). The Anthropologist, or the external view, is concerned with the measure and concrete limits of a concept, the grounds for its application by those to whom the concept is vibrant, active, employed, cognizant, etc. The external view is concerned with the pattern and strict behavior of a concept or set of. Certain conditions are met which ground the successful or unsuccessful application of a concept. Conditions may either be necessary or sufficient, or both. One has successfully applied or used a concept when the sufficient conditions for its application are met. Without question it is unclear that a concept ever is employed sufficiently, or with maximal success. For the most part, pragmatic constraints on conversation determine the meaning of “successful application of a concept.” However, at minimum, it seems to me, the lack of any necessary condition whatever, as explicit or implicit, determines the failure of application. (That is, one is not speaking within the language game of that culture. One may, we might say, be introducing a novel necessary condition or at least proposition a new condition as a candidate to complete or partial sufficiency.) If I say of a cat that it is on a unicorn, it is required of me to be speaking of a thing which meets the condition or set of conditions of cat-hood. At the same time, the preposition’s grounding, the article’s, etc must each lend to the (complete) sufficient condition of the proposition “The cat is on a unicorn.” This proposition has a sense which is grounded by the necessary conditions of its constituents which themselves lend to the first-order necessary conditions of the proposition itself. The constituents’ condition sit at the second-order, or of a lower order generally. We may say that a statement does not record if one of its lower order necessary conditions is not met. So, if “on” does not accord with the actual state of affairs, we may say that the speaker has failed to properly apply the concept “on” and has at the same time failed to acknowledge the actual ground of the appropriate preposition, say “under.” Questions of this sort may be entertained from the external view. The Anthropologist is concerned with whether speakers successfully or unsuccessfully apply concepts at local contexts, intervals, where, when, why (descriptively). From the internal perspective or viewpoint, we will be concerned with the correct or incorrect application of  a concept. “Beauty,” by Kant’s standard, was seen as Political in the way I shall describe. The concept of beauty, under Kantian presentation, was seen as, when invoked by a speaker, a candidate of some form. The speaker intends for hearers to agree or to at least consider whether the item, object or artifact in question is by agreement beautiful. We should not say “objectively beautiful.” The speaker is raising the object in question as a candidate for a policy. If two persons consider a thing beautiful, then this bolsters their political weight (as I see it), not the ontological status of the object itself. The objective or subjective nature of the item, this status, is a question of another order. I cannot immediately see what the metaphysical pedigree of an item has to do with two persons in discussion and whether or not they agree on explicit or potentially explicit properties. This is one feature of the internal view with which I am interested: candidacy of an object wherein it might receive a new property. Does “beauty” emerge from an object? Is “beauty” a relation between agreement and the object? That is: Let’s disregard the question of “beauty as related to a subjective state.” Let us regard beauty as a concept which bears a relation to agreements or events of agreement. More generally, what is the ontological status of agreement? (Ignore questions as to the ontological status of “beautiful objects.”)

item.title: Sign of a metaphysician
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: A new term need not require a new entity. (Ockham's Razor.) Metaphysicians, as they exist in every discourse, will introduce a sign for the purpose of achieving some explanation; or perhaps to make a description more readily accessible to the learner's mind. A vulgar metaphysician will leave the pupil with a captivating idiom yet a lurch, chaotic ontology. (More questions than answers.) But we say: That dichotomy does not worry us. Let us mind the utility of the new idiom. In many cases, I believe, the idiom itself is a motivating factor in continuation of a theory or conscious theoretical perspective. (Fetishism of the linguistic; inertia of a cultural property by the unconscious; "elegance" and "simplicity" of a theory.) We see, then, that Ockham's Razor takes us for a spin. We say to ourselves: Do not exceed the necessary quantity of things while being fascinated with the aesthetic quality of a theory. And if elegance requires a more rich ontology? (Ontological commitment by the viewer-aesthetic.)

item.title: Mereological nihilism
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: If A and B stand in a parthood relation, then A and B compose C. Mereological nihilism denies this for any given set of objects, C1-Cn. Often the nihilist of this sort will make distinctions between types of objects, where justification for those distinctions are in order. Where C1 may be permitted as a composite, or whole, to one brand of nihilism, D1 may be rejected as a non-composite. D1, then, consists of no proper parts insofar as those parts stand in no relation to one another. Often the argument in defense of mereological nihilism is epistemic. It is claimed that our perceptual faculties (olfactory, visual, etc) are conditioned for perception of composites where composites in fact do not exist. It amounts to a facon de parler our talk of persons, souls, the material, the nonmaterial. Though, I rarely see the nonmaterial under the analytic microscope. Governments, legal systems, theories, treatises, etc. rarely become those which are denied as bearers of proper parts. It is difficult, I suppose, to draw a conclusion that a democratic government, in the way we talk about its composing entities, of citizen-voters and branches or officials, is nothing more than a manner of speaking when we know this already: a conceptual scheme. But I doubt it reasonable to doubt that governments exists; I fail to see that one could take this kind of skepticism very far, beyond the 101 (of chairs and cats on mats). The object of study, then, for the mereological nihilist seems to consist of the object of study of science. Those mundane macrophysical objects we're in the habit of treating as if composite. The presumption is that only everyday objects are the suspicious beasts. But persons, propositions, thoughts? How do we support the conclusion that I do not exist? Am I a collection of parts? Presumably at the "critical" level of thinking, I am nothing more than a string of contiguous time slices sewn together by the third-person's untrained (or should I say "metaphysically trained"?)  eye. One question is the import of such a view as nihilism. If it is fact of the human condition that we ease into the perception of composites, then it is a feature of our underpinnings, that which is beneath our language and perhaps our pre-cognitive pretensions.

item.title: Permutation on a thought on the grammar of the Same
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
All too often I see the argument: Suppose there is a law-like relation between Xs and Ys. Where X occurs, Y is guaranteed to occur by law. The laws which are most vivid to us are physical laws. So we say: If you were to input X into Z (the conditions under which the law applies; if its a law, it should manifest as such given or without human involvement), then you get Y. If one inputs X into Z and gets non-Y, then one must deny that one was in possession of a proper X or one must give up that Z (as a set of conditions) are coherent or valid or cohere with the world. Suppose we put a person into some set of circumstances. In any given case, the person behaves this or that way; at the same time, the person chooses this or that way. The argument holds that a person only has a finite capacity for behavior. Similarly, choice is viewed as a finite capacity, in just the way behavior is viewed as a finite capacity. But this is confused. It abuses the sense of "choice" which carries with it potentiality of a kind very different from behavior. Of course we are wont to say choice has intentionality, where behavior does not. At a very minimum, our ontologies must incur a distinction. But does this warrant the name dualism? I see this term thrown around so loosely. The denial of psycho-physical laws amounts to dualism? I fail to see that this is the case. Since dualism is an ontological stance, I fail to see how the denial a positive ontological claim amounts to the admittance of a new set within our ontology. If we deny that minds are brains, are we left now with minds under the old conceptual scheme of brains or a new conceptual scheme? The dualist needs to answer the question.For the most part, "dualism" is often paraded on assumption that minds are just an addition to our assumed conceptual scheme. That is, many "dualists" enjoy the latter reception as if having taken it in virtue of vagueness.
