It's like we're dealing with a unique and exceptional conceptual scheme (dualism), but we're actually presented with monism+n. What's "n"? Well, just about anything whatever. Usually, the "dualist" opts for a shrug of the shoulder or fuzzy feelings. Saying that two exist while never stating what the second is means that you've permitted into your ontology a region which is mysterious. Vague language perpetuates that mystery. There's no truth behind the I-don't-know-what-but-you-get-what-I-mean; no truth behind appeal to an outright and obviously alien idiom. Really, I should say, it's nonsensical. Somehow the goings-on of physical phenomena give rise to new properties spiritual, unassailable, unanalyzable, ineffable. This is dualism? At least with Descartes we had an straightforward ontological mode of thought. Under these postmodern gimmicks we have uncouth dualism. Dualism which consists of the physical (rigidly defined, yet "infinitely complex") and everything else (vague, yet infinitely complex).

Grammar of the Same

I was going to say something about numerical and nonnumerical identity. That's where the "argument" I referred to earlier comes in. There are no psycho-physical laws. Moreover, there are no psychological laws. The conclusion that one would behave the same if put into Z assumes the existence of psychological laws and psycho-physical laws (since the argumentative resources -- the premises -- of the argument hinge on physical assumptions). Looking for psychological properties under the trial and error of experimentation; the faulty assumption is that psychological properties are governed by law. First we must address the question: What is a psychological law? The assumption is that psychological properties are caused by physical properties. This is innocuous, depending on our interpretation of "cause." We could just as easily, and more plausibly, construe "cause" as "provides the necessary conditions for." A cog in the greater machine, if removed, for instance, may very well undermine the machine's goal. So in a sense, the cog does cause the goal to come about. It causes cog X, X causes Y, and transitivity all the way up, if we are permitted to ignore "it"'s cause. The equivocation is that cause means determines; or that "gives rise to" -- a piece of vague language -- just means determines. One must look from a broader perspective to say that the greater machine determines its effect. From this view, the cog certainly did not determine nor did it determine the greater machine's effect. It played a part, just as with physical properties. My brain states play a part in my psychological "states," whatever these are supposed to mean, but brain states do not determine the latter. My resulting choice to act morally or to be optimistic are not determined by some "lower-order" brain functioning or behavior. In order to prove that it does, we must suppose that "acting morally" and "being optimistic" are properties which conform to some law under a given theory. The whole argument, then, uses what "law" means, on some supposition. But either there are laws to "acting morally" or there are not. If we say there are not laws, what we are in turn saying is that morality conforms to no regularity. But is being morally consistent the same as appearing to be morally consistent? The laws of morality, on a Kantian perspective, are not laws which are perceptible in the way the laws of physics are. One does not infer their existence in the same way; the properties in one ontology are of a different sort than the other (moral worth, duties versus mundane physical objects). Psychological laws are the same way (beliefs, hopes, etc).

item.title: The Unpoetic
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
We spoke on the plight of poetry in our age,
In a time where flagrant novelty shines brightest --
As an indication of the nihilistic lullabies with which
We charm ourselves to sleep
I cannot say I know much about the state of letters,
Of the heroic sort it lacks, from what I can muster:
A learned hand desperately compels itself from nothing;
Into an accidental structure it embodies it in body echoes
A lessened spirit lingers above license, as if to lambaste
Longing lines, loins unto itself, too languid to entertain
Even the licentious barren beneath anchored intellects
Like I said, the state of it all, weary as it is, cannot be
A thing of which I know; but I receive heretical howls
From a higher viking, wounded in the foreground
Of what may be the most tempting torture to us

item.title: Value relativism, cultural complexity
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: The proposition that "all values are relative" can be judged as either a description or an evaluative. It is usually taken as a justification for tolerance of some value-proposition or normative judgment. "We ought to tolerate rapists" or "Different cultures carry a certain significance relative to our own" presuppose a normative judgment, namely a judgment originated in one's tolerance. Nothing about the "descriptive" aspect of the proposition that all values are relative entails which interpretive position one ought to take within the evaluative aspect. The descriptive aspect goes without saying. It is no philosophically interesting question whether a set of people, X, hold some value or belief. It is no interesting question whether people here or there believe that this or that thing is of importance. It is similarly uninteresting at what time it is believed and the demarcating conditions of those beliefs. These questions are philosophically uninteresting and are not relevant to the normative aspect of the proposition. The proposition has no compelling force as a normative proposition if it says nothing more than: "Differences!" So what normative interjection does it make? What about the proposition obliges us to see value in said differences, supposing there are substantial differences to be acknowledged? We may be left with the simpler question of what is a value? What does it mean to hold a value, especially a cross-ethical value such as tolerance? Does such a value even exist, despite its being overtly problematic? Or is it artificial in that only a critical mind may perceive it as valuable? I draw a distinction between the intuitive and the critical moral thinker, much the way R. M. Hare does; moreover, I attach this distinction onto the artificial and the organic. These latter terms are anthropological, heuristic and technical. They draw on the question: What does it mean for a cultural belief, tradition or value to arise? It would seem that tolerance is essential to the coming about of artificial values relative to a cultural. The problematic, however, is just how close to the "intuitive" or the organic of a culture is to the critical moral thinker within that culture. And again, it should be reminded the question of whether tolerance presupposes a critical mind, something distinguished from the intuitive. I draw a close connection between the organic and the intuitive. The intuitive applies to particular moral thinkers, those who think in terms, or I should say from the internal aspect, of a moral domain. The moral domain itself may be either organic or artificial. A critical moral thinker, or set of, may be that motivating force which gives strength to the artificiality or contrivance of a moral system. What is artificial may be best introduced by examples: legal systems, political parties, aristocracy of varying degrees on various matrices (wealth, esteem, notoriety in sport, in the artistic, etc., the media and fame). The artificial within a culture is that which is easily perceived as recursive, as the unto-itself. We may view, in the States, the media as the unto-itself insofar as its fuel is its audience and its audience in need of it. We may observe it as Spinoza judges a collection: It becomes an unto-itself and as such it is a whole, a quasi-closed system, but nevertheless a closed system inasmuch as it should be treated. Only a pressing but useless skeptic would advance atomic or mereological arguments to the point where it is denied that an unto-itself exists. It may not be justifiable as such, but it certainly exists. On the issue of its justification is that exact issue on which one stands atop the question: What is its value? More generally, what is its relation to the organic of its culture. Should we tolerate unto-themselves? What does it mean to tolerate an unto-itself? Does it require a critical moral thinker to perceive such a thing? Do unto-themselves arises in virtue of critical perception? Let us draw a distinction between horizontal and vertical tolerance. I say vertical insofar as tolerance may be seen as an internal motivating force for cultural complexity. An existing cultural belief may be seen as tolerable so long as it is internally constrained by some the cultural net of value. Vertical tolerance is the embodiment of that net; it identifies the net in the most general way. Horizontal tolerance allows for the infiltration of other cultures insofar as those cultures bring about complexity. "All values are relative" must be viewed, at minimum, under these methodological tools: horizontal and vertical tolerance, the organic and the artificial, and the intuitive and critical moral thinker. However, before all of this, one can -- and it may be essential to do this -- expound upon the descriptive and the evaluative aspects of the proposition; namely, on how these aspects logically relate to each another.

I am sleeping on the edge of summer With a will like a melody All cognition enshrined behind A shifting wall lacking integrity
Cognates to those mentioned before: Pure yet scrambled in complexity Anchor themselves by ornate demand; Ransomed, dripping wounded in unanimity
The beginning of a daunting departure Fails in the midst of spring's entreaty Where florid deeds as rank impositions, Uplift unconcealed thinking's immediacy

item.title: Long-winded noise-making involving predicate logic
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Claim: The propositions Some coffee cups are black and Not all coffee cups are black entail a contradiction when conjoined. 1 ?x(Cx & Bx) P 2 ~?x(Cx ? Bx) P 3 ~?x~(Cx & Bx) 1QE 4 ?x~(Cx ? Bx) 2QE The important lines are 1 and 4. 4 follows from 2 by quantifier exchange; so, we can ignore line 2. 3 is more complex than 1; so, it won't do us any good. With 1 and 4 we're now left with the question of which shall be first to take an instantiated variable. But in truth, it really does not matter, as for every new existential proposition one must invoke a new name for the entity of that proposition. 1 is about at least one coffee up; we may reformulate it as There is at least one thing that is a coffee cup and is black. It's truth or falsity hinges upon events, states of affairs, etc. If a coffee cup fails to exist, or happens not to exist, then we have a presupposition failure. We may have a nonsense, depending on one's interpretation of linguistic phenomena like failure to successfully refer. These points raise the question of whether existential proposition presuppose the existence of the objects which, by that presupposition, correspond to the expressed terms; and whether they do this in virtue of their form. 2 may be reformulated: It is not the case that [if] it is a coffee cup, [then] it is black. The "it" is sufficiently general enough to grasp the universal scope of the proposition, to give it the "universal claim" status. In most cases we call such claims theorems. Is there any ontological commitment from a theorem? It certainly is not a prediction. In uttering such a claim, one is not suggesting that a coffee cup is likely to be black if it is indeed a coffee cup. One is, rather, picking out a relation between two classes of thing. There is a question of whether an empty class is meaningful; or rather, whether one can meaningfully talk on classes which are known to be empty. The presumption, then, is that whatever class "coffee cup" is, it's at least instantiated by one member; for, why should we even concern ourselves with a discussion that involves an empty class? If the class is uninstantiated, then how far would we get in "checking" the property, namely blackness, against any of its members? Perhaps the intuition that our theorem commits us to at least one object to instantiate the subject term class. However, where does that leave us with the predicate term? In any event, it's clear by the rules of predicate logic that there is no inconsistency when we conjoin these propositions. If we assume that line 2 must be "meaningful" by having some instantiated class, then we get, naturally, line 4. At line 4, at least, we may quell our worry by acknowledging its existential nature (its outer symbol). The proposition, or theorem, may be meaningful in that it talks about some thing; but, by the rule of logic we must admit that its about some thing other than the existential proposition to which it is connected.

item.title: Varied Vanilla Arguments for Knowledge Skepticism
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
1 If one knows some proposition, then [it is all right to say that] one is absolutely certain of it. 2 No one ever is absolutely certain of anything; or, [it is never all right] to say that one is absolutely certain. 3 No one ever knows [the truth] of a proposition.
1 If X knows a proposition, then X is absolutely certain of it. 2 No one can possibly have absolute certainty. 3 No one can possibly have knowledge.
1 If one knows that a proposition is true, then one is absolutely certain that it is true. 2 No one ever is absolutely certain that a proposition is true. 3 No one ever has knowledge [that a proposition is true].

item.title: A brain, more or less, in a vat (roughly)
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: The idea rides on the coat-tail of a Cartesian Skeptical mood. S'pose our brains could be duplicated down to their very corpuscles*. By this all the grammar that grounds our concept of duplication is permitted. Thus, we get to make analogous points which compare trading brains for lunch-money, etc. A brain is nothing more, it seems, than a bargaining chip. The problem is not with physicalism or materialism, but with the grammar. We inevitably wind up committing ourselves to an flummoxed and tenuous idiom in virtue of viewing a brain as roughly some arbitrary thing, on the one hand, while, in some ways, perhaps for the sake of argument, aiming to preserve the peculiar proximity we intuit or have philosophical pretense to insofar as thinking of each of our own personal brains. Look at the soul. Is it just some thing that you juggle with? Surely one cannot. It's non-material. So naturally one cannot juggle with one's soul (in any meaningful sense of the term [to juggle]). Well, we all see this is false; for which meaningful senses of the term are relevant given all use in language? I am free to metaphor, am I not? But this question adds complexity to the matter; complexity of which I am not talented enough to wrangle. Nevertheless, is a brain just some thing that just so happens to mean its possessor? Well, does my brain refer to me, whose brain it is? How can that which constitutes but one of the parts that may complete me be that which also picks me out uniquely? Is it a proper part to begin with? One may certainly identify my having been here or there, given some trace of me which was left. Or, one may infer that I was asleep some time in the recent past, given the relevant or perhaps conventional evidence. But am I identified through my brain in just this way? Is my brain nothing more than a set of contingent properties on which I supervene? The formulaic question is: Can there be a change in me-stuff without a change in my brain-stuff? Those who buy supervenience, under the duo-scheme, affirm that there cannot. Eh. Enough of this thought.

item.title: Zen Coding

item.title: @class' dual agenda
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Microformats exploits the @class to provide meta-data on the content layer, given some document. What this means is that the content layer and the structural layer are thus conceptually connected through that attribute. One benefit of this is that the @class is part of the core attribute list [1]; so, we as developers need not worry about validation errors that would arise in employing @rel where illegal or the headache of some custom DTD or DTD extension. But I feel this method is conceptually flawed. I buy into a rough taxonomy found in more recent practices of Web developers — or "front-end engineers," as we are now coming to be called [2] — wherein Web design projects are viewed as bearing four major layers:
  • the content layer
    • content writing
    • copyrighting
    • SEM/SEO writing
    • blogging
    • meaningful content
    • keyword gymnastics
  • the structural layer
    • markup (HTML)
    • natural SEO
    • RDF
    • structural semantics*
  • the presentation layer
    • isomorphic* CSS
  • the behavorial layer
    • JavaScript library
    • DOM Scripting (validation, "DHTML", etc)
    • JavaScript application or program
  • the data/server layer
    • Server-side scripts/program
    • Database application/model
On my view, the Microformats method is conceptually flawed. It takes an aspect of the structural layer, namely in its commitment to structural semantics, and employs that aspect (@class) in a purpose outside of its scope, thus mixing up the attribute in the additional commitment to natural SEO/RDF. The attribute, thus, becomes conflicted, confused.

A problem of conceptual elegance

I find, as I'm sure any developer would, back-end or front-end, it irritating enough to see class="padding-250". This description is too literal; inappropriate and under-utilized is that poor attribute. It is, by the structural semanticist of the Web, effectively meaningless. It says nothing more than an inline-style. I find it similarly irritating to see class="widget-object" 20 lines before class="street-address". Here the @class undertakes both a structural-semantic role and an Microformat/resource-descriptive role. My only real argument is that this is conceptually inelegant, especially since we have @rel and newfangled attributes being popularized by Dublin Core. And true. I may simply have a naive understanding of the relationship between RDFa/eRDF, RDF in general, and Microformats. They may be fighting different battles, where they overlap harmoniously rather than compete. They may be concerned with semantically marking up different kinds of data. But I doubt it. When I see property="vcard:street-address" (RDFa) and class="street-address" (Microformats), I cannot help stop short of the conclusion that each camp has a dog in the meta-data war.

Getting proscriptive

It's clear to me that the @class should be strictly used to add richer description, or "micro-description," to the structural layer, not the content layer. If not for the specific purpose I argue for, at least it should be constrained to one purpose. But it's clear by the the W3C's specification of its primary role ("As a style sheet selector") and the intuitive link @class has with the presentation layer, we should opt for no longer employing it in just the way the Microformats method requires. Granted, the W3C gives it the secondary role: "For general purpose processing by user agents" [3]; so, its "scope" is more or less up to the winds. But, for one, this applies to browser manufacturers; I'm addressing development practices. Two, scoping leaves the attribute too "loose," as it doesn't tell us much of anything toward particular non-stylesheet application. That said, I recommend that the attribute only be used as a bridge between the structural and presentation layers.

item.title: Thought & Theory
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Conceptual Grounding

  • Structure of thought (Grammar/Syntax)
  • Content of thought (Cognition/Semantics)
  • Presentation of thought (Expression/Appearance)
  • Behavior of thought (Actuality/Effect; Perlocutionary)

Modal Forms

  • Necessity/Contingency (Potentiality/Actuality/Possibility)
  • Temporality (Future/Past/Present; more basic: before/now/later/ongoing)
  • Existentiality/Universality

Epistemic Forms

  • A priori/A posteriori

Linguistic Forms

  • Analyticity/Syntheticality

Expositive Forms (Postures)

  • Descriptive/Explanatory

Pragmatic Forms

  • Entailment
  • Implicature
  • Presupposition

Deflationist Forms

  • Explorative
  • Expressive

Speech Acts

  • Illocutionary (in)
  • Locutionary (of)
  • Perlocutionary (by)

(On) Truth

  • Deflationism
  • Pragmatism
  • Correspondence
  • Coherence

Of the above, only the Deflationist sits not unsettled and unflinchingly silent at the syntactic construction: 'P' is true iff 'P'; that is to say, no identification of the predicate "true" to some other complex conceptual situation/evaluation is considered.

The point here is greater than merely rejecting that truth is:

  • (perceived) "effects" [=Pragmatic Theory of Truth (for the rest of my life, henceforth: ToT)] (obviously the assumption here, for jollies: "perception is reality" -- or: what can be perceived is a candidate for the Real -- hur hur;;;;I suppose it's "anthropic reasoning," reverse anthropic? Eh);
  • mapping to "facts" [=Correspondence ToT] (agents producing from linguistic components propositional senses about the World as Fact, etcetcetcdcs);
  • or beliefs held in (rational) conformity with some kind of idio-personal epistemic gestalt-web [=Coherence ToT]

For the deflationist, it's not merely a matter of denying these substantive thesis on truth, but rather reframing the concept of truth, emphasizing its expressive aspect.

Values, Normative Principles, Normative Epistemology

  • Normative/Descriptive (thinking; and making sense of normativity at varying levels of description of thinking)
  • Rationality (acknowledgment of conditions, or grounds, for the reward of "rationality" in the multiplicity of the cultural)
  • Justification (internal/external)
  • Belief generation/acquisition (ontology of belief/rules that constraint or ground "right belief," the "right to believe")

Inquiry

What would an a priori necessary proposition look like? A proposition which one knows independent of experience but is necessarily true? What kind of evidence? Does evidence frame truth, or truth evidence? Is any modal proposition

item.title: Moral surface (ramble)
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Utilitarianism is a euphemism for being selfish. It sates the "philosopher" who wishes to nurture justification from a manure borne of desire. From this we receive the "higher" and the "lower" in thinking. In a smokescreen we are led to believe that "giving a justification" is in some way connected with pleasure, and pleasure toward our own ends. As if to say: Well, what else would you have us do? We did not engineer ourselves to have just the desires we do act upon. We may as well account for them and record their occurrence. Here we see the anthropologist has become seduced by the external culture, into believing in belonging. (Internalization.) Again: Everyone has a limit, a point to which questioning comes to an end, a moral space. We may see certain undiscussable questions, as I call them, as "moral contradictions." Has anyone ever used a squared-circle in an intelligible sentence? Let us uncover just this feature of geometric and language in morality and language. Let us find moral statements which are undiscussable because morally unintelligible. I suppose the question, as most relevant, is whether certain kinds of desires or acts should be philosophically defended at all. The utilitarian presupposes a horizontal moral surface, on which to build an edifice of moral worth; whereas the deontologist presupposes that the moral surface has a form, but a stacked one. Looking upwards or downwards, from one's vantage, is nothing more than a quibble.

item.title: Analogical powers/proto-scientific linguistic philosophy
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: In order for one to be able to say of another that a rule has been followed, there must exist the possibility of failing to follow the given rule. (And what this means for saying of oneself that one has obeyed a rule.) We may be inclined to think that the less concrete, or transparent, the rule, greater is the subjection to possible misapplication. Guidelines and expressed doctrine may be viewed as transparent, for we can see directly their inner spirit. We extract their intention from their markings and interconnections. A spirit is a logical whole; a whole which demands in virtue of its being complete. May we say that a half-push or a inchoate article moved anything? (But something occurred!) On the other hand, "moral systems" and cultural underpinnings shunt from this steadfast notion of rule, one on which fables and computation rest with almost equivalent dependency. We sought for our wholes within stipulated muddy waters; and in stupidity we wonder at why we fail to grasp at a core; or even a morsel of propositional rigidity, that of which we dream while under fugue of rationality. (We draw a connection between stipulation and application.) DH pushed a thesis which feigns illumination; and it is an old hat: analogy as, or rather is (for sake of irony), the core of cognition. It is warmed over Wittgensteinianism (family resemblance). Moreover, since I am in that all-to-frequent irreverent mood, I should say what I call his approach: concept anthropology. It echoes from the homebase, I feel, of the relativist's philosophical penchant. We must pay more attention to something; let us be agnostic about conclusions -- "but wait, it is forthcoming!" This latter portion, the scare quote, is the fantasy science gambles with. It is the conclusion: pay attention to the use of words. Wittgenstein thought that we should look, rather than think, about our ourselves, our ways of life, and draw relationships from these findings -- not discoveries proper. These connections establish the meaning of words; the relation between human whole and a syntactic formula. "Is an analogy a function?" -- and this is nothing more than the pretension of functionalism. For, if we broaden our concept of analogy to include novel, because obscure or unstipulated, cases, then we should expect to force their placement as analogy by way of grounding them as function. (Language is this!) Thus, a "higher analogy" is one with which we readily identify; a "lower analogy" is one which, on this thesis (but I should really say worldview), we do not. But there is the identification of an analogy and the identification with. Analogy with this broad sense requires that we, if critical, ask whether the analogies we identify are in any way connected, in a logical fashion since we are talking on the philosophical, to analogies beneath the surface, as it were; those analogies we identify with. By "identify with" I mean to invoke analogies which are lacking in explicit, propositional form. Of this sort we are constituted as members of a linguistic community. Picture a being more apt to "retrieve" a memory (make a "connection", draw an analogy in the broad sense) because she hails from community P rather than Q under such-and-such (linguistic) circumstances. (But where do we find P or Q before or behind the neurophysical description?) In a sense, we identify with our lower levels of "connection-making" in virtue of the analogy. We call suppressed connect-making "analogy"; but in virtue of what? A drawing of a connection between the experience of "making a connection" and one's linguistic practice. To add clarity: from the third person, we are identified by our analogy-making. I can say of myself: Only I would draw such a connection; but this is vacuous, for only I have the experiences that I have. We are left with the question: What is the content of a subterranean analogy? Have we begun a false departure from dualism with yet another undisclosed admonition to schematization? A empty conclusion: Words are embedded in our use. In order to discover facts about cognition, we must travel along the fault lines (highways, roadways, wrinkles, folds) of linguistic practice. And then we say: "Language is manifold! Appreciate its complexity!" -- in the face of a science of which we romanticize.

Familial sensations come with a strict irregularity, Of which few have patience; tangibility to situations Is what grounds their truth, under a procedure

item.title: Defense of Zen Coding
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: I disagree with the criticisms that Zen Coding: (1) adds unnecessary complexity, (2) will lead developers to ignore semantic principles, (3) introduces spaghettism and (4) requires that one learn a new language. (1) In what way does it add complexity? In terms of output, you’re getting nothing more than what you would have coded by hand anyway. You, as the developer, determine the complexity of your HTML. ZC has no “norms” or “principles” to learn that intrude on existing best practice in HTML. It’s just a shortcut to syntax combination; concatenations on your dime. (2) Indeed, it is a proto-description language (a mark-up language for a mark-up language, or something more or less close to this). But to call it a mark-up language in any technical or substantial sense would be erroneous commentary; it’s really just hyperbolic. To be a full description language, the shortcuts would have to have meaning in their own right. However, the plugin author has made it clear that ZC purpose is “not to create a new programming language to make you [think about how to write abbreviation].” When you write with ZC, not in ZC, you are still thinking in terms of HTML. One is building an image before one’s mind as to what, say, the structure of the document will ultimately be. ZC helps you get to that conclusion faster. (Why am I arguing for code snippets? In what way does any criticism laid here not also apply to mere use of code snippets?) If you want to call it a proto-descriptive language, that’s fine. But it’s really just a “post-it note” language. You’re referring to existing HTML syntax only. ZC introduces no constraint on validity. If you want to make invalid mark-up, you can do this with ZC as well. But there’s no such thing as ZC invalidity. All you can do in this vein is fail on syntactic operation. Mark-up languages have validity and semantics. ZC leans on HTML’s validity, and it has no semantics. (3) This is absurd. You, as the developer, introduce the combinatorial possibilities that ZC makes more easily printable to the screen. There’s only as much spaghetti as your competence, prowess and grace will allow. (4) Basic arithmetic? CSS? CSS-like syntax is exploded into HTML syntax. Where is the “new language”? And even then, developers are expected to pick up no more than 5 “new to HTML” principles from CSS. Principles that are conceptually ingrained, or at least should be, already (after a sufficient understanding of CSS). But I do agree: Grouping makes sense. Parent-child relationships presuppose the possibilities of multiple children to one parent. Without this feature, ZC incurs diminished conceptual integrity. It feels wrong, on many occasions, because I have a picture of my desired mark-up before my mind, and without grouping, I am presented an obstacle. Thus, I have to split my ZC string into parts. It’s less than irritating, I’ll admit, but I still think the conceptual argument laid out above has merit. ZC at present does not seem conceptually, or theoretically, pure. Also, the arguments about RDFa hold no water. RDF and RDF-like languages have their own implementation problems. Once those are sorted out, ZC may likely increase productivity and speed. RDF is time-consuming. ZC saves time by mapping mark-up possibilities to “dynamic post-it notes”, etc etc.

item.title: Perfect(ing) IE9
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Microsoft has Internet Explorer 9 set for the immediate future: An Early Look At IE9 for Developers And the following commentary captures the Web Developer spirit of opposition toward IEX.
instead of focusing on things like: Direct2D and DirectWrite, please focus on better STANDARDS SUPPORT! Will IE9 support default ECMAScript events instead of stupid IE proprietary ones? Will it support as much css3 as other browsers do? Innovation is fine when you aren't so freaking behind on features other browsers have had for 5 years. Stop innovating until you get IE9 up to speed with CSS, Box model, canvas, SVG, base64, @font-face, etc. Stop trying to create your own APIs before you implement standard ones! Web developers hate you and recommend other browsers because of this asinine behaviour.
So yeah, M$, stop being moronic. Use Webkit.

item.title: Our paradox in aesthetic praxis
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: One says of an automobile "this is a beautiful piece of art"; and a common posture becomes lurched, perhaps. Some may quickly interpret this act as a kind of queer metaphor or at best idiomatic. Those less lenient a misunderstanding -- cultural in nature. And to those even less tolerant, something inappropriate or ungrammatical has taken place. And these responses are manifestations of cultural regions within a society. We may call them units for measurement; but how do we identify them? What makes them a measure? And what makes us assume "that is not what is really meant"? Original intent? Some thematic of a traditionalist programme? (Latent in commonspeakers.) And the act may occur before a photorealist's work. Might one object? or have the same pretensions against, as one may have toward ready-mades and irony?

item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: "Words are loneliness." A word in its meaning must consist of its infinite application. We suppose, then, that the subject under whose use a word is executed must so to possess an eternal kind of feature inherent to it. We say: "The Subject is a diagonal infinity. A vector multiplicity." The structure of a Subject's consciousness is isomorphic with the physical space of its language. A word is presented as a rampant duality of meaning: therein the physical space, but also within the ground for emergence of the physical space. Let us say that physical space is but a an attribute, part of the Multiple. The structure of Subject's consciousness is an attribute, component to the One. This may be the standard interpretation. We see in the physical space manifestations of the Multiple, but we assume that the physical space exists as an infinite inertia; motivation emerges from the static floor: Power accelerates not en tandem to Motivation, but is a logical representation of the Behavior of Motivation. Wittgenstein claims of the mathematical proposition that it has a necessary condition of an extra-mathematical criteria. That is, we say of, truly, a mathematical proposition any number of things only if its sense is connected with our finitistic model of the Multiple, granting that therein the concept of the Multiple, we imply the existence of the One. "A word implies an infinite space" -- but what kind of space? The word is merely a signifier, but we must broaden our notion of such an entity. It is not arbitrary is in presenting, though we may ease into this assumption because we see each signifier as a stage in the becoming of a concept. But our concepts are not arbitrary, especially since metaphorical. The becoming of a word does not entail the becoming of the word. Human use implies meaning. If a word is presented, this will be a stage in the becoming; we will see the word as embodied within a network, a construction (our model). Is the word ever presented? (Intentional localities: ruled under the multiplicity of semantic structures; whereas the latter are grounded in experiential evental sites (gestalt).) A primitive is not more fundamental than that which is basic. An experiential gestalt may be seen as primitive, but it has basic physical properties, yet we see the primitive as more fundamental than its properties. What makes us assume this? Must we bear a layer of human experience. (A cognitive mapping: tying a shoe and causal powers.)

item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Veiled by a word, a syntactic ornament for a community of Observers, and Counters; [behindsuch] flickers an eternal sardonic brutality Imagination demonstrates its limits in the utterance; Or so we assume in our neuro-cognitive musings, Under which formulae-manifestations are granted "A real mood conceals a real mode of existence"; Can there not be a "logic which underpins language"? (( There cannot be a logic to our language ))

item.title: Anarchism and Morality
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: If a thing counts as a proposition, and we see it as such, how much further must we look into the distance to observe its reification? The anarchist towards morality must ask herself the, now self-evident to me, framework-ontological question: Am I noncognitivist about moral propositions? (Simply put: Let us deny that one has a greater wealth (relation and quantification, the scientific) about the moral reality! Let us deny privileged knowledge (authority, the political) by attacking its genealogy! And let us preemptively spoil the earth that may infect us with talk of revelation (the religious)! If we -- the anarchists -- permit the existence of moral propositions, we subsequently allow the ethicist to ask the loaded question, feigning a grandfatherish, Chomskyan certainty: How could one not stand in relation to the moral proposition? ((There must be some (empirical) reason why one should fail to stand in relation to it.)) (The assumption that the amoralist cannot exist in relation to any moral system.) So much work has to be put in to unravel such an ontological commitment. It would be a practical argumentative, perhaps methodological, move for anarchists to give up, explicitly, the belief in moral propositions, before any one becomes enshrined in the domains of festival morality.

item.title: Unimorphic subjectivism
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: If I am a self, then who is the other? -- But let us entreat ourselves to the comparative relation between the self and the other. We may view, and we often find ourselves under such a view, our selves in such-and-such a light, or frame, and the other -- through such a frame. Let us invert without pretense the grounds for apprehension of selves. Let us frame each of our selves through the grounding of the other. Is it morally imperative that we do such a thing? Ought I to do it? Or rather, is it an essential feature (a fact) of cognition that the self as bearing the property of a frame at all possesses such a property in virtue of the gateway of the other. This is not merely walking in the others shoes; this is the possibility of the introspective -- in virtue of the possibility of the frame of the other. I may on occasion discover that I have shoes through the corridor of perception of those external to me, others. "A fact embodies the possibility of thought"; but not a thinking (the objectification analogy). Facts contain, rather, the possibility of thinking, to give grounds for asserting intelligibly that thinking has occurred. We look at grounds and events. A ground is that which much obtain for a fact to exist. But we are flummoxed by the idea of the emergence of facts. Worrisome is the idea that "facts," from an intuitive vantage, were hidden, now no longer concealed: conspicuous to a cultural narrative. (A culture as defined by its facts.) We toss the argument: but the facts may still hitherto remain undisclosed. The presupposition, then, is a potentiation, a strength, toward facts. But we may be motivated, as a culture, toward facts only of which we may "process" or those which reflect grounds. "Facts revealed are those which emerge from events." But the event stands in what way to a grounding? An event in space: and what kind of space? Our definition of space mutates, and thus commits us to, an understanding of emergence. We may just call this the framing of the facts. Yet this sounds pejorative if not trivial. "Under your conceptual scheme, the proposition holds" and the multitude of philosophical platitudes. But can one sincerely utter such a thing? Irony is the resultant of such a possibility. And has one explored the movements within a conceptual scheme? (A counterargument.) We may follow the principles and premises of a scheme, but how does one internalize such a thing? Let us assume that such a thing can be objectified: given contours and on-paper poignancy. We have assume, sure, that a way of life may be jotted down. All possible implementations ground such an image; and has it been transcribed?

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I'm still not sure what this title means. With hope, it means nothing and can be overlook'd.

item.title: The Self and the Stratosphere
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: "Live in fear of a self, but what is there to fear of your self?" -- We picture ourselves embedded within language games, systems wherein entity collide in sometimes rule governed, and in other times chaotic, gestures. The context, when suffocating under the lense of "pure deliberation," one may intuitively posture, is comprehendible, intelligible. The domain of consciousness, moreover, behaves as if rigid, naturalistic. Some abject metaphor conjures within one that one's own self is embedded within an interwoven fabric of intentional activity. That one is embedded in such a thing; that one is a player in such a game. So one drills through the undecidability of a deranged multiplicity -- all the way into, and less likely swept under -- onto a place of conviction. We may say: Conviction, ontological certainty, emerges from the embellished mess of an unreliable word. From a stratosphere of consciousness -- this is a pretension of the self. Fear is that which is underneath, wherein selves fumble and toil feebly. At the event of introspection one must admit, says the philosopher, as a token of imperative sincerity -- for ingenuity comes from those with a plain face! --: Let me fear what I often assume I cannot be, what cannot flow from within. The outer and the inner: "An inner process stands in demand of outward criteria." And what makes behavior that criteria? Is this something to which I cannot object? Is it on the same level as "Well, understandably so, everyone has to draw the line somewhere." But the anthropologist hopes to understand us; and thus to objectify us! We say of a structure: well, there it is (demonstrative gesture, ostensive definition). And then we take metaphor (take sail)! All structures are not isomorphic (as is plain); but they are all alike in that they are structures. Might I call to this concept a family resemblance. But yet we employ it without much effort, in discourse, in education, in casual conversation. Again: might the structured emerge from the nonstructured? Surely, we may say, this is evidenced by the interpretations from evolutionary science. (As domains:) Mind from brain, rationality from desire, sober religion from savage animal, bodily health from microscopic skirmishes, etc. But at one time, we held that women derived from men. Regardless of the truth of the matter, we simply do not buy it anymore: it is morally imperative that one does not. Now how is it that the analogy I've drawn fails on account of the kinds of things at play? My argument, on its face, resembles a form of social constructivism: the kind of the thing is irrelevant; look at how it is structured. The general countercounter: but we mean this by "structure." (A structure devise from transworld considerations, as opposed to by the upper limit of society: a race to the foundation of the stratosphere.)

item.title: Marketing goes tech
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
On the production site, online marketing added a Flash banner which causes both a CPU leak and a memory leak.
  • 50%-60% CPU usage, 100MB-150MB+ memory usage across all browsers when JavaScript is enabled. Likely due to Adobe's Flash detection library (method AC_FL_RunContent) not playing well within such a messy JS background maelstrom that is for some odd reason called an "architecture." I doubt this problem can be isolated and is idiosyncratic to Adobe's library. But who knows?
  • 50%-60% CPU usage, 30MB-50MB jumps in memory usage across all browsers when JavaScript is disabled.
Don't get me wrong, though. We do have a development team, a development server, a staging server and some others (a development life cycle). It's all very bureaucratic in the "development" circle. Online marketing just decided to skip all that hoi polloi. Beyond the obvious technical blunders, the Flash banner presents nonselectable text and has no call-to-action (not clickable). It's effectively a billboard, and it takes up 35-40% of the screen's real estate on 1024x768. Usability -- what? Accessibility -- what? Interoperability -- what? And for some reason, online marketing has claimed that "it is not Flash." Secondary click -- what? It was not pilot tested. It wasn't tested in development, nor in any of the staging servers. No compatibility testing, or even a precedent of compatibility testing. In truth, the banner came as a surprise Monday morning to just about everyone in the development department (the "development context"). Also, what is that expression on the woman's face? Is she pensive? Confused? Intrigued? By what? What does that copy even mean?
The Promise of Power starts with Reliant Advantage / Choice of plans, easy-to-use tools, best-in-class service, innovation and dedication to the communities we server. / That's The Promise of Power. / That's Reliant Energy.
She's clearly in the passenger seat of a moving vehicle, perhaps nonchalantly cruising through a busy city atmosphere -- sure, plausibly described by an animated bokeh effect. But what does any of that, and her expression, and the scene, have to do with "choice of plans, easy-to-use tools, best-in-class service, innovation and dedication"? [NOTE: The bokeh lights make sense now that I've seen the rest of their campaign. Beautiful lights at night in virtue of etc etc etc.] Is her expression s'posed to be the kind that is presumably elicited by such a "promise"? If I made a promise, I would feel as if I were taken as insincere if I brought about that kind of expression. Perhaps, though, her expression is best described as nondescript, and I suppose from a marketing perspective, if one has to reflect deeply on the connection between copy and visual presentation, then something has gone wrong. The copy and the visual system of the advertisement are so abstract and hollow in themselves, and together they make no successful connections to one another. And neither the copy nor the presentation give information. My head is filled with empty words and a vacuous situation. Oh, but at least the effects are cool and the woman is corporately attractive. I am consummately perplexed.

item.title: Ab esse ad posse valet illatio
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
By ab esse ad posse valet illatio:
  1. If [God exists] and [Evil exists] are both true, then it is possible that [G] and [E] are both true.
  2. If [God exists (and) Evil exists] is true, then it is possible that [G (and) E] is true.
  3. If [G (and) E] is true, then [G] is true.
  4. If [G (and) E] is true, then [E] is true.
  5. If [G (and) E] is true, then it is possible that [G] is true.
  6. If [G (and) E] is true, then it is possible that [E] is true.
If [God exists] is true, then [G] is internally logically consistent. [God exists] implies [It is not the case that God does not exist]. // Two logically consistent statements. Depending on the definition of "God," such that "X could not create evil" and "X created all things" [God exists] implies [That which created all things and that which could not create evil exists]. // This statement cannot be a record of a fact, as its precludes the modal statement undermines the true of the action picked out by the verb; and the action picked out by the verb implies the negation of the modal statement. The statement is prima facie nonsense (internally logically inconsistent), since it implies that a undescribed entity exists. So far as objects and their descriptions go, to assert that an unrecognized or unidentified or undescribed object exists on basis of a finite set of predicates is to say something similar to "At least one I-don't-know-what exists"; and this is manifestly true, as many things outside of one's experience do exist, but which cannot be described, or could not at the time of the utterance be described. Thus, one invokes the set of unknown entities, and asserts that at least one exists; and so the question is: Must we only assert the existence of just those identifies which we have descriptions for? Well, this question is quite general, and we must come to understand what we mean by "have descriptions for." Naturally this segues into a question about Russellian descriptions. Certainly "the round-square is orange" counts as a grammatical description, and Russell more than less provided to us a philosophical method for distinguishing grammatical and existential descriptions. "The $@#%@##$ is under the ~@~" would fail under both perspectives, and for different reasons. But the philosophical question is: Will we find an intersection between the set of those independent concerns (e.g., picture theory of language). If "A" is true, then "A" is possible. But if "A" is ungrammatical but true, then is "A" still possible? I s'pose the obvious answer is "yes." But I am in search of an intersection between true statements and grammatical ones: Are linguistic predicates grounded by true states of affairs? I wish to understand the response "That's because you ground all of your predicates in a materialist framework, which is not tenable" to the assertion "You've defined 'God' in a logically inconsistent way."
  1. "The $@#%@##$ is under the ~@~" if, and only if, The $@#%@##$ is under the ~@.
    1. If "The $@#%@##$ is under the ~@~" is true, then The $@#%@##$ is under the ~@~.
    2. If The $@#%@##$ is under the ~@~ is true, then "The $@#%@##$ is under the ~@~."
If "The $@#%@##$ is under the ~@~" is true, then my sufficient explanation as to its truth does not make it true. It is true whether it records a fact about the world; how the world is makes it true. This is why its truth, if it is true, would imply its possibility: under this world, such a state of affairs is possible. And the statement, or proposition, records that state of affairs. Yet, it is clearly ungrammatical: but its "surface grammar" is no indication of its existential directedness: what it points to. But why are we led to believe that grammatical statements tend more so to truth than ungrammatical ones? Well, my hunch is that we in fact don't, and we are, for the most part, consciously concerned with truth, or desire truth, whereas the possibility of truth lies in a kind of grammar. Of course, this is an old hat. One cannot make heads or tails of the statement "The $@#%@##$ is under the ~@~"; and so its truth is out of the question. Now we might ask: what is implied by its truth? With this question we may have hope toward understanding its meaning.

item.title: The Indispensablility Argument for Mathematical Realism
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Why Indispensability is Not an Argument for Mathematical Realism (pdf)

The Argument

1. We ought to have ontological commitment to all and only those entities that are indispensable to our best scientific theories. 2. Mathematical objects are indispensable to our best scientific theories. Therefore, 3. We ought to have ontological commitment to mathematical entities.
Vomit.

A tiff with fictionalists

You might think that mathematical existence claims should not be taken at face value claiming instead that when we say “There exists a prime number greater than five we mean something like “In the story of mathematics, there is a prime number greater than five.” Another possibility is that you think that to claim, “There is a set of all prime numbers less than 100” is to claim that “We can construct a set of all the prime numbers less than 100.” Perhaps you think mathematical existence claims are merely consistency claims. In any of these views, or others where mathematical existence claims are not taken at face value, there is no reason to accept Quine’s statement that we should accept as existing what we quantify over and thus no reason to accept the indispensability argument.

A flagrant analogy

Someone like Bas van Fraassen who argues that scientific theories need only to be empirically adequate to be our best scientific theories would balk at being obligated to accept hypothetical particles into his ontology; so the analogy to mathematical objects carries no weight. The fact that we should treat mathematical object in the same way we treat physical objects lest we be hypocritical does not lead to the conclusion that we should believe that mathematical objects exist unless you already believe that all of the physical objects quantified over in this way also exist.
Really, taking shelter under scientific pragmatism?

Naive holism

Quine’s view on this matter is that the mathematical claims and physical claims are all part of the same theory as a whole and thus get tested, confirmed, or disconfirmed as a whole. This view is called confirmational holism. If you held a different view, for example the view of Elliott Sober, you might think that you only confirm scientific hypotheses when you test them against other hypotheses. The key claim here is that you don’t confirm or disconfirm what is common to all of the hypotheses being tested – in this case, the background mathematics. Thus the mathematics is not being confirmed just because the hypothesis is being confirmed.
I doubt it even makes sense to "confirm the background mathematics" if one means to talk about the whole socio-cultural edifice underpinning one's practice.

item.title: Two senses of "meta"
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
The claim that empirical sciences like physics provides knowledge of ultimate reality is often said to be "metaphysical" in some sense. Such a description seems to obscure more than clarify the topic.
The Absolute subsists eternally
The above is customarily described as a metaphysical proposition -- a pseudo-proposition, under my personal view, but nevertheless we call it "metaphysical." It presupposes a kind of world and ontology that must be radical or queer to our own, wherein the relations and facts at that world make the proposition true. And it presupposes an "ontological relevancy" axiom which, often with hope, justifies that it has sense at our own world. In two ways the proposition is "metaphysical," under the first sense we shall treat, in that it bears a fiat ontology, where its terms have no readily accessible synonym in ordinary idiom, and it contains an agenda: the agenda to introduce a novel concept as being relevant to the way we typically organize our perception (relevancy axiom). It is plain that "the Absolute" is not a common or popular term to ordinary linguistic practice, and whether it resides in a genuine semantic family is highly questionable. The speaker aims to introduce, perhaps, a conceptual gestalt, or a wholly novel concept which is not grounded in the ordinary conceptual scheme (that which roughly maps to the ordinary idiom). Moreover, the term is given an exceptional property of "eternal subsistence" which flies in the face of modern physical knowledge, in and of itself. Certainly no empirical science as we understand it comports to such a property. Nevertheless, the claim stands in some sense, if not literal sense or "empirical sense." As said, we customarily describe it as "metaphysical." It presupposes a kind of world where observation is possible, but such a world is not our own nor is it anything like our own (perhaps because for such a thing to exist, the physical laws would have to be unidentifiable to us). The sense of "meta," thus, suggests the "other-worldly" or the "supernatural." We may say this is one sense of "meta"; it may be contrasted with a descriptive sense which "meta" often takes on in analytical discussions. Now the question is whether statements like
Physics provides knowledge of ultimate reality
is a "metaphysical" claim is just the same way, bearing the "supernatural" sense. McTaggart tackles the claim under the assumption that "meta" has a completely or exhaustively descriptive sense. Thus, the above statement, which I think is better described as anthropological or epistemological, is rendered and treated as "metaphysical." So assume there is something called "physics," and it stands in a certain relation to "ultimate reality" -- but in the way that we analyzed the manifest metaphysical statement above, or "metaphysical" in the "other-worldly" sense. And this is where I seem to hit a wall. What makes "physics" a non-term for physicists? Is it because it's "too big," or does the term always carry with it some stipulation that one is "talking about" the whole cultural phenomenon we call "physics"? To put it crudely, does the mere word persistently opt us out of being able to use it with a "physical backing"? Another point: Would we say "Physics is boring" or "Physics helps us understand the world" are "metaphysical" statements? Certainly these statements cannot be justified in terms of physical evidence alone, and thus they are "outside" of the domain of physics. But again, are they "metaphysical"? Merely because they satisfy an "aboutness" criterion they gain a "metaphysical" status? This seems like an inappropriate use of the term. With these points I consciously ignore the second term "ultimate reality." McTaggart may say that our latter proposition is a metaphysical claim about physics. But just what makes it "metaphysical"? With the term "physics"? Nothing about this term seems "metaphysical" when taken as a mere identification of a collection of human agents and their undertakings. What of "ultimate reality"? Well, just what is "ultimate reality"? (We may observe this question in two ways: the kind of thing "ultimate reality" is, a question of its category or, more simply, what constitutes it or what are its features, if it exists.) Is it metaphysical in just the same way "the Absolute" is metaphysical, or "god" perhaps, or "miracles"? We may, I think without disagreement, say that it is vague or bogus. It's a question whether it picks out anything, but is it "metaphysical" on account of its lack of precision? (And thus its lack of clearly and distinctly falling under the scope of physics?) It seems to beg the queston to claim that the term is "metaphysical" merely because of its fuzzy nature, but what demands that it refer to something "outside" of the realm of physics? Is there a lack of physical evidence for something called "ultimate reality"? It seems that that there's no such thing as physical evidence for such a thing. We may wish to say "There could never be physical evidence for 'ultimate reality.'" But why? It's not obvious to me that such a thing could or could not exist for the same class of reasons which comport to the status of "god," miracles, etc. There is physical evidence which at least makes plausible the disbelief in miracles, but there's no such thing as physical evidence either affirmative or negating to any belief on the status of "ultimate reality." Would "ultimate reality" not be a basic term which picks out some thing on which physical evidence is parasitic? How is "the Absolute" anything like this? Well, if we treat of various monisms, "the Absolute" would be synonymous than "ultimate reality" itself. I struggle to see how the latter proposition is "metaphysical" and not just "about" physics. We could say, then, that physics cannot speak to the proposition simply because physics cannot be in the business of talking about itself. It is not sufficiently generic, like algebra, in its methods, to describe itself. There is a clear divide, I think, between statements which count as metaphysical on account of "domain exclusion" and, quite differently, on account of identifying "phenomena" contra the physical laws as we understand them. One sharp contrast that we may bring in is that nothing readily answers to "the Absolute," whereas "Physics" can roughly pick out, say, "the total sum of professionally acting physicists, etc." It should be clear here that we have a dilemma as to which sense the latter statement is or could be metaphysical. It is not obvious that it is "metaphysical" in the way the former statement is, as it isn't patently absurd, with respect to the ordinary conceptual scheme, but at the same time is it the case that being able to "roughly" provide entities, which answer to the latter claim's terms, justifies its not counting as "metaphysical" in the other-worldly sense? That is, is it because we can wrap our minds, as it were, around the claim that it earns a "metaphysical descriptive" status? Aristotle rendered "metaphysics" as "after the physics," and we take liberties to understand this as "about the physics," "above the physics" -- and today we classify anything supernatural, occult, mysterious or counter to common sensibilities as "metaphysical." It's unfortunate that such a crucial term can be so diversely strung out and used. And this is centrally my concern here. It seems that anyone who takes the latter statement to be "metaphysical" in the sense that its terms stand "above" the physical, anyone who does this must so to give a descriptive attempt to its terms. What is physics? And why does it "stand above" physical investigation (observation)? If taken in the sense that one is merely talking about what physicists engage in on a daily basis its clear that no sin against a logical positivist's sensibility has been committed. But is talk about physics in the abstract a tip of the hat to the metaphysical? Is ultimate reality an itinerant and aberrant abstraction, or is it something incorporeal and without measurement? In which sense should we take it under such a discussion? Must we take it under both senses? It is my belief the latter proposition is one whose expression in popular or even obscure scientific literature would be incredibly difficult to find, along with any sufficient cousin. It is without doubt a peculiar thing to say, and it largely has no place, being as general as it is, in "rigorous" scientific discourse. Almost no one would utter it or write it save for a metaphysician, to be sure. But the lack of presence in the scientific literature, or the observation that it is not a "claim of" physics, does not entail that it is "supernatural," whatever this amount to. My point is a subtle one, as we describe "physics" as having some domain and other discourses their own, we tend to think of anything "outside" said domain as being "supernatural." Now, of course, American politics is "outside" of the domain of physics in one sense, though not the "supernatural" one, despite the pagentry, reification, and other-worldly charisma and sway of then and now historic figures. But to speak plainly, we don't think of religious discourse, American politics, legal studies, etc as counting as "supernatural" or "metaphysical" on grounds of their falling outside of the "province" of physics. (Which incites a question that I often find irredeemably inane: Can we "reduce" X to physics, where X is, well, "religion," "legal systems," etc. Perhaps it isn't quite so "irredeemable," but the question often arises with very little scope, precision. At its core, however, and I am pretty heavy-handed about this, I believe it is no more and no less than a conceptual blunder.) They're simply not about the subject; moreover, and as a brief justification for my own interpretation of the latter proposition, anthropological or epistemological claims about scientific discourse are not "metaphysical" in the "other-worldly" sense. We may call them "non-physical," which is what I think McTaggart likely meant. The concepts of "domain" and "province" become fuzzy here since, on McTaggart's view, it seems that all statements "about" physics are metaphysical, as if talking "about physics" and talking "about the Absolute" amount to the same kind of judgment.

item.title: To be a prgrmmr
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
What hostility to the richness of programming! To try to reduce it to something straightforward and predictable, to place a taboo on all the weird and beautiful programs. The landscape of programming techniques is enormous, fascinating in its diversity, still largely unexplored. It is certainly littered with traps and snares, luring the inexperienced programmer into all kinds of horrible mistakes, but that only means you should proceed with caution, keep your wits about you. As you learn, there will always be new challenges, new territory to explore. The programmer who refuses to keep exploring will surely stagnate, forget his joy, lose the will to program (and become a manager).
Eloquent JavaScript, http://eloquentjavascript.net/chapter1.html

item.title: return anon
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
var foo = (function() {
    var bar = 2;
    function baz() {
        bar = bar+8;
        return bar;
    }
    return (function(a) {
        bar = a()+4;
        return bar;
    })(baz);
})();
console.log(foo);

item.title: Conceivable Believable God
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
It's the Conceivable Thinkable Intangible Dreamable Knowable Perceivable God
It can answer one's prayer, or succumb to a dare Or exist without a thought or a care, Or act in a fit, like an intractable git Or compose a world from a[n empty] barbecue pit
Unlike a squared-circle or Q and ~Q
It's the Conceivable Thinkable Intangible Dreamable Knowable Unseeable God
And It answers to a host of names, how appellable, expressible, note-able, tell-able, shareable, and often nominal
Which goes for Its alter ids, Who have done the same things it did Ethereal, purposeful, radiant and right Pure and good for those saintlike
Hell -- they're all loveable, Laudable, almost improbable, Supposedly possible, (Un-)doubtedly plausible Nearly intelligible, Eternally pleasurable, Never-quite-billable, Always forgivable, Infallible, Enrageable, Invariably unpageable Conceivable, believable gods

into an humble pale

Tickle child, uncle
unto a child availed

item.title: More stupidity versus /g
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
function replaceAll(strChk, strFind, strReplace) {
    var strOut = strChk;
    while (strOut.indexOf(strFind) > -1) {
        strOut = strOut.replace(strFind, strReplace);
    }
    return strOut;
}

item.title: Hedons & Heroine
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I keep big friends because they're easier to find
And we keep to this pitiful world, laughing
colliding, persuaded by tumultuous situations
which flux and form from our unfathomable fervor

Time not for threnodies or enemies, but animosity
for smaller and smaller minds who see never the
pleasure in whiskey; 'til dawn we are pawns rushing
the invariably rigid streets -- we never cease gushing

Contemptible hushing and scare tactic blushing
invoke an Ode to Charlie Parker, who eternally resides
in the unfolded, unrealized distributions of our minds;
pining, we crumble into the sonic shores of Mr. Parker

Dejected and fell in a splendid world, but tethered to
the roaming rife rumbling, salient and squalid, keeping
each of us as towers tilting toward Tennessee, turned
by a torrid, trembling and tempting tinkering together

To where would I run?"

item.title: Method
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Avert [philosophical] confusion!

  • describing circumstances in which a seemingly problematic expression might actually be used in everyday life,
  • comparing our use of words with imaginary language games,
  • imagining fictitious natural history, and
  • explaining psychologically the temptation to use a certain expression inappropriately

"Meaning is use"

It is quite clear that here Wittgenstein is not offering the general theory that “meaning is use,” as he is sometimes interpreted as doing. The main rival views that Wittgenstein warns against are that the meaning of a word is some object that it names–in which case the meaning of a word could be destroyed, stolen or locked away, which is nonsense–and that the meaning of a word is some psychological feeling–in which case each user of a word could mean something different by it, having a different feeling, and communication would be difficult if not impossible.
1. All taken from http://www.iep.utm.edu/wittgens/

item.title: On spectre and parole (basic thoughts)
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Language as representation and language as function: repeatedly we run against these walls. A conceptual antagonism exists between these two definitions of language, as has been demonstrated in discourse philosophic, theologic, scientific, politics, etc. For my mind, and perhaps to my detriment as a Student of philosophy, I am constantly reeled in by Wittgenstein's most generic internal struggle: the harmonization of the two primal metaphors by which we understand language to exist, either as a picture, or collection of, or as a tool, etc. More abstract but more contentious, ultimately, is the claim that this or that deity is or basically amounts to a thing, like any other, with a name, just as any other, than whether it is a man. But in truth, which is more basic to human concern? We may say, in opposition to the inquiry into the presumably more important metaphysical-object status of the deity, for instance: But whatever a man amounts to physically, there persists all the nonphysical properties of this or that gender which most adequately captures the essential nature of the deity. Quickly, we should see that such a counterpoint invokes the notion of telos, purpose, function, and so forth, as it is clear that when I declare, however archaic: "Man is the measure of all things," I mean nothing about the physical properties of this or that man as rule for measurement to the expanse of reality, nor, what's more, man as a biological animal. Indeed, in god's image is a phrasing which troubles many for just the reason that the image of man is itself difficult to fathom: yet we possess so many garden variety, prototypical demonstrations of what counts as an image, and metaphorical images speak nothing but danger, as only a kind of talent, it may be said, might count them faithfully and judiciously ... The conceptual landscape out from which ordinary-down-to-technical-up-to-mystical speakers of a language apply concepts is a primary subject matter in philosophy of language. We may look at the myriad, sometimes confused, other times aright, forms of representation, the ontological backdrop of linguistic activity, or we may observe the effectual characteristics of performances we commonly describe as linguistic. We may investigation the distinctions and overlapping between fact-stating language (constative) and value-implying language (performantive); I say value-implying to appease the anthropologist whose task it is to uncover and reveal the cultural and historical underpinnings of speakers, archetype and peculiar. I'm terribly sorry for what I have done. And why apologize in this setting, we might enquire? Or more generally, what is the connection between the concept of forgiveness (and anticipated mercy), relative to a culture, and the language with which its members express said concept. Nevertheless, values are latent, most clearly, in performative utterances, for values are the reason for which a performatives emerge: they are necessary posits so as to explain such behavior. We, moreover, look at the pitfalls and paradoxes engendered by (apparent) concept mix-matching, wherein interpretation of an utterance fails to clearly demarcate the conceptual inner-workings of one speech act now performative, now constative and everywhere in between. Indeed, it is not clear that a description (a statement, say, of scientific propositions or -- hopefully -- precise and methodologically grounded contingent propositions) always fails to possess a value, even an implicit one. Thus, we may see that an organization of 1. performative always and only implies value 2. constative always and only implies fact which is highly contentious. But even then, this is a rudimentary starting point for my ruminations on this matter. Clearly these components ought not to be taken as gospel. The intuition, I gather, is that this is how one may typically view such cumbersome terms. So sure, indeed, a performative may be viewed as a mere behavior of a kind, and eager are we to classify it under those terms. A kind of associationism looms behind the methods in which performatives are treated. In a sense, performatives are linguistic behavior, and not the other way around; whereas the presumption, conversely, holds that constatives are chiefly and properly expressions of language. So further, one may assume that language is better understood in terms of the concept which acts as root to constative forms of speech; i.e., language as representation. We start of inquiry into the structural or logical tethers of language by observing its objects, artefacts, things and stuffs, where every noun a noun, every verb a noun -- a world of substantives and relations (which are just as well things but on a more abstract level). Readily we see the unfit nature of such a conceptual if applied to the notion of performative utterance and behavior so defined in those terms. Immediately we must observe and respect the psychical world and its denizens, motivations, agendas, goals, ideas (not as idealizations), laws (hardly describable, if at all, as nomic, but as moral or imperative): the mental. How might we connect the performative we the mental? Indeed, one may perform an action which some arbitrary linguistic behavior -- but why should she, or he? And why at this very moment? Granted, to be sure, these agents speak about this or that, and intentions are abound, inundating our skulls we philosophically trivial substitutable terms, but have we more to say than S stands in a certain [psychical] relation to P? (I should add some points about "criteria" and "process.")
