Not only is this block of code a semanticist's nightmare, but the original developer was compelled to accept false dilemmas, thus tripping into a practice of abusing two other languages (JSP and JavaScript). Honestly, I'm not the sharpest butterfly knife in the poke, but I find it hard to believe the developer who wrote this code has the intuition to avert complexity. But such an intuition (or talent) must be a common feature of human intelligence: "There just has to be an easier way" or "What the fuckballs am I doing?" -- apparently not.

item.title: Front-end developer quiz [draft]
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Methods

  1. How often do you comment your code? Do you have a particular schema for annotation?
  2. Purist versus hacker dilemma: How do you address this general problem? At the end of the day, Internet Explorer 6 reigns.
  3. What is the Separation of Concerns? How do you organize the resources (JS, CSS, Images, Templates, etc.) for a Web project?

HTML

  1. What is a doctype (DTD)? And what are some consequences of not declaring a doctype? Answer: If the mime-type of the document qualifies as "text/html," a doctype informs the user agent of which set of elements should exist for the following HTML document. Thus, for the CSS engine and JavaScript interpreter in that browser, elements can be said to "exist" depending on the declarations within the document type definition. Within the ontology of web browsers, there exist two kinds of entities: elements (objects) and [their] attributes; for any HTML document, the domain of discourse is defined by the document type: which elements exist and which attributes they can possibly possess. For true-XML documents, whose mime-type is application/xml or application/xhtml, since XML is "extreme" -- whups: "extensible" -- the domain of discourse is "up for grabs," since XML's semantic-ontology is almost completely nil. Doctypes also trigger, under the web browser context, the designated rendering mode: quirks, almost standards, and standards mode. (Never, ever, ever, ever, design in quirks mode.
  2. Are you familiar with HTML5? Describe a possible scenario in which one might declare its doctype.
  3. What do Web standards mean to you?
  4. List one advantage and one disadvantage of using line-breaks (<br />).
  5. There are two types of XHTML, "marketing XHTML" and "real XHTML". What's the difference? Answer: The former describes a Web document transmitted using the text/html mime-type, whereas the latter describes an XHTML document which is transmitted using the application/xml or application/xhtml mime-types.
  6. What's the difference between a tag and an element?
  7. What are attributes?
  8. How would you mark up a physical address?
  9. What is the difference between a block- and inline-level element?

JavaScript

  1. What is the difference between graceful degradation and progressive enhancement?
  2. What is the DOM? And what do doctypes and the DOM have to do with one another?
  3. How would you implement a lightbox or JS modal window?
  4. Compare and contrast innerHTML and appendChild.
  5. How does one traverse the DOM relative to a <form id="form_id">?
  6. What's wrong with Array.sort()?
  7. How does one extend the native String object such that function Funky can be invoked for any arbitrary string? Answer: String.prototype.Funky = function() { //... };
  8. What's wrong with the follow line? var o = { attr1: "", 2attr: function() { return 2; }(), _attr3: [], };
  9. What's the difference between the comparison operators == and ===?
  10. When should one include an external JavaScript file in the ?
  11. What are some best practices for traversing the DOM?
  12. What are best practices when dealing with performance? (HTTP requests, ensure server-side compression, etc)
  13. What is the primary difference between IE and Firefox's rendering engines?
  14. What is Just-In-Time compilation?

Browsers

  1. Which web browsers do you develop in?
  2. Which web browsers do you test in?
  3. What is content negotiation?
  4. Tell me the strangest thing you've seen IE do.
  5. Which web browser is your favorite?
  6. Which typeface looks better, Helvetica or Arial?

Tools

  1. Which tools do you use daily?
  2. How do you debug JavaScript?
  3. What's your favorite IDE or code editor?

SEO

  1. What are keywords and are they important?
  2. What are the most important elements of an HTML document's body?
  3. What is the most important element in the <head>?

Accessibility

  1. What is web accessibility?
  2. How do you feel about browser targetting?
  3. Are you familiar with sIFR?

CSS

  1. Do you like to organize your CSS in a particular way?
  2. What is a CSS Sprite?
  3. Do you prefer CSS hacks or keeping IE separate?
  4. What are font stacks? And how do you deal with font sizes?
  5. How would you center a <div> to a page, both vertically and horizontally?
  6. How would you pull off rounded corners?
  7. Do you still use tables for forms?
  8. Equal-height columns -- what do you do?
  9. Define the box models.
Some of the questions above are either inspired by or have been directly lifted from Interview questions to ask a front end developer.

item.title: (M)athematics$1us(i)c$2ence
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
First Act

Primitive Man
(Points ostensibly to a mundane stone situated before him.) One!
Primitive Man
(Again.) One!
Primitive Man
(Again; followed by extended sigh.) One! ...
Primitive Man
He begins to sulk and wail as if the act were a kind of superstitious ritual. He begins to dance, cajoled by the stone's physical presence.
Primitive Man
One! One! One! One! ...
Primitive Man
He stands dejected and immoral by his unsuccessful attempts. Rain shall not fall this season.
Our Primitive Man undertook a rain dance, say, so as to fruitfully introduce a new term into his language. His attempt, as given our scene, was a failure. But as he begins to stomp away from his alter, fire, what have you, he murmurs to himself as he paces. "One... One... One..."; he is "counting" his feet, as is clear, but he continuously, consistently fails (as he did before; he might now say: the set of his walking consisted in) -- though the point here is that he is not celebrating in this act. It is a mere transition to another game. (Imagine, if you can, pacing as a game we play. And why is it not? Indeed, what makes this behavior not counting? -- Do not say: "Well, obviously!" That is to say, I have generated a question, and if understood by any intellect, an answer must be given (we seek to, or rather are compelled to (theorem: psychologically), extend our epistemic rights.)

Second Act

Musical Man
Dun. Dun. Dun. Dun. Dun.
Musical Man
(Notice of a rhythm to his counting.)
Theory on correspondence theory of truth:
Music as a Representation of the World.
Consider the score a picture of reality in the "literal," physical sense; music as a description of the empirical world, -- now the mathematical world. Do not consider
Music as a Creation of the World.
We imagine music as a complexity, but is it, like with mathematics, necessarily not about the world? Would we say that music is an application of mathematics? Perhaps even founded on mathematics? Devil's enquiry: "The world created by a musical piece. What sense of world do we use here? Must it map to our understanding of world in the physical sense, world in the mathematical sense? Can we make sense of the question? Can we make sense of the use in ordinary language? (Will we resort to a psycho-causal theory to explain this phenomenon in ordinary language? Thus!: the sense of the question is best understood under the frame of the physical. But is the musical world created an approximation to our empirical world, or is it the Unto Itself, like how we view the world of the physical (the Natural world) or the mathematical (the world of Necessity)?

Third Act

(Rain fails -- the man enjoys the Real-ality: observation of real numbers through a waterfall. Quickly: might one continue to bellow out: "One!"?)

Fourth Act

We are those caught in the rain, Unable to embrace its insanity, For our lack of language: Language as a Necessity To the Possibility of Sensation; Of Seers See No Truth

item.title: Analysis, Warrantablility and Knowledge
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
(P) You like X for X's Q. (1) -> You [only] like X for X's Q, and no other property Z of X interests you. (2) -> It is possible that you like X for X's Q. (3) -> It is possible that you [only] like X for X's Q " (2) and (3) are trivially true, and a speaker would have no motivation to assert it. It is practically irrelevant, and moreover would only suggestion shared sentiment between the speaker and the inquirer. Inquirer should only consider questions of the reasons behind (1). The speaker may be justified or unjustified in asserting (1), insofar as the speaker can be said to [know] (1). The crux of the problem here is whether (P) counts as knowledge, or if the speaker merely wishes to pass off (2) and (3) with the overt form of (1), supposing (P) properly translates to (1). (I want to consider: The speaker thinks to him or herself in asserting (P): "Let's pretend that I know something substantial, but in truth, I have no relevant knowledge on the matter, but my language makes it look as though I do.") If the speaker has knowledge, then the speaker should be scrutinized insofar as that knowledge, where the inquirier is interested only in the speaker's evidence for (1). If the speaker merely wishes to insult or criticize from bias, then the speaker may employ (2) or (3), but if the speaker wishes to speak truly, even if the speaker may fail to do so, then the speaker may employ (P) or (1). If the speaker has no knowledge, or even further, no evidence, then the speaker counts as only semantically capable to genuinely assert (2) or (3). (Measure the conceptual utility of the new concept: "semantic capability," or "semantic rights" -- what we have a right to mean; or more generally "semantic laws." I fear "the semantic string" is of utmost relevance here.) If the speaker has knowledge or evidence, then evidence is what is relevant. Hunches, guesses, suppositions, mere belief, pure emotional expression which happens to take on the form of language (belting out "ow!" after stubbing one's toe), and so on, all should take treatment as if (2) or (3). Mere belief, for instance, gives you nothing to analyze in terms of justification, reason or evidence; thus, utterances of this sort are effectively equivalent to (2) or (3). "Justificatory content," so to say, in such a case, fails to exist; but this is not to say that the statement is meaningless or generally unanalyzable. This is only to say that in terms of the analysis of knowledge, our practice will inevitably fall flat, so long as we keep to a narrow definition of knowledge such that it is defined in terms of justified true belief. A purely psychological or emotional analysis may be in order, which appeals to the causal mechanisms of the brain and its neural inner-workings. This analysis may be consistent with our "procedure to the justificatory"; but it cannot overwrite or undermine it, without introducing harm to the ways we, in the most generic conceptual manner, treat of human behavior at the level of the mental (i.e., propositional, reason-based, etc). All this is to say: reasoned (linguistic) behavior may overlap or run in parallel to mere causal events, but both kinds of phenomena, insofar as the analysis applied, must equally be given at least a "parallel" treatment. Analysis and interpretation must respect categorical dissimilarity (when we speak of categories, we must always "look upward" in our minds to common descent: can the thing in question have mutually excluding parents; of which the thing in question, given the contextualization of our analysis -- *or "for our purposes" --, cannot -- *or should not -- bear entailment properties in virtue of being child to one or some other intuitively plausible parent), insofar as one phenomenon may count as a member of categories non-intersecting. We may do this, I believe, without being labelled "dualists," for this is a analytical method which commits one to no metaphysical parent narrative. The analyst, it is my belief, has no story to tell, but only one to uncover which speaks faithfully to most generally justifiable intellectual intuition. As usual the criticism may arise that this approach is too "pedantic," overly dry, or whatever; the general spirit of such a criticism is that it treats so cautiously as to become careless the heart of language and its use. But I feel this criticism is ill-founded, for it ignores the outset interest of our undertaking: to go our of our way, on the assumption that it exists, to investigate language as a picture. Indeed, the owner of such a critique cannot assert as if obvious that language never grounds from a picture, or that images in language and from which language may emerge never exist. Naturally, our approach assumes a "metaphorical assumption" that language [is] in some cases chiefly image-grounded, and this assumption should be said to stand or fall given its conceptual utility (which is a cumbersome way of saying that it makes sense so long as one is attentive). That the conceptual space of language holds a region purely of images, I think, is debatable; whereas the belief that all language amounts to images and their expression is clearly not justifiable (but this is another debate which centers on the status of private languages). Naturally, again, we can go on for quite a spell backwards into the conceptual underpinnings of our conceptual history. I choose to end here, for all this amounts to typical digression that can trap anyone. So, perhaps more succinctly, I should say: I aim to understand what assertions mean, and the approach given above, which is tethered to the popular definition of knowledge, is my effort to understand. Whether it is wholly unfruitful, I believe is a matter of preference, and I should not ever demand that others engage it. Assertions amount to pictures whose brush strokes come from the bristles of justification and whose directions analogous to the lines of right thinking, conspicuous or obscure. I perceive never obstruction of sense, but only the fog of language, should such a fog compel me to unmanageable thought: I shall aim ever to understand what I mean before I say it, only so when I venture to craft from the world rather than create into the world. And I end with the basis for my albeit archaic way of thinking:
I have laboured carefully, not to mock, lament, or execrate, but to understand human actions; and to this end I have looked upon passions, such as love, hatred, anger, envy, ambition, pity, and the other perturbations of the mind, not in the light of vices of human nature, but as properties, just as pertinent to it, as are heat, cold, storm, thunder, and the like to the nature of the atmosphere, which phenomena, though inconvenient, are yet necessary, and have fixed causes, by means of which we endeavour to understand their nature, and the mind has just as much pleasure in viewing them aright, as in knowing such things as flatter the senses.
Political Treatise, Baruch Spinoza

item.title: Justifiable Suicide
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Exploration of philosophical suicide. I seek not to justify the statement: I desire to commit suicide, but rather: I desire to understand whether I must commit suicide. One interpretation of the target statement is such that one may view one's own life as a mistake of a certain sort: the metaphysical sort. No one could possibly determine that the laws of nature, or that nature itself, underwent error; and even if this were the case, no palpable justification should emerge, for nothing about nature justifies or carries a certain logical conclusion. The mistake, then, would be such that one's continued presence in the present fundamentally works against the logical construction of the world: a logical mistake. Again, but for different reasons, logic itself and its laws cannot justify the conclusion, for a social element persists. One must speak to the intuitions of the Other, where logic may speak worlds but never values. It may be true at all possible worlds, but these worlds may be fictions; thus, truth at a fictional world may draw out a question of relevance at this world. Truth at all fictional worlds save the actual, I believe, incurs the same consequence. We may wish to understand the tone or the mode of the statement; must in what sense? By necessity in the same way that a circle must never possess angles at its perimeter? Or such that a square's walls must be equidistant from its center? Moreover, to understand, generally, does not entail that any particular action must be obeyed. What may compel one justifiably to commit suicide, then, is the question. Is a justified suicide self-contradictory?

item.title: Pedants & Pedestrians
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
"Well, we had to start from somewhere" was the claim. "Monarchs, we may be, but from bloodshed toward Babylon were we engineered." The man standing before you, clean cut from the dusty bowels of a peculiar industry, could not help himself from rambling restlessly on the linguistic constructions of the age. Charismatic but depleted of substance, he wielded whimsically the intuitions of his comrades, friends and antagonizers; or so it was thought. "It" -- but who may have thought it; and it, so some may have fought it. "No one thinks on these matters, like before, as one once was demanded"; before when? "We date ourselves to the time before the languid tremors emerged into precipitates to decadence" -- still vacuity.
Questions of the sort which demand a datum as their answer imbibe of the boredom and triviality current in our age. The mystic, the mandolin and the marauder mend the sweltering sick stink of their noisome institutions, which demand only allegiance of spirit. "And so the monarchs play their violins, with urgency, celerity and clamor."
Pedestrians of language demonstrate sharp contrast with the peripatetics, the pedants, unprompted by the platitudes which shockingly persuade. Gestures, postures and positions unfold into agreement and concordance of the facts with the great words of a generation. One's hand is held by the climate of the most mundane intellect, even as those who could not liberate themselves to our stature, as those who cannot be, as those slumber in the havens of their world's mind.

item.title: Euthyphro
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Source (Euthy): Is the pious loved by the gods because it is what it is; that is, pious -- or is the pious as such because it is loved by the gods? Form: Is X Y'd by Z because X has X-ness (X-ality, X-iscience, etc) is X (the former error actually is the conclusion which is typically drawn, where "having X-ness" amounts to "having a certain quality of being worship'd by the gods"; we do not aim to understand whether X is X-like, for that would leave us still to determine what X is, and X-like could reasonably be defined as "well, here is something that might constitute X" -- but we would still be unsure as to whether X is indeed a proper candidate for X-ishness, etc); or is X X-y (X-ish, X-iful, etc) because X is Y'd by Z?
X
The pious, piety (the Object)
Y
Love (Intention, Intentionality, Attitude)
Z
The gods (the Authority)
Either the gods stand outside of that which is pious, and are thus influenced by it, or in virtue of the gods' attitude toward piety, that which is pious -- piety -- sustains or bears piety thus.

Active and Passive

I typically call the first horn realism, others decide differently. Piety, right, wrong, etc are entities which, presumably, sustain or bear certain properties independent of influence from Authorities, divine or mundane. The latter horn advances divine command thinking, where the Authority plays an Active role in the properties held by the Object; the former, a Passive role. But along with "command" some additional conceptual consequences follow. Necessarily? I don't know. So let's just say there's a "divine connection," more generally: a conceptual connection, a theological metaphysic.

Horns

For the first horn, we might say that the Authority views piety as a source of inspiration or as a muse; the Authority describes or records the behavior of the pious, but the Authority has no authorship over its domain, influence, trajectories, "goals," if you will. Piety, say, is a thing-in-itself, subject not even to the Authority's thrust and telos. The Authority is, in the strictest sense, Passive. For the second, the Authority engineers, creates, molds and introduces piety. The Authority's attitude and focus'd effort circumscribes piety, control and shape it, found and contain it. The Authority constructs and defines the Object, and is thus, in the strictest sense, Active.

Thoughts

In large part, philosophers are concerned with possibilities. A philosopher's chief task can be described as ensuring possibilities for others, other thinkers, objects and their existence, the possibility of description, the possibility of successful reference sentences, unicorns, squar'd-circles, contradiction as possible objects of thought, etc. So, Kant was concern'd with the possibility of the categorical imperative (a fancy moral jewel); Wittgenstein the possibility of a private language; Hume the possibility of a rational inference into future states of affairs (beyond habit and continual perceived conjunction of events); Russell the possibility of marrying the number 3, etc. And Socrates: the possibility of explaining the true nature of things. In my reading, I sense an underlying assumption on Socrates'/Plato's part that if we fail to define or agree on a definition for a thing, it may as well not exist. Naturally language gets hog-tied and ransack'd in the whole intrepid undertaking. So, in a sense, Socrates is on the hunt for the existence of piety. Once defined, existence is granted; but for a thing to exist, the implicit verdict cries, we must come to a complete understanding of it. One feature of understanding, presumably, is the knowing of whether a thing essentially (necessarily) or contingently possesses a certain property or all of its properties. Moreover, granted that the gods are eternal and necessary themselves (?!), their Attitudes, if uninanimous, must also carry with it a kind of necessity. And surely the Object must be eternally sustain'd as such if the gods are unwavering (and they are -- they're "necessary"!). Thus, the problem of Euthyphro unfolds thus: A: X is surely X. B: But why? A: Since [X is X], it is loved for being X. B: But why is [X is X] true? A: Maybe the loving of X makes [X is X] true. Whups! The idea here is that we must expose the Object's definition, not merely describe some feature of it. As it stands, we are none the wiser or more informed as to what X (or piety, or what's right, or what we ought to do, etc). The concept at play, if it is at play, given the discussion, is essentially murky territory, which isn't to say that it cannot be penetrated. And what's at stake here is our uninformed use of the concept. In a way, this problem is similar to Hume's is-ought, except the "is" has been erased: -ought, or vacuous/unprincipled imperatives. Moreover, it takes a metaphysical assumption about the Authority -- that it is necessarily existing or necessarily holds these beliefs as opposed to others -- to counter the claim that the Authority does not only contingently have the Attitude it does have toward the Object.

Ramble

If we expose the conceptual machinery, as I've done above, and if we factor in the concepts of Activity and Passivity, and then finally color in all the cultural, historical, and metaphysical baggage (along with all those personal predispositions and preconceptions) usually associated with the concepts, we get a whole slew of derivative problems. Generally, as is typical with Socrates, the problem is that [X is (surely) an X]. But why? Well, now that we've agreed that [X is an X] and could not be otherwise, we would love to understand why [X is an X]. That "could not be otherwise" puts us a few steps ahead of ourselves, but perhaps we should just go there.

Tangents

I expose the Form of the argument to underscore its import. Often we see, in expositions of the Problem, substitutions of "piety" with "right" or "moral standards." With the latter, it's clear that the Problem can be made more abstract, covering a greater conceptual landscape; that is, piety typically falls under the domain of "the moral standards" under most ontologies of morality. That said, we could, and often do, use the Form to introduce analogous arguments in every discourse, so long as we pay attention to the conceptual framework doing the work in the Euthyphro argument: The Object, The Attitude, The Authority. And why do they stand in relations of the Active and the Passive? Why do they stand in any relation at all? Why must we assume that Attitudes take on these Active and Passive roles? And why does anything whatever follow from the status of these roles? Is there any bearing on the human condition? Are human lives influenced in any way by the relationships so agreed upon or established? I ask these questions because they apply, assuming adequately re-contextualization, to any derivative problem which may be introduced in near or remote areas of discourse: Anthropology, Science (of Perception), Politics, Art, etc.

item.title: Judgments
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
So is this it: I must recognize certain authorities in order to make judgments at all? (OC, 493)
If we bear Kant in mind (provide quotation/s for textual support), we can readily expose W's position through contrast and contextualization. This may be relevant for ethics, primarily, and any other field of philosophical discourse on which practical rationality comes before critical view. Kant placed his emphasis on the concept of human judgment; and for our purposes: the aesthetic and the teleological. First, the aesthetic: of the disinterest'd, of (judgment) universality and of necessity -- on objects purposive which may lack practical utility. By disinterest'd Kant recognizes judgments which lack any grounding in human desire or pleasure. Aesthetic judgments, of this sort, so it is assumed, are possible; chiefly that, in attaching a predicate to a thing, we may do so through inclination untouched by our subjective preferences. We attach it, in a sense, because we determine that the object must have it, regardless of whether it "really" does. The object strikes us as inherently, perhaps, possesses the property. We derive pleasure, then, because of the object as such and our judgment of it; the object imposes upon us, as opposed to our faculty of pleasure compelling us to attach this or that predicate. We may look at the matter of this kind of judgment in this way: an utterance may be non-propositional; as such, it may also qualify as a valid grammatic form: "the carpet is beautiful." But, we acknowledge that utterances may be causally influenced by sensations, thus becoming replacements for non-linguistic behavior. With this in mind, Kant anticipates the idea of emotivist theories of ethics, at least its conceptual underpinning anyway. The logical grammar, as it were, of such utterances indicates that it is not propositional: Kant aims to concern himself only with judgments which can be candidates for being a proposition. Pain behavior mask'd as linguistic behavior is not relevant. The other two features of judgment concern, and I'll put this in clunky terms first, our "mental state" whilst engaging in the act of judging. This is partly a psychological assumption, namely that in making judgments we tacitly assume that all others are in agreement and that the object so judged could not fail to possess the property so predicated of it. Not "all others would be in agreement" -- in a sense, cultural or ethical relativism is implicitly rejected here, for Kant's notion of aesthetic judgment involves the claim that we assume others come from nonexceptional, similar cultural and historical backgrounds. The object is a "real" in our life, and so we assume so for others. (Cultural ignorance goes unexplained when we more to aesthetic judgments of "reserved" or idiosyncratic cultural artifacts.) More or less, Kant identifies a possible kind of realism we all at some level assume in taking judgment. Added to this is that the object so judged, we assume, that the object came about from purpose, or was undertook through purposive action (or design), though the object itself may not contribute causally or purposely beyond itself. It may not move the world in any way other than that when one views it, one is moved; not necessarily to join this or that political party or what have you, but simply that one is pleased (or derives pleasure from it). The artifact or object itself, so far as its purposive becoming goes, is not connected, or cannot be held accountable for, those events which come about from its being viewed. What has the artist's brush strokes to do with the enraging of a community. The brush strokes had behind them the purpose of completing the piece itself, not the propelling of a nation or, more specifically, the observer. There is a fundamental disconnect between kinds of purpose: there is the purpose behind the, say, physical properties of the piece and the purpose behind the greater, or outer, intentional or nonintentional effects to which said piece may be a determinate cause. Now, when W makes his claim, I address it in terms of the definition of aesthetic judgment (and later teleological) so defined. Again, to wit:
So is this it: I must recognize certain authorities in order to make judgments at all? (OC, 493)
We have "recognize," "authorities," "in order to," "judgments," and "at all." Like Moore, W had an idiosyncratic way of being succinct, in some cases obscuring his point. With W, have a kind of eloquence and grave way of speak; with Moore, we have a strictly refutational tone which demonstrates the mark of the Everyperson:

"Your assumption, truly, is that I am not speaking correctly, -- that my facon de parler suffers from an impropriety which blocks my practical goal -- but what need have I got with your unrestricted concept to which 'unrestricted goal' applies? I need not speak in the way of 'ultimate ends' to talk fruitfully talk about my practical, finite end. Universals, ultimate ends, etc. do not set a criteria for the conclusion of practical ends."

(Revise.) I make such a point because, at first glance, one should require a clarification:

"'At all'? Such a judgment would be impossible lest I personally count as an authority, but this would abuse the term, as in my private musings there exists no authority unless all others are just as familiar with my personal thoughts as I am. To affirm the positive to the question would mean that all judgments must in principle be public. Such judgments would, in principle, require 'recognizability,' the implicit rejection of judgments in isolation. But then how are 'new judgments' introduced, if "at all" is the qualification? What have I got before the judgment is introduced?

And who counts as a valid authority? Or what? What is an authority in such a case? One feature of a judgment, or a connotation that we commonly, in philosophy, speak of is the involvement of subjectivity. Where a judgment is contrast'd with a report. "The Labour Party has got a sham-system" as opposed to "The Communists took to the streets." The former introduces an opinion in excess of the facts (the Labour Party has some kind of system, of whatever sort, that is complex in some way or other, which brings about consequences in the greater political sphere, consequences on which the judgment expresses its speaker's personal position." The latter reports nothing more than the fact itself and the way in which its speaker chose to express that fact, her own brand of report-language. With all the "realism" at play in Kant, we are left with the question: It seems that Kant attempts to impose a requirement that judgments, in truth, are report-like; judgments not fitting into the "report-framework" fail to be true judgments. But how does this ride with subjectivity? Emotivism?

item.title: What CSS Frameworks Must Do
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: A CSS Framework must be a codification of definitions of Information Architecture, so far as it influences design (content, functional or otherwise, ontology), Creative (design ontology), a cross-browser grid system; it must it must not needlessly impinge upon server-side controls and must rather assist server-side controls with layout and design (.last-child, .last, .even/.odd classes); it must promote and enable the Standardization and Ease-of-Implementation of all visual elements, common or particular. I have been developing a Master CSS Framework (GDGS) which, essentially, is not itself a stylesheet, per say. Rather, it is a conceptual tool which outlines the grammar of "master stylesheets" for any particular project, webapp or otherwise. I personally do not believe that being "light-weight" should be a requirement; assuming caching and compression. The ROI for a Framework of the sort on which I have been focusing my efforts, even if 50KB, outweighs such "performances sensitive" arguments. File size alone should not be a determinate of a stylesheet, but rather development capabilities within certain time-frames should also be considered. Moreover, Standardization, Consistency, Communication, and Ease-of-Implementation are the partly defining features of such a Framework.

item.title: Demo: Death Rites
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I like the artist name "Wept Without Wit". Below is a demo, consisting of 7 Considerations. I name/describe them as such as they do require extension and addition; so I consider them entangled and de-postured but significant potential musical fragments.
  1. Hatred Hallows the Marching Meek
  2. Fickle Child (Come On) Home
  3. Rustling Mammoths Know, Saints Tow
  4. Trees Become Tombstones for Themselves
  5. Him Who Loved Us in the Home Found Lost
  6. Dishevel'd Procession
  7. Sympathetic Symptomatic
  • Full Archive: Wept Without Wit - Death Rites (~240VBR, ZIP)
  • Last.fm: Album page
The demo's title is "Death Rites," and it was recorded at ~240VBR on my laptop's mic. I went nuts with unconditional reverb and simply failed in a splendidly stupid way the mastering of each track. Huzzah. (Please ignore the file name enumeration.)

item.title: The Internal Property of a Rule
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: The internal property of a rule: determine the internal structure of its expression. Take a simple rule: "one, o, must not x"; o here stands in a certain relation, r, to x. In this case, in order for the rule to be said to count as a rule, its internal property must be manifest. Or rather, in the expression we capable to identify the internal property of the rule; it exists in virtue of the property analogous to the relation, r. Thus, rules have internal properties; but what connexion does the internal property have with respect for the rule? We have the mere words, a sentence, utterance, etc., which express the rule, but how is it that this expression's internal logico-grammatical structure occasions to expose the internal property of the rule it expresses? I aim here only to identify that rules have internal properties; in a way, a grammatical structure maps to an internal property of a rule. This property may be isomorphic with the grammatical structure; that is, if the grammatical structure can fail to exist, for a given set of reasons, the property may fail in a similar way to exist.

item.title: Hatred Hallows the Marching Meek
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Hatred hallows the marching meek --
Triumphantly, and with philanthropic prayer,
Earnest funnel'd horns blast magnificent praise:
"Withering yet weak, the marching meek!"

With virtue follows the divinely teeth --
Mendaciously, and with peripatetic revolt,
Inscribed on their  juniper tombstones:
"Weeping without wit, you wilting sheep!"

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Mix'dly.

I feel like I've been rickroll'd by the wrong side of the bed.

item.title: Discussion with Rajiv Shah on Mathematics/Nature/Stuff
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Raj offers the argument:
1. Mathematics is the language of nature. 2. Everything around us can be represented and understood through numbers. 3. If you graph these numbers, patterns emerge. Therefore: There are patterns everywhere in nature.
My response:
On this premise (1) I am compelled to focus on the term "nature." In virtue of ZF, we can rule out any such conception of "Nature", "Substance", etc. And I feel, in order for such a premise to be provocative/compelling at all, one must assume that the sense given to the term "nature" bears some socio-intellectual gravity which is aimed at triggering one's contingent imagination; or, more specifically, it must have a sense which makes it a prime target for such a readily available interpretation. (Moreover, do we really wish to assume some kind of innocuous naturalism? Perhaps: but nevertheless, the point I make here concerns the metaphysical pretension I suspect colors this premise.)
So, perhaps my previous statement needs clarification: In ZF -- or rather, assuming ZF, as I feel you are positively personally, intellectually, oriented in this framework -- Russell's Paradox is avoided, but fundamentally it undergirds and constrains ZF; and the axiom of foundation secures the nonexistence of Nature (the provocative sense I take you to mean it; that is, "Substance," as this entire discussion is framed, perhaps even curtailed, by an underlying assumption of monism), "God," the Universe, the One, the Absolute, or even, I s'pose, the object of a grand unified theory/theory of everything.
A "Nature" of the sort assumed, would count as a master set, containing all others, but at the same time would flout Russell's constraint and that of AOF, for it would belong to itself; so, self-containment is ruled out. Now what does it mean for nature not to contain itself? (To contain itself?) Nature is contained by another or that it is simply not contained. With the former, we have infinite regression or dualism here (dualism flies in the face of the pragmatic constraints of mathematics); not contained, we face a problem of monism. If the One is all there is, there must be containment of itself and all things; but this again goes against AOF, etc.
Perhaps this comes down to "containment" and the limitations of the set theoretical metaphor. (What does "Nature" contain?) But that said, on pain of contradiction, we may give up our monism (belief in the One), but how elegant is that? Maybe we're on the wrong foot?
Best is it, I believe, to give up the "nature" business unless we diverge radically from an essentially naturalistic framing of the concept; let's keep the letters but not the force.
The gist of my point is chiefly that "nature" brings unnecessary pain to the argument; however, what's more, I would disagree that there is a more (ontologically?) apt term. Essentially, there is no "Nature" for which mathematics describes; by ZF we can rule out any such thing.
All this said, and for my own bit, I believe that mathematics cannot describe nature, that nature cannot have a language. Nature, as previously understood, is strictly nonexistent. This isn't to say that applied mathematics is a tragic failure; a dose of pragmatism has earned its due. Certainly local regions in the universe can be graphed, represented, modeled, etc; but any such grander implication such that patterns are in nature leaves me with an anxiety: that the conceptual scheme of patterns may illicitly flow into the domains of art or science; that the form (not conception) of Truth in mathematics may disrupt the form of Truth in science, say.

item.title: CSS Ontology
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
._utilityClass { }

A concept I founded a few months ago and have quickly come to disdain. If one has reached the limit of one's imagination in determining all elements of the Web project (generated a list of all necessary subsequent class names and ID names), one may introduce a utility class for a specific purpose; a flawed intuition behind the utility class is that it is "universal" or would be better served taking residence in some library. These are benefits, perhaps, in themselves, or taken in isolation: universal applicability, a loose implementation, etc., but utility classes also become unwieldy due to the ease with which they can be added. Within any Web project, they are ad hoc; without a Web project, they are Platonic. They are better conceived as attempts to standardize a project, steps in the mental process of formulating a mental "shape" or "form" of the Web project, its scope, etc. To wit, why would one create a set of "._basementN" classes with no need to quickly and without greater influence of the other all implementation, change some set of elements' margin-bottom? In one way, such a class type is conducive to widespread standardize and "re-skinning," assuming the classes have been applied consistently: but this is another downside. Utility classes, in short, are nothing more than potential implementation classes; their existence within any Web project should be considered a shortcoming. Conceptual predecessors of this class amply crop of, the infamous: ".paddingLeft20", "marginRight10", etc. The crucial distinction, however, which still happens to overshoot the fatal flaw of all classes of this type, is that the utility class also attempts to standard:  One should never create a "paddingLeft20" which maps to the padding-left CSS property, exposing CSS properties to the implementation (in one way, the markup) reduces coherence; but exposing a standard to an implementation promotes the conceptual role the presentation layer plays within that implementation.

.structuralClass { }

Includes "container," "sidebar," "module" (though module is arguably a "semantically loaded" term, "sidebar" as well); may well be identical with "grid system class." The architecture metaphor, and consequent nomenclature, partly determines the applicability and naming of such classes; it is preferred to have these classes' names not intersect with the implementation class conceptual metaphor (the basis or inspiration for naming for implementation classes). Structural classes, in theory, count as the skeleton of the Web project, where the implementation classes constitute is "skin."

.implementationClass { }

This class includes complex style definitions which style for:
  • Buttons
  • Rounded Corners
  • Drop Shadows
The type of the items which fall under the above list vary in terms of complexity. A rounded corners class might be "loose" in that the intention behind the class is to use it in various regions or parts of the Web project, but its (essential) scope is partly defined by the scope of the Web project. They are part of the implementation of the overall application. In a way, one is committed to coupling them to the implementation markup if one uses them at all, and the strength of that coupling is determined by the liberality with which one tacks on this class to new, sui generis elements. "Tight" classes are contrasted primarily with their "looser" counterparts in that the intention behind them is to become coupled with some complex markup structure, but this is taken for granted as a necessary pain. Buttons, for instance, will only have one (or two) markup structures, with varying text node contents. An implementation class for this design element would be just as essential to the Web project as the markup itself. With "tight" implementation classes, the inner markup contents ("btn btnSubmit", "block blockStatusMsg blockStatusError", etc.) remain strictly fixed, saving for text node contents; by contrast "looser" anything below the class may change, e.g., "module modulePrimarySidebar moduleHTMLBox", etc.
  • Loose Implementation Class: Scope of Applicability partly defined by Scope of the Web project (the total set of pages which constitute the application); e.g. may be applied to generic containers (<div>s), unordered lists, input fields under one project.
  • Tight Implementation Class: Scope is stipulated by HTML structures, complex or otherwise, which strictly adopt the class. Indeed, nothing prevents one from applying the class to variants of some "tight" complex markup structure, but this naturally increases code redundancy. So, thought possible, even permitted, such practice is discouraged.

#uniqueCommonPageElement { }

Includes "Chat Boxes" which follow a user across pages, widgets which are sui generis to all pages (if widgets are dynamically generated: uniqueCommonPageElement1, uniqueCommonPageElement2, ..., uniqueCommonPageElement37, etc.), etc.

#uniquePageElement { }

Includes "Status Update" message blocks, navigational elements, content sections, sidebars, and, for the most part, the named structures of a Web project.

item.title: Life::Repeat
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: S'pose, at the event of death, you are given the opportunity either to re-live your life again, as it was lived, by you, the first time, or to simply cease to be: an end, death, etc. At any moment in the construction of a thought experiment, nothing in the words which constitute the expression of that experiment compel one to treat them "literally" or "figuratively," "logically" or "whimsically," etc. What I concern myself here is with "structured experience." What sense can we give to such an idea? In a way, "structured experience" is a term only meaningful given a sufficiently complex language, containing relational predicates (X is adjacent to Y, (hypothetical) imperatives (the grounding principles under which objects of an experience are expected to behave and how one ought to behave with respect to those objects, entities, etc.), etc. The topic is of course phenomenological in nature. (Early humanity must have had a concept of structured experience, even if it is incredibly abstract, for the concept itself does not depend on a complexity of language. [Quantitative complexity, not qualitative]) We might say that to step into an automobile is to step into a structured experience. Or rather, an automobile enables a structured experience. So our initial thought is a presentation, a collection of characters, words, phrases, punctuation, etc. It is underpinned by a set of a logico-grammatical structures, quite like an automobile is structured by mechanical and metal systems, devices, etc. But with a sentence, or set of, and an automobile, each of which can be presented or have presentations, the structure of one is less conspicuous than the other. Of course, the consequences which may follow disrespecting the structure of the automobile results in pain, collision, mild discomfort, etc. With the sentence: nonsense. I aim only to make this contrast. But let us take an aside: What does it mean to "repeat" something? One might respond, "Don't play that game! The metaphor is quite clear!" But what must I buy before I checkout? : Lives can be thought of as sets of experiences, enumerable sets of experiences. In order for this thought experiment to make since, there must be isomorphism. (Often I feel that I am ridiculed for making counterarguments of this form: "There lacks isomorphism in your analogical argument!" I find this odd when I am pitted against someone who fails to recognize the conceptual status of his or her argument, for the Argument from Lack of Isomorphism is a trump of the intuition: "Well obviously it's an analogy, take from it what resonates with you." My claim here, the trump, is that nothing quantifiable could be taken from an argument which fails by the Argument from Lack of Isomorphism. Is a life a set of enumerable experiences? One consequent of choosing life-on-repeat is, well, life-on-repeat. So, in a answer, if one does answer the question at all, one has answered the question already. But, perhaps there is an asymmetry: Answering affirmatively entails that one has answered it before, and thus that lives are enumerable sets of experiences; but not vice versa (answering negatively). We have an understanding, roughly of what counts as living a life, what counts as living, what is alive, etc. "Life-on-repeat" however commits one to a weighty ontology, I think. But Quine might think otherwise. I am concerned here with ontological commitment, lives as enumerable sets of experiences. [This post has no rhyme; it is not linear.]

item.title: Description
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Descriptive language as the criterion for a sophisticated form of consciousness. Enables one to build in the abstract. The quality of descriptive language, which is a subset of any arbitrary language, determines the quality of intention. Without description, observed or otherwise, it makes little sense to speak of intention. Descriptive language grounds any conceptual scheme wherein objects are sutured to intentional frameworks. Without a descriptive "building up," even if riddled with falsity, of such multiplicity, which the world compels upon us, consciousness, C, amounts to an indissoluble, inscrutable mass of intractable qualities. Hence, we look for the Descriptive in animal languages.

item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: The bridge between morality and my favorite type of pie.

item.title: Candidates for "Claims"
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: 1. A/symmetry Skepticism: Stipulation of conceptual symmetry between two distinct experiences or concepts, whereby symmetry presupposes a set of concepts no less than two; as such, one attempts to defeat the claim of existence to the experience or concept under critical analysis.

item.title: Neuroscientism and Philosophies without Comrades
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
The idea that the neural can replace the psychological is the same idea that led to thinking that all psychological ills can be cured with drugs. -- Burge
Surprise, surprise! Reductionism in neuroscience! But not one mention of Peter Hacker or Max Bennett's work, Philosophical Foundations of Neuroscience. Sure, it's only one book, and perhaps it's great that this philosopher has arrived at his woes independently — but perhaps that's another problem: that the author of this article has likely only heard of it in passing, whilst zipping through the corridors of UCLA.
In recent years popular science writing has bombarded us with titillating reports of discoveries of the brain’s psychological prowess.  Such reports invade even introductory patter in biology and psychology.  We are told that the brain — or some area of it sees, decides, reasons, knows, emotes, is altruistic/egotistical, or wants to make love.  For example, a recent article reports a researcher’s “looking at love, quite literally, with the aid of an MRI machine.”  One wonders whether lovemaking is to occur between two brains, or between a brain and a human being. ... First, it provides little insight into psychological phenomena. ... Second, brains-in-love talk conflates levels of explanation. ... The third thing wrong with neurobabble is that it has pernicious feedback effects on science itself. -- Burge
One obvious consequence of "getting the 'mind' wrong" is that in lieu of motivating the introduction of novel concepts to the program of artificial intelligence, neuroscience of this unfortunate conceptual scheme/tradition presents an impoverished, normative model of the brain. Aside from muddling descriptions with confused and unfit metaphors, the corpus of neuroscience itself becomes a storehouse for antiquated empirical [descriptions]; more importantly, future science will have less ingenuity to depend upon, from current science, since current science is concerned with developing nothing more than a static image of not only its object, but of itself. ("This is what we [see] in the 'mind'"; as opposed to: "This is how the mind works. Is your object of investigation [similar] to ours?" -- I am sure this is the underpinning aspect of divisive science (non-collaborative science).) Without question, the brain and computer systems are ontologically different, but that difference need not carry over into the explanatory principles which ground our understanding of human cognitive, conative, perceptual, &c phenomena and categorically distinct artificial systems and sub-systems of AI projects. The bridge of explanations between these two discourses stand a stipulated conceptual asymmetry between their objects of study.
Excerpts taken from "A Real Science of Mind" by Tyler Burge

item.title: Clients: 1
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
His name is unimportant, and I won't bore you with introduction. Short of it is, he sent the following message to me.

RE:  Best Practice SEO: Body: http://yoast.com/articles/wordpress-seo/

It should become clear, through my second e-mail response, how my first e-mail response and what you see above are connected. But just in case: Open the link in the Body: and search for "breadcrumb".

First e-mail response

W, As to the first point, it is consistent with the one I made on the call. This has less to do with SEO and more to do with Usability (navigating the site more easily). And Usability is itself its own unique practice in Web development, along with Accessibility. Since the introduction of XML sitemaps, breadcrumbs have been rendered obsolete. Nothing more easily informs a crawler of your site's "structure" than a well-formed XML document, whose chief reason for being introduced as a technology is its structure and that structure's ability to reduce the interpretation required of a search engine crawler or parser. Granted, before sitemaps, breadcrumbs were a means of enabling the capture of a site's structure by crawlers, but at the same time, breadcrumb trails are isolated to one page. Thus, the crawler, for instance, would need to crawl the entire site, which takes time, more time for larger sites, to formulate a "picture" of the site structure, based on independently existing documents that contain unique breadcrumbs. A sitemap is one file that the crawler need only hit once, and for any subsequent hits, the crawler already knows where the file is (since no one changes the sitemap's location frequently, nor need they change it). Thus, neither point from Yoast substantiates the claim that breadcrumbs are good for SEO. They were an inefficient means to boost search engine rankings before the whole Web got smarter (smarter crawlers, smarter algorithms, smarter browsers, smarter, more robust technologies). I would like to make another point, though. It seems that the scope of our project is turning into something quite different. This is known as "scope creep." While I may be able to provide you with brief introductions to topics on Wordpress and comments here and there about "best practice," given the specific requirements and features of your projects, I have not agreed to a full consulting role, nor have I agreed to participating in argument-by-proxy with "trusted sources." You must understand what is communicated with messages like the one you have sent. It implies very clearly to me a lack of trust in my abilities and knowledge, as you do not indicate what you mean to say specifically, and given the generic nature of the article, one could easily infer that it is believed that I should read it in its entirety. I understand that I may have overly complicated our scheduled talks earlier today, and I by no means seek sympathy for my other projects impinging upon yours, but these administrative issues are very separate and distinct from what training and knowledge I have both earned and acquired over the span of my career. I really do not mean to be heavy-handed about this, or rude, but at the same time, it's not exactly clear how you expected me to respond to your message. There was no attempt to spark discussion and it seems somewhat passive aggressive. If you feel that what I have explained so far is inaccurate or unhelpful, please say this, but "corrective" e-mails with no foundation for discussion will do us more harm than good if we are to continue this project.

Second e-mail response

W, Actually, I believe it is better to call this Web project off. I cannot say that I apologize for my apparently quick-tempered response. This project, as you must clearly see, was taken on good faith. M D is a close friend beyond a co-worker/co-developer, and so my reason for taking this project had less to do with financial incentive and more to do with following through on what Matt and I mutually observed to be a low stress, timeline aggressive, high value collaborative effort. But with your message, you have committed three improprieties at once, which cannot go unnoticed:
  1. Failure to prompt discussion
  2. Demonstrated lack of trust
  3. Inability to follow discussion
To the first and second points, your message gave me no guidance as to its point, and this resulted in a passive aggressive implied tone which colored what could not be perceived any other way than as a test of my knowledge. I'm not exactly sure I deserved that. Put yourself in my position: As a developer yourself, in your field, you always meet clients eager to best to tech staff of their consultants. This is how you appear just by calling out that you are yourself a developer. So naturally if you send a message like the previous one, I can plausibly assume that you think you yourself know my craft better than I. And this, in fact, is not the main point, for at the same time, you describe yourself as a good communicator, one I assume has mastered the graces of conversational exchange. Your message, combined with the qualities of "good communicator" and "hobbyist web developer," for your part, supply me with compelling evidence to assume that you are in some way attempting to manipulate the terms of our engagement. Why be so blithely tactless if a good communicator? As a developer, this can only mean a lack of trust. You should have obviously seen that I would take it this way. And if you don't trust me, why should I not interpret your message as a sign of you yourself dropping this project. (As yet, you have not responded to my message and have gave no indication that you sent your own message by accident.) (Also, and this is just an aside which does not pertain to my actual argument, but if you're going to screen share, in the future, make sure you clear out your browsing history or disable thumbnails in Chrome should you have porn sites in your history. Perhaps this has to do with tact. I know for certain that many of my colleagues would terminate all interaction, lucrative or otherwise, should they find themselves, by no will of their own, placed in the unsettling scenario of having to see a complete stranger's personal, private pornographic interests in the middle of a conference call.) And bear in mind, again, the nature of the entire collaborative effort: You are getting an immensely fair deal; PSDtoWordpress (less than 48 [hours]), Wordpress set up, Wordpress plugins, minor consulting, possible design consulting, for $400-$450. Companies like psd2html.com, who provide exactly these services, would charge in the range of $900-$950. (Walk through their "Order" section and fill in each field based on the features you have listed in your e-mail, assuming that I would provide the "hi-end" package with Wordpress options and highest quality coding standards.) To the third point: You had absolutely no reason to post that message. Everything that was said about breadcrumbs was circumscribed by the requirements of The Daily Cougar project, one unique project. It was not claimed that breadcrumbs are inherently flawed or useless or that they should never be used. It was stated that they were not used, not that they should not be used. And certainly not that they should not be used on [your] project. So it is totally unclear what prompt'd you to send the message, given its content alone. It would seem that your intent was nothing more than to argue like a pedant, as if your message were a word of warning about the decision(s) made on The Daily Cougar project. (And what's more, your pedantry was sourced in outdated information.) With all that said, it should be clear what I have decided. Any further communication, as I am sure you can assume now, will be a waste of both our time. Your e-mail messages have been consigned to my "trash" and I have blocked your number. Good day.

item.title: On modal windows and "Lazy Interaction Design"
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Modal windows have become widely deployed in various Web applications and Web sites, largely motivated by their "wow"-factor. Without the right implementation strategy, a developer could turn Pop-up's hotter sister into an accessibility nightmare, JavaScript disabled. Without a fall-back option, for users who unwittingly disable JavaScript or who use assistive technologies not smart enough to interpret complex JavaScript, or which disable JavaScript for their users, a modal window design pattern could prevent, albeit small, a portion of the Web from accessing the important stuff, the content. Sure, internal Web apps or projects which assume JavaScript enabled are safe from such concerns, but the Web is a different story. Accessibility considerations increase the effort necessary to develop any project: it's a plain fact. If one wants modal windows on the Web, one had better develop a fall-back for the world of JavaScript disabled. This imposes a requirement of a flexible modal window library (usually), a need to radically re-consider one's development pattern (for implementing the modal window pattern and making it compatible within the limitations of the rest of the tech stack, client- and server-side). Now, most Web developers are aware of all of this. These points determine the frame in which front-end developer might participate any discussion on modal windows, especially user experience discussions. Typically justification for modal windows appeals to the dictum of shiny, new hotness. Much the same way Flash earned its popularity. Inherently there's nothing wrong with this argument: the Web should be prettier, have increased usability, accessibility, etc. But this principle of design usually is placed on the table without mention of the inherent features or technical aspects of a modal window. To say the least, user experience teams should bear in mind that modal windows are modal. What does it mean to be modal? One argument that bases itself in the concept of modality, sometimes proposed by UX folks, is: Restrict the interaction of the user to promote focus and usability. The modal window simplifies things for the user; it forces a user to attend only to the modal window and its contents. In a sense, modality implies urgency. I often see modal windows used outside of "emergency" situations or "urgent attention needed" situations (deleting that really important thing that contains all the cool stuff you have downloaded), but merely as a tool for narrowing user focus when navigating forms or submitting data. Moreover, it is claimed that modal windows promote usability (decreased mental/cognitive load) since the user is limited to a smaller range of actions to make within a Web page environment: the modal window visually and functionally (usually) limits what the user can do. But is a modal window design pattern really necessary assuming a well-done, logical information architecture? In many cases, modal windows are used to make up for less-than-desirable or poorly designed aspects of the basic user interface and IA. Like entering a building by helicopter (landing on the conspicuous pad) because the front-door is cluttered by people (say, because of a popular event that's been unexpectedly hosted inside). In some cases, such a (grandiose) entrance is necessary, but, switching back to our target concept, modal windows, in most cases they are used because the entrance (or the rest of the building; i.e., the Web site), cannot account for peculiar circumstances (say, when business requirements somehow translate into a 25 field Web form on a single page; or fundamentally different types of content sitting on one page; say, a form and a really important info graphic that the user must have access to). Split up the form, or just endure it (what kind of business is it anyway?). I'm sure there's a storehouse of IA literature that deals with simplifying Web forms. Hell, I should probably dive into it myself. Of course, Web sites and Web projects are nowhere near as complicated as a building's architecture and design. But I think the point holds: Where is the deeper argument behind modal windows? This is what I'm searching for, a justification beyond shiny, new hotness. More attention to information architecture and usability flow, I think, defeats the narrow'd-interaction/usability argument; and, what's more, as said, modal windows imply a sense of urgency, where I believe in some cases it is unnecessary. Why not just explode the functionality within the modal window onto the page, using some cool localized state management DOM scripting? Less "drilling down" and tangential interaction (going down rabbit holes) by the user; less round-about development and implementation (JavaScript enabled and disabled scenarios); less management necessary between front-end and server-side. And if JavaScript is disabled, pass that server-side to treat form interaction accordingly (hard way) or assume it (as if JavaScript never existed) through ensuring that "warnings" and "prompts," however complex, make it either to the Browser's confirm or some tangential flow that eventually puts them back snugly where they began. (You'd have to build it anyway if you had to build a 508c Web application: the more you localize functionality and compact it onto a page, web designer, the more a developer has to build out from it to conform to Web accessibility standards.) To say the least, it isn't quite clear to me that restriction of user interaction is itself a good thing for usability or user experience. From a personal stance I often find it jarring to have Netflix or Facebook steal my window. But I have stumbled onto an interesting opinion. Modal windows should only be used for complex tasks, never for simple tasks. Granted, modals may be jarring and they're sometimes counterintuitive (if done incorrectly). But look at Netflix's "Add" functionality. It is difficult to imagine what the alternative would be: a new page that loads, where you have lost your current, parent page's state. Preserving the parent Web document's state is important, but Yes/No modals, say on "delete" buttons, I feel should be re-casted into some other nifty UI feature: say, persistent functionally-modal tooltips. Tooltips that do not visually close until dealt with and who block the original interaction until dealt with. I'm sure there's a way to make these visually appealing and they don't steal your window. I suppose they would promote what I might call "lazy interaction." Sure, it's a big deal that you're about to delete your so-and-so account on the whatchamacallit CNI system, but one key principle behind front-end development is that false positive interaction should be minimized. We don't want to delete accounts in the system, say, only because of a user's unstable, dance-about shaky click finger and mouse. But such a requirement can be just as well satisfied with "lazy interaction" design. Don't steal or intrude on the user's system, but be more suggestive. Let the UI enable interaction, not enforce it. Though, with UI components like the one found in Netflix, I can see a justification for the use of the modal window: there's a lot going on in that thing. It's complex information more so than complex interaction. I'll have to consider this point again in the near future, but for some reason it seems independently compelling that one should use modal windows in cases of complex form interaction or rich information presentation (Netflix). Another good argument is for persistent forms across pages, like Feedback or Contact us, but this are complex forms, not simple "Yes/No" or "choose one!" forms, which is a common use-case for modal windows. Of course, it makes it even more difficult to see a good total justification for modal windows when the only argument usually is shiny, new hotness [and] given that browsers have innate modal window functionality. For me, in the end, the result is usually a wealth of hacks (for unruly, ancient browsers like IE6) and overly complicated development patterns across multiple languages, technologies and developers, all for either proof that browsers can pull 'em off or that developers are ingenious. I find it difficult to imagine that the average user spends enough time looking at the modal window to allow it to shift their perception of the brand or trust, etc. And largely the cool factor behind modal windows is bound up with, or follows from, modality, which inherently is neither good nor bad for the user experience, but rather depends on the nature of the thing given that modality.

item.title: &theism (and its criteria)
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
For a time I held the belief that all agnostics are atheists -- in philosophical denial, &c.; my conclusion here, however, more than less, will be that agnostics are conceptually confused (as opposed to being irrational or rationally unjustified), for those feeling TL;DNR -- on the assumption that the suspension of belief implies a lack of belief; therefore, all agnostics are atheists. Really, who could deny that a withheld belief is missing belief? How many other synonyms, anecdotes or analogies could I throw at such an odd, presumably rational rebuttal? It seems almost a meta-philosophical position, inherently so, that agnosticism! Contained is a positive belief (something epistemological, roughly amounting to some position about the state of Knowledge, &c. -- Would an agnostic entertain a discussion which presupposes philosophical merit to the term religious knowledge?) which fails to intersect with the conceptual trajectory of the question raised: Do you believe in X? -- Well, I don't know if X exists. I've felt this oddness so often: knowledge presupposes belief. So, as far as conversational* exchanges go, such an epistemological response begs the question, so to speak (*crude analogy, admitted). One is not being asked what one knows or speculates to knows but what one believes. My estimation now, from what of those memories I can gather, is that my early meta-philosophical intuition was something closely related to the subtle, festering unease & anxiety one feels when it is sharply realized that one's conversation partner has gone off-topic -- that is to say, that agnosticism is philosophically off-topic. So my "refutation" to agnosticism was at once both a fashionable philosophical subversion, OLP-style, within "skeptical" social circles and arrangements, and a nasty (usually impromptu) prompt: You're in denial! Now defend your atheism, heretic! And why should anyone defend their atheism? Is it not merely the lack of belief? Well, agnostics lack belief too! (Maybe!) But children, your dog or your neighbors dog, or your dog's neighbor's pup, grains of sand between your toes, field roast sausage, bananas, asteroids, gods (What utility do beliefs bring to gods? Imagine that!), all the tornadoes last Sunday, books, the Universe, atoms, languages, ideologies, sets, Numbers, political parties (except in an odd, figurative-philosophical sense but one could argue -- and I just might! -- an idiomatic sense), &c. also lack belief in gods, or whatever interesting god of the season. Then I learn'd of the varieties of atheism: weak, strong, strict, philosophical, practical, pragmatic, scientific, &c. And then there's "non-theism" and "non-belief"; it's a real buffet, indeed. What the varieties indicate, in truth, is that atheism consists of at least two conceptual components: a positive claim and, as discussed above, a negative orientation. The claim, such that God[does not exist, cannot exist, should not exist]; Gne, shall we? I'll explain anyhow. On the first, I would say it is primarily the basic proposition for verificationist language games. The proposition functions as a basic representation of observation-fallibility models of justification (logical positivism, falsifiability, scientism, pragmatism, instrumentalism, functionalism, &c). The second represents the logical model of justification (noncognitivism, emotivism, most philosophical positions, nihilism, &c). The third the moral, or ethical, model of justification (problem of evil, existentialism, &c). As said, this claim, constituted by at least three (I'm sure you can think up other categories) models of justification, amounts to the positive aspect of atheism. It distinguishes atheism from non-belief, though atheism presupposes it, and in similar fashion, the positive aspect of atheism distinguishes it from agnosticism since agnosticism is, if on-topic, at most a non-belief toward G, off-topic, a positive position as to the (metaphysical?) situation of human knowledge (epistemology). So, then, it should become clear, the crassness of my "prompt": if agnostics are preoccupied, philosophically (which can arrest one spiritually, mentally, intecllectual for months, years, &c), with, unwittingly or not, the "metaphysical situation of human knowledge (epistemology)," being off-topic, since it is a broader discussion and does not itself presuppose the significance of "religious knowledge," it must be a show of poor philosophical table manners to accuse and assert all at once: Atheist!, for one likely has failed to see the tangled alignment of philosophical concepts, and thus has failed to even imagine a response to the question; thinking, perhaps, it bogus or somehow inappropriate (the question, and sorry for the lack of due repetition, being Do you believe in ...?) The agnostic simply doesn't have a response because there is, in a way, and for good humor, a psycho-theological block. I could fancy the idea that since agnostics are intellectual champions, given the logical relationship knowledge and belief have, such that knowledge presupposes belief (or is "higher" or "more complex" or "tougher" or "stronger" or whatever), they need not bother themselves with the unstable domain of belief, where everything's more or less up for grabs anyway. One can believe whatever one wishes whilst agnostics leer in the clouds, plotting, scheming, dealing with the real problems or the deep problems, all the while, and to push this disingenuous hunch further, the problems of belief are ignored. My project here is becoming difficult to maintain. A re-thinking of the categories in which we frame these aspects of atheism may be in order. Instead of "positive" and "negative," I should use "transitive consciousness" and "intransitive consciousness" which, I believe, color the concept of atheism. We might say there is an atheist of and an atheist because. Most atheists are not conscious of the negative state they are in; and, of course, this state does not imply a philosophical position or any awareness that one is an atheist. A parrot could only parrot a proof for the existence of god, a genuine non-believer; but an atheist isn't just a non-believer. Atheism says something, beyond the "intransitive" business. Agnostics are "intransitive atheists"; this is uninteresting, but what is interesting is this claim, which I hope can emerge from all of this: To count as an atheist, one must claim Gne and one must provide a justification (which is itself bound to a "model" of justification) for Gne. So, to count as an atheist?
  • One must, ceteris paribus, sincerely believe Gne,
  • One must have a justification for Gne (which presupposes a satisfaction of the transitivity requirement and the justification's model may or may not fit into the three I have specified; there are more, surely!)
  • One may satisfy the intransitivity requirement (though, this is just the state of non-belief; in a very strict sense, with this terminology, the agnostic misses the object of denial, the epistemic preoccupation overlooks or perhaps blocks the introduction of the object; i.e., G, so, like an infant or a mountain, the agnostic is effectively in a state of atheism but one which is not conscious, transitive, etc.)
