item.title: # vs javascript:void(0); vs return false vs javascript:; versus javascript:func();
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
For basic hyperlinks, or anchors, there's no question as to what  the HTML content (the HTTP payload) should be; i.e., what one sees when one calls View Source or View Page Source: 
<a
 href="http://domain.com/some/human-readable/url/"
title="Relevant copy that gives a title to the link">
TextNode
</a>
But with the wild west that was "practical JavaScript" of the mid- to late-90s, anchors took on a various additional, sometimes counterintuitive roles, through the practices of clever Web developers aiming to build in dynamic behaviors into the Web browser. The anchor took on the role of being the sole event-hook -- from dry and boring html/text through the eyes of theDOM -- into JavaScript programs. Such practices were largely motivated by Trident browsers' limited implementation of the "onclick" or "click" event. Back in the day, one could not just attach onClick to a <div> or really anything else for Trident browsers: one got anchors and so one had to make due. It seems that even today some Web developers still rap about questions like: 'Should I use href="javascript:void(0)" or href="#"?' Of course, with libraries like jQuery and Prototype, such questions become immediately invalid. One finds in these libraries cross-browser sensible binders that allow one to preserve the Separation of Concerns. That is, don't put nasty JavaScript in the HTML source. The HTML source is the article for the crawler or assistive technology, and their parsing algorithms are going to attempt to overlook or get around aberrant forms of markup. But it still slows them down when they have to enter those sub-routines, and such circumnavigation of oddities in HTML schemas costs cycles, ultimately, for the overall task that the device is to perform. Even if these bots have sufficiently evolved to provincially comprehend JavaScript, and present it in a structured, predictable manner, this obstacle for bot-developers raises the question for Web developers of the best practice which prevents undermining those bots from accomplishing their task. Libraries like jQuery solve this problem, sure, but the question remains: Why do these practices persist? Moreover, it seems that each deviant form triggers inconsistent behavior across multiple browser platforms. Or, let's say, some forms are often seen as programmatically similar, in developers' unit tests, but, when actually, behind the scenes, they may perform quite differently between any two given browsers. For instance, in Chrome 10.x and Firefox 3.6.x, @href="#" and @href="javascript:;" both cancel the default behavior of an anchor, yet when binding animations, the latter "out performs" the former, or rather, ensures better performance. Why should this be the case for those browsers but quite different for Trident-based rendering engines? Does the latter form route the anchor's communication with the DOM differently? "#" hooks to @ids on the page, as an document-internal referencing procedure. Think pointing to your head when someone asks you for your thoughts, as opposed to pointing to an essay when someone asks you for your thoughts on the current nuclear crisis of country X. By the W3C understanding of "@href", it's fair. Is linking to a JavaScript file fair? In some cases, where one intends to offer a download. But what about an abstraction in JavaScript? Does sendToSiteStatistics() (a JavaScript function) make sense does under the scope of @href? Is this a purist's dilemma? Why would one refer to parts of a Web application? What does the user care? But the problem is more nuanced than this. One often finds, after Viewing Source: <a 
href="#"
title="Relevant copy that gives a title to the link"
class="sendToSiteStatistics openCrayonBox">
Open my Crayon Box
</a>
Say that after the user clicks the anchor, a modal window appears (openCrayonBox) which contains a slew of design tools and, implicitly, data is sent to the site stats application using its sophisticated API. If JavaScript is disabled? No sweat, it's a crayon box. Why would a crawler care about that? That is, it's a web application, or part of. It's meant to be used, not interpreted or "read". Fair enough. But what if the modal window contain'd simply an image? That's no different from an image on the page which contains the link; in fact, the link and the image may, in terms of View Source, be "sibling tags" (but we should really say "elements", since the notion of sibling is meaningful at a semantic-level (in the DOM) and only superficial at a syntactic level (the characters themselves can't know or care who they sit next to; all the same, the tags can't know or care; the parser-interpreter uses these arrangements of characters to build a picture for the browser, as efficiently as it can. So why not link to the image? Or perhaps a page that contains it? That bot or clever crawlers needs to hit something, and it certainly isn't going to try too hard to follow-through on what arbitraryFunctionFoundOnTheWeb() thinks the content of the @href should be. There's no connection between them, in principle, or implementation, rather, but one can be made in practice; and one often is. With functions in JavaScript, one can manipulate the DOM; however, the crawler needs to first find out, before all else, where that function is actually stored physically or in memory. Say, the parser stumbles onto the function syntax, then inspects all JS documents or <scripts> embedded into the HTML document. It has already consumed these chunks of code anyway; what else is it going to do with them? True; but who's job is it do pull off this parsing miracle? The crawler? The browser? The developer? Coordination is in order. But in truth, the term "arbitrary" is operative chiefly because in this context, it is meaningful. At least this is an assumption that the crawler must make; and a presentation change does not always follow from function calls. Why should the bot assume that it must re-inspect the document because a particular function simply fired? Functions do more than just bootstrap CSS (which is someone one shouldn't practice too regularly anyway; remember the Separation of Concerns). A DOM implementation is a subset of JavaScript, which is itself a subset of EcmaScript. The problem might be that any valid JavaScript syntax may be placed in @href. Is it the crawler developer's job to develop a generic solution that isolates the DOM from the superset that is all of JavaScript? Perhaps. What of those bits of JavaScript syntax that might disrupt the crawler insofar as its respect for the standardized @href? In truth, JavaScript could tell the crawler to stop, in a syntactically valid way (e.g., javascript:void(0)). That is, instead of saying something JavaScript can be used to force anchors to say nothing to the browser itself. Bots and crawlers must then keep this in mind when parsing JavaScript, should they bother to venture that fair. The gist of this issue is that many assumptions go into connecting the layers of the Separation of Concerns (SoC), and if crawlers want to "experience" the end result that those assumptions produce, crawler developers so too must enter the complex world of Web development. And yet, these developers wish to develop assistive technologies and data miners, not sophisticated browsers. Moreover, there are obviously better ways (jQuery with the right naming conventions for @class) to facilitate the connection between SoC layers. The question left: How should we respond to these practices? Do we toss the baby out with the bath water? Is there some actual generic problem -- when one takes a step back to understand the intention, effect and prompt for each approach -- that these tactics set out to solve? (And there are others, I'm sure; especially for canceling anchors and, seemingly, their communication with the DOM in which they are but a node). To me, they strike as now-outmoded by-products of the wild wild web, as it was just maturing from its infancy, and such code should be correct'd wherever discover'd. [draft]

item.title: The Problems of UI Development: Part One / <div> and @class-itis
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: JavaScript has received a bad rap since its introduction, and its notorious reputation certainly has come to precede its actual rank, expressiveness and elegance, etc., as a language. Moreover, in principle, the language itself is interpret'd; thus, its perception is inherently framed by those implementations -- Web browsers -- which choose to adopt it, with greater or lesser accuracy by those browser developers' hands. Unfortunately, all this spilled into the bucket of the "front-end engineer," since JavaScript is one of the many languages which this role oversees. Ill-reputable language, ill-reputable developer. Certainly a pragmatic assumption. But I should rather start of with a more modest topic, one which likely falls under the former, more grandiose sociological theme. Others might include Readability; a questions as to how OOP fits in given that most classically-train'd programmers and developers today stand firm either from ignorance, rigid definition, or lack of imagination against the notion that any of the languages govern'd by "the UI" individually possess the expressiveness and architecture to support more sophisticated design patterns (generally OOP in nature); piloting, or pilot integration, within legacy systems; the god of the gaps between daily methodologies between uxers, designers, business teams, and "centralized-compiler" teams; integration within management systems and code-generation systems; the role of the front-end engineer; the conceptual significance of description languages in Web application in light of the separation of concerns; etc. Today, however, I will entertain a perplexing question that for me remains too complex to state specific terms. At the moment I should wish to remain very distant from the stratospheric topic, or set of, previously mention'd. I am in no position to guard such a posture. The problem is this. Two principles guide programmers: Be Explicit and Avoid Redundancy. They are so basic and general such that rejecting them individually immediately engenders obstacles for developers. Not being explicit hinders code readability and comprehension; redundancy increases code overhead and, usually, decreases performance. All that said, a practical problem that follows from these principles arises when one determines a naming convention scheme for "meta-HTML" in the context of Websites and Web applications. Developers shun those who submit to <div>- and @class-itis, primarily because of an implied principle that was born from the disdain for bloated <table>-based layouts and templates. Now there is an implicit tenet such that <div>-itis, say, has a common methodological problem with <table>-based development: code bloat. But is it redundant? What exactly is the basis for attacking <div>-itis culprits? @class-itis is a different topic, since it can take on various forms. @class-itis is usually a veiled criticism of poor naming convention adoption and the misuse of @class names. Yet @class-itis often presupposes a kind of complex <div> arrangement, something akin to <div>-itis. A preliminary problem is the criteria for identifying when these suspect methodological patterns objectively arise in Web projects; then one might come closer to understanding the basis for the attack. For it is one discussion to have such facts about a Web app, say, be true, namely that there is a presence of this aberrant design patterns, and another to state why they are problematic for the context in which they occur. Above all this, assuming that transparency of architecture, or "being explicit," is key, thus ignoring the pains of redundancy, there is a question as to whether any generic, or universal, naming convention schema is palatable for wide adoption. But, on the other hand, considering the pains of redundancy, there is an initial question, I believe, of whether a "universal naming convention schema" for @classes in Web application would be necessary to trump the criticism of redundancy, code bloat, and other similarly incurred troubles.

item.title: User Interface Metaphors
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Another set of thoughts to be contributed to The Problems of UI Development.

How content determines metaphor

A Web project's content limits the range of applicability in user interface metaphor. Even further, then, since a wider range of user interface metaphor enables a greater potential for development of intuitive and accessible controls within a user interface system, a Web project's content partly determines the range of viable device-accessible development practices, where one practices the development of user interface metaphors that are conscientious of human and non-human consumers, possessing a wide range of psychological and physical abilities and limitations.

A problem for user interface management

User interface developers often speak of future-proofing our Web applications, and this concept has certainly influenced the development practices of cowboy coders and freelancers in the wild. Content management systems have broken down the barrier of entry which might prevent a developer from offering nearly self-managing products, Web projects and Web apps, to their clients. With these two concepts, self-management and future-proof, one might consider their application in the practices of user interface development. Beyond allowing a client to manage their content and, to some extend, their brand, a more difficult problem would be to allow them to manage their metaphor. By self-management, I refer to a capacity to allow a client to control and reliably choose a set of user interface metaphors by which that client might express her message, within a Web context. Future-proofing applies in a bit of an indirect way: By allowing one to manage one's own content, the developer in a limited sense future-proofs the project itself. This often translates into a break from "maintenance commitment" which clients often assume the developer implies merely in virtue of providing complex and, often counterintuitive, systems that is the product.

item.title: Please Scroll
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Look, There Is No Page Fold. Web designers and developers should embrace all of the UI functionality and constraints that makes the Web a sui generis medium for communication: the Web browser, the OS, the screen resolution, the monitor size, the device on which a UI is expressed. The Web's form is much different from print's, and this should be acknowledged fully by the UI and the UX designer. I honestly believe the only real reason this page fold junk conceptually infected web design is due the dependency users have on the mouse. Why else completely disregard a UI element that is integral to web design. Are standard UI components inferior when pitted against the principles of print design? So it's easier to scroll with the mouse since, well, you're already using it. To scroll the page quickly and intuitively, one may use the Page navigation keys, which are standards in most keyboard formats, or the Arrow keys. I wouldn't stop short of just calling this lazy computer usage, or a lack of disciplined understanding of how to properly operate a keyboard. Most users have no clue what Home and Page Up do, since their behaviors are largely contextual, and what's more, these keys are often hidden across a wide range of popular keyboard models. Even further, again, one's hand, upon entering a site, is usually already on the mouse. I s'pose it's a matter of consistency, or standardization. In any event, learn how to navigate with the keyboard, or something. But the Web isn't a newspaper, nor is your site a magazine, through the Web's semantics and aesthetic design patterns have flourished from the consumption of print's rich tradition. The point made in Debunking the Myth of the Page Fold in Web Design is a good one:
The key is to make sure there are no barriers that would make your users think there is no “below the fold” content. One example cited in the study had a large horizontal bar running across the page, which acted as a barrier — it looked like the bottom of the page even though it wasn’t. Eliminating the horizontal bar encourage users to scroll the page. — Scott Gilbertson, Debunking the Myth of the Page Fold in Web Design
Other sites:
  • http://thereisnofold.com/

item.title: "Rough Draft"
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
The following is the track order. My apologies for such a gloss with the metadata.
  1. Black Bones
  2. The Terminal Haircuts of Silouhettes
On Last.fm.

item.title: Open Internet Order
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
• Transparency of network management practices, performance characteristics, and terms and conditions.
  • No blocking of infrastructure-relevant content, applications, services, non-harmful devices.
  • No unreasonable discrimination (or artificial obstruction) during transmission. ("Information wants to be free.")
[Paraphrased from: FCC-10-201A1.pdf]

item.title: The Future of Names
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I am often unsettled when I glance at my "friend's list" only to stumble onto names not immediately familiar to me. Soon after, that guttural reaction to the unknown takes over. Sure, the program doesn't matter. My eyes wince, or I grimace. It is as if the name becomes a genuine presentation of the person, in the most literal way. We see them more and more often. Collections of texts, markings, signs. I s'pose, at least for my sake, more often than I see Sarah do I see "Sarah."
There are lesser unknowns and greater unknowns. We form positive physical attachment to those lesser. And physically shirk those greater. Hence, always take the lesser evil. Point is, such a principle seems nothing to do with our philosophizing, but rather with our hunting, living, roaming...

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Idiot.

item.title: INTP
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Often I find that others treat INTP as if it were some kind of disorder, as if "logical" treatment of problems is in some sense a fanatic's game, as if, instead of the assumption of "concentration," one is "cold" or "stoic." And usually the "problem" amounts to nothing more than a restatement of what INTP is (or subjectively seems), while the "solution" turns on ad hoc folk contrastive analysis of the "problem." Regardless of the content of terms like "logical" and "cold," I believe there is an overarching, widely deployed notion of "autonomy," or perhaps "liberty" or maybe even "agency," largely conceptually confused (and this goes without saying, usually; see: Hume) which, in a peculiar way, I believe frames those INTP or INTP-like, in the minds of others, as being categorically less autonomous, given a supposed indebtedness to "logic," &c. That is, a metaphysical indebtedness at all to something outside of one's self (where emotions are seen as, regardless of whether one can control them, within one's self; I believe anyone would say "one's emotions are external, in principle"). Perhap's it's all one sad category mistake. Whatever "logic" amounts to, say, it's nevertheless not in one's self, or something one controls. Consider Euthyphro.

item.title: Worlds word enough
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Words worldly enough, bitter enough and old enough, get evenly and repentfully enough;
Words well-formed enough and words whack'd savagely into catastrophe; words, well,
Words enough for me; And what if truth is what it is, nothing more, feel less enough those
Words woven against the chasms and crevices of every organ constituting all Whole
Words enough for you; And play pitiful and wrong on truth's cold weavings or prolong'd
Words absolved in the dusty shoes of a dried husk of a thought, some thought whose
Words wept with generations through; This or that fashionable atrocity subverting its
Words smashed beautifully into form; or post-back again every utterance before here;
Words enough will do; And again truth, somewhere along these lines must be admitt'd
Words alone may be hope enough lest the world be just that cold and old enough for
Words to merely show us some narration again and again, dry-eyed and scentless
Words enfeebled yet true; And truth again, or some other number, or world or two

item.title: Take Pills
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Pills. Take pills. Y’know? Take pills. 
These pills, if you take them, right? —
Something special. Pills. That’s right. 
And take them regularly. If you forget, 
the pills won’t mind. They’re always there, 
or around. You can come back to them, 
if there’s a need. Picking them up is easy, 
right? Just pick them up. Each day; 
pick them up. Put one in your mouth, or two. 

I cannot be buggered for your prescription. 
But take them, after picking them up, 
and after putting one, two in your mouth. 
Take them, or one; or any some quantity. 
Take them, each day; or we will not take you.

item.title: Grado SR225i
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: I cannot believe these headphones exist. — I almost cried. Something in me has been completely re-adjusted, re-aligned… The SR60s were amazing, but these literally fuck my ears. Literally. “Holy fuck!” I kept shouting.

item.title: Nether or not
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Frivolous, widely deploy’d morbidity;
Blind and passionate, quick to release;
Launch’d into the departure of death;
Rancorous diatribe of an ornery universe;
A god without sustenance save in its nethers

I said ‘frivolous, widely deploy’d morbidity’;
Quite blind and passionate, not quick but released;
Launch’d above the departure of death;
Ravenous for the rancorous diatribe of that universe;
Gods without sustenance save in their nethers

item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I simply find it odd that so many people demand upfront sincerity in love, or this kind of blind flailing about into fast-forward emotion, a rejection of the Material and a dive into the pools of hearts, in a world riddled with neuroses, moral and religious blight, systematic psychological harms, global-technojargonization, a world inundated by abject sensationalism which seems only to exist with the intention to desensitize for the next big tragic oversight of our pallid civilization. People desperate to stay afloat in a world drowning in intellectual disease.
People are weak — weak.
Not strong; nor composed; not stable; not “with it” or in control, not free; rarely ever capable, and usually with reason; and perhaps systematically under-appreciated while over-stimulated. Why should [love], of all the rarest emotions, be made even further beyond apprehension in light of the wretch’d and pitiable state that is “being human”?
What reason do we have to assume that anyone is any better off in securing for themselves that one is indeed the lover that others need one to be, compared to, say, determining what one first must needs for oneself?

item.title: The Other Night Someone Called Me a "Stranger"
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: The other night someone called me a “stranger,” after I offered a ride. This person also has slept, and probably made out with some other person on my sofa. And knows this, knows that I know this, and possibly knows that I know that she knows this. — She had a four mile walk at 2 a.m. from the bar. The morning next I searched for her name on Google. When my mother missed a date, I searched hers as well. — But that’s the silliness of it, for who indeed knows what there is to know to arrive at a reasonable next step? And quite conspicuously she made a pass at me some other night before. Maybe it’s this city? Absurdity on every street corner. Indeed, the same night my life was threaten’d in a restroom because it’s impossible for not everybody to have the same information. Like how it’s impossible for certain outcomes to come to fruition given one’s future efforts, and this much is clear, and it is clear; everything here is obvious. Everything follows necessarily as it has before and nothing is a mystery, except the mundane and everyday. Seems, anyway. Maybe I just keep around too many people who’ve got it all figured out, as if there’s something to figure out, to have settled. It’s charming, for a spell; the surefire with no misfire. What better place to learn humility than in adulthood. All I’ve learn’d is that there isn’t anything funny about it, except what in principle should make one simply wish to scream. If you’ve ever read Neverwhere: I feel like Richard, in the scene where he realizes that his ATM card no longer works, as if that is some kind of proof that he ever existed. I have these spells, wherein I feel to have slipped into the crack in the pavement between cousin dumpsters not seen each other in years, the crevice just forming webs in the attic of some house dreamt of by a child recently recovering from nightmares, the breaths unnoticed as music brings one into a dim morning world. But this is different. I’m fooling even myself in my promenades of self-assurance and established identity. The better half of the year, more or less, has been that panic-frenzy Richard underwent on the street as if a microcosm of everything Mr. Croup and Mr. Vandemar would put him through. Everything seems to be a terrible mess, and how many countless times — and if you know me at all, you know this — I have sat comfortably and with calm, ensuingly (word or not) entertain’d the countless reveries, rants, confessions, diatribes, etc. of my friends. Never have I felt so alienated and distant from, and I’ll point this out again sooner than later, everyone. I once emphatically attempt’d to persuade a very close-friend to read the Sandman, even physically exchanged the book — totally and utterly overlook’d it. Not pick’d up for any considerable length of time, or any length of time worth mentioning. At thoughts like this, I wonder what it means to be valuable. And why do I share with people, as I do? Systematic misfire — A piece of literature that I cherish’d, consign’d to the nethers and underrugs of some evening pregnant with nonsense and the nonmemerable. When should I start valuing anyone at all? My little cerebral world, filled with puzzles and world-word-play seems to interest no other. I feel as the space between others. It feels like a switch; where everyone is set to “mild inconvenience, but nonpunishable and hardly noticeable” and I’m left wondering. For instance, my moral friend decided that the best time to become my moral judge is after I’ve taken to the bottle. I said something to myself the other day, or the other week: “Don’t look for moral virtue under the bar.” And as if I have everything to be grateful for; as if I’m wrong in my positions, it seems every single one. Lately my skeptical auto-pilot has been full-on; hell, I can hardly sleep without imaging (not “imagining,” for this lacks the detail to which my mind transcribes the emotional terror) my landlord, who I know very little about, rushing into my easily penetrable home to slash me indecipherable. (And who better to say it? Why shouldn’t it be said? Perpetuating what? In the face of the grimmest image what can language do that is worse? Well, my language haunts me incessantly. It tries. If you think I’m overly wordy and often off-topic, consider how I feel about all of this. Then, what loneliness must mean. No shortage comes to this blathering simply because you aren’t around. Filled with images, disgust, bile of all sorts match’d with wit, eloquence, innocence and flame (and I’m mentioning here, for wont to claim narcissism) — indeed, it has come to the point where only this schism inside me, or perhaps this projection, have it as you will, and its verbosity can match the value of my deepest concerns. Most others ask me about the latest shows, or the proverbial “what’s up?” — if you don’t know, and you do, I’m not going to play some language game with you, on your terms; not to doesn’t entail that I do, incontrovertibly, require a shrink. — What is my language? — My face? Where I am? The boundless expression of my wit? Linguistic constructions sewn together from loosely connected memories of the yesterday before the time you once rode a pony into a ditch? — You’re talking about nothing in particular, as you might readily and jadedly admit, so why should I muster the energy to engage in a waste of idle phonetic markers indicating ultimately that we lack common interest?) Just in case you were unclear on what prompt’d this message. I have other motives; chief of them being that I’ve simply had enough. Even if I’m not entitled to lashing out, I’m going to do exactly this. Much of grief follows a dictum of simply “let the person be.” I’ve received not only this, but, out of some odd result, oversight. Never have I felt so remote from almost every person I’ve ever encountered in my life. Various of them talk my head off about things any person in their right mind, knowing the circumstances I am in, should know I am incapable of finding interest for. It feels as if I’ve stumbled into a small theatre room where on repeat is a broken reel of some child handing a lollipop to a widow at a funeral. Others in the know are painting me out to be a bomb, and others who are not seem simply twist’d or human. Perhaps I did this to myself (Can anybody read me? Even here? Doubtful.), or perhaps someone or something else is culpable, but the short of it is, I’m sick of weeping alone, drinking with people who are more interest’d in crowd-pleasing and keeping the thing that we had a minute ago before the beginning of the last bottle on that thing about the exam regarding the concept of the story tomorrow. One of my acquaintances even tried to sneak in a tangentially related joke about death into polite conversation. He eyeball’d me throughout the “conversation point processing” moment of silence — contrived laughter ensures; like a child who drops a plate, or the other thing, or that one time, whose eyes become glued to entrances and mysterious corners, stares blankly and dim-witted into the face of fear or the Father. As if I’m some kind of test bed for emotions. At my first feel for death, at its first genuine tug, I’m in a mind-field of tinkerers and rampant conversationalists. And all, again, as if, as so, like so, etc., I somehow must face a dilemma: Either I stay lock’d up with thoughts which only engender rage and insanity where I do not undermine the social norms, whatever they may be (because when someone asks you “what’s up?”, don’t be impolite! Respond with a cheer!), or walk about, leaving my emotions to take me as they will ‘til I’m reprimanded for emoting too hard, too extremely at the cost of others. Who really wants to talk the issue here? Indeed? Who wants to discuss the details? Who, even, is prepared to discussed such a topic with such manifest gravity? I certainly do not, of course, but I certainly do not wish to be treat’d as if a test-subject or as if I’ve obviously reached certain conclusions, emotional or otherwise, despite not having expressed or vocalized them. It’s like watching a football game where every receiver fumbles, but for some reason, the coaches play on. Another fumble. And another. Football isn’t interesting, but that should be a game to see! Logically no different from hitting, as a reflex, the “same keys”: “pdawouojihsarnfshf” on the keyboard in that hurry to save some abject porn video. Another presumed friend informed me that I’m “being analyzed”. This is what you say to someone grieving? Or not? There has to be a right answer here? Or not? Does this end? Or not? — Every turn I’m being toss’d curve balls with no clear intention of winning, an object, any old object should do!, except to revel in the curveballishness of the curveballitude. And then someone says something else. Exactly. Here’s another idiom. (If you’re reading this and you feel that you in some way are directly connected to some of my conclusions or ramblings, or at worst, feel offended, you must understand that, at this point, your opinion on the matter no longer interests me, whoever you are. How did I get to this point? Well, admittedly I “gave up,” to whatever extent this may mean, when recent events passed by some odd stroke of linguistic anguish came to be described, and once at all should itself be a sin, as a “ceremony.” Look, let’s play a game: Think of ceremonies, with the waving and mindless glee, usual occasional dance, the word “celebration” comes to mind, the intention to celebrate; so scratch all of that. But what of the verbal component? There must be one, indeed? And what must one say to death? Why must one say anything at all? And in fashion? Never have I witness’d such in apropos. Every revisit to the thought strikes me like a cell guard. 5 times used; 5 times — It has become obvious that I have pinned myself to a wall, and there may be little of a dignified alternative. I’ve certainly given no one any reason not to take a “hands off” approach. But in the past couple of weeks, I’ve drunk myself into oblivion, slept in the rankest of piles, walked the streets aimless for hours on end, cursed myself repeatedly with suicide and put cigarettes out on my thighs and arms. For no good reason either, or perhaps as a means to organize the emotions I’ve been dealt, but one thing is clear: I don’t get along with most people nor do I like most people, and it’s obvious to most of them most of the time. (Plus, “most” people would not read this entire message, and not out of lack of interest. My language is pinned to the wall.) In attempting to hide my obviously rank disposition, as I usually do, I’ve fooled myself into believing that it’s not true. Exciting. But now it’s obvious to me. That said, unfollow at will. I have no shame. Primarily because I don’t have anyone else — and I sincerely want anyone who would be inclined to shout “get help”: first off, one would likely only say this to someone one knows personally, very personally. That said, stop. Imagine, just imagine what such a conversation would look like. Is it not obvious that I would spend every bit of energy that I can muster in attempt to undermine and shatter not only the doctrine but the person as well? Have I given any reason to believe I don’t have such ammo? (This is the bit about feeling alienated. Either I’m an ass or I’m a complete buffoon at this point.) When I’m backed into a corner (or trapped in a bottle, as Wittgenstein would have it), which is what the whole subtext of therapy is, I will doggedly and ruthlessly attack; you know this. You do. Lock me in a room with someone for argument? I honestly cannot imagine sincere reflection on the possible outcomes has come to anyone who has ever suggested this advice to me; the crux of the point is this: if you’re really a pomo and all of that, where you gaze into the dimmest of installations expressing the vacuity of art as its message and find aesthetic solace in the pitiable moral bankruptcy of Miller or Bukowski, the untethered pseudo-pseudo-intellectual anthropology of the intellectual deceit of the 20th century à la Joyce or Beckett, if you praise the pain and inhale again knowing the ground-floor absurdity of your lifestyle, you will shirk immediately the notion that the Shrink is a blessing, for why should blessings exist at all? In accepting the Shrink, I accept that there is some right answer to any of this, that there is something which is “correct” for me … It’s all too suspiciously teleological; why can’t a mess just be a mess? And why shouldn’t the person who made it, or rather whose doorstep it appear’d on, clean it up? I don’t feel right. Yes, every morning, or some 3 a.m. I’m turn’d up with the need to vomit. The world less sanitary as a whole, and the idea of predicting anything beyond my hands comes off as a audacious effort at tying my own shoes. And yes, I’m supposed to feel that way. To say the least, it’s not obvious one way or the other; I’ve even had one person suggest medicine: as a response to grief! Unbelievable this country we live in, to some even grief is an error —, oh, and talking to my walls isn’t as productive, as the end of this rant shall again note.) “Always good to network!” — Why would anyone actually believe this? Is it true? False? What does such a thing, assuming its thingness, “picture” as it were? It certainly isn’t true for the aristocracy, under some social cases, and it certainly is hardly relevant, in the capitalistic fashion, for the homeless and downtrodden. — Is it Platonism? I came across a foolish looking website, something seeming to date back to ‘94 in terms of usability and style. Haphazard, wrong, clashing, illogical. Whatever the case, it proffer’d the notion that forcing one to live through what is an undignified physical effort (say, life-support, etc. under certain conditions) follows from the “monstrosity” of the medical industry. — Humans are indeed peculiar; moral for moral, toe for toe. It has become apparent to me that there is a certain requirement of “being social”; namely that one express interest and concern for the other, but what’s more that one minimally initiates “fun.” As if some peculiar gestalt; being social is the name, but “fun” seems to truly capture what “being social” is about. We often demand of user interfaces, branding, designs, concepts, etc., that they be “fun,” where “fun” is often ill-defined and petty, cheap, inane, in the end — a ragtag collection of niceties. Arrows pointing scatter’d; arbitrary noises; stream of consciousness confessionalism; sophisticated banter riddled with non-jokes for the sake of saying what one said — that’s all I’m sayin’; indeed, and it’s all a fuck’s worth of fun. Of course, all of this is qualified with that one is physically present to some extent, sociality being curtail’d by physical distance. All old news, I s’pose, but it’s upsetting. This reminds me of the accounts in an essay in the anthology, Language and the Social Context, of the Apache people and how they dealt with “being sad.” The section on the matter isn’t well-written and the quotes are too narrow for generalization, in themselves, but the gist given is that the Apache people understood that one usually took solitude as a means to coping with death. This meant keeping to one’s close quarters, perhaps one’s “rounds.” In my case, I’ve decided to venture on, as normal, as is demanded by both job and social obligation, yet in the end, I’ve lost out. Apparently I know no grief. Perhaps it’s this crowd; perhaps it’s this city, but the most absurd thing has happened, it seems that it has become unanimous that I am simply cold and, perhaps, a shell of a person. Persistent has this theme been: there’s not much going on behind what I bring to the present. As if I’m unphased. It’s quite unbelievable. Anyone initiated to the facts of the matter should hardly believe that anything less than suicide or drastic, violent retaliation count as the best coping mechanisms — But nothing so extreme. I’m simply “doing well.” I’m not sure how I convinced anyone of this. And it certainly makes continued interaction undesirable and markedly disingenuous; period. Well, well, perhaps I did this to myself? Perhaps this is what coping for me amounts to, as one of my professor’s would begrudgingly have it. Well, that was about truth, but what isn’t true or not or is but true then true is not what is. That’s a trick! I’ve managed my public grief in such a way as to demonstrate no grief at all! — It’s human magic. Simply being physically present, under certain contexts, suggests to many people, it seems, that one is of a certain mental order. How is this any different from Cartesian dualism? And why do so many people mock him when this pernicious mode of thought, this asinine dualism, persists and unfolds itself at every turn? (Likely because they never actually read Descartes, I’ll assume; why chase ghosts?) I often dislike noting people of my Spinozism, and that is usually for the fact that in the name alone it seems, or should seem, perhaps, that I find most kinds of dualist thought, which seem to infect most kinds of personas, characters, etc., of people, who roam the streets, the shops, the offices and the social stratosphere, freakish and conceptually unhygienic. Often this empty house’s offer isn’t much inferior to the vapidity of human experience. But at least I can effectively hide here. This ride has been one platitude after another, a fantastic overrun of platitudes — I’m reminded of the Odyssey Ed. illustration of “Overrun” —, and I’m sure I deserve it. Most people make being myself around them an insufferable experience.

item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Only becoming more difficult to get up as days pass. And sleep holds like beer. I’m to the point of drinking ‘til I find the right & chance opportunity to perform virtuous acts for strangers. Doesn’t help looking as I do; being so twitchy and absent-minded, something like a crack’d pontificator. Frenetic ramblings only to preserve some feeling that social experience has value. Half blind most days, which may change soon, but doubtless it should matter as I must feel disengaged from people, to this extent, for a reason. Idle speculation in the unfolding moments of my day have taken over. Mind becoming unwieldy & constrictive; people less clear, less compelling.

item.title: Wine on the occasion
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
When the world grew intolerant of those
Who took to drink with the faint’st need for occasion,
We and they return’d to our quarters and consummat’d
Our wills through the pleasures of intoxicat’d introspection
Under pallid shadow and the dimly bell

item.title: Bukowski
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Wake up to four walls, 
Walls all around you 
Every morning;
The walls don’t change
So why should you?

And that person, sitting 
As if cradled beside you, 
Who means absolutely anything 
To you, or nothing absolutely, 
Who whispers through fibers

Unawares, lines that pierce the rain, 
The wall of noise, 
The constancy of never change — 
That person shewing you 
The rain and the wall are impossible

item.title: Observe
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I do not observe, 
I dream —

  12. Maximillian Colby - Discography - Right Right Left

item.title: Treehouse
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Do you remember our Magnolia competitions? 
I was always just courageous enough to climb up the canopy, but never back down. 
We were so young; I don't deserve to be this old.

Once, you said of me, "she's the nicest person, but it's really hard to make her smile".

What happened to her? 
What happened to you? 
What happened to us? 
We share a face, but I don't see it anymore.

— Author

item.title: Safer
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I'll be safer
talking to myself;
Human beings are not
the right kind of thing
Through which I can be human,
lacking withdrawal of self,
For Common Humanity is beholden
to the crushing feeling of neglect

item.title: My one poet friend as many
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I'm rolling in laughter and disgust. Literally shuddering, shaking physically at this mode of thought. He refers to her funeral as "the thing." And when he got all self-righteous and indignant a month or so ago, after his sister's birthday, vocally attacking me, for being a "downer" to social events, etc. because my job was on the line, I had been arrested, among various other incidents, he responds, after I call him out on it, "That shit that happened like 10 months ago? (long pause suggesting that this is a fair time-frame)" I find the idea that someone's death "resets" all the social history between people who happen to be connected with the deceased to be the most abominable idea. Suddenly someone's death redefines all kinds of moderate indecency between people? How does this logic even begin to work? It's all trivial when compared to someone's death, apparently.  "When compared"? What on earth is that? Is that even English? How did this trash get into my language? What has anyone's death got to do with me smashing someone's window in with a baseball? Committing adultery? Unjustly or not, attacking someone verbally? Why should I even begin to conjoin these thoughts with that of the death of a cherished one? It's not "trivial by comparison." There is no comparison, unless the word couches some deeper thought. The idea of comparison simply does not fit. I am now to take the death of some person and apply a utilitarian-style calculated comparison against all other "events" in social life. Someone's death is not just some other thing or happening, some other note in the song, some other line in the sonnet of life, or whatever pernicious diminution. I don't nor do I want to parade about, claiming my Kantianism, but whatever that is I everywhere I can, in whatever conversation I participate in, must make clear that I not only disagree with it, but I despise it. And I think it will be one of the principle causes for the ruination of our culture. I hate the utilitarian mode of thought. It is morally disgusting. I change my tune. It's not poetry, in my experience, but poets that should be removed from the Republic. I believe I have come closer to a true interpretation of this work.
"Books, records, films — these things matter. Call me shallow but it's the fuckin' truth." — Rob, High Fidelity
I'll explicitly add to this, though it is entailed, but it definitely ties the bow on, I believe, an entire phase of my life which I am now resolved and comfortable to put behind me: Words.

Books, records, films, and words — these things matter. Call me shallow but it's the fuckin' truth.

Poets cannot let you have your meaning. This is why I despise poetry.

item.title: A house is not a home
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: I'll keep this short and sweet, since I have actual fish to fry. Or maybe not. But it's worth it. Trust me. And if you can, feel offended, I don't give two, and pass it on. (Tracy Morgan style: "That's a meta-metanym.") Two close friends, Min and K(c)it, have come to the opinion that my "attitude" is sour. And it brings the party down. And so on. Lost job. Got arrested. Girlfriend problematics. Et cetera. Put my pedantry first. Who gives two about the order. Rejoinder: that's my fucking house too. My home. (Do I need to extract the idea that their perception of me is inevitably going to be colored by their experiences with me at home? Next you'll say, "Well, they know how to distinguish between the two different Aaron's." I hope your degree in psychoanalysis, or whatever drivel philosophy you train yourself in saves you. But I am not going to argue that bullshit. It's my home. If you cannot understand that, god help you. That I should have to point this out: god help you. That it should be overlooked: you're an bloody fucking buffoon.) And others have most certainly extended their own opinions from the aforementioned. Is it my fault everyone defined that house as a "party house"? Did I invite you in? Drinking my beer, forming those opinions? Why "my beer"? Because by legal definition, my home has become a bar, or a private place, whatever's non-public, or fuck's sake whatever counts. I'm not sure what tortured logical acumen allows one to think that one shouldn't lick one's wounds at one's only place of recovery, repair, restitution… (And if your conclusion is, "That's not my aesthetic. It's an unattractive way of dealing with one's problems. That's not how I would 'lick my wounds,' as you put it," then fuck you. Actually, simply put, what the fuck is wrong with you? Exactly those words; generate the proposition if your wit can allow it. But I cannot help one swamped in such conceitedness. Or better yet: Get the fuck out.) But I'll ask the obvious question, turning on that notion of obviousness which some of my friends have come to hate. Which principle should I adopt? Maintain face for social grace, or salvage one's dignity where most certainly no one can kick one when one is down? And in the same token that one might argue: "That's what you signed up for by moving into the party house." The only response to that is ridicule, I firmly believe; I really think you should re-think such a position. But nevertheless, fine. Again: My home. Do you understand what this means? Run the categorical imperative for all I care. When you sign up as a roommate, don't air dirty laundry directly or indirectly. Fair? Fine, not fair? Not at all clear to me why, but shouldn't that apply those extending their own opinions from those who are in-the-home? Or at least take that into consideration when forming such new opinions? So I "went too far"? "Ranted for too long"? Again: My Home. How is this any different from the conclusion: "That isn't how I'd handle my issues [at home]." And if you're ready to assert that I was totally consumed, that I was unjustified in being that upset, I'd first ask you re-assess your understanding of empathy. Or perhaps the "unattractive" bit again. Because I was in a bad way, you know it, and relative to the sum total experiences we shared while I was in a bad way (and I will tell you again, systematic headaches, family continuing to fall apart, real threat of zero job opportunity, etc.), do you even want to come close to "totally consumed"? Or should I ask you to distinguish those opinions you formed either directly or indirectly from in my home with those formed after I doggedly hunted you down to spill all of my problems into you? (I hope you're not so infuriated by now to be incapable of perceiving sarcasm. You know me, I'm always a one-way street. I never listen. Need I go on?) In other words: Betrayal. If you cannot understand that; if all you can be is postmodern offended by these deductions, we should not have been friends to begin with. Thanks for wasting my time. I learned nothing from you. (And if you fail to see that the if tracks those sentences subsequent to the first, that it is implied, if your let your emotions fail to incorporate such an interpretation, then all the same.) And so on.

item.title: This is called bereavement.
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This is called bereavement. And if you do not perceive (not "understand") this, and you should not absolutely (I say this because others, some others seem rubbed that I demand such understanding, as if I am requesting, expecting this, as opposed to simple conversation with due care in words and wit, mindfulness and grace on the matter, and perhaps other matters -- Is this, I sincerely ask, so much to ask, even for a spell? -- Say, that it should first be understood why my behavior has changed at all, which entails an understanding of why it is that I embrace those familiar to me less, as if it would be some kind of surprise.), as this one must believe bears some measure of inscrutability, inexpressability, and as yet, if you know me: "Worüber man nicht reden kann, darüber muss man schreiben." And to those who feel I should obviously pour être capable de maintenir, I should be ineffectual in asking you to consult empathy, as your moral bearing, I can only assume, is other-worldly, perhaps even sociopathic, or perhaps your language has been sutured to madness (-- but I have nothing left in me to explain, as now I fear malnutrition and insomnia, the voices in my head, night-terrors, and so on have given me real, obstinate fear for my own well-being; and all I wish is to work, create, and breathe, despite whatever ambiguously disingenuous, rarely less than identical to practice in obscurantism and skepticism, amateurs académiques, grandiose, obdurate and stagnant psychoanalytic-slash-postmodern hubris-flatulence, along with appendum ad nauseum notes on suicide, as "support" and "commiseration," the older part of my "friend group" has proffered): ((Because, I have only one question: What if you are wrong? -- What if your analysis is simply wrong? What have you lost in attempting to confirm it? Can you even confirm it? And why must you not? Where does that put me, given your distance and utter rejection of verification? — And if your response is: "Haha! This cannot be real!"; What else can I say but that I genuinely hope you die in a gas fire; I severely doubt you understand the first thing about what it means to be human (as a social animal); or you're just a complete idiot who somehow managed to convince people of mastered literacy and even grade school intelligence.))

Web definitions

mourning: state of sorrow over the death or departure of a loved one wordnetweb.princeton.edu/perl/webwn (bereaved) a person who has suffered the death of someone they loved; "the bereaved do not always need to be taken care of" (bereaved) sorrowful through loss or deprivation; "bereft of hope" wordnetweb.princeton.edu/perl/webwn Grief is a multi-faceted response to loss, particularly to the loss of someone or something to which a bond was formed. Although conventionally focused on the emotional response to loss, it also has physical, cognitive, behavioral, social, and philosophical dimensions. ... en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bereavement Bereavement is a 2010 American horror film starring Michael Biehn, Alexandra Daddario, John Savage and Nolan Gerard Funk. It is written and directed by Stevan Mena. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bereavement_(film) The state of being bereaved; deprivation; especially the loss of a relative by death en.wiktionary.org/wiki/bereavement (BEREAVED) (N) The immediate family of the deceased. (V) suffering from grief upon the death of a loved one. www.readsomebooks.com/Glossary.htm (Bereaved) Someone who is experiencing a loss. www.harrisonfunerals.com.au/resources/glossary-of-terms.html Family Bereavement is an extension of Cast insurance. It indemnifies the production company for the net loss or for extra expenses to begin or complete principal photography of an insured production, due to serious illness or death of an immediate family member of any insured artist or director. ... www.dewittstern.com/content.asp To dream of the bereavement of a child, warns you that your plans will meet with quick frustration, and where you expect success there will be failure. Bereavement of relatives, or friends, denotes disappointment in well matured plans and a poor outlook for the future. www.paranormality.com/dream_dictionary_b.shtml To be in a sad or lonely state due to a loss or death. www.vnacj.org/about_us_glossary.php Grieving a death. Hospice of the Valley offers grief support groups, individual counseling and a quarterly newsletter to the bereaved for 13 months following a death. www.hov.org/glossary_of_terms.aspx The act of grieving someone's death. www.stoppain.org/main_site/content/glossary.asp means those supportive services provided to the family to assist them in coping with the death of the patient. [700.2 (c)] www.health.state.ny.us/facilities/cons/more_information/definiti… A process of loss, grief and recovery, usually associated with death. wisdom.unu.edu/en/glossary/ means the period of time, usually occurring within the first year after the loss, during which a person or group of people experiences, responds emotionally to, and adjusts to the loss by death of another person. www.carefordying.org/mainwebsite_html/careOptions/terminolo… A weakling's loss of a weak reference to another object, occurring when that object is not reachable along a path of strong references from a root object. www.mimuw.edu.pl/~sl/teaching/00_01/Delfin_EC/Glossary.ht… the grief and sadness experienced after a significant loss, such as the death of a loved one. www.responseability.org/site/index.cfm A reaction to the death of a loved one (for example, feelings of sadness and associated symptoms such as insomnia, poor appetite, and weight loss). www.theroyal.ca/en/mental-health-at-the-royal/mental-health-gl… Loss, due to death, of someone to whom one feels close and the process of adjustment to the loss. www.mhhe.com/socscience/devel/common/gloss/a-c.htm Emotional and role changes that follow death www.ncstatecollege.edu/webpub/blewis/NewFiles/Glossary1.htm… symbolizes your need to eliminate negative influence from the past. An aspect of you has to die before another aspect can find expression. For example, to dream of the death of your father means you need to eliminate the negative influence of your father. www.dream-analysis.com/dictionary/page10.htm is the state of being deprived of someone close (usually a relative) by death. It refers to the fact without necessarily implying any emotional reactions, or their content. Verb: to bereave. www.uib.no/isf/people/doc/grief/goodgr5.htm refers to the period of mourning and grief following the death of a beloved. carejourney.com/about-overview/definitions/definitions-b/ The state of grief and mourning over the death of someone close or significant to the individual www.torontotherapycounselling.com/glossary.html

item.title: That such is possible.
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: And with that. A very dear and close friend's first words: "I honestly wouldn't know how to handle the death of someone close to me, or how to comfort someone else who is grieving. Perhaps you could enlighten me on what you feel or what I, as someone who is not you, could offer you or should be expected to do." Stunning. Sublime. That such is possible. My response, or say "analysis": I say this -- that such is possible -- because, of course, perhaps "of course," I have been toiling, on and on, more of that grieving business. Bereavement, if you will. And at my last smoke break, I reflected on all of the responses I have received, from [no response] to psychoanalysis to skepticism and probing to ridicule to avoidance to utter forgetfulness as first response. But one response nagged me the most. As it pulled at my training as a philosopher. It was like "what would you have me say?" but it was framed as "what if were you in my shoes?" And it came not first, but after some argument. It came off totally insincere. It was more like "what would you say to someone like you?" Which in my mind sounds utterly evil. Asking a grieving person to consider how to mend him or herself. Of course, and I believe this "of course" is valid. If I should know that, I would have done it been now. And now I do have that answer. I would say, more or less, exactly what you said. Yet as a grieving person I cannot say it. Me saying this to myself does not count. And being incapable of such an answer is inadmissible to me. Posing that question though, "what would you say to yourself" however does not deserve reward of anything, in my mind. Because, well, you actually said it. This is what I mean by: That such is possible. I did not say it. And it is only possible that I might. And so, reminding me that it is possible deserves nothing. However a grieving person needs a certain something, I feel, that is concrete. And what you said is concrete. Real. Particular, explicit, actual, existing, in response, and genuine. Not a struggle to understand, but simply understanding. And I have lived most of my life by this rule: "Do not weep. Do not wax indignant. Understand." The author means "struggle to understand." But in rare cases, I firmly believe, it must means not "attempt" but simply "have that understanding as such." And this understanding that I believe you expressed to me is the acknowledgement that one does not understand. Not, absolutely not, that one should struggle, or be permitted to struggle. But simply that one is in fact in the grips of a struggle. This is what your words meant to me.

item.title: Top 5 Greatest Albums for Rigorous Study of Human Relationships
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Top 5 Greatest Albums for Rigorous Study of Human Relationships. In no particular order; or maybe one will strike me. Polvo: Celebrate the New Dark Age EP. Merge. '94. Or something like that. Oh, right. And one other thing. At significant moments in my friendships with others, where sincerity and wherewithal to engage in open steadfast dialogue of Self, selves, identities, and all that, for the first time, as a kind of baptism into seasoned companion, rare indeed, for just about anyone, but nevertheless possible, it is confessed that indeed one of my most valued qualities is the expressive and "animated" nature of my personality, in speech, ranging from Wittgenstein to the historical underpinnings of contemporary Analytic philosophy, under the rancors of the nuance often opaque in existentialisms, bad faiths, Satre's name pronounced in American English, Saussure's signs and other silliness, radical politics, the science of love, and on and on next to the shit I slept next to in jail. And then I'm accused of rationalism, or coldness, or something else turning on this double standard. -- "Don't be too expressive! And be expressive always as I see fit! I have sensibilities too, y'know!" When do I get a say in how you ought to interpret me? I might get loud. And the point about my race is that it all counts so long as you're going to stick to this abstraction called expression. It's constituted by all of my properties. And the perception of race in this country if willingly rejected; if one hurriedly seeks to reject or abstain from such mode of thinking; one moronically fails in understanding the historical underpinnings of this country we live in. It is not pancultural just yet. It is a total mess of interconnected histories and ethnicities of trial and tribulation. To willing oversee this is not a principle I should adopt for myself. I don't see why anyone should expect me to. But nevertheless: This is what it means to be me. This is how I express myself, all the way down the vertical organization of my emotional capacities. And to tell me that any of it is unattractive is to leave me unclear on where stand. And if you think I didn't see such an evaluation months before you did, any single one of you, then you must not have been paying attention to the moments where I am most silent. You call yourselves analysts!  In the end, you have to ask yourself, given this double standard: Did he ever viciously and without reason ever attack me? Call me an "idiot"? Simply insult me or present a kind of gross, toxic apathy that seems incapable of apprehending any interest whatsoever? Simply dismiss me? Has he ever been unclear and totally divorced so much as to leave no entry or exit? Has his language ever given to waving and the rancid, dogmatic idiom of our age, into the cliche of the multitude's thought, into obstinant blind ignorance? Has he ever not driven you to express yourself in a way that even if cumbersome and unappealing, manages to help manage what may be obscured by quite palpable human error. I may be expressive, and that's because I need to be... And you can probably rot in hell, or Montrose, or whatever city's your fancy. -- Third track, Tragic Carpet Ride, makes it all pretty damn clear. Remember? I'm the guy with over 300 gigabytes of music: looking for the story of another disbeliever fascinated eyes open wide every opportunity the eager receiver tracing every step outside don't back away from me now there's a strategy i'm willing to use stand in my path and i will state cause there's some shit that i'm willing to lose i won't get out i'd rather burn i won't trust scarred survivors and i will never learn tell me that you understand tell me why you look concerned tell me that you know or i will never learn Ash Bowie "shouts" all of it. Or so it seems.

of the coffee bar,

Is accosted by

item.title: "Report on Resistentialism" by Paul Jennings
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
It is the peculiar genius of the French to express their philosophical thought in aphorisms, sayings hard and tight as diamonds, each one the crystal centre of a whole constellation of ideas. Thus, the entire scheme of seventeenth century intellectual rationalism may be said to branch out from that single, pregnant saying of Descartes, ‘Cogito ergo sum’ – ‘I think, therefore I am.’ Resistentialism, the philosophy which has swept present-day France, runs true to this aphoristic form. Go into any of the little cafés or horlogeries on Paris’s Left Bank (make sure the Seine is flowing away from you, otherwise you’ll be on the Right Bank, where no one is ever seen) and sooner or later you will hear someone say, ‘Les choses sont contre nous.’ ‘Things are against us.’
This is the nearest English translation I can find for the basic concept of Resistentialisin, the grim but enthralling philosophy now identified with bespectacled, betrousered, two-eyed Pierre-Marie Ventre. In transferring the dynamic of philosophy from man to a world of hostile Things,’ Ventre has achieved a major revolution of thought, to which he himself gave the name ‘Resistentialism’. Things (res) resist (résister) man (homme, understood). Ventre makes a complete break with traditional philosophic method. Except for his German precursors, Freidegg and Heidansiecker, all previous thinkers from the Eleatics to Marx have allowed at least some legitimacy to human thought and effort. Some, like Hegel or Berkeley, go so far as to make man’s thought the supreme reality. In the Resistentialist cosmology that is now the intellectual rage of Paris Ventre offers us a grand vision of the Universe as One Thing – the Ultimate Thing (Dernière Chose). And it is against us.
Two world wars have led to a general dissatisfaction with the traditional Western approach to cosmology, that of scientific domination. In Ventre’s view, the World-Thing, to which he sometimes refers impartially as the Thing-World, opposes man’s partial stealing, as it were, of consciousness – of his dividing it into the separate ‘minds’ with which human history has made increasingly fatal attempts to create a separate world of men. Man’s increase in this illusory domination over Things has been matched, pari passu, by the increasing hostility (and greater force) of the Things arrayed against him. Medieval man, for instance, had only a few actual Things to worry about – the lack of satisfactory illumination at night, the primitive hole in the roof blowing the smoke back and letting the rain in, and one or two other small Things like that. Modern, domesticated Western man has far more opportunities for battle-losing against Things – can-openers, collar-studs, chests of drawers, open manholes, shoelaces . . . .
Now that Ventre has done it for us, it is easy to see that the reaction against nineteenth-century idealism begun by Martin Freidegg and Martin Heidansiecker was bound eventually to coalesce with the findings of modern physics in a philosophical synthesis for our time. Since much stress has been laid on the ‘scientific’ basis of Resistentialism, it will not be out of place here, before passing on to a more detailed outline of Ventre’s thought, to give a brief account of those recent developments in physical science which have so blurred the line that separates it from metaphysics. It is an account which will surprise those whose acquaintance with Ventre is limited to reading reviews of his plays and who, therefore, are apt to think that – -
Resistentialism is largely a matter of sitting inside a wet sack and moaning.
A convenient point of departure is provided by the famous Clark-Trimble experiments of 1935. Clark-Trimble was not primarily a physicist, and his great discovery of the Graduated Hostility of Things was made almost accidentally. During some research into the relation between periods of the day and human bad temper, Clark-Trimble, a leading Cambridge psychologist, came to the conclusion that low human dynamics in the early morning could not sufficiently explain the apparent hostility of Things at the breakfast table – the way honey gets between the fingers, the unfoldability of newspapers, etc. In the experiments which finally confirmed him in this view, and which he demonstrated before the Royal Society in London, Clark-Trimble arranged four hundred pieces of carpet in ascending degrees of quality, from coarse matting to priceless Chinese silk. Pieces of toast and marmalade, graded, weighed, and measured, were then dropped on each piece of carpet, and the marmalade-downwards incidence was statistically analysed. The toast fell right-side-up every time on the cheap carpet, except when the cheap carpet was screened from the rest (in which case the toast didn’t know that Clark-Trimble had other and better carpets), and it fell marmalade-downwards every time on the Chinese silk. Most remarkable of all, the marmalade- downwards incidence for the intermediate grades was found to vary exactly with the quality of carpet.
The success of these experiments naturally switched Clark-Trimble’s attention to further research on resistentia, a fact which was directly responsible for the tragic and sudden end to his career when he trod on a garden rake at the Cambridge School of Agronomy. In the meantime, Noys and Crangenbacker had been doing some notable work in America. Noys carried out literally thousands of experiments, in which subjects of all ages and sexes, sitting in chairs of every conceivable kind, dropped various kinds of pencils. In only three cases did the pencil come to rest within easy reach. Crangenbacker’s work in the social- industrial field, on the relation of human willpower to specific problems such as whether a train or subway will stop with the door opposite you on a crowded platform, or whether there will be a mail box anywhere on your side of the street, was attracting much attention.
Resistentialism, a sombre, post-atomic philosophy of pagan, despairing nobility, advocates complete withdrawal from Things. Now that Ventre has done the thinking for us it is easy to see how the soil was being prepared for Resistentialism in the purely speculative field by the thought of Martin Freidegg (1839- 1904) and Martin Heidansiecker (1850-1910), both well known anti- idealists and anti-intellectualists. It is in the latter’s Werke (Works) published at Tübingen in 1894, that the word Resistentialismus first appears, although it has not the definite meaning assigned to it by Ventre. It is now possible to trace a clear line of development to Ventre from Goethe, who said, with prophetic insight into the hostility of one Thing, at least, ‘Three times has an apple proved fatal. First to the human race in the fall of Adam; secondly to Troy, through the gift of Paris; and last of all, to science through the fall of Newton’s apple’ (Werke, XVI, 17). Later we find Heidansiecker’s concept of Dingenhass, the hatred of Things. But in the confused terminology of this tortured German mystic we are never sure whether it is Things who hate us, or we who hate the Things.
To the disillusioned youth of post-war France there was an immediate appeal in Ventre’s relentlessly logical concept of man’s destiny as a néant, or No-Thing, and it was the aesthetic expression of this that gave Resistentialism such great popular currency outside the philosophical textbooks. Ventre himself is an extraordinarily powerful dramatist; his first play, Puits Clos, concerns three old men who walk ceaselessly round the bottom of a well. There are also some bricks in the well. These symbolize Things, and all the old men hate the bricks as much as they do each other. The play is full of their pitiful attempts to throw the bricks out of the top of the well, but they can, of course, never throw high enough, and the bricks always fall back on them. Puits Clos has only recently been taken off at the little Theatre Jambon to make room for another Resistentialist piece by Blanco del Huevo, called Comment sont les choses? Del Huevo is an ardent young disciple of Ventre, and in this play, which is also running in London under the title The Things That Are Caesar, he makes a very bold step forward in the application of Resistentialist imagery to the theatre. He has made Things the characters, and reduced the human beings to what are known in Resistentialist language as Poussés. The nearest English translation that suggests itself for this philosophical term is ‘pushed- arounds’.
The chief ‘characters’ in Comment sont les choses? are thus a piano and a medicine cabinet; attached to the piano is Poussé Number One – no human beings are given actual names, because names are one of the devices by which man has for so long blinded himself to his fundamental inability to mark himself out from the Universe (Dernière Chose). Poussé Number One is determined to play the piano, and the piano is determined to resist him. For the first twenty minutes of Act I, he plays a Beethoven sonata up to a certain bar, which always defeats him. He stops, and plays this bar over a hundred times, very slowly. He gets it right. He begins the sonata again and when he gets to this bar he makes the very same mistake. He pours petrol on the piano and is just about to set it on fire when he hears a huge crash from the bathroom, also visible to the audience on the other side of a stage partition.
All this time the medicine cabinet has been resisting the attempts of Poussé Number Two to fix it on the wall, and it has now fallen into the bath. Poussé Number One who is in love, naturally, with Poussé Number Two’s wife, Poussée, mimes his derision at the woeful lack of manhood of one who cannot even dominate Things to the extent of fixing a medicine cabinet. While he does so, the piano, with the tragic irony of a Greek chorus, speaks of Poussé Number One’s own hubris and insolence in imagining that he can master the piano. Poussé Number Two is too busy to retaliate, as he is sweeping up the mess of camphorated oil, essence of peppermint, hair cream, calamine lotion, and broken glass towards the plug end of the bath, meaning to swill them out with hot water. He is desperately anxious to get this done before Poussée arrives home. She comes, however, while he is still trying ignominiously to get the bits of glass off one sticky hand with the other sticky hand, the glass then sticking to the other sticky hand and having to be got off with the first sticky hand (a good example of choses co-rélatives in the Resistentialist sense). Poussée expresses her scorn and asks her husband, all in mime, why he can’t play the piano like Poussé Number One (who has persuaded her that he can). Eventually she goes out with Poussé Number One, and Poussé Number Two, exhausted by his labours at the bath, falls into it and into a deep coma.
Act II is extremely unconventional, and although some critics have hailed it as a great attempt to break down the modern separation between players and audience it seems to me to be the weakest part of the play, the nearest to a mere philosophical treatise. The curtain simply goes up on a Resistentialist exhibition, and the audience are invited to walk round. While they are examining the exhibits, which contain not only Resistentialist paintings but also what Ventre as well as Del Huevo calls objets de vie (chests of drawers, toothpaste caps, collar buttons, etc.), the stage manager comes on in his shirt sleeves and reads the chapter on sex from Ventre’s Résistentialisme. Ventre takes a tragic view, of sex, concerned as it is with the body, by which the World-Thing obtains its mastery over human territory. In so far as man is not merely a body he is only a pseudo-Thing (pseudo-chose), a logical ‘monster’. Ventre sees woman, with her capacity for reproduction indefinitely prolonging this state of affairs, as the chief cause of humanity’s present dilemma of Thing-separation and therefore Thing-warfare. Love between humans, i.e. between Man (Not-woman) and Woman (Notman), perpetuates bodies as Things, because a man, in being a Not-woman, shows the capacity of all things for being only one Thing (it is all much clearer in the French, of course). Just as a man is a Not- woman, he is also a Not-sideboard, a Not-airplane. But this is as far as man can go in Thing-ness, and if it were not for women we could all die and be merged comfortably in the Universe or Ultimate Thing.
In Act III, the action, if one can call it that, is resumed. When the curtain goes up Poussé Number Two is discovered still lying in the bath. The tragedy of man’s futile struggle against the power of Things begins to draw towards its fatal climax as we hear a conversation between the piano and the medicine cabinet in which the piano suggests an exchange of their respective Poussés. The piano, realizing that Poussée doesn’t know anything about music anyway and will probably accept Poussé Number One’s word that he can play, queering the pitch for Things, with this ambivalent concept of love, wishes to lure Number Two on instead. (In Ventre’s system, Things are quite capable of emanations and influences by reason of their affinity with man’s Thing-Body or Not-other.) Accordingly, when Poussé Number Two wakes up in the bath he feels a compulsive desire to play the piano, forgetting that his fingers are still sticky – and of course it is not his piano anyway. The piano, biding its time, lets him play quite well. (In Resistentialist jargon, which unashamedly borrows from the terminology of Gonk and others when necessary, the resistance of the I-Thing is infinite and that of the Thou-Thing is zero – it is always my bootlaces that break and of course Poussé Number Two thinks he is playing Poussé Number One’s piano.) Number Two only leaves the instrument when he hears the others coming back. He goes to the bathroom and listens through the partition with a knowing smile as Poussé Number One begins to play for Poussée. Naturally, his fingers stick to the keys, the piano being an I-Thing for him, or so he thinks. This makes Poussé Number Two feel so good that he actually manages to fix the medicine cabinet. Poussée, returning to him disillusioned from the pseudo-pianist, flings herself into his arms, but it is too late. He has cut an artery on a piece of the broken glass sticking out of the medicine cabinet. In despair she rushes back to the music room, where Poussé Number One has just lit a cigarette to console himself and think out the next move. (‘As if that mattered,’ says the piano scornfully.) As she comes in there is a great explosion. Poussé Number One has forgotten the petrol he had poured on the piano in Act 1.
The drama is not the only art to have been revivified in France (and therefore everywhere) by Resistentialism. This remorseless modern philosophy has been reflected in the work of all the important younger composers and painters in Paris. Resistentialist music, based on acceptance of the tragic Thing-ness, and therefore limitation, of musical instruments, makes use of a new scale based on the Absolute Mathematical Reluctance of each instrument. The A.M.R. of the violin, for instance, is the critical speed beyond which it is impossible to play it because of the strings’ melting. The new scale is conceived, says Dufay, as ‘a geometric rather than a tonic progression. Each note is seen as a point on the circumference of a circle of which the centre is the A.M.R. The circle must then be conceived as inside-out’. Dufay
Dufay has expressed in mathematical terms that cosmic dissatisfaction of the artist with the physical medium in which he is forced to work.
