Kodak, approaching the problem from a different angle, has taken more positive steps to limit the ‘cosmic offence-power’ of the conventional scale by reducing the number of notes available. His first concerto, for solo tympanum and thirty conductors, is an extension of the argument put forward some years ago, in remarkable anticipation of Resistentialism, by Ernest Newman, music critic of the London Sunday Times, who said that the highest musical pleasure was to be derived much more from score-reading than from actual performance. Kodak is now believed to be working on a piece for conductors only.
I have left Resistentialism in painting to the end because it is over the quarrel between Ventre and Agfa, at one time his chief adherent among the artists, that the little cafes and bistros of the Quartier Latin are seething today. When Agfa first came under Ventre’s influence he accepted the latter’s detachment, not so much Franciscan as Olympic, from Things. His method was to sit for hours in front of a canvas brooding over disasters, particularly earthquakes, in which Things are hostile in the biggest and most obvious way. Sometimes he would discover that the canvas had been covered during his abstraction, sometimes not. At any rate, Agfa enjoyed a succès fou as a painter of earthquakes and recently he has shown himself impatient of the thoroughgoing néantisme (no-thingery) of Ventre, who insists relentlessly that to conform completely to the pure Resistentialist ideal a picture should not only have no paint but should be without canvas and without frame, since, as he irrefutably points out, these Things are all Things (ces choses sont toutes des choses).
The defection of Agfa and of other ‘moderates’ among the Resistentialists has been brought to a head by the formation, under a thinker named Qwertyuiop, of a neo-Resistentialist group. The enthusiasm with which medieval students brawled in the streets of Paris over the Categories of Being has lost none of its keenness today, and the recent pitched battle between Ventristes and followers of Qwertyuiop outside the Café aux Fines Herbes, by now famous as Ventre’s headquarters, has, if nothing else, demonstrated that Paris still maintains her position as the world’s intellectual centre. It is rather difficult to state the terms of the problem without using some of the Resistentialists’ phraseology, so I hope I may be pardoned for briefly introducing it.
Briefly, the issue is between Ventre, the pessimist, and Qwertyuiop, the optimist. Ventre, in elaborating on his central aphorism, les choses sont contre nous, distinguishes carefully between what he calls chose-en-soi, the Thing in itself, and chose-pour-soi, the Thing for itself. Chose-en-soi is his phrase for Things existing in their own right, sublimely and tragically independent of man. In so far as Ventre’s pregnant terminology can be related to traditional western categories, chose-en-soi stands for the Aristotelean outlook, which tends to ascribe a certain measure of reality to Things without reference to any objective Form in any mind, human or divine. There are even closer parallels with the later, medieval philosophy of Nominalism, which says, roughly that there are as many Things as we can find names for; Ventre has an interesting passage about what he calls inversion (inversion) in which he exploits to the full the contrast between the multiplicity of actions which Things can perform against us from a slightly overhanging tray falling off a table when the removal of one lump of sugar over-balances it, to the atomic bomb and the paucity of our vocabulary of names on such occasions.
The third great concept of Ventre is le néant (the No- Thing). Man is ultimately, as I have said, a No-Thing, a metaphysical monster doomed to battle, with increasing non-success, against real Things. Resistentialism, with what Ventre’s followers admire as stark, pagan courage, bids man abandon his hopeless struggle.
Into the dignified, tragic, Olympian detachment of Ventre’s ‘primitive’ Resistentialism the swarthy, flamboyant Qwertyuiop, has made a startling, meteoric irruption. Denounced scornfully by the Ventristes as a plagiarist, Qwertyuiop was, indeed, at one time a pupil of Ventre. He also asserts the hostility of Things to man – but he sees grounds for hope in the concept of chose-pour soi (the Thing for itself) with which it is at least possible to enter into relationship. But he is more a dramatist than a philosopher, and what enrages the Ventristes is the bouncing optimism of his plays and also the curious symbolic figure of the géant or giant which appears in them all. This giant is a kind of Resistentialist version of Nietzsche’s superman, a buskined, moustachioed figure who intervenes, often with great comic effect, just when the characters in the play are about to jump down a well (the well is, of course, a frequent Resistentialist symbol – cf. Ventre’s own Puits Clos).
The Ventristes point out acidly that in the first edition of Résistentialisme the word géant appears throughout as a misprint for néant. Friction between the two groups was brought to a head by Qwertyuiop’s new play Messieurs, les choses sont terribles, (loosely, Gentlemen, Things are Terrible). On the first night at the Théatre des Somnambules, the Ventristes in the gallery created an uproar and had to be expelled when, at the end of the second act, the inevitable giant had stepped in to prevent three torturings, seven betrayals, and two suicides. The battle was renewed later with brickbats and bottles when Qwertyuiop and his followers interrupted one of Ventre’s choseries, or Thing- talks, at the Café aux Fines Herbes. Five of the moderates and two Ventristes were arrested by the gendarmerie and later released on bail. All Paris is speculating on the outcome of the trial, at which many important literary figures are expected to give evidence.
It is, however, not in the law courts that the influence of Resistentialism on our time will be decided. It is in the little charcuteries and épiceries of the Left Bank. It is in the stimulating mental climate of Paris that the artists and dramatists will decide for themselves whether there is any future for art in the refined philosophical atmosphere to which Ventre’s remorseless logic would have them penetrate. Although Qwertyuiop has succeeded in attracting many of Ventre’s more lukewarm followers among the arts, who had begun to rebel against the Master’s uncompromising insistence on pictures without paint and music without instruments, without any Things at all, there seems no doubt that Ventre is the greater thinker, and it is an open question whether he will achieve his object of persuading the world to abandon Things without the indispensable help of the artistic confraternity in moulding public opinion.
There is no doubt, either, that Ventre’s thought strikes a deep chord in everyone daring these sombre, post-atomic times. Ventre has, I think, liberated the vast flood of creative hatred which makes modern civilization possible. My body, says Ventre, is chose-en-soi for me, a Thing which I cannot control, a Thing which uses me. But it is chose-pour-soi for the Other. I am thus a Hostile Thing to the Other, and so is he to me. At the same time it follows (or it does in the French) that I am a No-Thing to the world. But I cannot be united or merged with the WorldThing because my Thing-Body, or Not-Other, gives me an illicit and tragically deceptive claim on existence and ‘happiness’. I am thus tragically committed to extending the area of my always illusory control over the Thing-body – and as the ‘mind’ associated with my Thing-body is merely the storing up of recollected struggles with Things, it follows that I cannot know the Other except as one of the weapons with which the World-Thing has increased its area of hostile action.
Resistentialism thus formalizes hatred both in the cosmological and in the psychological sphere. It is becoming generally realized that the complex apparatus of our modern life – the hurried meals, the dashing for trains, the constant meeting of people who are seen only as ‘functions’: the barman, the wife, etc. – could not operate if our behaviour were truly dictated by the old, reactionary categories of human love and reason. This is where Ventre’s true greatness lies. He has transformed, indeed reversed the traditional mechanism of thought, steered it away from the old dogmatic assumption that we could use Things, and cleared the decks for the evolution of the Thing-process without futile human opposition. Ventre’s work brings us a great deal nearer to the realization of the Resistentialist goal summed up in the words, ‘Every Thing out of Control.’
<em>Paul Jennings, The Jenguin Pennings, 1963, reprinted from Town & Country (USA).</em>

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Damn it! We need to talk about Things. "To restore silence is the role of objects." I can't stand silence. But words, too, are desolate.

item.title: The typeface
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: I have just count'd ~25 conspicuously situated typefaces in my living quarters. Let us say, such a fact, that it is the exemplar basis of my quandary in hermeneutics. The philosophers do not touch such a domain so much as expose its anxiety. Language, say, is a footprint. Yours, mine, ours, and so on. This is the inevitable end of humanity. It is much clearer now that automation has been elucidated so imaginatively with computer systems. These typefaces say everything of my humanity. Class, madness, physiology, economy, potential, intellect, hopelessness, amorality, neural subsystems, modes of predictability. Qualities more or less opaque in each of us, in so many ways. Such is their existence, a volley — What might I find outside?

item.title: hashoccupy
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: #occupy need to demonstrate that the fledgling Web movement (moveon.org, etc) is underpinned by some substantial non-Web coalition, where the means of producing dissent are not utterly contingent upon the modes of production by which capitalism augments itself (The Internet, the Web, telecommunications, etc). The Internet, in the end, will hash out the winners and the losers. Democracy is over. Analysis of it amounts to nothing more than idle ruminations on postcolonialism. The Internet is the kind of social system where anarchy can conceivably be the basic structure by which means of production and modes of communication work harmoniously. "The Internet" should be a competing form of government; or let's say the principles and normative aspects of Internet relationships (assuming accurate descriptive models of subsumed relationships like B2B, interpersonal, etc) should define the basic structure of political thinking.

item.title: Generations
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Well here's a find.
Sanford Alexander Sr. was born a slave in South Carolina in 1823. His exact arrival in Sandtown Community in Neshoba County near the Bogue Chitto Community is not known. He was purchased at a slave market in New Orleans, Louisiana, by the Alexander family and brought to this area. Sanford was freed in 1865 in Neshoba County, Mississippi, at the age of 42. He lived 64 years as a free man in Neshoba and Kemper Counties. Sanford was the father of 10 children from two marriages, this expanded the Alexander name for over six generations. Sanford was a successful farmer who acquired several hundred acres of land. The offspring of this former slave are productive citizens who are proud of their heritage. His grandchildren and great-great-grandchildren are successful lawyers, doctors, corporate managers, computer programmers, pilots, professional football players, cattle ranchers, insurance agents, underwriters, educators and entrepreneurs. He died in 1929 at the age of 106. Sanford was buried in the Liberty United Methodist Church Cemetery in Collinsville, Mississippi. His grandson, the late Kutcher Threefoot Alexander, Sr., purchased a memorial headstone for his grave. Kutcher Threefoot Alexander found and preserved a portrait of our great-grandfather. Sanford was married to Charlotte and Mandy. His children are: Mary Alexander Polluck, Mike Alexander, Frank Alexander, Daughty Alexander McClain, Miles Alexander, Lewis Alexander (father of Kutcher), Jerry Alexander, John Alexander, Maranda Alexander Donald and Mary Louise "Lou" Alexander Hall. From "Kemper County, Mississippi - A Pictorial History", placed here with permission by the Kemper County Historical Commission. http://home.comcast.net/~alexanderpeden/FamilyTree2011/1.htm
I'll build out a CSS-based interactive tree later. I'm sure their hosting setup won't last.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Wow... That is quite a find...
And I agree - this information is too important to trust to someone else's web hosting.
I look forward to seeing your family tree implementation.
Dammit.

item.title: Think of <b>
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: In reply to: http://www.developerdrive.com/2011/08/10-essential-differences-between-html4-and-html5/#comment-345886528 The b and i tags are still valid and have a measure of applicability. Please read the specification before you attempt to instruct others. It shows a misunderstanding of the phrase "more semantic" when one says that "strong elements are more semantic than b elements." Not only is this not the case, but it makes no sense for it to be the case. The applicability of b and applicability of strong are mutually exclusive. For one, it is obvious that strong has a connotation to represent on top of the text itself where as b has no connotation beyond stylistic marking. Style is the only property they share, while their uses determine their meaning. We don't mean to only suggest, and nothing more, "this is italic text" or "this is bold text." If the task were that simply, sure, we would have redundancy in the markup, and so on. But "more semantic" suggests a measure of applicability. So surely strict observance of the specification which describes the criteria for use, and key awareness of doctype, is markedly instrumental to discussion. Worth a shot, no? Any mention of the linguistic markings which go on in academic literature, European, American, etc will easily attest to the major role of the b and i elements' and their meaning. Think of i as having an implicit meta-data taxonomization which may describe dialectic or historical data; we think this when identifying the Latin mid-sentence. In a web design context, think of b as the most basic textual representation of a "call to action." b represents a kind of thingness on the page. One way to look at them is with fear, as a developer, due to the verb implication of b's. They don't have much to say linguistically, in terms of the content itself or otherwise, but they do shoot upwards the idea that the text itself, as a whole message, stands in a certain relation to the web page. b, then, seems to me, under the worst case scenario, like a UI hook. Think of b as the "prompt" for inline elements. @see http://coding.smashingmagazine.com/2011/11/18/html5-semantics/

item.title: Classing Mnemonic, "HOMR": Hiding Objects and Modules Religiously
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
;(function(window, document, undefined) {
var Rows = (function() {
    var _RowElement = function(cellname) {
        var _name = function() {
            return "_RowElement";
        }
        var _cellname = function() {
            return cellname;
        }
        return {
            "rowname": _name,
            "cellname": _cellname
        }
    }

    var _CellElement = function(cellname) {
        var _row = _RowElement(cellname);

        var _content = function() {
            var content = "content";
            return content;
        }

        _row.content = _content;

        return _row;
    }

    return {
        "cell": _CellElement
    }

})();

var cell = Rows.cell("theo");
console.log(cell.cellname());
})(window, document);

item.title: Call: Listeners needed for TTS standards intelligibility test
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: "Virgin apple." — "That's that sad." — "Bridges ate them all." — "Nerf that bedroom, ma'am." — "Clock that replied, 'Spencer.'" — "How should gorillas share shit?" — "The thumbs rented a summer vacuum." — "The spasm is made of bureaucrats." — "I show stencils." — "The pillows questioned the cub." — "The jet pack left us." — "Terrorism claims us." — "Tend to read front to mum." http://languagelog.ldc.upenn.edu/nll/?p=3577 Try to adjust the pace you keep, as you engage the mechanics of the form and popup window pairing (try to use only keyboard shortcuts and commands for navigating the two), as if in a freeform conversation. It'll become very fun at ~35.

item.title: Web phenotype
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
"Language is part of the human organism and is no less complicated than it." -- In language we find that expression never lacks an authority, chiefly, one for whom such expression entraps and fails to disclose. Nevertheless, authority orients meaning, the stuffness and "poignancy" therein, those words, dry as they are, the objects of reference.
But what is language, indeed? The stuff on the street, hidden behind my showering wall? I see it here before me, and littered grid-ly across my screen and driver's side view. Perchance I should avoid such broad sweeping strokes of language? -- Much of that ain't language!
And yet the Web phenotype is lost. The extension of life, persistence, technically more divine, on abouts and in expression, than any religious doctrine or psalm. No text grants the doctrine of immortality, save the storehouses of the Web phenotype.
And soon, should it become medically relevant, as study wherein an age only real-time study is credible, morally and toward one's economic sensibilities? I wish to understand the language I speak, and yet the Web is here, stifling it with immortality.
What kind of god is this? I imagine in me, this one needs for you to know my Web organism. And why shouldn't you? Or I? What have I done? -- Lacking any opinion from enframement and mechanics of browser -- the perspective of forensics. A god that will let the linguistic phenotype exceed its parameters.
And what science demands to understand.

item.title: The patient code
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Lackluster -- the gripping stone ripping Bone into you --
Openly floating the patient code
The chambers of a rotten engine; Machinations terribly oblique
To the patient code

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: It's a fucken poem!

item.title: SOPA and the Extended Phenotype
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
The result is that we don’t seek reproductive success directly; we seek tasty foods that have tended to promote survival, and luscious mates who have tended to produce bright, healthy babies. The modern result? Fast food and pornography. -- http://seedmagazine.com/content/article/why_we_havent_met_any_aliens/

Some time ago I had a similar thought. It struck me after I found myself interested in autism, largely for personal reasons. Immediately it seems no less disconcerting to analytic philosophy, a tradition dogmatically rooted in a rejection of the historical mode (the dialectical passions of history). Thus, they must reject the propositions of history, but not that they are incapable of philosophical fruit, or even just assisting fostering it. Simply that it yields only anecdotal truth, something like relative truth. In any event, I've usually found it repugnant, philosophy, for this observation alone. -- It seems an artificial meekness. The peripatetics will likely find root in any genuine context for the explorative passions. With autism, the unclear idea may become clearer, the realization of a genetic safe-guard. Christians have an artificial safe-guard, their language; a principle of engineering abstinance, and at base, it is psychological. Their terms will refer for many years to come. Peripatetics, likewise, the mental obfuscation that language allows. Use in technology is inherently not philosophically interesting. Their façan de parler will be in tract. And really, how long can we go on with ignoring austistic claiming, for all intents and purposes, to be (aasimar)[http://www.jonathans-stories.com/non-fiction/autism-genetics.html]? Their language is above all the rest. If information wants to be free, at what cost? At what relevant cost? Want could information feasibly and conceivably damage in terms of the human phenotype, should its rate of production excessively make erratic the structure of the human condition? How can information be an enemy to us, a survival threat? How much semantic, architectural, economic, ideological scaffolding does one find in an interface? And how widely, systematically, and reliably are these languages deployed? As a child I never quite understood what the interface stood for. With legos, I developed everything. I'd learn the manuals, but after recurring parades of bedroom destruction, I would rebuild in my own language. While stepping through the manuals, I never would take the time to identify complexity. Every manual produced one construction. I saved the "learning of language" for my own creativity endeavoring in the Lego system. For years I did this, and I believe such practice instilled in me a capacity to reject interfaces. Let's say, the notion of the Common (polite dinner talk, morality, religion, gods, voting, popular music, etc). I often rarely _disagree_; but the grid is a bit off. I’m quite sure I am even less capable now; but often "representation" becomes a topic in philosophy. The interface is a unique manifestation of actual representation. Even more abstract.

"iP address"? That's something Steve Jobs did right?

The interesting part, however, is that the U.S. government, I think, is has (realized)[http://motherboard.vice.com/2011/12/16/dear-congress-it-s-no-longer-ok-to-not-know-how-the-internet-works] it too. A certain feature is required to address what Heidegger observes in "man":

Man is what lies at the bottom of all beings; and that is, in modern termsww, at the bottom of all objectification and representability. -- Martin Heidegger, 1940

Mike Judge, Steve Pemberton, and others have seen it. Soon our human phenotype must harmonize with the potential threats of alluring phenotype extension (now, as evolution would have it, between the technological mode of thought housed inside the human capability and the Semantic Web, a web which has internalized the framework development of the Analytics of the early 20th-century and the ordinary language professors, and dating back to the Latin with its prescriptive and proscriptive qualities, the basis of Cartesian thought, and on and on. The web is a systematic articulation of grammars: a complete distillation of power structure, and thus authority; the basis for understanding liberty, as they define each other -- thus, the incompatibility of the Web and Governments). In object-oriented programming we allude to problems like this by saying things like "that object is too big," namely suggesting that not only does it bear too much, but the complexity itself seems to imply only further complexity in certain undesirable ways. When interfacing with it, checking its properties, etc. Often I hear people talking about computers, the Facebooks and Tumblrs and all, as if they're natural events in one's everyday life. But with Christians, autistics, philosophers, and certain other types, these computer events are less accidental and more intentional; Christians usually in reaction, autistics in production, philosophers in speculation (meta-production). But the common thread of humanity will simply yield, and the U.S. government hopes to manage the inevitable rupture to the status qua that the Web is now presenting. It is a human psychological-cognitive scalability issue, latent with ethical strictures and with an underpinning trajectory to preserve the common language, such that the Web's rules for communication and privacy do not uplift what the U.S. government sees as protecting, protection of "We, the people". If the government cannot understand the objects of reference of its populace, it is no government. The Web and Government must pass over in silence.

This, too, may be happening already. Christian and Muslim fundamentalists and anti-consumerism activists already understand exactly what the Great Temptation is, and how to avoid it. They insulate themselves from our creative-class dreamworlds and our EverQuest economics. They wait patiently for our fitness-faking narcissism to go extinct. Those practical-minded breeders will inherit the Earth as like-minded aliens may have inherited a few other planets. When they finally achieve contact, it will not be a meeting of novel-readers and game-players. It will be a meeting of dead-serious super-parents who congratulate each other on surviving not just the Bomb, but the Xbox. -- http://seedmagazine.com/content/article/why_we_havent_met_any_aliens/

item.title: Whendy
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Sorry, kid.

item.title: Economy of silence
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Again, 'thereof one must be silent.' Where is this in our aesthetic? An aesthetic wherein a culture is no greater than its effects. Rooted in belief or by product of evolutionary narration, the explanation must concern itself with present existence of culture and the meaning such a fact holds with respect to it. The possibility of privacy secures for one the foundation for happiness; but as yet, the genuine expression of silence is incapable where the aesthetic exists. I confirm those in silence for its sake, or those who genuinely depend on it for survival. We live in an economy of silence underplayed.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Anything!
Hast 'ou been reading Heidegger? Perhaps you'd jive with some Contributions to Philosophy. That word perhaps.

I very likely would. I am a fan of Heidegger.
But at the moment I’m very much concerned with whether or not I actually have Asperger’s. Not sure if “awareness” of one’s symptoms disqualifies (as that sounds asinine and "philosophical" anyway), or to what degree, but too much of this is adding up. Sometimes it’s unsettling how long I can spend thinking about one sentence someone has uttered. Or spend working on one thing, doing one thing, missing what people are saying or being misunderstood.
Even today it takes mental effort to feel comfortable with people touching me. I often have to draft a brief mental list of "who's a friend" before I go outside such that when I do run into X, I can pre-establish/prepare what I'll be comfortable with. And often that thinking follows a historical progressive path _for the person_ or set of people I'm to encounter. I think: "Well, we shook hands yesterday; now, _this_ is appropriate."
I don’t… think I like it. Lately everything has felt like overload. Sometimes I don't even want to leave the house for fear of disruption... As if every day I expect to me restructured. For a while I thought I was getting "better," but it seems more like people are just predictable (cynicism).

That's heavy. I mean, if so, hopefully it assists in understanding and configuring your life. I dunno. I remember thinking I had ADD, possibly bi-polar. Then I was on anti-depressants but all that happened was an onslaught of breakdowns. I'm sure there's some short-circuit in my wiring. Was it time, place, a slip of seconds, a neural space? I dunno. I hate leaving the house too. So much. And more and more it's coupling itself religiously with some (may or may not) existent spiritual place.
I dwell on words, stupid words for far too long, though I try to jettison the "philosophic" hemisphere frequently. It chokes me. I cast it off, but it returns like a mercury boomerang. And they, the words, have more dimensions than our nauseating space, which we drift through largely mute and motionless. You gotta do, goddamn it, what you gotta do to make the many miles to wherever it is we're going.
Mayhap we'll run into each other's proximity soon. Until then, I hope something allays the slow burn of time. Whatever weight it has, I wish the best for my few friends.

item.title: Behold!
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Finally done with the idea, I s'pose. The design concept is based in a problem of personal organization style: Given that one's writing style will emerge and disrupt a design over time, how does one maintain connection between types of content? -- My answer is a command-line-esque interface which listens for hypertext entries, littered over the page and strategically/thematically named. [ The next design element removal should be obvious and perhaps shocking. And the vertical rhythm is spot on. -- An exploration into minimalism has its rewards, I suppose. But interesting problems are engender'd: Is a website not a program? Are links not its subroutines? Is hypertext a subset of English? Does microdata describe the program or the capacities for its use (which are infinite -- but the program is not nullified, then whence come the description?)? ((A programmer not read up on the metalanguage/object language distinction will never truly perceive the Seperation of Concerns. A world of pontificators.)) -- Remove everything. Undesign at all costs. What are input conditions (truth conditions)? ] Ramble, ramble. It'll still need polish. Nevertheless, this is A weedy florilegium (try me out).

Technical details

For type: I'm using a mix of Pigeon from losttype, an Austin-based type co-op suggested by a dear friend, and Philosopher from the Google Web Fonts library. The layout, constructed on 960.gs. Yes, yes, yes, wordpress. Repo here. -- I do not consider it novel by any stretch. I sat on the design of the toolbar long before finding the updated (12/2011) google.com toolbar hack. Of course, it's pretty self-evident that commandline-based terminals aren't new, only forgotten. I've only recently initiated myself in this world of mouse-less computing. And I believe it a skill only capable of exactness through experience, but at the cost of losing various modes of thinking which find source in habit and conclusion. I cannot be any less vague. But loss of linguistic form and grace is what it takes. For color the color palette... What the #fck7f4? I don't see color. I've tested in maybe two browsers? Then again, I test on just about every device within smelling distance. Internet Explorer isn't a browser. It's an internet explorer. Its chief purpose is to enable unfettered bidirectional communication between you and the world. Every attempt at exploration has fundamentally changed the course of human-kind. How noble. The internet is a vast array of -- I can't do this... Get a real browser. And if you don't like scrolling, go read a newspaper.

item.title: First Notes on Asperger's
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: I cannot remain ignorant on this question any longer. I've been having too many "it all adds up" moments. And sure, I'm twenty-six now: The question of whether I could potentially have a happy life, given the absence of normal social orientation, should be settled. In the end, it might be Asperger's, and this would be palatable. What brings fear to my heart: Going deaf, losing my fingers or voice, the loss of reliable mental performance. Often I've wondered if I have a speech impediment. I have far too much personal evidence from linguistic performance, or lack thereof, alone. Some people with Asperger's are known to spend literally days reflecting on single sentences, uttered or read, or resurgent; I am known to do the same. Is this memory? Which compartment? But what seems definitive is my upbringing. I believe it raises the interesting question of whether or not the Spectrum can be engineered in a person. -- I am by no means a highly intelligent person. Trust me, I've been there, through most of it. (Need I remind you that social intelligence is indeed a real thing? Without being "accusative"?) However, as a child, young teen (7 through 13-14), I had many, many imaginary friends. Some I keep with me, safe; the rest: hundreds of names lost. Often when you approach pomo-men or sentimentalist types, they will join in with you in a usually punctuated discourse on the finer points of Lego. Typically the discussion ends off at how much one had, and rarely, the discussion will touch on the educative-instructive qualitive of the Lego concept. Most males simply want to prove that they identify with something cute; others that they are so mature in their logical acumen, lego is a nostalgic experience (but now "I'm practical in that I can given up a kind of ivory tower behavior.") I recall quite vividly, daily, chasing down people to show them something I've built. Weekends were often dedicated to sharing Lego concept ideas with friends. I ended friendships on account of lack of creativity. Yes, Hitlerian perhaps, but I was maybe 9. What's interesting is that someone 9 years of age believed himself to be a critique of something. In this case, I s'pose, it was the arrangement of blocks, to put it in a philosopher's terms. In a sense, their import and significance is wildly low, but there I was, casting friends aside in the silence of my room until the next lego push -u origin shelf. When people mention Legos, that feeling recurs. At every mention. I suddenly lose the concern with being touched by strangers, my sarcasm radar gets kick'd, and I'm grabbing hands to dash off to some room in an old apartment that I haven't seen in a decade's time. I remember a room policy. There was a building time. How strange, that I allotted this for myself. Engineering Asperger's seems like a pointless effort. Some aspies consider themselves higher forms of life. So many heads, so many opinions. But one effect (which may have fallen out of this litter of wordsoup) is the activation of certain forms of highly accurate, emotionally dense memory modalities through the capacities of those affected by echolalia. Like I said, not smart; and whether the content is true or not, a major preoccupation of my mind's activity it seems is the relocation of autohistorical events through the exercise of known physical-linguistic capacities. Often times I will depend on and exploit language in ways that resembles religious practice, so as to get through a thought. But what counts as language?  I cannot withstand these thought any longer for the moment. Somewhat overwhelming, but to put it briefly: Asperger's explains too much to be totally unjustifiable or irrelevant. (And the great thing is, neurotypicals usually don't want to talk about how you may be of the ranks of Einstein or whoever the fuck. Or then there's the whole Rain Man neurosis that is now pervasive; like I said, sentimentalism, etc. -- The point is, if you want to fucking talk about Legos, don't fucking bring your bench team memories.)

item.title: # Heavy metal queen
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: ## First thought She's standing uncommonly close In those learn'd boots of only pair She knows it's been the long'st year With those wily lips curl'd to my ear Every grip and tug of her reminds Of old magnolia in only spring air Every glance the theft of wonder In her bosom and gun I'll wander

item.title: Testing Mnemonic: "A DEMO"
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
For discussion with testers. Applies to the "meta-views" for all Web projects. So, a "view" would correspond to a use-case. Developers product templates which are the physical components of the Web project. A "meta-view" concerns the "environment" wherein the view is perceived by the user. That is to say, what structures and defines content solely in virtue of the constraints and limitations of the environment. The physical templates combined with the data models (as used physical "data tags," (like {{ someObject.someProperty }}); since the HTML idiom is our base) produce views. The controller does all the magic, etc. The "view" has at least one sense: the use-case, but the use-case is defined irrespective from the "meta-views" or physical aspects of the Web project. A tester analyses and reports the physical limitations of the Web project (the code arrangement and the limits of arrangement). The types of code arrangement, I believe, roughly conform to the concept list in the mnemonic. Accessibility concerns human readers while SEO non-human consumers/navigators/agents/etc. The idea here is that a baseline set of front-end problems exists for each "meta-view" (I prefer to call them "front-end aspects" or just "aspects".) "Desktop" is where a majority of the focus has been historically. "Edit Mode" concerns tests involving, traditionally, "back-end" or "administrative" front-ends.

A demo

  • A, Accessibility
  • D, Desktop
  • E, Edit Mode
  • M, Mobile
  • O, Search Engine Optimization
Ideally, then, a successful Web project's issue tracking system should entail at least 5 narratives about these "aspects" (environments of possible user experience). So, let's prepare for a demo!

item.title: #sopa-side-effects
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
❝ Through the website, radio, phone calls, things like that, we raised about $1.5 million in nine months. — University of Alberta DCA Research Center, Michelakis.
Query: Could $1.5 million fund a U.S.-specific deployment to administer this cure?
❝ Scientists cure cancer, but no one takes notice Canadian researchers find a simple cure for cancer, but major pharmaceutical companies are not interested. Researchers at the University of Alberta, in Edmonton, Canada have cured cancer last week, yet there is a little ripple in the news or in TV. It is a simple technique using very basic drug.The method employs dichloroacetate, which is currently used to treat metabolic disorders. So, there is no concern of side effects or about their long term effects.
Boring. What's going on with this planet? [EDIT, Jan.1.2012: Turns out there's a lot of debate on the safety of DCA, but people still have hope for it. And are generally concerned with the lack of information on its progress. @see http://www.sciencebasedmedicine.org/index.php/the-latest-chapter-in-the-seemingly-never-ending-saga-of-dichloroacetate-as-a-cancer-treatment/]

wp:comment.wp:comment_author: a big brain in a wheelchair
wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Physical systems are altering. This rock casts off entropy into the cosmos.

item.title: Welcome to the New Dark Age.
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: So here's the deal. I'm wagering that you will never actually receive this message. I'm not a hacker, but what seems to be clear is that now, knowing basic *nix programs mv, echo, ssh, apt-get, their syntactical combinations, etc., configuring routers, proxying, rebuilding parts of the damaged Web, will become necessary to maintain a level of human dignity established by our creation, the Internet. A principled exploration into Babylon. Safe, assured, backwards-compatible. But this world introduces an economic class bifurcation too basic for the categories of proletarian and bourgeoisie. Low-to-middle-to-high-class spectrum rubbish. The Internet has self-sustaining complexity... Somehow. (For those tl; dnr: basically, Congress doesn't know how to politik this kind of innovation, I feel. It's showing in the cracks of the media industry: #sopa, #protect-ip, #nick-bostrom, #google-will-relocate-to-europe, #microsoft-will-relocate-to-canada, #microsoft-will-begin-research-on-curing-the-aging-process, #chi_b-(3P), #spinoza's-ethics-and-its-warnings-on-religious-knowledge, #noninformation-on-earth-shattering-cures-for-evolutionary-villains-and-drawbacks-to-being-human, #etc. It's the fact that you're reading this on whatever device, wherever it is that you are _right now_. Last week, some British kid kickstarted a millionaire-career after dabbling with a research web app as a side-note to his school homework. In the screen shot. Imagine something of that complexity -- just imagine mere complexity -- being handed around in grocery stores. It's not that Web development is gold. Or that the market's good now for the tech sector. In commoditization of data, we see a strange kind of science fiction. The U.S. needs to manage complexity. It's a fear-monger. It's like handing a (mechanalogue)[http://www.flickr.com/photos/wittysense/4776779403/in/photostream] to a primitive human. It's that I can make up any language I wish and have it bring about real change in the world. Why? Congress views every click of a link as a potential transgression of law; and they need the infrastructure to prove it.) In a sense, it has become clear to me that two worlds now exist. Marxists could not have predicted when the proletariat would need to secure its own poverty of the imagination. Democracy is just a category for Marxist theory, anyway. It's not a theory, it's an experiment that must be studied. The complexity of the Internet has rendered knowledge to the problem: Assuming that can understanding is possible, what real good does knowledge bring? I have discovered for myself that the world in fact does not want the Internet. Information must travel at a rate subject to human limitation. Why produce such a thing? That must grow in ways unimaginable? The Internet tells me there is a cure for cancer. That Congress -- the simple facts of what it is that they're talking about. That the topic is this, namely the regulations of #sopa or the #protect-ip. It tells me Canadians are confirming vaccinations for AIDS/HIV. Canada is just North. We've recently discovered Chi_b (3P). Like hackers will care. Like China could mobilize. I think we've hit a peak. Some say the Internet will route damage. But #sopa is the product of people fooling people. We mismanaged ourselves, and now Congress has simply become cannibalistic. This country has become cannibalistic. It's happening in glimmers now on your fax news station, or in your Times. And no one cares. (But that will change once other countries realize the U.S. is a #failed-project.) It's clear that this country is not ready for something like the Internet. What is #sopa? It's a #fucking-innovation-eviction-notice. --- Notice the dragged-and-dropped screenshot. Notice everything going on there. That's happening most likely on some rinky dink Moore's Law lovin' toaster. Your Macbook, your solaris rendering machine, your Windows vomit-garage. All the same, that shit is going on by virtue of commodity software. That science fiction. That obfuscated language of nerdy loverboys. That philosophical tone of matured technical mastery, almost sorceress-like. The DOM trees and representationalism gone mad with sophistication... Why is #sopa and all this strangeness of media fog of war going on? Well, I've always scoffed at those who raise the question, "Well, you're better off than most, no? -- We're in America for crying out loud!" Interesting. My only response would be, and has been, in convenience store scenarios: "Have you seriously stopped to reflect on the philosophical tenets of your outburst?" My most well informed friends will be talking about cancer months from now. And then they'll realize. The U.S. government and its political schematization of power was ready for coffee and oil as commodity. It's laughable ready for energy. And this is why Chi_b and the higgs boson research largely go unnoticed. This country and its humble religious background and cultural bootstrapping can handle the widespread deployment of simple-minded tools. But technology has adopted its candidate for first commodity: Information. And Congress has a response: "WHAT THE FUCK? SLOW THE FUCK DOWN." Welcome to the New Dark Age.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
1. Rate limited by human faculty of accessing and performing operations with data. Biologically limited system. Not sold on it being a necessary, hard, or inviolable limit. Indifferent to the facticity of "hard AI".
2. Sold on the dark age bit. Peppered with a bit of enlightenment era hubris, sufficiently advanced technologically opulent society will endure shifting norms, as bio-hedonism becomes the mark of virtue.
3. Good point raised with the importance of knowledge. Should knowledge bring improvement? I think the tragic state of things (Prometheus, the tree of knowledge, the Iron Age) was apprehended time ago. Hell, even philosophic anamnesis suggests it. Not everyone handles knowledge (or information) in the same manner. See last clause of 2. What do we mean when we speak of the initiate? Arbitrary power structure or prudence? Even if arbitrary, then all arbitrary and so why not, where does civility gain its thrust? Even if relativism, or no "legitimate" moral ground, that doesn't imply a defense of enlightenment ethics (which was already ethics corroded quite a bit).
4. I see the explosion of the microchip and then its trickle down into other markets, introduction of the pc, the cell phone, the internet: a general shift of the market value of information--- as fairly responsible for boom in world population. Floated on credit, which got its "lasting appeal" in the computer age, and now credit to absurdity. That's obviously coming down. But so have (and for a longer time) advancements in microchips, as they've been "regulated" on the market via entertainment feedback on the part of consumers. That was what really spurred the explosion of the home pc and the internet (which became widespread in homes even faster than the pc). Personal control of content, and sufficiently stimulating content. Combined with the physical limitations of 2dimensional chips. Plateau. The new markets had been established. Microchips in cars, microchips in blenders. It's the norm. Boom is bust. Excess cash flowing around, excess going to entertainment, parts made in third world countries, excess going to humanitarian organizations, more unendemic food sources. Population up. No boom seen of that magnitude. Next boom, if it can be reached, will be a continuation of the refinement of information. But how to make that narcotic appealing to consumers? Control of 3d spaces. Holographs, biotech, nanotech. (Not to mention the humanitarian benefits medical science will accrue.) Government will limit like a dying madman.
I'm not sold on it not limiting. I think that urge comes from that last clause of 2. Maybe Nietzsche called that nihilism, I have no fucking clue.
Should life be about living, or waiting? That seems to be the final question of technology.
"Censorship is telling a man he can't have a steak just because a baby can't chew it." -Mark Twain

item.title: Web workin'
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: The total collection and chronological arrangement of one's actual and potential IP address states defines one's spirit. The engagement of a link so as to follow it is an action. One may, naturally, follow a link blindly or wittingly. One may be destroyed or rewarded. The U.S. government has made it clear that the following of a link, a particular form of engagement, is politically interesting. The proliferation of links, a problem for education, and insofar as link debt. We may also consider a language for describing the roaming, formation, flocking, hiberation and so on, of links. As we believe that the Web breathes, that the Web's complexity is self-sustaining: that the Web and the Internet are not one -- that we can imagine the Web without the Internet, and without the physical limitation its superstructure brings -- it should become clear that the basic currency of the Web (as a sui generis economic system incompatible with democratic installations) and the following of a link must be made known. That is, in light of the unexpected intrusion of the earthshakers into the Web's ethical and philosophical space. You can see this interpretation now. Recent legislation is considered damage or something like a virus. In the Web, things like #sopa don't live long enough to become a political concept.

item.title: O beautiful type
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
What a lie
[This experiment is an end to poetry: A poem whose meaning first follows from the nonhomogeneous collective experience of the hyperlink.]

item.title: #ndaa
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
A writeup.
SEC. 1031. AFFIRMATION OF AUTHORITY OF THE ARMED FORCES OF THE UNITED STATES TO DETAIN COVERED PERSONS PURSUANT TO THE AUTHORIZATION FOR USE OF MILITARY FORCE. Paragraph (e) “Authorities- Nothing in this section shall be construed to affect existing law or authorities, relating to the detention of United States citizens, lawful resident aliens of the United States or any other persons who are captured or arrested in the United States.” SEC. 1032. REQUIREMENT FOR MILITARY CUSTODY. Paragraph (b) Applicability to United States Citizens and Lawful Resident Aliens- (1) UNITED STATES CITIZENS- The requirement to detain a person in military custody under this section does not extend to citizens of the United States. (2) LAWFUL RESIDENT ALIENS- The requirement to detain a person in military custody under this section does not extend to a lawful resident alien of the United States on the basis of conduct taking place within the United States, except to the extent permitted by the Constitution of the United States. -- Text of S. 1867: National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2012

item.title: #pipa will not win
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Developer #1: Look at this beautiful website: *jazz hands* [caption id="attachment_2970" align="aligncenter" width="940" caption="www.opencongress.org - PIPA first on Senate agenda on Jan. 24th, 2012 - Blog - OpenCongress"][/caption] Developer #2: Legislation like this does something funny. Developer #1: Have you ever seriously wondered, how does one actually piss off a programmer? Developer #2: What, at a dinner party or in a polite family reunion? Developer #1: Assume you're a cocky marry-in. Well, you ask that person to recant their GPL licenses. You ask all of them to do this. You ask them to take the document their hero, Stallman, the guy they don't talk about much, the document he drafted. Which they accepted into their hearts. And well, now they just don't talk about him much anymore. Developer #2: You ask them to dig that guy up. And delete him from their repositories! Developer #1: Hahah. You think they're going to win that?

item.title: A friend renders a deadly serious game, "What is the Internet?"
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: We're authors too. We call our leaders "benevolent dictators for life". Things like that. We aren't governments building sites. We're people who stay up and toil for something most people never see. I'm usually expected to defer or effect a continued veil over my work, but in light of the direct, expressed assault on it by the United States: I'll say something. The Internet is a marketplace that people have been experimenting with for the past 20 years. That DARPA stuff isn't it. The Web browser was our gateway drug. Imagine the whacky hobbyist who collects pigeon beaks to produce a sculpture so immense, complex and pointless. When people do this in concert, the idea emerges that the complexity of doing so in such fashion produces other structures. My friends, we are drafting programming languages so to assert our eternity in the light of the coming accelerated mass production of the computer system. We cannot stop it. And we're not really doing "it," are we? The Internet is a twilight graveyard (alluding to the place dragons go when they die in the DND universe; these are the kinds of narratives, truths, that we have allowed to harmoniously merge into our marketsquares; pixies, porn and art deco chairs). Hoarders, collectors, OCD people and this ilk have built a system for communication whose only material assumption is the existence of the number system. The Internet needs IP addresses, not computers. This is why we are building commercial quantum computation systems NOW. Imagine if you could put the DNS system ANYWHERE and claim that it without proper Observation statements, it exists nowhere? All we need is the number theory. The fact that the Internet is on a planet now is a fact of nature. With these laws and these terminals owned by the same markets that import cheese and porn. On this planet the only poignant metaphor that works is that the DNS is a phone book. The Internet a marketplace. The Web is its newspaper. Hyperlinks are the basic currency. Money is a transitional phase to us. Our licenses that protect our ideas, between ourselves, where we've hoarded and brewed since the first implementation of the Internet, do not understand "money". You have to understand that these documents exist. The Internet, in the Marxist-Capitalist idiom or narrative is an implementation of anarchy. My friend, Congress just asked that question. You're asking me and my peers what we've been up to? While I entertain your views on money, the cynicism, the moderate views, others with extreme views, etc, I've been building the Internet On Your Soil. And it does Not need money. Our licensing system IS our Dispute Resolution Guideline, and we all know it by heart. The Internet is monolithic anarchy.

item.title: The Intellect
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I am living in a world Where my philosophers Are defeated by pens
I am living in a world Where logic dictates Greater than fewer
I am living in a world Where the proletarian May index her labor

item.title: A convergence of worlds
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
He who fights with monsters should look to it that he himself does not become a monster. And when you gaze long into an abyss the abyss also gazes into you.
I would like to describe for you, what I consider to be the beginning of an epoch: the convergence of worlds. Where I become a micro science fiction publisher, or you confess to the coming of an end. Sincerely, with salivation and grievances. Please pardon that I should be so cliche, in choosing Nietzsche. It simply dawn'd on me, the acute sting of anxiety in one's vacillating mind. Some days it ceases, but today, we might call it a quaint emancipation. Whatever it is, what remains clear is that should it happen at all is the same kind of question as why any of it should be. Dear brothers and sisters, Enemies and Friends, we have set our hearts to build the Tower of Babel. There is something we all have in common, and that is which is not. The stone, the brick, a whistle, a rub. These things are, and quite so they cannot not. It's quite simple. You see, the hyperlink is not. What indeed does it contain? My philosophers, I ask you: What if it contains nothing? A supreme ethicist might reply: "Well, indeed! One's politics should be highly subject to fear should it become interesting to the fewer of the greater!" -- "What if they truly are saying nothing?" You see it on television shows, film noirs, police dra-mas. The moment of dead silence. This is what the world has come to, for we are applied at the thought. One might say, that in a definitive sense we have solved the mind-body problem. A hyperlink consists of two parts, part stone and part spirit. We may traverse the history of stone, and the history of heaven: the heaven unto we shall build. On earth, we have accomplish'd a number of things. We have come near to the thought of deep exploration. Miraculous science and art, but yet as like with old, it is our selves which has consumed us. Our names shall be scattered across the earth. What I say to you is this. When you share a hyperlink, you say two things, what is commonly called a tag's "hypertext" and what is called the "hyperlink." The distinct is deadly serious, as it were. If your government wants to know what you've shared it shall coincidentally know what you say. And whereof one cannot speak thereof one must pass over in silence. Legislated surveillance. How many of your links do you believe look like the following?

... <a href="#">Anonymous</a>: <a href="http://mypersonalsite.com">personal site, </a> ...

Careful how you link.

item.title: What we wrote
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: In my mind, it makes perfect sense. Google et al. are right. We _are_ "innovating" faster and smarter than all other industries. But what is innovation? The new colonialism? Or did the Capitalists fully harmonize away "the error" in Marx's critique? Innovation _on_ U.S. soil _in_ a place claimed to have no soil, The Internet. We are, in a sense, leeches. And we know it. We don't care about your television, your baseball games, you designer shoes, your mortgages, confessions; we _can_ care these things. And we can turn it off. We. Don't. Need. The. Internet. But you do. Microsoft is mass producing the television-computer. It was an easy, easy transition for you. You moved from the radio, to the soaps, to the reality television, until finally, you. became. the. reality. No, you cannot stop flicking the channel. You cannot stop sharing the hyperlink. In 30 seconds, I can have a personal copy of the Internet downloaded to my personal 2TB drive. There are a lot of numbers going on here. I, for the most part, understand the proportions. I can personally say how much of the Internet I want. But can you? Will you be able to find others who have done the same? And rebuild? In my mind, the Internet is a public experiment. Who will acquiesce? Who will learn the most? Who will use our tools? These are the terms our government thinks in. When the market is producing business execs who systematically fail to under terms like "AJAX," terms we've understood for  years, and when we start to build more APIs than consumers can digest, that's when the government realizes a utilitarian premise. An abominable one. The programmers are being under utilized. And sites like "clientsfromhell dot com" exist, where we only deride you and sometimes unfairly. But it is a good rule of thumb, right? "Clients are stupid." Will the programmers be avoided such benefit of the doubt when the brick and mortar business come rolling back with vengeance? Doubtful. Most of the time, my clients become visibly discontent when I try to explain my processes to them, processes that involve the delicate handling of and close analysis of their content. And they argue with me that I should respect Internet Explorer users as "good business sense." Their clients, stupid. My client, "stupid." Everybody, "stupid." They're not really watching the other industries. "Innovation" has been defined too narrowly. They've only been watching the technologists. They're going to take back the Internet because you people stole it from them. With your "demand." It makes perfect sense, "Ugh. Why do I have to compete with 14 year olds in Malaysia?" What client is more put together than the United States? No, no, I mean, surely they can put together an RFP that would tickle the mind of any programmer. Under laws like #sopa, programmers who take on non-governmental projects subject themselves to absolute liability: Protect your client from the U.S. government, or [simply] be allowed to continue to innovate by government ideology. How many of your friends choose "chaotic evil"? The Internet is a market, and you do not own it any longer.

item.title: Old skin
item.dc:creator: admin

item.title: Preferable
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: What I see before me is a screen, filled with information. Why? Does it enrich my life? Does it bring about desirable ends? Now streams of content flood our screens. We permit this. Unlike a newspaper, static and clear, we have built interfaces To madness, clutter and debris -- this device presents information Without opinion, or direction, or standard; without bounds We believe ourselves to be expressing openly into the machine; Undertaking eternity and all; but indeed into the machine Untrained to unlearn the machine, Some feed, become derelict, some ignore, Yet render unto the machine

item.title: A new kind of war
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I call it the _Tower of Babel_. This must be what it looked like then. Our politics have reached a convergence with the limits of imagination. And now we must scatter.
"General-purpose network" will become a definition for terms we use to identify actual communities.
Things like 1337speak need new gods. "Filesharing as a religion" is an indicator. Perhaps the powers that be see a problematic in effects of information density?
What are the casualties of this new kind of war, the cyberwar? What are their affects on the general-purpose media network?
What are our causalities now? The U.S. government wants us to understand something, and I'm not quite sure what it is. But I feel they are telling me that I haven't been safe from what they are trying to take control of. As an American citizen, one must face, it seems, an issue of trust. _Who_ is prepared to talk in terms of war when the traditional weapons bring no weight? When ssh is a rifle?
What are the causalities in this kind of war?

item.title: The Obamas,
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: (Rubbish. I hate tainting my things in this way.) All right, fine, Politico et al (even after you put me through that invasive sign-up process, you manage to overlook subtly): How does this story actually affect us? You're telling us we should be prepared for a fact-based introspection into Obama's social justice spirit. We haven't seen it, but apparently it's there. How will this change the stage of NDAA? SOPA? PIPA? GMOs? Our debt? Our ongoing wars (most notably the cyberwar that nobody truly understands the casualties of)? Media blackouts? War on half-baked metaphors? The bloody STINK of capitalist bravado in the Streets? Shoving around dissenters? Veterans telling me to get a gun, in Texas. People need to be seeing these questions. Because the substance of Obamas failure will be their answers. Let's see your story. Everyone is saying it irrational to believe it's "just Obama," and then you release _this_. You're telling us some confluence of some kind of raw humanity or passion between them will ultimately determine our benefit. Let's see it. Give us paternalism. Give us your Grand Theory. I want to here this narrative.

item.title: I'm an asshole
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: I really do not understand why any of this has grown to such maturity (#ndaa, #pipa, the fact that Comcast cannot comply with a DNS redirect policy, but somehow its medialawyerXPs, at NBC Universal, simply don't talk to the nerds; and now our president apparently has to re-find the backbone of marriage so that we can see his platform get a genuine shot; more American bullshit; now I have a practical threat of media blackouts, I'm looking at casualties of war apparently) manage to wage a full on war with every other industry. It's absolutely mind-blowing. This country looks, on its face, painfully and tragically mismanaged. It's cannibalistic. The drifting, rotting husk of a accidental suicide victim. I can hardly stomach it sometimes. My government is threatening me directly, dismissing plain English explanations of Google, while insinuating that Google feigns god-like morality. Not one person is prepared to stop feeling offended and simply write. Feeling offended is easier, and there's always something better one could be caught in. But now when even you cannot genuinely understand how Google is doing what it's doing, and it directly affects your life, perhaps even the basis of your reality (your gateway drug into the Internet), and it could all flip, like a switch? Recall, Google did this to China. And the fact that I say "recall" isn't some mechanism to instill anxiety or insult. It's just a damn voice. What happened to that? Why can't people just have a voice? Talk? Share? Why must compassion and emotion fall out because we're communicating through some third-party? They're your words, and they're a liability to the party, sure, but they're still yours. They're your links.  And people are telling me to see a shrink. Really? Because I'm highly opinionated? Polemical in style? Are you kidding me? I openly admit to my lack of intelligence, my slowness, my philosophy degree, my flaws and fears. It's not my fault you keep putting modesty in my mouth. I'm not modest. I'm the same person who shouted at so-and-so down the street about hacker ethics. I'm the person who quotes Voltaire and his views on assassination. I call people "motherfuckers!" And engage in reckless, bicycle behavior. HL Mencken, Nietzsche, Žižek are our posterchildren. 1984 our bedtime stories. Hitler's now a meme to promote positive messages. You know all of this. I don't know what to do with you if you're nice going to face reality with me. And me with my biting tongue? I'll say it because it comes to me. I'm an asshole, here's a link. (Now just add 5,000 users.) Yeah, that isn't going away.

item.title: On text editors
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
# Main On OS X I use a combination of byword/vim/macvim/sublimetext2/textmate2.
  1. Byword/Dropbox for task management/note taking
  2. vi/m as my "in-house" editor (for stuff like pair computing)
  3. macvim (w/ nerdtree & powerline with .vimrc) for my primary development
  4. sublimetext2 for trial sprints on small coding projects
  5. textmate2 for pointless code snippets and whatever else
  6. Codebox/Snipplr for snippets storage
  7. I use jsfiddle and dabblet extensively.
# Opinions
  1. Aptana is too fat.
  2. Coda is too counterintuitive (and it has no sort options for File Browser).
  3. Espresso is too cute.
  4. TextWranger just isn't my cup of tea.
# *nix
  1. Debian/Ubuntu, nano/gedit/vi. (I don't really mess around with other distros now. I install things CentOS systems from time-to-time, since that's my host's flavor. But right: vi.)
# Windows
  1. SublimeText
  2. notepad (I get really lazy and forget to install apps after finish the Windows install; plus, I only use Windows for foobar2000 now. So I don't care to make it a dev station.)
But I'll code in an address bar if I need to.
