item.title: Messages
item.dc:creator: tofuanarchy
item.content:encoded:
You all, on islands of various size,
ripe with exotic nectar and marvelous
flora, sun bright songbirds of selcouth
melodies, some with shady groves and
gentle streams, others with sandy pits, and
caverns full of shiny things, shorelines
defended by legions of scuttling crabs,
pacific beachfront dappled with the shadows
of drifting dreaming bands of nimbus
clouds, must understand it is difficult
for me to get out to you, for I possess
but the humblest of boats, which to
all appearances has more in common
with a dowsing rod. It shudders like a leaf
at every passing breeze and offers no protection
from the shadows of the sea, which might
be as benign as a flying fish,
as gentle as a sea-turtle, or garrulous
like a pod of wayfaring dolphins
who stop to chat and pirouette a bit,
or icy cold as the terrifying
recognition of a razor-toothed
emissary of pelagic death.
I'd want that you should know, when I can I cast
out bottles containing messages.
If this one should reach you, know I care
about you, whomever you are, and I am
preparing, always struggling, like a nervous
tick, my mind, voice and heart, the various
accoutrements of the soul, so when
next we meet, or drift idly in those placid
currents (who are the gentle progeny of 
those multipotent tides on which, in the old days,
we worked the fearsome ship's ponderous oars
through the savage saltsea crests beneath
the violet and blood red cumulonimbus,
grand and terrifying as the gods,
prone to thunderous displays of primeval
strength, though we in our brave array flinched not
but worked the mast, defended the sails, and held
steady our course), we can share a song, or think
while carousing or daydreaming over drink.

item.title: Urgent: The Failure of Facebook
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Like other “social” apps (cough eVite cough), Facebook has all the social graces of a nose-picking, hyperactive six-year-old, standing at the threshold of your attention and chanting, “I know something, I know something, I know something, won’t tell you what it is!” -- How Your Creepy Ex-Co-Workers Will Kill Facebook

Social Network Mismanagement

Someone once made the counterpoint to me: "Facebook allows for me to manage my social network." It's not clear to me, but when software allows for anyone, ranging from nuisance to acquaintance, that is, anyone under the sun, even date terrorists and under-radar sex-addicts, to demand "Friend me on Facebook (now)!", it seems something horribly wrong has emerged in my social world, generally. How can I possibly have the social orientation, the gusto, and stamina to take on and defend against the fray of in-real-life "Friend Requests"? Cory Doctorow puts this sentiment perfectly:
The fact that she doesn’t like her boss doesn’t really matter: in the social world of Friendster and its progeny, it’s perfectly valid to demand to be “friended” in an explicit fashion that most of us left behind in the fourth grade.
Indeed. Quite fucking indeed, and fuck you; fuck you and your friend request. I am not a child; I am an adult; what have you said that actually warrants the opportunity to sleuth and investigate my social world? -- and what's more, to color these thoughts with a bit of reverse sexism, or unjustified, speech-into-nothingness, unprompt'd sexy valor and all that: Women. Women, women, women. "Give me your number!" has replaced the finishing school desperate dater's dialogue with "What's your Facebook?" It's an implied threat to "friend"; and subsequently, disclose infinitely more than any number could disclose. Would you give your number to some random stranger? Is it "safer," a more defensive strategy to give out your Facebook instead? Did you really think that offer of your Facebook profile through? -- In some states, they use Facebook IDs to allow entrance into bars and so forth. All the frightening concerns apply: Will this bar now track me? Deny me when I "check-in" at the competition? What, ultimately, is it that they are after?: One consideration is your timeline. At the end of the day, how many stalkers have you accrued? Again. I manage my social network; not some automated personal data collection monolithic network. My friends are those who strive to extract from me genuine experiences, not stalkers who anticipate me or predict my next utterance by virtue of a unacademic psychologizing of my status updates. Again. Fuck you:
You’d think that Facebook would be the perfect tool for handling all this. It’s not. For every long-lost chum who reaches out to me on Facebook, there’s a guy who beat me up on a weekly basis through the whole seventh grade but now wants to be my buddy; or the crazy person who was fun in college but is now kind of sad; or the creepy ex-co-worker who I’d cross the street to avoid but who now wants to know, “Am I your friend?” yes or no, this instant, please.

Be a Real Friend

Stop cheating, and learn how to be a real friend. Delete your fucking Facebook. 83 million plus of those users aren't real anyway.
Mr. Crabb, the Facebook executive, said his primary concern was that people live balanced lives. At the same time, he acknowledges that the message can run counter to Facebook’s business model, which encourages people to spend more time online. “I see the paradox,” he said. -- Silicon Valley Says Step Away From the Device

item.title: What anarchism is not...
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: [...] a fixed, self-enclosed social system but rather a definite trend in the historic development of mankind, which, in contrast with the intellectual guardianship of all clerical and governmental institutions, strives for the free unhindered unfolding of all the individual and social forces in life. Even freedom is only a relative, not an absolute concept, since it tends constantly to become broader and to affect wider circles in more manifold ways. For the anarchist, freedom is not an abstract philosophical concept, but the vital concrete possibility for every human being to bring to full development all the powers, capacities, and talents with which nature has endowed him, and turn them to social account. The less this natural development of man is influenced by ecclesiastical or political guardianship, the more efficient and harmonious will human personality become, the more will it become the measure of the intellectual culture of the society in which it has grown. -- Rudolf Rocker. Anarchosyndicalism.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Forgive the length, and the time we are both wasting.
What is the nature of this "social account"? An averaging function of some abstract concept of humanity, which regards its members as interchangeable and measures efficiency in place of human qualities? Is our goal to minimize the amount of injustice that occurs? Then we should have to make everything illegal! Does it not also assume the premise that each individual not only knows what's best for oneself but also knows this better than anyone else could? Surely the addiction-prone tendencies of certain people should be considered. Plus what justifies the libertarian notion that if people were left to their own devices it would work out best for everyone? Is this a divinely sanctioned truth, or did evolution stumble upon it? Does it not suppose a certain amount of indoctrination before we can consider someone a capable human being who can make rational decisions? If people were left to their own devices, we would have warrior led societies again, unless we are in a sufficiently post-scarcity society, which simply means we would have achieved digital feudalism and have affected a reduction of the worth of a person to nothing more than caring about their own pleasure. And by either some libertarian philosophic magic, or the magic of the machine, all of that works to benefit the system, aka "humanity" (a concept which already requires sufficient machine technology). Certainly, one can apply the efficiency principle to man, it's just a physical truth that evolution didn't get it entirely right. Perhaps the progeny of a small subset of our brains will function more efficiently. But that's still all abstract mumbo jumbo. What's the psychological effect of thinking that way? Why should I care if future efficiency is better, if it means obliterating my memory, in a blind attempt to increase information rates? A goal always beyond now, since, in physical terms, efficiency can always improve, and by so improving it rapes and pillages all the modes of life along the way, to make it to the masturbatory theoretic endpoint. The shared delusions of a conquered people, worshiping an infant god? Their very lives sacrificed, the fecundity of time slashed and burned to produce the crops of efficiency? The 19th century still thought that each person was a courtly gentleman, who, if not imposed on by the will of unjust power structures (at this time both church and state had been sufficiently bureaucratized through industrialization he would be polite and studious, so would be enlightened enough to make the right decision, for the sake of the social account. One must always measure the psychological effects! man's drives where selected for over a long period of time and to radically change the environment, the intimate form of relationships (I'm talking intra-culturally even!), will have immense psychological effects, which could very greatly. One such radical environmental change is the rate at which information can spread (until the 19th century the fastest information could spread was at the rate a horse can travel over land). Another change is world population. Both of these changes caused the notion of "humanity" to appear more legitimate, though at the same time domestic, or proximal life was being eviserated, so we moved from a face to face conception of people to one based on secondary and tertiary feedback and compilation through statistics, news headlines, cynical novels, mass media, yada yada; all of this has psychological effects and the more a person is concerned only with necessary conditions of existence (eat poop orgasm pee), and the more the person is a coward who functions reflexively to avoid being startled, or to escape thoughts of death, the more comfortable they are in a cage, so long as their caretakers feeds them.
Forgive my staggering typos, and an unclosed parenthesis.
STNDBY.

item.title: Ariadne's thread / Historical Consciousness
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Photo by Jay Marroquin

¶ Throughout slavery’s history, white women have been held up on a pedestal, deemed virtually untouchable to black men. During slavery, and for many decades after its abolition, the punishments dealt to an African-American man who had sexual relations with a white woman (whether consensual or not) were strict and extremely violent, often ending in a lynching focused on stripping the accused of his masculinity. Thus, it is possible to see how anxieties about such penalties could create in the minds of black men an impression of white women involving a strange mix of hate and desire. ¶ Such a combination of conflicted emotions is prevalent in the Battle Royal when the young fighters are put face-to-face with a naked white stripper. At such a sight, the protagonist recalls, “I tried to back away, but they were behind me and around me. Some of the boys stood with lowered heads, trembling. I felt a wave of irrational guilt and fear. …Yet I was strongly attracted and looked in spite of myself.” Furthermore, he says, “I felt a desire to spit upon her as my eyes brushed slowly over her body” (19). He describes similar reactions in the others saying, “Another boy began to plead to go home…wearing dark red fighting trunks too small to conceal his erection…He tried to hide himself with his boxing gloves” (20). With this the protagonist calls attention to the shame associated with such a desire. And this shame is not just a reaction to the scene at hand, but part of a whole “historical consciousness” (Clinton, 212), formed by the institution of slavery and reinforced by the yells of the white spectators. “Some threatened us if we looked and others if we did not,” remembers the protagonist (20). The ambivalence of this chant carries with it an inherent pleasure for the spectators, as it uses the sexuality of the young men against them in an irrational test of both their fear and masculinity. ¶ This test uses sexual humiliation in order to bring these men down to an emasculated state so they might welcome the upcoming fight as a way to restore their dignity. Before this occurs, however, the white spectators begin harassing the white dancer. “They caught her just as she reached the door, raised her from the floor, and tossed her as college boys are tossed at hazing,” describes the protagonist. Watching this happen, however, he relates it to his own experience just a moment before. He says, “Above her red, fixed-smiling lips I saw the terror and disgust in her eyes, almost like my own terror and that which I saw in some of the other boys” (20). Where she is one moment the source of their guilt and fear, this blonde white woman suddenly finds herself sharing in the humiliation of these young black men. She is held at a distance from them, and yet they are all subjected to the same exploitation for the pleasure of the spectators.
“Hang Her by Her Long Hair”: White Women’s Guilt and the Legacy of Slavery. Lucinda Newns.
Why "blacks on blondes" is a thing. I cannot make this shit up. Quick, let's cover it up with another linguistic diversion. -- Off yourself. "Why is he so worked up about the man?"; "Hung up on white women?" "Jungle fever!" And all the recursive social grammars for reconstituting racism through language, art, music and watercooler conversation. -- Listen, go read a fucking book on the history of a America. Just about ever other trope or meme is a fucking slap in the face, as ignorant prick swill peruse the bars for an easy fuck, against all odds, come what may, despite the most recent blow to the head. That is, a book that you had to find yourself; not one that was spoon-fed to you by a university or your deranged psychotropic grandmother. And stop thinking that because you have an opinion, it's at once some kind of valid rebuttal. You do not know what you are talking about because you are undereducated. You do not. Stop talking. Or maybe listen to Bob Dylan. How is anyone expected to love in this country? Where our historical backdrop, so soon ago, influences every dating scene to the T. Women hunting for drug dealers with few strings attached, and Bob Marleys on every street corner. -- Is Obama's Presidency really just a existentially grand "too soon" joke? At the cost of how many infinitums of folks down the thread of history, into our technofuture? And so on. (Is Obama's Presidency, that is, a "scenario" or "disaster situation" a la Nick Bostrom et al? -- How soon "after slavery" is an arguable range of "too soon" or "you must be kidding?" or "Is this a joke?" -- Look'it how fixated our Big Media is on race. And that every black guy with dreadlocks must be rasta. -- Each day I am, at least once, robbed of my identity simply on account of a hair style that occurs naturally. Dreadlocks I have very little say or control over, have somehow given me a form of transcendence. Great. "It happens all the time. People are stupid." -- No, fucking stop. How often are you assumed to be a Jew or Christian simply on account of your hairstyle? (( And bear in mind, I'm a Strict Atheist. I am the farthest removed from even tolerance of Judeo-Christian thought. I am Hostile to orthodox theistic thought. )) Stop fucking talking and blabbering and answer the question --) Why -- any of this? Because I'm getting sick of people interrupting me when I try to work, under the sun and clouds and near the divinely trees, just to remind me that my work is either: 1. Boring 2. Academic 3. "Nerdy" Fuck you. Why -- any of this? Because anyone without a right mind would, in an attempt to console me, argue with me that when some Anglo-American ex-junky maintenance worker for brothel apartment complex didn't really mean to shout out "Boy!" as if it were my name. From the street. Twice. Or the old grunge-punker guy who asks my close-friend, after just meeting and while greeting a female friend: "Is this your woman?" People are petting me, and calling me "Boy." Why? Because I'm wearing cutoffs like every other lanky "hipster"? What is the connection? We see the thread of history. Many entertain the idea that racism is over, but in truth, it has only become thicker while entrenched in news media garbage and the melting pot swill that is American culture. It is not that racism is over: People are too mentally handicapped, such that everything becomes permitted. Most of these people cannot remember yesterday since the beginning of the "f"-twitch that goes off whenever they are at a keyboard. Or the jittery phantom phone jig. These people are so exhausted from their own inability to think and live happily, that they feel their lack of vitality, like a sick person, allows for them to say and do whatever they please. Men call other men boys whom they feel are not their competition, in any way, and more specifically, in the dating game. Women spill their hearts out into boys, as if they were their children. Each day I see nothing but "fear and masculinity."

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: what is your point?
Category: "Rant".

item.title: Technopolitics (Absconded Ethnopolitics)
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Preventative Economics -- Planned Economies -- Non-taxed lifestyles -- Microlabor -- Transitory Geocultural Gestalts -- Epigenetic Normative Movements -- Escape Rate of Meta-machine Intelligence -- Fingerfaces (Finger interfaces) -- Perpetually Politically Transparent Autonomous Action Logs -- Feline Politics Subsystems -- Generational Starships -- Bank Network Subversive Social Media Exploitation Strategies -- Auction House Web Scrapers -- Bitcoin Leakage Quotas --
Fuck you. Prepare. Understand.
Will you sacrifice Your money Into a NoSecurity System of trust?
What is belief In money?

item.title: The car's on fire; there's no driver at the wheel; and ...
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This country is on fire. I have not watched television in nearly 2 years. I feel like I just stepped out of a fucking time machine, into a dystopian future. I am not fucking kidding you. And I'm expected to conform? Are you fucking kidding me?

The Daily Show

OMG @ this country. You mean to tell me while Bitcoin exchanges worth $250,000 are getting hacked, and while bank systems are getting pwned for millions of accounts, we're not all expected to be flipping shit right now? And while THIS is our entertainment media? Where we continue to pay (taxed groceries, 34 million tons of food waste, taxed education, war tax, academic attacks on filesharing, and soon: taxed Internet; with N-strikes policies, lack of spaceward-consciousness, the war on computing, overurbanization, along with the neurotax of Facebook; the wave of violence, etc.)? That we are to continue to roll on as if we are not establishing an economic baseline for gross-budget nonsense like the Republican National Convention? And all the rest of this? -- Perhaps my implied message is in itself ethically suspect: but in truth, what the fuck? Why isn't anyone listening? Look: RNC has built a campaign ("We built it") based on not being generous, or forgiving, towards this current President's speech patterns; his façon de parler. "Taking out of context" and "failing to follow a foreigner" are two totally fucking different issues. Fuck you. That is racism.

item.title: How To: Use Facebook
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Facebook attempts to design away your privacy. This shouldn't be news; your intuition is right. What is it about the Facebook interface that engenders web surfer loyalty? Do you truly find it a convenience app? Or is it a convenience of habit? Is "managing my social network" a matter of me manually interacting with streams by streams of the world itself responding to my virtual and physical existence? Facebook gives one the opportunity to perceive their own virtual presence, but what in the order of "response" does Facebook enable? Should I find myself, daily, perpetually, conducting impromptu digital rap sessions with every chitter-chatter in my status stream? Or my chat? What more could this app do for me, other than proffer a "virtual-out" from reality. How is it managing anything? It's not, in and of itself, doing anything for me; it's providing for me. The name fits: imagine a high school year book, from the future of course, that "organically updates" throughout the years. For instance, each Name label for each student automagically appears in the current hand-writing style of each student, decades upon decades down the line into the future. How useful is this kind of information to you? What can you do with it? It is instant nostalgia. Do you recall that guilty feeling after successfully circumventing another 2-hour long snoozefest with your grandmother, where you both, for the 3rd time that month, painstakingly browse the family photo album? -- That is it. What is grandmother after? Why does she need to share in this way? What is the practice of dying? Is the photo album doing anything in particular, or is it simply being acted upon? Flipped through; commented on, where the comments take you -- But how about this. Place your family photo album at the entrance of a busy restaurant. Or sneak it into doctor's office. What comes of this? Who is affected? What relationship has one developed from finding that album in exactly the place hidden? I have what I am calling a "Community Facebook" account. The password is "123456"; e-mail: "nerdfiles@gmail.com". My actual computers have hosts files which point to 127.0.0.1. When web pages call facebook.com, nothing happens. I do not wish to have blogs and Web networks like CBS or CNN, or what have you, identify my machine as a Facebook user simply on account of the fact that I have an account, and I am currently logged in. I do not want for CBS, for instance, to know that I am a Facebook user simply because I have entered their site. This is equivalent to a store knowing which credit card I use simply on account that I have window shopped by them. Ideally, a social networking receptacle, which is what Facebook is, should provide content to your interests, but the actual acting upon that content, in Facebook's hands, in your hands, involves a painstaking effort at physically, personally, etc., hand-tuning a machine. Imagine having constantly to adjust or maintain your car's alignment as you drive it. Imagine building the Ship of Theseus as it floats you across the Aegean. How taxing is such a practice. Whereas one could implement actions over the wealth of their interests (that is, exploring your interests). These actions are automated. And they might inform others of your true identity and character. And in truth, what good is my saying that I like something? A "like", in truth, is an independent discovery, and it should be coincidence that others like it. No one should be forced to the prompt, "Do you like this?" Imagine the question in everyday conversation. Undoubtedly it is intrusive and mildly authoritarian. It's almost a demand: "Do you like me?" Automated actions over the web ensure that when we find pleasure in things, we are cooperating in our discoveries because we are focused on our interests, and not our powers to persuade or coerce. Our pleasure should emerge naturally out of our quest for information.

item.title: Ethnonutrition and food hacking
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Diets that ignore lifestyle are greedy. How about a new term? "Ethnodiet," or "technediet" rather than "logodiet" or "science-based diet." "Food hacking"; or the hacking of one's self through molecular gastronomy, presupposes a set of ethnonutritional axioms which require expression in the language of its imperatives. Those imperatives are not manifestly given in the realist statements of the effects of foodstuffs on the human organism. One is not hacking oneself if one blindly obeys the "truth" of nature; there is no creativity expressed in obeying what is perceived to be a maximal law; hacking involves a persistent belief in circumvention. How can one hack food if its existence can be talked about in a fully deterministic way? -- This is the approach of standard "nutrition" theories. The philosophy of "food hacking" might be labeled "mereological gastronomy."

What kind of science

Regardless of the authority of scientists, or nutritionists, you are probably not one. Whereas appealing to the authority of astronomists may be an epistemtically defensible practice, appealing to the authority of nutritionists may not be. The discoveries of astrophysics arguably have direct influence on your life, but if they do, we'd be hard-pressed to integrate those findings in our everyday lives; the discoveries of nutrition, oddly researchers and laypeople alike, seem to carry an inherent imperative as to what-comes-next after said discovery is made. Whatever the content of the discovery, the "what-comes-next" is a matter of decision, but at the same point, it is a decision of whether the discovery is amenable to all of food science or not. In astrophysics, for instance, we have a long-standing set of metarules for the integration and change of the overall conceptual system. Where is this in food science? And what is more, Does a scientist's finding in and of themselves say anything about normative structure? (This idea is from Alain Badiou: "Situations are nothing more in their being than pure multiplicity. Nothing normative can be drawn from the simple realist's observation of the becoming of things.")

"In Defense of Food"

  1. Eat Food that could be readily identified by most traditional cultures; no Food Disputes; don't eat foodlike substances;
  2. Mostly Plants -- they have the most mature survival systems, eat them;
  3. Not Too Much learn how to eat little; that is, learn austerity, not asceticism; apply more traditional diets as this doubly expresses a political note and expresses Occam's Razor which does not aim to lose weight, but return one's body to an earlier state of humans within "civilization"
"Science-based diets" tend to lack consciousness of the ethnological structures we must persist within. A diet that says {nothing} about the contextualized features of Eating is blind. -- Something like what Einstein said.

Related reading:

  1. In Defense of Difference
  2. Obsessed With Nutrition? That’s an Eating Disorder
  3. In Defense of Food by Michael Pollan
  4. Khymos
  5. Food Porn Daily
  6. FoodGenome

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
wait. what? rule 2 does not follow sound logic, if the fact that they have the most mature survival systems is used as an argument for the conclusion that we should eat mostly plants. (I really doubt you are attempting to present it as such: because computers are also better at storing certain types of information, therefore we should eat them. We don't siphon the powers of systems we eat (otherwise I'd eat the brains of geniuses))
I think an argument that uses the logic of evolutionary biology would favor a paleolithic diet (which attained 64-68% of its calories from animal sources, due to their typically denser protein and caloric content), as agriculture is still relatively a young mutation that has laid nowhere near a majority claim on the human genotype.
but anyway, just food for thought. personally, i'm sick of living like a cyborg, everything always spliced and sliced up on the cartesian grid, everything a function of efficiency. perhaps it's inevitable, but then again so is my demise.

Note: that post was critiquing in defense of food, not your claim of "techne-diet" v. "science diet". Though I think any attempt to diet, whether or not based on the "facts of science" is an attempt to, if not circumvent, at least manage, through some degree of exclusion, your cravings, which requires some theoretical content based on some function of the nutritional potential or causal effects of the food(-matter).

I was a bit careless with 2. The gist I have here is that we often revel in the thought of common roaches survival a nuclear disaster scenario. Likely, I believe, any form of vegetation would survive, in the broadest sense. Ultimately we should base our diet, a subprocess of our survivability, on those ingredients most probably capable of extended survival throughout any disaster scenario. In a sense, the idea is to learn from the wisest member of any species possible of existing on a given planet. This is both a biological-normative claim and pragmatic claim at once; our subsystems may learn best from those species most capable of survival, and our ecological epistemology (normative pragmatic) requires ethos attain sensitivity to, let's say, an emergent wisdom quotient that is embedded in the brute facts of survival of a long-lasting embedded species. Ideally what this means is: "birds of a feather" in terms of naive survival. I'd like to institute a movement of naivism: the embrace of multiply realized realities under the pretense of trust.
Perhaps I am thinking of [mock] resistentialism, where one is implored to view the phenomenological experience of inanimate objects as, pragmatically, for all intents and purposes, "out to get us." No matter the structure of experience, the lack of intentionality entails the probability of an object's bringing about of one's ruin. This is tin-foil-hatism, indeed, but with the array of pianos which topple grandmothers and every-variable-so-determines car accidents, and with the chances of ever-dreaming or anything science {may} say, a wanton embrace of the maximal good of all objects seems a toss up. Perhaps it is.
In a way, the statements of science postulate "sciense"; the common sense of science, that which should be obeyed as good sense in one's ethnologically holistic experience. Any statement of science, including statistical probabilities, either do or do not fall within the scope of "sciense." I'm suggesting that if they do, they tell us that statistically, we should fear analyzed reality on top of the whole of nature as an existential limiting point. If they do not, we possess a set of statistical probability statements degrees remove from every experience. But then what should direct everyday experience? I'm suggesting a robust model-descriptive approach to reality acceptance; discover and embrace, and this is all.
Bit of distractions around. Losing lucidity... I should hope these rambling carry any weight, if only as insight to my mania.
